                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                           November 14, 2006 Tuesday
                                  Main Edition

Golf course loan was legitimate

BYLINE: F. STONE WORKMAN; For the Journal-Constitution

SECTION: EDITORIAL; EQUAL TIME; Pg. 11A

LENGTH: 400 words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture Community Facilities program has provided
financial assistance to allow communities to purchase emergency equipment, build
community centers, hospitals, day care centers, clinics and public safety
buildings.

Community Facilities loans, both direct and guaranteed, have done a great deal
in Georgia to improve the quality of rural life. Projects include a substance
abuse treatment facility in Cuthbert, a replacement hospital in Clinch County, a
combined police and fire station in Blackshear and renovation of the Irwin
County courthouse.

Concerning the Nov. 13 AJC article "$1.8 million bailout" (Page One): The golf
course was eligible for funding, based on our criteria. The applicant submitted
a solid business plan and had proven credentials in the golfing industry.

In addition to our process, the application was reviewed by the lending
institution that made the loan, and USDA brought in an outside market analysis
consultant, a nationally recognized firm, which based its loan analysis on the
data provided by the National Golf Foundation.

The financial projections were studied closely, as were the demographics,
golfing population and other standard indicators. All pointed toward a
successful project. This loan was made on business merits, but even when one
undertakes a rigorous review process, there are risks, and factors external to
the golf course business plan may have contributed to the default.

The property itself was in an area that qualified for a loan guarantee under our
regulations. Rural Development is permitted to make loan guarantees for
recreational facilities to benefit the public. This course was required to be a
public facility, open to all.

The overall default rate for this program is low, and the number of guarantees
made nationwide for a wide range of community facilities is substantial. The 1
percent guarantee fee paid by loan recipients covers projected losses.

While we have provided loan guarantees for eight additional golf courses,
including another one in Georgia, we will look very carefully at any future
requests for guarantees for golf courses.

Rural Americans receive good value for the funds provided as part of our
commitment to the future of rural communities.

* F. Stone Workman is Georgia director of USDA Rural Development.

This column is solicited to provide another viewpoint to an AJC editorial
published today.

USDA Invites Applications For Loans To Fund Community Facility Projects

BYLINE: The Johnson Pioneer staff

LENGTH: 555  words


USDA Rural Development has more than $22 million available in funding to be
dispersed for community facility projects throughout Kansas. Funding is
authorized through the Departments Community Facilities Direct and Guaranteed
Loan Program."USDA provides critical financing to rural Kansas communities to
improve essential services to rural Kansas residents," stated USDA Rural
Development State Director Patty Clark. "With federal financial assistance,
these communities are improving the quality of life for their residents, and
creating communities that will span generations."

USDA Rural Developments community programs enhance the quality of life for rural
Kansans by providing funds to public bodies, community-based non-profit
organizations and Federally-recognized Tribes for essential community facilities
and services. Funds may be used for a wide range of community projects. These
1:. elude, but are not limited to projects such as those which will expand,
improve, or construct:

Education Projects: Schools, libraries, technology upgrades

Health Care Projects: Medical clinics, hospitals, assisted living centers,
mental health facilities, medical equipment, medical transportation

Local Food Projects: Farmers markets, food hubs, summer meals programs

Public Buildings Projects: Courthouses, city halls, police stations, community
centers

Public Safety Projects: Street improvements, sidewalks, storm shelters, storm
sirens, ambulances, fire trucks and equipment, other emergency devices

The Community Facilities Program can make direct and guarantee loans to develop
essential facilities in rural areas and towns of up to 20,000 in population.
Direct loans are available to public entities such as municipalities, counties,
and special-purpose districts, as well as to non-profit organizations and tribal
governments. Loan guarantees are also available to lenders such as banks,
savings and loan companies and other lending institutions for essential
community facilities. In some circumstances, grants may be awarded to smaller
communities.

Applications are now being accepted to fund projects meeting the criteria for
community facility loan, guaranteed loan, and grant programs, as outlined at:
http://www.rd.usda.gov/programsservices/community-facilities
-directloan-grant-program/ks

For more information on the Community Facilities Program, contact a USDA Rural
Development Community Program Specialist near your location:

David Barber, Hays, (785) 628-3081, Ext. 1444, david.barber@ks.usda.gov

Michael Billings, Iola, (620) 365-2901, Ext. 1406, michael.billings@ks.usda.gov

Tom Finger, Newton, (316) 283-0370, Ext. 1438, tom.finger@ks.usda.gov

Kevin McCann, Manhattan, (785) 776-7582, Ext. 1409, kevin.mccann@ks.usda.gov

Chelsea Morris, Newton, (316) 283-0370, Ext. 1436, chelsea.morris@ks.usda.gov

Janette Womack, Topeka, (785) 271-2742, janette.womack@ks.usda.gov

USDA, through its Rural Development mission area, administers and manages
housing, business and community infrastructure programs through a national
network of state and local offices. Rural Development has an active portfolio of
more than $206.2 billion in loans and loan guarantees. These programs are
designed to improve the economic stability of rural communities, businesses,
residents, farmers and ranchers and improve the quality of life in rural
America.

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                      February 9, 2004 Monday Home Edition

Loan backed by feds;
Golf course deal one of the first

BYLINE: KEVIN DUFFY

SOURCE: AJC

SECTION: Business Horizon; Pg. 1E

LENGTH: 1236 words


The federal government's Rural Development branch is known for lending money and
doling out grants for health care and public safety facilities in sparsely
populated areas.

Success stories on its Web site include a child care facility in an Iowa town of
3,700 and a health clinic in an isolated Alaskan village.

Less known is Rural Development's loan guarantee program for recreational
facilities, including two upscale public golf courses in Georgia.

Under the program, the feds will guarantee 90 percent of a loan from a private
lender to build or restore a recreational facility --- even a posh golf club
surrounded by luxury homes.

The obscure federal program helped John Boykin of Roswell realize his dream of
owning a golf course. He'd spent 30 years in the golf business as a club
professional and organizer of golf hospitality events with an Atlanta
advertising company.

Last year, Boykin borrowed $6 million from Heritage Bank to buy the former
Whitewater Country Club --- complete with an Arnold Palmer-designed golf course
--- near Fayetteville in Fayette County.

The course, renamed the Palmer Course at Starr's Mill, is part of Whitewater
Creek, a gated community of 306 homes on lots of 1 acre or more. Prices of
nearby houses now on the market range from $439,900 to $699,900.

"I call this a Mercedes neighborhood with a Chevrolet golf facility," Boykin
says.

Boykin bought the 294-acre property from Robert Brooks, chairman of Hooters of
America, the restaurant and airline company. Included in the deal: six tennis
courts, a swimming pool and a 35,000-square-foot antebellum-style clubhouse,
which had fallen into disrepair.

The 8-year-old clubhouse includes a 200-seat ballroom and a winding staircase,
the backdrop for countless prom pictures.

So far, only three golf course projects nationwide have secured the federally
guaranteed loans since the unusual program began in 1999. Two of them are in
Georgia.

The state's other golf course recipient is in Columbia County, just west of
Augusta. A nonprofit community development corporation borrowed $8.8 million
last year to build a championship golf course there. The course, now under
construction, will be part of the future Bartram Trail community, 800 houses on
land bisected by scenic Euchee Creek.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture, which administers the Rural Development
program, is guaranteeing most of both loans, meaning that if either borrower
defaults, the government is responsible for repaying the outstanding debt.

Rural Development doesn't require golf courses to be in needy areas to qualify
for loan guarantees. The program says only that they must be open to the public
and owned by public bodies, private nonprofit corporations or Indian tribes.

Thus, a golf course in a development of high-end houses can be deemed an
"essential community facility" in an unincorporated area or a town of less than
20,000 people.

The government looks at what will improve the quality of life in a rural
location, no matter what the income level, explains Arthur Garcia, administrator
for USDA's Rural Housing, which handles the loan guarantee program for Rural
Development. A golf course creates jobs directly and indirectly, and attracts
businesses and residents, Garcia says.

"We're not in the business of building recreation for high-income folks," he
says. "Our job is to help communities do what they want to do to build vibrant
communities."

Jerry Thomas, director of Rural Development's community programs in Georgia,
says, "Recreation is something the government considers essential to the
development of a community." He predicts that more golf course projects will
seek government help as the program becomes better known. "Word is kind of out
now that we do golf courses," Thomas says.

The default rate for guaranteed loans is less than 2 percent, according to the
USDA. Garcia says ability to repay is the most important factor when deciding
whether to approve a loan guarantee.

When there is a default, the government uses fees paid by borrowers, rather than
tax dollars, to settle the loan, after the facility's assets have been sold off.

Didn't have the money

When Boykin was inquiring about conventional loans to buy the country club in
Fayette County, he was told by lenders that he would have to put up as much as
50 percent cash equity --- money he didn't have without bringing in other
investors. And if he brought in investors, he would be working for somebody
else.

So Boykin formed a nonprofit corporation, Wyant Golf Enterprises, to qualify for
the federal loan guarantee. Holding forth a binder containing 762 pages of
paperwork, Boykin says getting the guaranteed loan took nearly a year.

"I was fortunate to find this," the 51-year-old Roswell resident says. "I wanted
to orchestrate a quality program. And the best way to do that was to take
advantage of a government program."

The guarantee gives the lender, Heritage Bank, greater peace of mind. And only
the unguaranteed amount --- 10 percent of the loan, or $604,000 in Boykin's case
--- counts against the bank's lending limit.

Any profits the nonprofit Palmer Course earns will go to local charities, Boykin
says. In a couple of years, $200,000 to $300,000 a year could be distributed to
the Friday and Asden Johnson Homes for abused children, the Joseph Sams School
for children with special needs and Fayette Senior Services, he says.

The Palmer Course held its first charity event just before Christmas: the Santa
Open, a one-day golf tournament. The event raised $700, and 120 gifts were
donated to needy children.

"The idea is to make the facility more accessible," Boykin explains. "This is
not about John Boykin getting wealthy. This is not about entrepreneurship."

Boykin says he has no intention of eventually selling the course or converting
it to a for-profit business. The facility won't pay income taxes, because
profits are distributed to charity. But it will pay property and sales taxes.

Boykin's salary as the head of a nonprofit organization will become public
information after his first tax forms are complete. Until then he won't disclose
his pay, saying only that it's in line with industry standards.

His loan guarantee application projects that in the first full year of
operation, the Palmer Course will have gross revenue of $3.84 million and
expenses of $3.45 million, leaving a net income of $388,067. The Palmer Course
has 56 employees.

After buying the property, Boykin sold 66 acres --- including eight golf holes
that had been added on to Arnold Palmer's original 18-hole design --- for $1.8
million to fund renovations and create working capital. Boykin is spending about
$1 million to renovate a 270-seat bar and dining area, called Arnie's, and to
install a new irrigation system.

While the work is ongoing, members of the public can pay $45 to $55 to play the
course or plunk down $1,000 to join the club. But when the renovations are
complete in April, the greens fees will increase and so will the membership fee,
to $5,000.

Boykin says that when he succeeds --- with the government's help --- the
community also wins.

"The real story is somebody who had a vision, had the tenacity to see it
through, and is going to do something to improve people's lives in Fayette
County."

The following projects in Georgia have won loan guarantees under the U.S.
Department of Agriculture's Rural Development program. The borrowers are all
nonprofit organizations.

* Fiscal year 1998 (Oct. 1, 1997-Sept. 30, 1998): Bethany Assisted Living Inc.
got a $700,000 loan with an 80 percent guarantee to build an assisted living
facility in Vidalia. Bethany also got a direct government loan of $700,000.

* FY 1999: No guaranteed loans.

* FY 2000: Southwest Georgia Housing Development Corp. got a $600,000 loan with
a 90 percent guarantee to build a personal care and Alzheimer's facility in
Randolph County. Southwest also got a direct government loan of $2.5 million.
Northeast Health Systems Inc. got a $520,000 loan with 90 percent guaranteed to
renovate a community health center in Gainesville and buy equipment. Northeast
also got a direct government loan of $504,271.

* FY 2001: No guaranteed loans.

* FY 2002: No guaranteed loans.

* FY 2003: Bartram Trail CDC Inc. got an $8.8 million loan with 90 percent
guaranteed to build a public golf course in Columbia County.
Wyant Golf Enterprises Inc. got a $6.04 million loan with 90 percent guaranteed
to buy a golf course and make improvements in Fayette County.
Kids Peace National Centers of Georgia Inc. got a $3.6 million loan with 90
percent guaranteed to build a facility for at-risk children in Carroll County.

Utah: USDA Community Facilities Loan and Grant Program

LENGTH: 357  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Office of Rural Assistance Center, The State of Utah has issued the following
news release:

Sponsor
USDA Rural Development
Deadlines
Applications accepted on an ongoing basis
Contact

For a list of USDA Rural Development State Offices, see
http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/recd_map.html
Purpose

The USDA Community Facilities Loan and Grant Program provides loans, grants, and
loan guarantees for essential community facilities in rural areas. Priority is
given to healthcare, education, and public safety projects. Funds may be used to
construct, enlarge, or improve facilities.

Projects that are more typical to receive funding include:

Hospitals
    Health clinics
    Mental health facilities
    Schools
    Fire houses
    Community centers
    Other community-based initiatives

Applicants can apply for one of three options: the Community Facilities Direct
and Guaranteed Loan Program, the Community Facilities Grant Program, and the
Rural Community Development Initiative.
Eligibility

Community Programs provides grants to assist in the development of essential
community facilities in rural areas and towns of up to 20,000 in population.
Grants are available to public entities such as municipalities, counties, and
special-purpose districts, as well as non-profit corporations and tribal
governments.

Loans and guarantees are also available to public entities such as
municipalities, counties, and special-purpose districts, as well as to
non-profit corporations and tribal governments.
Geographic coverage
Nationwide
Amount of funding

Amount varies. Grants are authorized on a graduated scale. Applicants located in
small communities with low populations and low incomes will receive a higher
percentage of grants.
Application process

Applications are handled by USDA Rural Development field offices. For a listing
of field offices, see http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/recd_map.html
Tagged as
Capital funding, Child care, Community development, Emergency services, Health
information technology, Hospitals and clinics, Long-term care, Schools,
Telehealth

                          Ocala Star-Banner (Florida)

                             October 3, 2011 Monday

120-unit facility for seniors possible near I-75

BYLINE: Susan Latham Carr, Ocala Star-Banner, Fla.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 552 words


Oct. 03--If the Ocala City Council agrees tonight to participate in a federal
loan guarantee program, it could open the door for the development of Ocala West
Senior Living, a 120-unit facility west of Interstate 75 providing independent
living, assisted living and Alzheimer's care for citizens in the city, Marion
County and Levy County.

Tonight's meeting is the first of two public hearings. The second hearing is
Oct. 18.

White Coral Partners LLC and United Development Communities Inc. are asking the
city to participate in the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development's
section 108 Loan Guarantee program to create the facility. Marion and Levy
counties also are being asked to participate.

The developer wants to build a 100,900-square-foot, multi-story residential care
facility for independent living, assisted living and Alzheimer care for seniors.

The project, estimated to cost $20.1 million, would be built on 7.3 acres west
of Southwest 44th Avenue between State Road 200 and Southwest 20th Street in
Ocala.

What the developer is asking for is $14.38 million in combined community support
comprised of loan guarantees of $1 million from Ocala, $1 million from Marion
County and $12.38 million from Levy County.

According to Marc Mondell, the city's executive director of municipal
development, this will help both Levy and Marion counties provide for low- or
moderate-income seniors.

"Levy County has a greater need for this type of service than they have been
able to provide in their community," Mondell said.

But, because Levy County is small, it is difficult for them to attract a lot of
capital to their community. This HUD project will allow Levy County to offer
this service in a neighboring county.

Nevertheless, residents of Levy, Marion County and the city of Ocala all will be
eligible to utilize the facility, but Mondell could not say Monday how the beds
would be allocated among the city's and the two county's residents.

If Council agrees to the plan and gives final approval on Oct. 18, the city will
pledge 7 percent of its federal Community Development Block Grant money to
guarantee the developer's bank loan. The most the city could be liable for is $1
million over 20 years if the developer defaults on its loan. If the developer
pays the loan, the city will pay nothing.

Like Ocala, Marion County will be obligated for 7 percent of its CDBG dollars
over 20 years. Levy County will be obligated for 86 percent of its CDBG dollars
over the 20 years.

The city also will benefit from the project's investment, Mondell said. The city
will receive about $50,000 a year in taxes and electric usage. In addition, the
developer will complete a portion of Southwest 44th Avenue from Southwest 20th
Street and Saddlebrook Elementary. The city also will be able to apply for other
grants to complete Southwest 44th Avenue to its connection at State Road 200.

Mondell said that, before the Oct. 18 meeting, the Ocala/Marion County's
Economic Development Council's Financial Review Committee will review the two
developers' financial statements to determine their financial strength.

Contact Susan Latham Carr at 867-4156 or susan.carr@starbanner.com

                             October 5, 2015 Monday

Washington: Treasury Guarantees $327 Million In Bond Funding For Projects In
Low-Income Communities

LENGTH: 918 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: U.S Department of Treasury has issued the following news release:



 The U.S. Department of the Treasury's Community Development Financial
Institutions Fund (CDFI Fund) announced today that an additional nine bond
loans, totaling $327 million, were guaranteed in fiscal year (FY) 2015, bringing
the total guaranteed to date to $852 million. All of the bond proceeds, provided
through the Community Development Financial Institutions Bond Guarantee Program
(CDFI Bond Guarantee Program), will provide long-term, fixed rate capital for
projects in low-income and underserved communities.





 &ldquo;I am very pleased to recognize the CDFIs that are creating new
partnerships and innovative ways to fully utilize the CDFI Bond Guarantee
Program,&rdquo; said CDFI Fund Director Annie Donovan. &ldquo;The program is
reaching diverse organizations and communities across the country, allowing us
to greatly expand access to financing for low-income areas nationwide.&rdquo;



 The CDFIs that participate in the CDFI Bond Guarantee Program are at the
cutting edge of community development finance. The FY 2015 program participants
share an equal commitment to financing a wide range of job-creating and
community-building projects in urban, rural, and Native American communities.



 Three Bonds were issued on behalf of 9 Eligible CDFIs as follows:



     Community Reinvestment Fund, USA issued a $100 million bond on behalf of
Raza Development Fund. Raza Development Fund is headquartered in Phoenix,
Arizona and is the largest CDFI serving the Latino population on a national
basis. Raza Development Fund plans to finance senior living and long-term care
facilities, daycare centers, healthcare facilities, rental housing,
not-for-profit organizations, and charter schools.



     Opportunity Finance Network issued a $100 million bond on behalf of
Clearinghouse CDFI. Clearinghouse CDFI is headquartered in Lake Forest,
California and is the first non-depository CDFI to receive a public rating from
Standard and Poor's. Originally approved in FY 2013, Clearinghouse CDFI is the
first entity to receive multiple bond loans under the program. Clearinghouse
CDFI has expanded its lending from California to Arizona and Native American
communities, and will continue to serve the rental housing and commercial real
estate market.



     Opportunity Finance Network also issued a $127 million bond on behalf of
seven Eligible CDFIs serving urban, rural, and Native American communities in
the most diverse application approved thus far in the CDFI Bond Guarantee
Program. This bond issue includes the following CDFIs:



         [#x200b]Bridgeway Capital, headquartered in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania,
will provide financing to small businesses, commercial real estate, and
not-for-profit organizations in Western Pennsylvania using its $15 million bond
loan.



         Chicago Community Loan Fund, headquartered in Chicago, Illinois, will
provide financing to commercial real estate, rental housing, not-for-profit
organizations, and charter schools in low-income and underserved areas in
Chicago using its $28 million bond loan.



         Citizens Potawatomi Community Development Corporation, headquartered in
Shawnee, Oklahoma, is the first Native CDFI to participate in the CDFI Bond
Guarantee Program and will provide financing for large scale commercial real
estate projects in the Citizens Potawatomi Nation using its $16 million bond
loan.



         Community Loan Fund of New Jersey, headquartered in New Brunswick, New
Jersey, will provide financing for rental housing and charter schools in
low-income and underserved areas in New Jersey using its $28 million bond loan.



         Community Ventures Corporation, headquartered in Lexington, Kentucky,
will provide financing to small business and commercial real estate in Kentucky
using its $15 million bond loan.



         Federation of Appalachian Housing Enterprises, headquartered in Berea,
Kentucky, will provide financing for rental housing in the greater Appalachian
region using its $15 million bond loan.



         Kentucky Highlands Investment Corporation, headquartered in London,
Kentucky, will provide financing to small businesses and commercial real estate
in Kentucky using its $10 million bond loan.





 The CDFI Bond Guarantee Program was created through the enactment of the Small
Business Jobs Act of 2010. In the three rounds of the CDFI Bond Guarantee
Program completed to date, Treasury has guaranteed bonds for $852 million
dollars for investment in the nation's most underserved rural and urban areas.
While participants are allowed up to five years to fully deploy bond loan funds,
it's anticipated that borrowers in the FY 2015 round will completely commit
their capital to community development projects by the end of calendar year
2018. This means new jobs, new community and neighborhood facilities, and
enhanced economic opportunities for Americans who need it most.



 The CDFI Bond Guarantee Program was extended until September 30, 2015.  The
President's Fiscal Year 2016 budget proposes to extend the program, subject to
reauthorization by Congress.



 To learn more about the CDFI Fund and its programs, please view the Fact Sheet
or visit the CDFI Fund's website at www.CDFIund.gov.  For more information about
the CDFI Bond Guarantee Program, please view the Fact Sheet[#x200b] or visit the
CDFI Fund's website at www.cdfifund.gov/bond.

Washington: Hoeven Announces Nearly $28 Million in USDA Loans to Support Rural
Health Care, Education Facilities

LENGTH: 248 words

DATELINE: Lahore



 Washington: Office of the Senator John Hoeven has issued the following news
release:



 Senator John Hoeven, who serves on the U.S. Senate Agriculture Committee and
Agriculture Appropriations Subcommittee, announced today that the U.S.
Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development has approved direct loans and
a loan guarantee totaling nearly $28 million for health care and education
facilities in rural North Dakota. The funds are made available through USDA's
Community Facilities program. The details of the loans are as follows:





     Hazen Memorial Hospital Association - An $11.1 million direct loan and a
$10.3 million loan guarantee to construct a new Critical Access Hospital and
clinic.

     Hill Top Home Comfort in Killdeer - A $3.5 million direct loan to construct
a new assisted living facility.

     Cankdeska Cikana Community College - A $3.1 million direct loan to
construct a centrally-located, new Head Start facility.



 &ldquo;We're working to support our communities' efforts to ensure their
residents have a high quality of life,&rdquo; Hoeven said. &ldquo;Access to
essential services, like health care and education, are a vital part of that
effort. Today's loans will support the construction of such facilities in Hazen,
Killdeer and Fort Totten, which will promote the well-being and prosperity of
those communities and the surrounding areas."

                                 The Bond Buyer

                              May 27, 2005 Friday

House Bill Seeks USDA Guarantee For Tax-Exempt Rural Water Bonds

BYLINE: Humberto Sanchez

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 6 Vol. 352 No. 32142

LENGTH: 398  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Rep. Ron Lewis, R-Ky., introduced a bill last week that would change the tax

code to make tax-exempt bonds issued by rural communities eligible for a

federal guarantee by the Department of Agriculture.

"This legislation seeks to reduce the backlog of loans for small

communities to build or improve water, wastewater, and essential community

facilities," according to documents provided by Lewis' office. "Currently,

USDA's Rural Development has an accumulation of $1.8 billion of water and

wastewater applications due to the inability of communities to afford the

full expense of the projects."

The bill would have to be approved by the Ways and Means Committee, which

oversees tax policy in the House. Lewis is a member of the committee.

An aide to tax committee chairman Rep. Bill Thomas, R-Calif., declined to

comment on the measure.

Under federal tax law, tax-exempt bonds generally cannot be backed by a

federal guarantee. The only notable exception is for tax-exempt debt issued

for housing.

Supporters of the measure argue that a USDA guarantee would increase the

lending authority of rural banks, which would be able to offer longer loan

terms and reduced interest rates.

The bill would also decrease rural communities dependence of on federal

funding for water, wastewater, and community facility projects.

"In recent years there has become an increased need for projects in rural

communities to facilitate safe drinking water, adequate water treatment, and

essential community facilities for fire and emergency services," the

documents said. "The ability to obtain a guaranteed tax-exempt loan will aid

these communities in their efforts to build these essential projects."

Federal agencies or instrumentalities are prohibited from guaranteeing

tax-exempt debt under Section 149 of the tax code, but that the code also

names a number of exceptions. Those include certain insurance and housing

programs, and Lewis' bill would add water, wastewater, and essential

community facilities to that list. However, the Treasury Department has

traditionally opposed any guarantees of tax-exempt debt.

The bill comes after the 2002 farm bill authorized the secretary of

agriculture to issue guarantees for the water bonds of rural communities, but

made no change in the tax code to carry out the measure.

Sen. Herbert H. Kohl, D-Wis., introduced a similar bill on January 25.

                          Ocala Star-Banner (Florida)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           November 3, 2011 Thursday

City Council votes to approve application to federal loan program

BYLINE: Susan Latham Carr, Ocala Star-Banner, Fla.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 601 words


Nov. 03--The Ocala City Council voted 4-1 on Tuesday to apply to participate in
a federal loan guarantee program that could lead to development of a 120-unit
independent living, assisted living and Alzheimer's care facility for citizens
in the city, Marion County and Levy County.

The vote came during a second public hearing on the subject.

The application does not obligate the city to participate. If the application is
approved, the council then will have to decide whether to enter an agreement
with the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development pledging a portion of
the city's federal community development block grant (CDBG) dollars to guarantee
the project developer's loan.

Each year, the city receives CDBG dollars from the federal government to use on
projects such as housing rehabilitation or providing water and sewer to the
underprivileged. If the city elects to go forward with this loan program, any
funds for which the city might become liable would come from these CDBG funds.

Councilwoman Suzy Heinbockel was the dissenting vote.

"I don't believe the city needs to be involved in securing loans," Heinbockel
said Wednesday. "It's not something we have ever done before and I don't think
we need to start."

Developers White Coral Partners LLC and United Development Communities Inc. are
asking the city to participate in the HUD Section 108 Loan Guarantee program so
they can build the Ocala West Senior Living facility, a 100,900-square-foot,
multi-story residential care facility on 7.3 acres west of Southwest 44th Avenue
between State Road 200 and Southwest 20th Street. The project is valued at $20.1
million.

The developer is putting up roughly $5 million, half in cash. The developer is
hoping to get $14.38 million in loan guarantees, including $1 million, or 7
percent, from Ocala; $1 million, or 7 percent, from Marion County; and $12.38
million, or 86 percent, from Levy County. Because Levy County is small and does
not receive CDBG funds, Levy's participation, if approved, would be guaranteed
by the state's CDBG funds.

This program guarantees the developers' loans. If the developers pay their
loans, the city will owe nothing. However, if the developers default, the city
and the others would be responsible for seeing that the loans are repaid.

"The city's maximum exposure is $1 million over 20 years," said Marc Mondell,
the city's executive director of municipal development.

If Ocala participates, the maximum obligation of $1 million would come from
pledging 7 percent, or roughly $50,000, of its annual CDBG funds over 20 years
until the developers' loans are repaid. The money is payable only if the
developers fail to pay their loans.

The city's 2011 CDBG allocation is $442,477. If, for some reason, the city was
no longer eligible for or was not granted CDBG funds, the city would have no
liability.

Levy County would be eligible for 86 percent of the facility's beds and 86
percent of any jobs generated. This is an opportunity for a small community to
have access to such services. Any beds or jobs Levy County cannot fill could be
taken by people from Marion County.

Ocala would benefit by having access to a portion of the beds and jobs, would
collect revenue from property taxes and electric usage, and a portion of
Southwest 44th Avenue between Southwest 20th Street and Saddlebrook Elementary
School would have to be completed by the developer.

Contact Susan Latham Carr at 352-867-4156 or susan.carr@starbanner.com

(Ocala, Fla.) at www.ocala.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                            November 13, 2006 Monday
                                  Main Edition

$1.8 MILLION BAILOUT;
Why did feds spend taxpayer money on a golf course in an upscale area?

BYLINE: KEVIN DUFFY; Staff

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1A

LENGTH: 1808 words


With its grand clubhouse and 18-hole course that Arnold Palmer helped design,
the former Whitewater Country Club near Peachtree City didn't seem to be the
kind of project that would need help from the federal government.

Yet when a businessman wanted to revive the struggling club, the U.S. Department
of Agriculture, through its Rural Development branch, agreed to guarantee 90
percent of his $6 million loan.

The turnaround plan flopped --- leaving taxpayers on the hook.

The federal government lost $1.8 million after making good on its guarantee and
reimbursing a local bank and four other note holders.

The government closed the book on the sour deal in September, marking the
fourth-largest loss in the loan program's 16-year history.

What was the USDA doing helping a golf course in a Southside enclave where some
homes top $1 million?

Just following the rules.

Loans guaranteed by the USDA are earmarked for "essential community facilities,"
such as nursing homes, schools, hospitals and community centers, according to
the agency's literature. A "success story" on its Web site describes a clinic
built for Eskimos living above the Arctic Circle.

Since 1990, the USDA has guaranteed 553 loans, including those for nine golf
courses --- two in Georgia.

The public, nonprofit courses qualified because the USDA believed they would
provide a boost to the local economy and improve the quality of life. In the
case of the Whitewater Country Club, the owner promised to donate some of the
revenue to local charities.

The USDA doesn't take into account an area's wealth, so Whitewater Country Club
got a guaranteed loan in 2003 --- even though it's bordered by 300 high-end
homes. Less than a year later, the owner defaulted when he couldn't attract
enough players.

"It sounds like to me some people have learned how to scam the system," said
Rep. Lynn Westmoreland (R-Ga.), whose district includes Fayette County. "If you
fill out the forms correctly and all the numbers add up, they're going to do
something. It's a little bit scary."

John Boykin, the former golf instructor and magazine publisher who secured the
loan to buy the country club, declined to discuss the project.

"There's really nothing more to say," the 54-year-old Roswell resident said. "We
made a go of it, and it didn't work."

Heritage Bank, the lender, turned down repeated requests for comment.

Without the guarantee, though, the bank would not have made the loan, according
to USDA documents, some of which were obtained by The Atlanta
Journal-Constitution through the Freedom of Information Act.

"The projections showed the course could make it on its own," said Jack Stanek,
who works for the USDA and handles loan applications. "It just didn't work out
that way."

Unpopular owners

The Whitewater community began more than 20 years earlier through the efforts of
John Blanchard, a Fayetteville dentist, and Joel Cowan, a key figure in
Peachtree City's early development.

In the early 1990s, Robert Brooks, the late owner of the Hooters restaurant
chain, bought the course.

Under Brooks' ownership, the country club was losing members, some of whom had
grown disenchanted with him, according to loan documents and interviews with
residents in the Whitewater community.

Brooks had built a grand clubhouse and another nine holes --- altering the
Palmer design --- but failed to build relationships with the home-owners and
fought their efforts to make Whitewater a gated community.

"He didn't seem to have a lot of friends," said Dave Davis, a retired Delta
pilot who's lived in the Whitewater community for 18 years. "You'd see him up
there eating dinner by himself."

In September 2003, Boykin bought the club from Brooks, who died this past July.
"Just like a chef wants his own restaurant, this is a lifelong fulfillment of a
dream," Boykin said at the time of the purchase.

In his loan application, Boykin said Brooks was one of Whitewater's biggest
problems. "It has often been stated on many occasions 'as long as Bob Brooks
owns Whitewater Country Club, I won't spend a dime there,' " he wrote.

Boykin figured he could woo back the departed golfers, attract new ones and
boost revenue-producing rounds. His resume describes a career devoted to golf:
former editor and publisher of Golf Industry Magazine, inventor of The Scoring
Academy course, owner of the Business Golf International consulting firm, and an
instructor who, during one six-year period, said he taught 200,000 golfers.

The USDA figured Boykin had what it took to make Whitewater a success.

Its loan guarantee was contingent on Boykin forming a nonprofit organization ---
Wyant Golf Enterprises --- and agreeing to open the course to the public and
donate any excess profits to charity.

What went wrong?

The business plan flopped.

Boykin blamed extreme weather, construction delays, stiff competition from three
courses in Peachtree City and the "Delta Air Lines scare" over cutbacks.

Those problems could not have been predicted, the USDA explained.

"It looked like a very good loan for us to do or we wouldn't have done it," said
Stone Workman, the state director of the USDA's Rural Development program.

But Heritage Bank also faulted Boykin's management.

One memo called the financial record-keeping "a disaster." According to
interviews and documents, Boykin, like Brooks, failed to make friends --- a
fatal misstep at a facility that's all about social interaction.

"Members obviously don't want John around and are hard-pressed to recognize
change with him there," the bank's vice president, Benson Freeman, wrote in a
Dec. 23, 2004, memo to the USDA. "I plan on calling John Boykin and encouraging
him to begin spending much less time at the facility."

Retired Delta pilot Herb Summers recalled Boykin's first meeting with
home-owners. "He said, 'Folks, I can make this project work with or without
you,' " Summers said. "That's a heck of a way to start out with a new endeavor."

Boykin made his last loan payment in July 2004 --- less than a year after
getting the money. Later that year, Heritage Bank hired a new management company
to run the course, as the bank tried to find a buyer.

In the summer of 2005, the bank repossessed the course, then sold it to
Canongate Golf Clubs, which owns three courses in Peachtree City and 13 others
across Georgia.

The course, now private and called Whitewater Creek Country Club, is doing well,
according to Ken Guerra, Canongate's vice president for marketing.

"We've had hundreds of new members join," he said. "The rounds are going great."

In a separate deal, the bank also sold Whitewater's swim and tennis facility to
the Whitewater homeowners association.

The proceeds from both sales, however, were not enough to recoup the entire
investment, so the USDA made up most of the shortfall --- $1.8 million.

The money came from institutions that have applied for loan guarantees and paid
a fee --- 1 percent of the guaranteed portion of each loan. Many of those
institutions are public bodies that get their money from taxpayers.

Boykin's loan was the 20th to default since the USDA began its loan guarantee
program in 1990, a failure rate of 3.5 percent. The defaults have cost the
government $16.9 million.

Among the casualties: a hospital in Pennsylvania, an assisted-living facility in
Florida, a community center in Michigan.

Boykin was crushed that his dream of owning a Palmer-designed course had
collapsed, said Jerry Thomas, Rural Development's community programs director in
Georgia.

"This was really devastating to him," Thomas said.

Bill Bozarth, executive director of the government watchdog group Common Cause
Georgia, questioned why the government would lend a hand to a golf club in such
an affluent setting.

"It kind of bothers me," he said, "that a loan guarantee is going to something
that's not eradicating poverty, but to something that otherwise probably is not
economically viable."

AT A GLANCE

THE PROGRAM: The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Rural Development branch makes
loan guarantees to build "essential community facilities," such as schools and
fire stations. Sometimes, golf courses qualify.

THE BORROWER: Roswell resident John Boykin, who has spent his entire career in
golf, wanted to buy the Whitewater Country Club in Fayette County but couldn't
get a loan without the government's help. Less than a year after getting the
loan, Boykin defaulted.

THE LOSERS: Taxpayers. The USDA reimbursed the note holders, losing $1.8 million
--- one of the largest losses in the program's history.

GEORGIA PROJECTS

Ten facilities have received guaranteed loans totaling more than $25 million
over the past 16 years.

                              The American Banker

Agriculture Department Mortgage Plan Helps In Meeting CRA Goals

                            April 20, 1995, Thursday

By ROBYN MEREDITH

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Banks looking to make safer rural loans - and get credit toward Community
Reinvestment Act goals to boot - can turn to a federal loan guarantee program.

The Department of Agriculture runs the popular program, which spurs
homeownership by extending guarantees on loans to poor and working-class rural
residents. Last year, $725 million worth of those loans were supported by the
guarantees. This year the plan is to support $1.04 billion in such loans.

The nation's 20,000 banks and bank branches outside metropolitan areas may find
it particularly useful. The loan guarantees are administered by the USDA's Rural
Housing and Community Development Service, formerly known as the Farmers Home
Administration.

"We look at it as a great way to serve a wider range of rural housing needs,"
said Maureen A. Kennedy, administrator of the service. "The kinds of projects
that we are talking about would all qualify for the Community Reinvestment Act"

The service has two main programs that push credit into rural communities.

The first is its section 502 plan, which provides 90% guarantees for home loans.
The second is its "community facilities loan program," which last year supported
roughly $30 million in loans for rural hospitals, jails, street-paving, and
other public facilities with a government guarantee on 80% of the loan.

Would-be homebuyers who earn 80% to 115% of their community's median income are
eligible for section 502 loans. The USDA guarantees 90% of the loan amount, and
the bank takes the risk on the other 10%. Lenders may make loans for up to the
full value of the house.

"There are plenty of people with low to moderate income that don't have a
$10,000 down payment to buy a home," said former community banker Jan Shadburn,
who is now acting Florida director for the USDA housing service. He said the
guarantees give banks a "comfort zone" on loans they might not ordinarily make.

"In any state, this is a tremendous asset for lenders to be able to participate
in their community and minimize their risk at the same time," said Mr. Shadburn,
formerly an executive vice president at Marianna, Fla.- based Citizens Bank.

Some bankers might be leery of turning to Washington for help making loans in
their own backyards. But the American Bankers Association praised the USDA
program.

"They have done a tremendous job of making it work for bankers," said John
Blanchfield, the ABA's associate director for agriculture and small business
banking. "It has been remarkably free of bureaucracy."

"We've got to be taking our cue from the private sector," said the USDA's Ms.
Kennedy. "We can't say, 'Look, here are our rules - follow them or else forget
it.' We need to be saying, 'What do you need from us?'"

In fact, the rural housing service will be meeting with banks, investment banks,
and others over the next two months to collect their suggestions on how to
improve service.

Nearly 1,000 participating banks get market returns on safe loans through the
program and score points with their regulators under the Community Reinvestment
Act. The average rural housing service home loan is for $61,000, according to
the USDA.

For their loans to qualify for the USDA guarantees, banks must register with the
agency and agree to follow conventional lending practices on qualifying loans.
That process can take less than a month.

The USDA housing service has 7,000 staffers in county offices across the
country. Banks wishing to participate start by contacting the state office of
the service to find the nearest local office.

"We have the expertise in holding the banks' hands," Mr. Shadburn said.
Sometimes real estate agents do the legwork in finding loan customers.
"Generally what we do is set it up through a realtor doing the packaging" of
moderate income loans, Mr. Shadburn said.

Three hundred Florida lenders used the mortgage guarantee program to make $45
million in loans last year, he said. Banks can hold them in portfolio or sell
them into an active secondary market.

In addition to the guaranteed loan programs, the USDA also runs a small pilot
program in some parts of the country that provides added leverage to its rural
housing subsidies.

In Florida, Iowa, Minnesota, Tennessee, Ohio, and Wyoming, banks can lend 50% of
the total amount, while the USDA lends the other 50%. Although there is no
Federal guarantee on the bank's portion of the loan, the USDA takes a
subordinate stake in the loan to lower the bank's risks.

The Rural Housing and Community Development Service also provides direct loans
to low-income rural households and communities - $1.8 billion in such loans last
year. It also runs other programs that do not directly involve banks.

                                US Official News

                           September 9, 2014 Tuesday

Nevada: USDA Announces Loan Guarantee to Help Innovative Company Turn Waste Into
Renewable Jet Fuel

LENGTH: 682  words

DATELINE: Carson City


The State of Nevada has issued the following news release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced that USDA has closed on a loan
guarantee to Fulcrum Sierra Biofuels, LLC to build a biorefinery to produce jet
fuel from municipal solid waste.

"This represents a huge step forward in the development of clean, renewable,
job-creating American fuels," Vilsack said during a speech at the National Clean
Energy Conference. "The nation is entering a new energy age that will make us
more energy independent, cut carbon pollution and strengthen our economy,
especially in rural communities where clean fuels will be produced."

USDA is awarding Fulcrum a $105 million Biorefinery Assistance Program loan
guarantee through Bank of America, N.A. to construct a facility in McCarran,
Nev., to convert municipal solid waste to biodiesel jet fuel. USDA Rural
Development's loan guarantee represents less than half of the $266 million
project cost. The plant is expected to produce 11 million gallons of fuel
annually.

This is the first loan guarantee USDA has made for the production of bio jet
fuel.

Fulcrum will produce synthesis gas from 147,000 tons of municipal solid waste
and catalytically convert it to synthetic paraffinic kerosene/jet fuel through a
proprietary technology. The plant will be the first of what the company expects
to be several bio jet fuel plants throughout the country.

Last month, Cathay Pacific Airways announced that it is investing in Fulcrum
Bioenergy Inc., the parent company of Fulcrum Sierra BioFuels, LLC, and has
negotiated a long-term supply agreement with Fulcrum for 375 million gallons of
sustainable aviation fuel over 10 years. This would represent about 2 percent of
the airline's annual fuel consumption.

USDA awarded the first loan guarantee in 2009 to Sapphire Energy in New Mexico.
Sapphire has already paid off its $54.5 million loan guarantee. The program's
current portfolio includes Fremont Community Digester, located in Fremont,
Mich., which received a $12.8 million loan in 2011 to convert food and
agricultural waste to biogas that is used as fuel to generate electricity. INEOS
New Plant Bioenergy, located in Vero Beach, Fla., received a $75 million loan in
2011 to produce cellulosic ethanol from woody biomass and municipal solid waste.

USDA is negotiating three additional loans for biorefineries in Iowa, North
Carolina and Oregon. These loans would provide financing to produce renewable
fuels from woody biomass, municipal solid waste and energy grasses such as
switch grass, miscanthus and arundo donax. One of these ventures will retrofit
an existing corn ethanol facility to produce cellulosic ethanol.

Biorefineries have broad economic and environmental implications. They lower
greenhouse gas emissions, reduce dependence on foreign oil, give businesses and
consumers more energy options and create jobs.

Congress established the Biorefinery Assistance Program in the 2008 Farm Bill.
It reauthorized and extended the program in the 2014 Farm Bill. The 2014 Bill
expands the program to include bio-based renewable chemicals and bio-based
product manufacturing. USDA staff are working on regulations to set forth
upcoming application terms for additional loan guarantees under the program.

The 2014 Farm Bill builds on historic economic gains in rural America over the
past five years, while achieving meaningful reform and billions of dollars in
savings for taxpayers. Since enactment, USDA has made significant progress to
implement each provision of this critical legislation, including providing
disaster relief to farmers and ranchers; strengthening risk management tools;
expanding access to rural credit; funding critical research; establishing
innovative public-private conservation partnerships; developing new markets for
rural-made products; and investing in infrastructure, housing and community
facilities to help improve the quality of life in rural America. For more
information, visit www.usda.gov/farmbill.

current portfolio includes Fremont Community Digester, located in Fremont,
Mich., which received a $12.8 million loan in 2011 to convert food and
agricultural waste to biogas that is used as fuel to generate electricity. INEOS
New Plant Bioenergy, located in Vero Beach, Fla., received a $75 million loan in
2011 to produce cellulosic ethanol from woody biomass and municipal solid waste.

USDA is negotiating three additional loans for biorefineries in Iowa, North
Carolina and Oregon. These loans would provide financing to produce renewable
fuels from woody biomass, municipal solid waste and energy grasses such as
switch grass, miscanthus and arundo donax. One of these ventures will retrofit
an existing corn ethanol facility to produce cellulosic ethanol.

Biorefineries have broad economic and environmental implications. They lower
greenhouse gas emissions, reduce dependence on foreign oil, give businesses and
consumers more energy options and create jobs.

Congress established the Biorefinery Assistance Program in the 2008 Farm Bill.
It reauthorized and extended the program in the 2014 Farm Bill. The 2014 Bill
expands the program to include bio-based renewable chemicals and bio-based
product manufacturing. USDA staff are working on regulations to set forth
upcoming application terms for additional loan guarantees under the program.

The 2014 Farm Bill builds on historic economic gains in rural America over the
past five years, while achieving meaningful reform and billions of dollars in
savings for taxpayers. Since enactment, USDA has made significant progress to
implement each provision of this critical legislation, including providing
disaster relief to farmers and ranchers; strengthening risk management tools;
expanding access to rural credit; funding critical research; establishing
innovative public-private conservation partnerships; developing new markets for
rural-made products; and investing in infrastructure, housing and community
facilities to help improve the quality of life in rural America. For more
information, visit www.usda.gov/farmbill.

Nevada: USDA Announces Loan Guarantee to Help Innovative Company Turn Waste Into
Renewable Jet Fuel

LENGTH: 682  words

DATELINE: Carson City


The State of Nevada has issued the following news release:

Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced that USDA has closed on a loan
guarantee to Fulcrum Sierra Biofuels, LLC to build a biorefinery to produce jet
fuel from municipal solid waste.

"This represents a huge step forward in the development of clean, renewable,
job-creating American fuels," Vilsack said during a speech at the National Clean
Energy Conference. "The nation is entering a new energy age that will make us
more energy independent, cut carbon pollution and strengthen our economy,
especially in rural communities where clean fuels will be produced."

USDA is awarding Fulcrum a $105 million Biorefinery Assistance Program loan
guarantee through Bank of America, N.A. to construct a facility in McCarran,
Nev., to convert municipal solid waste to biodiesel jet fuel. USDA Rural
Development's loan guarantee represents less than half of the $266 million
project cost. The plant is expected to produce 11 million gallons of fuel
annually.

This is the first loan guarantee USDA has made for the production of bio jet
fuel.

Fulcrum will produce synthesis gas from 147,000 tons of municipal solid waste
and catalytically convert it to synthetic paraffinic kerosene/jet fuel through a
proprietary technology. The plant will be the first of what the company expects
to be several bio jet fuel plants throughout the country.

Last month, Cathay Pacific Airways announced that it is investing in Fulcrum
Bioenergy Inc., the parent company of Fulcrum Sierra BioFuels, LLC, and has
negotiated a long-term supply agreement with Fulcrum for 375 million gallons of
sustainable aviation fuel over 10 years. This would represent about 2 percent of
the airline's annual fuel consumption.

USDA awarded the first loan guarantee in 2009 to Sapphire Energy in New Mexico.
Sapphire has already paid off its $54.5 million loan guarantee. The program's
current portfolio includes Fremont Community Digester, located in Fremont,
Mich., which received a $12.8 million loan in 2011 to convert food and
agricultural waste to biogas that is used as fuel to generate electricity. INEOS
New Plant Bioenergy, located in Vero Beach, Fla., received a $75 million loan in
2011 to produce cellulosic ethanol from woody biomass and municipal solid waste.

an existing corn ethanol facility to produce cellulosic ethanol.

Biorefineries have broad economic and environmental implications. They lower

consumers more energy options and create jobs.

                                 The Bond Buyer

Federally Guaranteed Health Bonds Proposed In Bill From Rep. Stark

                            March 22, 1994, Tuesday

Joan Pryde

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


Buried in Rep. Fortney Stark's health care reform legislation is a provision
that would permit federally guaranteed tax exempt bonds to be issued for certain
health care institutions, according to government and legal sources who have
examined the bill.

Those sources said they were surprised by the California Democrat's plan because
Congress has killed nearly all proposals to waive the prohibition against
federal guarantees for tax-exempt bonds in the 10 years that the prohibition has
been in effect.

Stark's proposal appears to be designed to help health care facilities with
marginal credit ratings gain access to the debt markets, the sources said. Aides
to Stark could not be reached for comment.

Stark is one of the key players in the health reform process, because he chairs
the House Ways and Means Committee's health subcommittee. Several weeks ago,
Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., the chairman of the full committee, called on
Stark's panel to prepare a health care reform proposal that the full committee
could work from in debating the issue.

The subcommittee is now in its second week of debate on a comprehensive package
proposed by Stark. Over all, the measure would require all citizens to carry
health insurance, with most of the cost borne by employers. The bill would also
create a new program to provide insurance for the poor and for anyone not
covered by their employers.

The guarantees for bonds are proposed in a section of Stark's bill that would
create an Essential Community Provider program, to "facilitate the organization
and delivery of primary, preventive, and acute care services for medically
underserved populations in urban areas by fostering networks of essential
community providers."

Under the program, the federal government would offer grants to states,
localities, and health care facilities to set up the networks and build new
health care facilities in the underserved areas.

The government would also offer loans, loan guarantees, and interest rate
subsidies for health care facility projects that involve tax-exempt bond
financing. Under current law such pledges of federal support amount to a federal
guarantee of tax-exempt debt.

"Interest subsidies would be available to reduce the cost of financing
qualifying projects by providing partial federal subsidy of debt service
payments where state and local entities have issued bonds," the bill's
description states.

To obtain credit support from the federal government, "facilities would be
required to demonstrate that a federal loan guarantee is essential to obtaining
bond financing from non-federal lenders at a reasonably affordable rate of
interest," according to the bill's description.

A bond lawyer who examined the proposal said, "What I read this to say is that
there will be loans, loan guarantees, or tax-exempt financing provided with some
sort of credit support for health care facilities who wouldn't otherwise have
access to the market."

Micah S. Green, the executive vice president of the Public Securities
Association, said, "It's encouraging that Mr. Stark in his proposal to the
subcommittee is looking to the capital markets to play a role" in reducing the
cost of financing for health care facilities.

"The combination of loan guarantees and interest rate subsidies with municipal
bonds is an intriguing idea, particularly in this time of interest rate
fluctuation," Green added.

The legislation proposes to amend the Internal Revenue Code so that the bonds
would be exempted from a law enacted in 1984 that prohibits, in most cases,
federal guarantees of tax-exempt debt.

At the time, Congress granted two exemptions to the prohibition on guarantees,
one for housing bonds and the other for student loan bonds. Since then,
lawmakers have steadfastly declined to grant any other exemptions.

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 642 words

LOAD-DATE: March 22, 1994

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        Calgary Herald (Alberta, Canada)

                   November 3, 1994, Thursday, FINAL EDITION

Track seeks loan guarantee

BYLINE: MIKE SADAVA AND MARTA GOLD, EDMONTON JOURNAL

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A12

LENGTH: 517 words


Province to review Edmonton Northlands plans for new casino, updated grandstand

EDMONTON -- Edmonton Northlands is looking for a $ 20-million loan guarantee
from the province to spruce up its racetrack.

But the organization could have a hard time convincing the province it should
get it, and the project will be delayed by city council because there are many
unanswered questions about the renovations.

The renovated grandstand -- which would also include a Las Vegas-style sports
room, video lottery terminals, simulcasting of races from other tracks and
possibly even a future casino -- has been touted as the key to getting people
back to the track.

Frank Johnson, head of finance for Northlands, told executive committee
Wednesday that the project would be funded by a $ 20-million loan from the
Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce, and that loan would have the backing of the
provincial government.

"Alberta has traditionally guaranteed our bank loans, and we're quite optimistic
they will guarantee this loan," Johnson said.

If the province doesn't guarantee it, Northlands would end up paying a higher
interest rate on the loan, he said.

But Municipal Affairs Minister Steve West said the government could have a
difficult time giving the guarantee, given the current climate.

"Although we had in our past some traditional business arrangements, I think . .
. that would not play well today," West said. "Absolutely not."

The province has said it would get out of the business of loan guarantees after
being stung for hundreds of millions of dollars on deals such as Gainers.

Still, West didn't rule out the guarantee to Northlands and said it would be
reviewed.

Racing has been through some hard times over the past few years. Two
thoroughbred cards were cancelled over the summer and both on-track and
teletheatre betting were down considerably.

Some members of Edmonton city council also had problems with the idea of putting
more money into racing.

"I've heard that racing is going downhill, and I have a problem with that," Ald.
Bruce Campbell said. "How is it that Northlands people are convinced that racing
will go up?"

But Northlands president Bob Westbury said the new grandstand would be an
"entertainment centre" that would boost attendance by more than one-third with
the help of other changes such as free parking and admittance.

Executive committee gave approval in principle to the project, but Northlands
must answer a number of planning and tax questions before any work proceeds.

Northlands was especially criticized for its failure to consult with surrounding
communities about traffic and parking problems, as well as the effects of the
extra gambling on community casino and bingo revenues.

Representatives of both the Alberta Avenue Community League and the Area 17
Council, representing northeast Edmonton community leagues, said the project
should be put on hold until the communities get a chance to have some input.

"Right now it's being driven solely by the Northlands agenda," said Richard
McCabe of Alberta Avenue.

Washington: USDA Announces Loan Guarantee to Help Innovative Company Turn Waste

                                American Banker

                           September 9, 2008 Tuesday

Competing for Bond Deals with FHLB Guarantee

BYLINE: Rob Garver

SECTION: SPECIAL REPORT - LEGAL/REGULATORY; Pg. 3A Vol. 173 No. 174

LENGTH: 980 words


About a year ago Dale E. Oberkfell, the president and chief operating officer of
Reliance Bank in Frontenac, Mo., found himself in a frustrating situation:
Working with a local development authority in an economically distressed part of
St. Louis, his bank was trying to secure financing for construction of an
ethanol plant.

The authority needed a letter of credit from a bank with a triple-A debt rating
to get the most favorable pricing for its bonds. Because only the largest
money-center banks have such a rating, the $1.4 billion-asset Reliance needed a
partner. If Mr. Oberkfell could negotiate a deal in which a large institution
would provide a backup credit facility - essentially transferring its triple-A
debt rating to Reliance - the deal would go through.

"My initial choice was to call the Federal Home Loan bank, but I found out they
can't do economic development-type letters of credit," he said. "My only choice
was to go to Wells Fargo at a higher rate, which is ultimately transferred to
the borrower."

The ethanol plant got its funding, but the authority paid more for its bonds
than it might have if the Home Loan Bankof Des Moines, whose members include
Reliance, had been able to offer its backing for the deal.

So Mr. Oberkfell was pleased when President Bush signed a housing rescue bill
into law in July that included a provision letting Home Loan banks issue standby
letters of credit to members backing municipal debt.

The Housing Assistance Tax Act of 2008 changed a key element of the Internal
Revenue Code that had effectively prevented Federal Home Loan banks from
offering guarantees for certain municipal bonds.

In general, municipalities can issue tax-exempt bonds to finance all manner of
projects, from water treatment plants to schools. However, the federal
government historically has been unwilling to allow agencies such as the Home
Loan banks guarantee tax-exempt bonds. Part of the reasoning was that the
government was already lowering municipalities' borrowing costs by giving the
bonds tax-exempt status, and that adding an implied federal guarantee in the
form of a standby letter of credit would give the bonds a status akin to that of
Treasury bills, creating competition for the government's own borrowings.

Before the new law, Federal Home Loan banks were allowed to offer standby
letters of credit for housing-related debt. But any other bond issue would lose
its tax-exempt status if it were backed by a Home Loan bank. The new law removed
that provision, allowing municipal bond issues backed by Home Loan banks to
retain their tax-exempt status even when used for nonhousing purposes.

The upshot for small banks is that more of them will be able to issue backup
credit facilities for municipal bonds.

"It has typically been the case that municipalities had to go to larger
money-center banks for this," said Robert Davis, executive vice president for
government relations with the American Bankers Association. "In some cases, they
would rather keep the fees and services local."

The primary impact of the new law will be to let community banks challenge large
banks and specialized bond insurance companies for business they previously
could not touch, Mr. Davis said.

"Right now there are community institutions that know local municipalities well,
but they don't have the ability to compete for their business when they issue
bonds," he said. "Of course, nothing guarantees that this arrangement will take
certain market share away from larger banks. I'm sure municipalities as a
general matter will look to where they are getting the best service and best
pricing."

Clearly, community banks will not be in the business of backing huge projects
like Boston's Big Dig or the reconstruction of the World Trade Center site in
Manhattan, Mr. Davis said. "Obviously, they are going to be serving smaller
communities."

And according to some bankers, those small communities need of financial backing
for infrastructure projects the most. The credit crunch has made borrowing more
difficult across the board, but the recent troubles at large bond insurance
companies have put increased pressure on the market for backing of small
municipal borrowings.

"Historically it has been a problem," Mr. Oberkfell said. "Even with the ethanol
facility in St. Louis, the large insurance companies didn't want to look at it,
because the transaction was under $20 million. If a municipality goes to one of
the bond insurance companies, the premium they charge today is pretty
excessive."

Glen Marshall, the president and chief executive officer of the $100
million-asset First Resource Bank in Exton, Pa., echoed that view.

"When some of these credit markets started to close off, you saw a lot of small
to medium-sized school districts that were having trouble financing things," he
said. "This legislation gets them back in the bond market, where they want to
be."

The law does not require Home Loan banks to offer credit guarantees to members
backing municipal bonds, so it is not clear when or even if guarantees will be
available in all 12 of the Home Loan banks.

However, Mr. Marshall said that in general, the banks are highly attuned to the
need for local economic development projects.

"The FHLB doesn't want to see those projects not get done," he said.

Several Home Loan bank presidents have been vocal in their support of the
legislation,

John R. Price, the president and CEO of the Home Loan Bank of Pittsburgh, said
in a press release that he was "tremendously pleased" with the law, and that it
would allow community banks to step into an underserved market, bringing needed
liquidity.

"Insurers today are not as willing to engage in small-scale deals in support of
municipal projects," Mr. Price said. "Injecting additional competition into the
market through FHLB guarantees will keep projects moving while holding down
costs for local taxpayers."

URL: http://www.americanbanker.com/

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              21 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                         Deming Headlight (New Mexico)

                            February 9, 2010 Tuesday

USDA opportunities for NM projects

BYLINE: By Terry Brunner We are at a critical juncture in New Mexico's history
as we approach our Centennial in 2012. Of great concern to us all should be how
our rural communities will fare over the next 100 years. Will they continue to
struggle or will we mak

SECTION: OPINION

LENGTH: 737 words


Before us lies an extraordinary opportunity, through the American Recovery and
Reinvestment Act of 2009 (also known as the Stimulus), to make immediate and
necessary investments in our rural communities.

The United States Department of Agriculture New Mexico Rural Development office
saw funding increases in many of its programs as a result of the Stimulus. USDA
Rural Development in New Mexico almost tripled its regular programmatic spending
for dozens of new projects in fiscal year 2009 to $354 million. We hope to have
another banner year in FY 2010 before the Stimulus expires in September.

As we see tight budgets at the state and local level in New Mexico there is no
better time for New Mexico's communities to consider USDA funding for their
projects. USDA Rural Development offers programs in three areas: Community
Development, Business and Housing.

Businesses and value added agricultural producers in New Mexico communities with
a population less than 50,000 are eligible for our Business Programs. Most types
of new or existing enterprises qualify -manufacturing, wholesale, retail or
service. We offer up to a 90% loan guarantee for bankable projects as large as
$10 million and can provide smaller guarantees on proposals as high as $25
million. It is our goal to guarantee at least $29 million in business loan
guarantees around New Mexico this fiscal year.

We also offer programs to help businesses and agricultural producers save on
energy costs. Our Renewable Energy for America program allows USDA to cover 25%
of any renewable energy or energy efficiency project for a rural business or an
ag producer. If your farm or business hopes to install a new water heater,
upgrade swamp coolers or even take advantage of solar, wind power or bio-diesel;
USDA would like to help with that investment.

For those producers that add value to an agricultural product, we provide up to
$100,000 in grant funding for planning costs and up to $300,000 for working
capital. Value added projects can include a wide variety of efforts such as
turning tomatoes into salsa, carving wood products, and making a popcorn product
from locally-grown corn.

On the community side, the stimulus program enhanced greatly our ability to loan
and grant to communities less than 20,000 in population for community
facilities. USDA Rural Development can invest in community facilities, such as:
health care facilities, community centers, libraries, roads, emergency services,
and community greenhouses -- just to name a few.

Water and Wastewater infrastructure is of tremendous importance to rural
communities in our state. In communities under 10,000, USDA offers loans and
grants to help with water and wastewater systems. Hundreds of New Mexico
communities have participated in this program over the years and we are prepared
to help many more.

To be competitive and innovative, rural communities need access to modern
telecommunications. The stimulus set aside billions to increase broadband access
in rural America and USDA Rural Development spent $199 million alone in rural
New Mexico last year for broadband and telecommunications infrastructure. Not
only do we invest in the first, middle and last mile of telecommunications
infrastructure but we are very interested in supporting distance learning,
telemedicine and other efforts that connect rural communities to the power of
the internet.

When we talk about the sustainability of our rural communities, nothing says
sustainability more than providing families the ability to make their home in
rural New Mexico. In communities under 10,000, USDA provides home loans, home
loan guarantees and grants for the construction, purchase or renovation of a
home. More than 6,500 New Mexicans currently use our housing programs.

This is just a sample of the many programs USDA Rural Development has to offer.
The Stimulus presents New Mexico with unprecedented opportunities to improve the
quality of life in rural New Mexico and give rural communities the tools they
need to prosper. The time to act is now, while federal agencies like the USDA
have the resources to make more investments than ever. If you are interested in
any of these programs, I hope you will contact the USDA Rural Development office
in New Mexico at (505) 761-4950.

Terry Brunner was appointed by President Barack Obama on September 3, 2009 to
serve at State Director for the New Mexico Office of USDA Rural Development.
