                     The Idaho Business Review (Boise, ID)

                              May 25, 2010 Tuesday

Local officials see $2 billion loan guarantee as another step on road to Eagle
Rock uranium enrichment plant

BYLINE: Anne Wallace Allen

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 563  words


Bob Everhart, the executive director of the Idaho Falls Convention and Visitors
Bureau, had been confident all along that the proposed Eagle Rock uranium
enrichment plant would move forward as planned 18 miles west of Idaho Falls.

But news that the plant's French-owned builder, Areva Inc., had won a $2 billion
federal loan guarantee for the project came as a relief to Everhart, who has
been following Areva closely since the company chose Idaho Falls as its site for
the plant in May 2008. The plant will provide uranium enrichment services for
the nuclear power industry.

"Now that it has actually happened, we can look forward to one more step, and
that is getting the actual permits," Everhart said May 24. Areva has applied for
licensing from the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission, a process not expected
to be completed until June 2011.

"Once that happens they'll start hiring employees," Everhart said.

The U.S. Department of Energy announced May 20 that Areva's U.S. subsidiary,
Areva Enrichment Services LLC, would obtain $2 billion in federal loan
guarantees for its Idaho Falls project. Areva has proposed to build a
multi-billion-dollar plant that will use advanced centrifuge technology for
uranium enrichment, a step in producing nuclear energy.

"AREVA is elated by this decision which will enable us to continue development
of our Eagle Rock facility in Idaho and contribute to rebuilding America's
energy infrastructure so we can produce more CO2-free electricity," said Jacques
Besnainou, chief executive officer of AREVA North America.

The Boise-based anti-nuclear group Snake River Alliance said it considers the
loan guarantee a subsidy from the U.S. government that should not go to a French
company.

"This won't produce any power for the state of Idaho," said Liz Woodruff, an
energy policy analyst for the state of Idaho, noting that the proposed plant
would produce enriched uranium, but not energy.

All four members of Idaho's congressional delegation have shown support for the
plant, saying it would produce clean energy and reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Everhart and Linda Martin, the executive director of the business group Grow
Idaho Falls, said the local community is strongly behind the plant as well. The
area's population is about 54,000.

"Everyone in the community is pulling for Areva," said Martin, who has seen her
area's unemployment rise from 1.9 percent in 2008 to about 6 percent now.

It will likely take another full year for Areva to complete the NRC licensing
process, said Jarret Adams, a spokesman for Areva based in Bethesda, Md.

"We'll expect to break ground as soon after that as possible," said Adams,
adding that Areva aims to have the plant running sometime in 2014.

Areva has said construction of the plant will create thousands of temporary
jobs. The plant will employ about 400 people full-time after it is completed.
Martin said those jobs are expected to pay $40,000 to $60,000 and that Areva
would hire its staff from the local community, where there are skilled workers
available.

Martin said she hoped many of the people who are now working for the Idaho
Cleanup Project at the Idaho National Laboratory site will be able to move to
jobs at the nuclear power plant.

"What we had always hoped was as the tasks with the Idaho Cleanup Project were
completed, we have people who can dovetail into the Areva project," Martin said.

                     The Idaho Business Review (Boise, ID)

                              May 21, 2010 Friday

Idaho uranium enrichment plant wins $2 billion loan guarantee

BYLINE: IBR Staff

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 569  words


A nuclear project in Idaho Falls is getting a $2 billion boost as the oil spill
polluting the Gulf of Mexico has the government eager for alternatives to fossil
fuels.

The Energy Department has announced a $2 billion loan guarantee for French-owned
nuclear services company Areva Inc. to support construction of a uranium
enrichment plant in eastern Idaho.

That news comes as President Barack Obama is poised to ask Congress to agree to
$9 billion more in loan guarantees for the atomic energy sector. That's
according to a statement made by Democratic aide who spoke on condition of
anonymity to the Associated Press.

The new spending follows $18.5 billion in nuclear loan guarantees the Obama
administration announced in February to spur building of the first nuclear power
plant in the U.S. in almost three decades.

Idaho Senators Mike Crapo and Jim Risch and Congressmen Mike Simpson and Walt
Minnick today praised a decision by the U.S. Department of Energy to provide
federal loan guarantees for construction of the Eagle Rock Uranium Enrichment
Plant near Idaho Falls. AREVA officials say the project would create 400
permanent jobs near Idaho Falls, create another 1,000 construction jobs and
result in the creation of up to 5,000 jobs in related services.

The Energy Department announced today that AREVA's U.S. subsidiary, AREVA
Enrichment Services LLC, will obtain $2 billion in federal loan guarantees to
assist in construction of the Idaho project. All four members of the Idaho
Delegation have supported the project in letters and phone calls and note that
appropriate federal support will lead to the expansion of clean nuclear power.
They said the DOE Loan Guarantee Program is among the few policy tools
immediately available to deliver market-ready innovative, clean energy
technologies that will have economic and environmental impacts.

"Developing new U.S.-based sources of uranium enrichment is critical to the
country being able to reduce greenhouse gas emissions, achieving energy
independence, having a reliable supply for domestic power reactors and
protecting our national security,"  Crapo said in a statement.

The Eagle Rock plant will be one of Idaho's contributions to this worthy and
attainable goal of reducing green house emissions, Crapo added.

Sen. Risch said the loan guarantee from the Department of Energy is a crucial
step in meeting the demand for a reliable, U.S.-based source of enriched uranium
to fuel our nuclear power plants.

Risch, a member of the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee, said the
development of the plant will be a great benefit to the local communities and
the state.

Simpson, a member of the House Energy and Water Appropriations Subcommittee
which funds the Department of Energy and the Loan Guarantee program, said the
people of eastern Idaho have worked together with Areva, the DOE and other
agencies to secure this loan guarantee for the Eagle Rock facility.

"Nuclear energy must play a strong role in our nation's energy future and the
Eagle Rock facility's contribution to that future will be enormous," he said.

Minnick commented on the alternative energy solutions such as nuclear power and
woody biomass as being a crucial part of working toward an economic recovery.

"This project will help Idaho businesses and universities do just that, and will
help meet our shared goal of Idaho becoming a national leader in the new energy
future," he said.

                                The Toronto Star

                             June 12, 2014 Thursday

Council votes to save Red Door Shelter

BYLINE: Paul Moloney Toronto Star

SECTION: GREATER TORONTO; Pg. GT1

LENGTH: 390 words


Toronto city council wants to keep the red door - a beacon for families in need
for 32 years - open.

Councillors voted unanimously Wednesday to assist the Red Door Shelter on Queen
St. E., which is threatened by a real estate sale, though what form that
assistance may take has yet to be worked out. The 106-bed family shelter in
south Riverdale represents 13 per cent of the city's 814 permanent beds for
families. The city pays Red Door $2.56 million a year for helping some 500
families.

The facility has strong community support, including a 50,000-name petition.
There are signs posted in store windows and community fundraising going on, said
Councillor Paula Fletcher.

"It's not that often that you have a community standing up to support a shelter
in this way," Fletcher said. "Often, communities stand up to say they don't want
a shelter.

"I've never heard one voice against the shelter," she added.

Council was told that staff will report next year on possible options to assist
Red Door.

It may need an increase in its operating funding from the city, and a city loan
guarantee if the shelter acquires space in a new building on its site at 875
Queen St. E.

The shelter is talking to the purchaser of the property, council was told, and
could obtain new space for $4.6 million to $6.2 million.

Deputy city manager Brenda Patterson pointed out that the city has successfully
granted loan guarantees in the past to help out child-care centres.

Councillor Denzil Minnan-Wong urged caution, noting that a $5-million city loan
guarantee to the Bixi bike share project ended badly. He urged councillors to
look at any deal that comes forward "with a very careful eye and a very sharp
pencil."

Red Door executive director Bernnitta Hawkins said she was pleased with the
unanimous council vote.

"It says very clearly that our funder is supporting us, and that's very
important," Hawkins said.

"This gives us a foundation underneath us when we go into negotiations."

The shelter is heavily used, with an occupancy rate of 95 to 97 per cent, she
said.

"We're used by any family that for any reason finds themselves without a home.
People come to us (as) women and children fleeing violent homes; they come to us
from the airport because they're refugees to Canada and don't have a home; they
could be experiencing eviction or some other housing crisis."

                     The Pantagraph (Bloomington, Illinois)

                             June 17, 2008 Tuesday

Lincoln College welcomes federal backing

BYLINE: By Michele Steinbacher;msteinbacher@pantagraph.com

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A3

LENGTH: 495 words


By Michele Steinbacher

msteinbacher@pantagraph.com

LINCOLN - The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Rural Development program is
standing behind Lincoln College's latest project: an $8.4 million athletic and
convocation center that also will house a museum of Abraham Lincoln artifacts.

On Monday, U.S. Rep. Ray LaHood, a Peoria Republican, visited the private
college along with USDA officials to announce the federal support.

In particular, USDA Rural Development will guarantee a $3.8 million loan from
State Bank of Lincoln. State grants and private donations will cover the
remainder of the project's cost.

That loan guarantee helps both the city's business community and the college.
The college gets better loan terms while the U.S. government backing means a
local lender can step in without adversely affecting its lending limits, said
Joan Messina, a USDA Rural Development spokeswoman.

"This is another great day for Lincoln and Lincoln College," said LaHood,
standing outside the college's University Hall.

Douglas Wilson, who heads USDA Rural Development's Illinois operations, said
many people don't realize the program's role in supporting the small communities
that dot the United States.

"We work to try to improve the quality of life for rural America," he said,
noting that help extends to homeowners, businesses, and community facilities,
such as the Lincoln campus.

"This shows the USDA has confidence in us and understands the importance of the
project for the region," said John Hutchinson, Lincoln College president.

The 143-year-old private college enrolls about 700 students on its main campus;
another 500 attend its Normal campus.

LaHood noted that as one of three chairmen heading the Abraham Lincoln
Bicentennial Commission, he's especially excited about the building's role
housing the Lincoln Heritage Museum.

The museum contains more than 2,000 Lincoln volumes, manuscripts and artifacts.

The fact the museum is in a college and town both named for the nation's 16th
president while he was still alive means both the nation's history and future
are celebrated, he said.

"That's what colleges are all about: the future," said LaHood.

General contractor Core Construction created the building's design as a
two-story red-brick building.

The 66,000-square-foot structure will stand at the northeast corner of the
campus.

--

convocation center

When: 10 a.m. June 25

Where: Just north of Heritage Hall on Lincoln College campus, Lincoln

Construction: The 16-month construction project, led by Core Construction,
should be complete by December 2009.

Cost $8.4 million.  Size: 66,000 square feet; convocation center/gym to seat
1,500

HUD to fund new Gary fire station, West Side fixes

BYLINE: Joseph S. Pete, The Times, Munster, Ind.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 222 words


Nov. 02--A $6 million loan guarantee from the U.S. Department of Housing and
Urban Development will finance some much-needed projects in Gary.

The federal funds will pay for the rehabilitation of the Hudson Campbell Fitness
Center downtown, renovation of the auditorium and athletic facilities at West
Side High School, and the construction of a new fire station in the University
Park area.

Gary's Station 5 used to be based at 4101 Washington Ave. in the University Park
neighborhood, but it has been a "homeless" firehouse since 2012, when a
contractor found asbestos. The station has since bounced around to different
locations in Merrillville and Calumet Township.

"We were simply thrilled to receive news of the loan guarantee," Mayor Karen
Freeman-Wilson said. "HUD has been an extremely supportive partner that
understands what we are trying to do to revitalize the city. This loan will
allow us to make some significant progress on projects that our residents have
been asking for."

Community development block grants provide communities with a source of
financing for economic development, housing rehabilitation and other large-scale
projects.

U.S. Rep. Pete Visclosky's office helped secure the grant.

                           The Mount Airy News, N.C.

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                              July 13, 2012 Friday

Local utility to make $20 million in improvements

BYLINE: Tom Joyce, The Mount Airy News, N.C.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 537 words


July 13--DOBSON -- Surry-Yadkin Electric Membership Corp. will be improving and
expanding its facilities with the help of a $20 million loan guarantee by a
federal agency.

The local provider was among rural electric cooperatives and utilities in 15
states tapped for loan guarantees announced Wednesday by U.S. Agriculture
Secretary Tom Vilsack. They are being provided through the Department of
Agriculture's Rural Development unit.

This will allow the various entities to make improvements to generation and
transmission facilities and implement smart grid technologies. Only two
companies in North Carolina were approved for loan guarantees, Surry-Yadkin
Electric Membership Corp. based in Dobson, and one in the Cape Hatteras area.

The $20 million loan to Surry-Yadkin isn't coming from the federal agency
itself, but will be guaranteed by it -- "which helps our interest rate,"
explained Robert Maxwell, the company's manager of engineering and operations.

Maxwell added Thursday that the loan is part of a five-year $21 million
construction plan for Surry-Yadkin Electric Membership Corp. "It's for capital
projects -- it's for system improvements," he said.

The financing will allow Surry-Yadkin to build and improve 114 miles of
distribution and transmission lines that will serve nearly 1,500 customers.

This will include about $6 million for new lines to serve consumers added within
its service area, such as through home construction.

Other funds are targeted for upgrading or replacing existing equipment.

Surry-Yadkin Membership Corp now has about 28,000 service accounts and maintains
nearly 4,000 miles of lines spanning five counties. The utility that was
organized in 1940 employs around 55 people.

No More Meter Readers

A portion of the guaranteed loan targeted for smart grid technology locally --
some $3 million -- will mean the end of conventional meter-reading for
Surry-Yadkin Electric Membership Corp., whereby personnel must physically travel
to a customer location.

Maxwell said an automated meter-reading system is being added which will allow
electrical usage to be monitored from a remote location and free up employees
for other tasks.

That project is about halfway complete, Maxwell said.

This week's announcement includes support for more than $10 million in smart
grid technologies nationwide. Such innovations help utilities make efficiency
improvements to the electric grid and mean lower power bills for consumers by
reducing energy use in homes and businesses.

The agriculture secretary's goal is to fund more than $250 million for smart
grid technologies around the country.

Along with ensuring continued service to residential users through the
maintaining of a reliable, up-to-date electrical infrastructure, the federal
loan guarantees announced this week will allow rural communities to retain
existing businesses and support new ones, officials say.

"These loans I am announcing today will have a lasting impact on the rural
landscape for generations to come," Vilsack said.

Reach Tom Joyce at 719-1924 or tjoyce@heartlandpublications.com

(Mount Airy, N.C.) at www.mtairynews.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                        Lincoln Journal Star (Nebraska)

                             May 2, 2007 Wednesday
                                  City Edition

Definitions differ, but 'rural America' is bigger than you think

BYLINE: THOMAS C. DORR, For the Lincoln Journal Star

SECTION: B; Pg. 5

LENGTH: 856 words


The Journal Star recently carried a Washington Post critique of a small number
of USDA Rural Development projects, largely in New England or along the Atlantic
seaboard.

The Post's general criticism was that the communities featured in these selected
examples were insufficiently "rural." (The Post's story also was cited in a
Journal Star editorial "USDA should give rural aid to rural areas.")

I appreciate this opportunity to provide additional context regarding the
definition of a rural community and why this issue is not as simple as drawing a
hard line of distinction, if our goal is truly to assist rural communities.

For the record, all of the projects highlighted by the Post's story met the
statutory definition of rural as defined by Congress, and all were successful
projects. In addition, many of these investments involve loans or loan
guarantees in which the USDA Rural Development commitment leveraged additional
private funds and will be repaid over time.

Even more fundamentally, however, the narrowly selected examples in the article
do not represent the broad scope of rural development projects, and the
challenges associated with defining rural America went unrecognized.

USDA Rural Development's mission is to increase economic opportunity and improve
the quality of life in rural communities. It administers more than 40 programs
that provide grants, loans and loan guarantees to support rural infrastructure,
affordable housing, vital community facilities and business development
opportunities. Some are means tested; others are not. Most are competitively
awarded. The cumulative loan portfolio currently exceeds $96 billion with an
aggregate delinquency rate of only 1.03 percent.

Given the diversity of rural America, what this means in practice varies widely
from one community to another. If rural America were a nation of its own, it
would have a population equivalent to France or Italy in a land area larger than
Europe west of Russia. USDA Rural Development does indeed support economic and
community development in small New England towns where tourism and recreation
may be the primary economic drivers. It also works aggressively in the colonias,
on Native reservations, in the Mississippi Delta, across the Northern Plains and
throughout the Farm Belt.

Some rural communities are quite affluent. Others are economically distressed.
Most are middle-American and middle-income in character.

This diversity unquestionably gives rise to definitional challenges. In many
places, the urban-rural boundaries are blurred by modern communications and
transportation, the increasing regionalization and diversification of the rural
economy and closer integration with urban hubs. Individuals in these areas,
however, still live in rural communities as defined by law and as understood by
the residents themselves. It is difficult to tell a family farmer who gets his
electricity from a rural electric co-op and draws his water from a rural water
system that he is no longer "rural" because he now has a neighbor who commutes
an hour, perhaps two, to a regional hub of 50,001 people. Very often, in fact,
"metropolitan" counties contain large areas that remain rural in character.

Similarly, it is difficult to tell the year-round, often low-income residents of
a small fishing town in New England or a vacation community in coastal New
Jersey - two cases cited by the Post - that they are no longer "rural" because
of a seasonal influx of vacationers. The Post makes much of Provincetown, Mass.,
as an example. It would have added considerable depth to the story to note that
Provincetown, with a Census population of 3,341, has a Census median household
income of $32,716, well below the state nonmetro median of $56,354. One needs to
look beyond the millionaires' summer homes on the beach to assess the needs of
the community.

As the economic and demographic structure of rural America continues to change,
these definitional issues will continue to spur debate. Definitions of "rural"
have been established over the years on a program-by-program basis and vary
widely.

We agree that some standardization would be useful. In fact, the administration
is proposing the consolidation and retargeting of a number of rural development
programs in our budget and in our 2007 Farm Bill proposals. Consolidation would
lead to simplification and greater clarity. At the same time, our Farm Bill
proposals suggest important new initiatives to support rural critical access
hospitals, renewable energy development and vital community facilities, such as
fire stations and water treatment facilities, in rural America. We welcome a
simplified approach to delivering these important programs.

We will continue to work with Congress to resolve the difficult line-drawing
issues that arise. However the urban-rural boundary lines ultimately are drawn,
USDA Rural Development remains committed to the future of rural communities.
These communities don't all look alike, but they are rural America, and our
programs make a very real difference in the lives of many Americans.

Thomas C. Dorr is USDA undersecretary of rural development.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

PUBLICATION-TYPE: Newspaper

                              All Rights Reserved

                              The American Banker

Minority Bankers Creating Fund to Rebuild Churches

                           October 3, 1996, Thursday

By SARAH YAVORSKY


A coalition of minority-owned banks is organizing a loan fund to finance the
rebuilding of black churches razed in the recent rash of arson fires across the
South.

Members of the National Bankers Association committed last month to amassing a
$5 million fund to make loans for the felled churches, many of them in rural,
poor minority communities.

National Bankers, a group of minority and women bankers, hope the loan fund and
federal government guarantees will help the churches rebuild, and in some cases
improve, their facilities.

"We had to respond to the need of the churches," said trade group chairman Louis
Prezeau, who is chief executive of City National Bank in Newark, N.J.

Mr. Prezeau said that for him, helping rebuild African-American churches was a
way of returning the good will given to his bank by religious organizations in
Newark - and a good business opportunity.

"City National was formed with tremendous support from the community and local
churches," he said. "In the 23 years we have been making loans to churches, we
haven't lost a penny."

The fund will work as a loan-participation pool. A church can contact National
Bankers in Washington, which will put it in touch with a nearby member bank. The
member bank will then evaluate the loan and parcel it out to the other banks in
the fund.

In addition, trade group members hope to use a $10 million loan guarantee fund
administered by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The guarantee,
provided for by July legislation in response to the church burnings, will allow
banks to make below-market loans to churches.

The programs are part of a wellspring of efforts to help rebuild the affected
churches. National Bankers, HUD, Habitat for Humanity, the National Council of
Black Churches, and other nonprofit organizations have formed a task force to
rebuild the churches and help them establish lasting financial relationships.

"Many of the affected churches do not have insurance, and (thus have) no
pre-existing relationship with a bank," said HUD Assistant Secretary Andrew
Cuomo. Many such churches do not know how to access a loan guarantee fund, and
with an income stream dependent on their congregations' generosity might have a
hard time trying to secure a loan to rebuild.

Tri-State Bank of Memphis offered Truelight Missionary Baptist Church a $50,000
loan at 4.5%, using the HUD guarantees, and hopes to make it a part of the
National Bankers fund. However, the loan has not been approved yet, said Jesse
Turner, president of Tri-State and an association member.

"Tri-State is a very heavy lender of church loans, particularly to black
churches, and we have never lost any money on a church loan," he said.

Churches, he said, make extremely good customers because of the commitment of
local pastors and deacons. "That group of people takes their fiduciary
obligation very seriously," he said.

Regarding the HUD guarantee, Mr. Turner said the trade group was already
committed to helping the churches rebuild. "The HUD guarantee makes it easier
for us to do that at subprime rates," he added.

Mr. Turner stressed that a loan would not be made if it is felt "the church
cannot pay the note."

SECTION: COMMUNITY BANKING; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 535 words

                          Kitsap Sun, Bremerton, Wash.

                              May 9, 2013 Thursday

Navy plans to renovate Jackson Park housing

BYLINE: Ed Friedrich, Kitsap Sun, Bremerton, Wash.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 633 words


May 09--BREMERTON -- The Navy and a private company will renovate or replace all
of the units at the Jackson Park Housing Complex.

In a draft environmental assessment released Wednesday, the Navy proposes
transferring ownership and operation of the 870 units to a limited liability
corporation.

The preferred alternative is to renovate 601 units, converting two- and
three-bedroom homes to four and five bedrooms, and demolish 241 units. The
result would be a total of 629 larger family residences.

A second option is to tear down all 870 units and replace them with 629.

The company also would build or renovate support facilities, including play
areas and parks, trails, sidewalks and bike paths, outdoor lighting, parking
areas, athletic facilities, community centers and fencing.

"One goal for the Navy is to support the war fighter," said Capt. Chris
LaPlatney, commanding officer of Naval Facilities Engineering Command Northwest.
"In transferring the Jackson Park military housing community to a
yet-to-be-determined private partner, the partnership is able to provide Navy
families with updated, improved quality housing for their families."

The Navy chose the first alternative, stating it's more energy-efficient to
renovate than to demolish and rebuild. The draft assessment concludes it
wouldn't significantly affect the quality of the human environment.

Cost estimates are being developed, said NAVFAC Northwest spokeswoman Leslie
Yuenger. The housing project is scheduled to go private Oct. 1.

Most military housing has already traveled this route. Navy Region Northwest
privatized 2,972 units in 2004, and now has 1,340 units in Kitsap County.
Jackson Park was left out because of a Superfund cleanup of possible unexploded
ordnance.

The site on the west shore of Ostrich Bay housed an ammunition depot from 1904
to 1959. In 1965, 133 acres were transferred for housing. The first 25 buildings
and 50 carports at the development named for U.S. Sen. Henry "Scoop" Jackson
were completed that year. One hundred units were added in 1968, 200 in 1970 and
300 in 1975. In 1996, 190 were renovated and 170 built. Most are about 40 years
old.

Congress established the Military Housing Privatization Initiative in 1996 to
address two major problems -- the poor condition of military-owned housing, and
the shortage of good, affordable private housing. When the program began, more
than half of Department of Defense-owned family housing units needed to be
renovated or replaced because they hadn't been maintained or modernized. Through
the traditional military construction process, that would have cost taxpayers
nearly $25 billion and taken 20 years, according to the Pentagon. Private
developers can build housing faster and less expensively, particularly when
given financial tools like direct loans, loan guarantees and rental guarantees.

Public-private partnerships are no guarantee of success, however. Navy Region
Northwest and American Eagle Communities joined up in 2005. American Eagle was
responsible for building 605 homes, demolishing 585 and renovating 1,639 in four
years. Three years later, it was $14 million over budget and behind schedule
when it sold its Northwest properties to Forest City Communities.

Companies that partner with the Navy lease the properties for up to 50 years.
They handle all resident matters, including maintenance. Sailors receive a
housing allowance and pay rent directly to the company.

The Navy is accepting public comments on privatizing Jackson Park until May 22.
Comments can be sent to christopher.runner@navy.mil or to Christopher Runner,
NAVFAC Northwest, 1101 Tautog Circle, Room 203, Silverdale, WA 98383.

___ (c)2013 the Kitsap Sun (Bremerton, Wash.) Visit the Kitsap Sun (Bremerton,
Wash.) at www.kitsapsun.com Distributed by MCT Information Services

                               November 30, 1998

HUD Funds to Revitalize Polluted Sites

SECTION: AFFORDABLE HOUSING; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 232 words

DATELINE: Washington


The Department of Housing and Urban Development last week issued $ 152 million
in grants and loan guarantees to help revitalize 21 communities designated as
industrial "brownfields."

Those communities receiving brownfields money include: Huntington Beach, Calif.;
Los Angeles; Stockton, Calif.; Atlanta; Thomson, Ga.; Chicago; Springfield,
Mass.; Benton Harbor, Mich.; Kansas City, Mo.; St. Louis; Ithaca, N.Y.; Nassau
County, N.Y.; Rochester, N.Y.; Syracuse, N.Y.; Oklahoma City, Okla.; Allegheny
County, Pa.; Bethlehem, Pa; Philadelphia; Memphis, Tenn.; and King County,
Washington.

The seed money provided by HUD will be used to transform polluted and abandoned
commercial and industrial sites into businesses, homes and recreational sites.
On top of the HUD assistance, businesses and local governments are expected to
chip in more than $ 715 million in additional money to help rebuild the
brownfields communities.

"We are taking polluted sites once given up for dead and bringing them back to
life," said HUD Secretary Andrew Cuomo.  The HUD assistance includes $ 22
million in brownfields economic development initiative grants and $ 130 million
in economic development loan guarantees.

The loan guarantees provide communities with a source of financing for job
creation, housing rehabilitation and construction of public facilities and
largescale development projects.

                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                             August 15, 2014 Friday

Officials give thumbs up to 3,000 houses plan

BYLINE: David Mckay

SECTION: NEWS; OTHER; Others; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 679 words


A proposed housing development that would significantly expand the western
outskirts of Aberdeen has been recommended for approval by council officials.

The plans for 3,000 homes at Countesswells were tabled by a consortium headed by
north-east businessmen Stewart Milne and Ian Suttie.

The £700million project - including primary and secondary schools, shops,
leisure facilities and land for employment use - also has the backing of the UK
Government.

The Treasury yesterday said it has guaranteed an £80million loan to help finance
the development as part of nationwide scheme to boost private investment in
infrastructure.

The 410-acre farmland site lies between Bieldside to the south and Kingswells to
the north. It is bounded to the east by Hazlehead woods, park and golf courses,
and to the west by Foggieton and Countesswells Wood.

A report to be considered by the council's development management subcommittee
next Thursday has recommended the project for conditional approval.

The land is zoned for housing in the local development plan, but the scheme has
met with opposition from community councils serving Kingswells, Craigiebuckler
and Seafield, as well as Cults, Bieldside and Milltimber.

Chief among the concerns are the impact on traffic, public transport links, the
road layout and future management of green spaces.

A further 12 letters of representation were sent to the authority raising issues
including loss of green belt land, inadequate pre-application consultation and
fears that it could create "urban sprawl" rather than a "new community".

The council's head of planning, Margaret Bochel, says in a report to councillors
that "supporting infrastructure", including new roads, schools and healthcare
facilities, would have to be provided over the course of the development to meet
the needs of the community.

The report adds that Scottish Government agency Transport Scotland requested
that a condition should be attached restricting the first stage of the
development to 1,000 residential units and requisite retail and office space up
until the opening of the Aberdeen Western Peripheral Route (AWPR).

Further upgrades to access roads and junctions would also be required as the
scheme grows.

Ms Bochel adds: "In conclusion, the proposal complies with the land-release
policy as the particular circumstances, in terms of investment in
infrastructure, justify the granting of planning permission."

Ms Bochel recommends approval, subject to agreements on the provision of 25%
affordable housing and developer contributions towards improving the local road
network and building schools, community and healthcare facilities, a library and
sports fields.

The applicant would also be required to provide "detailed analysis" of the
impact on roads including Lang Stracht, Queens Road, King's Gate, Springfield
Road, Countesswells Road, Kirk Brae, Friarsfield Road and North Deeside Road.
Also, no more than 2,000 houses should be occupied until the Jessiefield
roundabout is upgraded - and a public-transport strategy and proposals on
"reducing dependency" on the car would also have to be developed.

Announcing the UK Treasury deal yesterday, Chief Secretary Danny Alexander said
the development would be "fantastic news" for north-east families and the
economy of Scotland generally.

He added: "This is an excellent example of using the strength of the UK's
balance sheet and hard-won credit rating to guarantee and support infrastructure
projects across the country."

Glenn Allison, chief executive officer of the Stewart Milne Group, said: "It is
a critical project for the city over the next 15 years, delivering much-needed
homes and community facilities that in turn will support Aberdeen's economic
growth."

Aberdeen City Council leader Jenny Laing said: "I warmly welcome this important
loan guarantee from the UK Treasury, which comes at a time when construction
companies are finding it challenging to secure sizeable loans from the banks.

"This will allow upfront investment in the vital infrastructure which will be
necessary for the development to go ahead."

                               February 26, 2015

Big Horn Basin chambers to host USDA/Rurai Development grant and lending
workshops

BYLINE: The Lovell Chronicle staff

LENGTH: 448  words


The three Big Horn County Chambers are hosting two workshops that will feature
grant and loan programs available through USDA/Rural Development. The workshops
will be in March or April.

The chambers are asking to hear from their members and the public as to which
programs the public would like to see. The choices are:

Business and Industry (B&I) Guaranteed Loan Program, target audience would be
lenders and businesses. The purpose of the B&I Guaranteed Loan Program is to
improve, develop or finance business, industry and employment and improve the
economic and environmental climate in rural communities. This purpose is
achieved by bolstering the existing private credit structure through the
guarantee of quality loans, which will provide lasting community benefits. It is
not intended that the guarantee authority will be used for marginal or
substandard loans or for relief of lenders having such loans.

Rural Energy For America Program (REAP), target audience would be ag producers
or small businesses. The Rural Energy for America Program (REAP) provides
financial assistance to agricultural producers and rural small businesses in
rural America to purchase, install and construct renewable energy systems; make
energy efficiency improvements to non-residential buildings and facilities; and
use renewable technologies that reduce energy consumption.

Energy Audit and Renewable Energy Development Assistance (EA/REDA) element to
the energy program, target audience would be units of state, tribal or local
government; instrumentalities of state, tribal or local government; university
or institution of higher education; rural electric cooperatives; public power
entities; and resource conservation and development councils. Funding is
provided to perform technical assistance in conducting and promoting energy
audits and renewable energy development assistance.

Rural Business Enterprise Grant (RBEG) Program, target audience would be private
non-profits, public bodies and tribal entities. The purpose of this program is
to assist small and emerging private business enterprises.

While the workshops will only focus on the two most requested programs there
will be information regarding these and other programs available through
USDA/Rural Development at the workshops.

The chambers need to hear from the public as soon as possible about which
programs and what days/times they would be able to attend. The workshops will
most likely be held Monday-Friday with one a morning class and the second an
evening class. The proposed location will be the Weed and Pest building at the
junction of U.S. Highways 310 and 14/16/20.

Call the Lovell, Greybull or Basin chamber as soon as possible.

                  Wisconsin State Journal (Madison, Wisconsin)

                           February 1, 2007 Thursday
                                  ALL EDITION

FCI HELPS NONPROFITS WITH LOW-INTEREST LOANS

BYLINE: By JAMES EDWARD MILLS

SECTION: CAPITAL REGION BUSINESS JOURNAL; GOOD WORKS; Pg. 36

LENGTH: 706 words


Nonprofit organizations regularly raise money to support their good works. But
every so often they may find the need instead to borrow it.

Forward Community Investments, formerly known as the Dane Fund, helps aid
organizations acquire low interest loans that bridge the gap between their
immediate need for capital and the cash flow of their fundraising initiatives.

"What we do is lend money at below-market rates to nonprofits," said Salli
Martyniak, president of FCI. "We started off just in Dane County and did that
for 11 years. But we realized that we needed to extend throughout the rest of
the state."

Hence the name change. Now FCI offers financial assistance to charities across
Wisconsin. Many of its clients are organizations and individuals that might have
difficulty or have trouble affording working with a bank on their own.

Bruce Moffat, executive director of the Wisconsin Community Fund, said FCI
provided the expertise his group needed to construct its Madison headquarters,
called the Social Justice Center, at 1202 Williamson St.

"We had really never done a real estate transaction before," Moffat said.

The WCF vests most of its resources in funding grassroots organizations who work
to solve problems in their communities and fight for the rights of
disenfranchised citizens. FCI loaned their expertise in navigating the loan
process.

"Over several months there was a lot of advice provided," Moffat said. "The
project was finally approved for a loan of $120,000. That enabled the project to
be viable to M&I Bank who was ultimately the lender of the mortgage."

Since the Dane Fund, now FCI, began in 1995, Martyniak said no nonprofit has
ever defaulted on a loan.

"And that's pretty remarkable," she said. "We do get a few delinquencies here
and there but no defaults."

Martyniak takes special care to assure the groups she works with have the
resources to raise the funds they'll need to meet their loan obligations.
Defaults are unlikely by design. When it comes to dollars and cents she said a
nonprofit is just like any organization that manages money.

"Really non-profits are no different than small businesses," she said. "They
have financing needs just like small businesses do but for different reasons."

A nonprofit might have plans to renovate or build an operations facility like
the Social Justice Center. A loan can cover expenses immediately while donors
continue their contributions over several months or even years.

"Contractors really want to have their money on time instead of waiting over a
five-year period," Martyniak said.

Many FCI loans go to support renovations and real estate transactions rather
than the day-to-day operations of nonprofits. Becky Steinhoff, executive
director of the Atwood Community Center, said FCI assistance was crucial in
securing the capital needed to refurbish the Theo Kupfer Foundry and Ironworks
building, 149 Waubesa St. The renovated structure is scheduled to open in 2008
and it will serve as her organization's new headquarters.

Steinhoff said FCI and Martyniak in particular helped Atwood prepare a very
attractive investment package that was tapped for funding by U.S. Bank in St.
Louis.

"We had great legal and accounting advice, but Salli was the one who really
brought the project to them and really nurtured that relationship so that they
made the investment," Steinhoff said. "U.S. Bank had $100 million to invest in
26 states. And every state wanted all the money so it was a big deal for a small
nonprofit in Wisconsin to get an allocation."

The federal Community Reinvestment Act, enacted by Congress in 1977, encourages
banks to help meet the credit needs of nonprofits in their communities. Lynn
Mayer, vice president and CRA officer at Guarantee Bank, based in Milwaukee,
said FCI helps her provide loans to qualified borrowers who are likely to do the
most good. Since 2001 Guarantee Bank has provided more than $1 million in
low-interest loans to non-profits.

"We can be assured that working with Salli and her group that the funds will be
used appropriately," Mayer said. "Our ongoing relationship working with them is
a true partnership. They provide a service that as a financial institution we
would not have the capacity to do. And that's a good match."

LOAD-DATE: February 2, 2007

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

NOTES:  James Edward Mills is a State journal reporter. He can be reached at
jmills@madison.com.

GRAPHIC: Joseph W. Jackson --State Journal Salli Martyniak leads Forward
Community Investments, a lending institution that provides loans to nonprofit
organizations.

Utah: USDA Community Facilities Loan and Grant Program

LENGTH: 359  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Office of Rural Assistance Center, The State of Utah has issued the following
news release:

Sponsor  USDA Rural Development
Deadlines  Applications accepted on an ongoing basis
Contact

For a list of USDA Rural Development State Offices, see
http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/recd_map.html
Purpose

Community Programs, a division of the Housing and Community Facilities Programs,
is part of the United States Department of Agriculture's Rural Development
mission area. Community Programs administers programs designed to develop
essential community facilities for public use in rural areas.

These facilities include schools, libraries, childcare, hospitals, medical
clinics, assisted living facilities, fire and rescue stations, police stations,
community centers, public buildings and transportation. Community Programs
utilizes three flexible financial tools to achieve this goal: the Community
Facilities Direct and Guaranteed Loan Program, the Community Facilities Grant
Program, and the Rural Community Development Initiative.
Eligibility

Community Programs provides grants to assist in the development of essential
community facilities in rural areas and towns of up to 20,000 in population.
Grants are available to public entities such as municipalities, counties, and
special-purpose districts, as well as non-profit corporations and tribal
governments.

Loans and guarantees are also available to public entities such as
municipalities, counties, and special-purpose districts, as well as to
non-profit corporations and tribal governments.
Geographic
coverage  Nationwide
Amount of
funding

Amount varies. Grants are authorized on a graduated scale. Applicants located in
small communities with low populations and low incomes will receive a higher
percentage of grants.
Application
process

Applications are handled by USDA Rural Development field offices. For a listing
of field offices, see http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/recd_map.html
Tagged as  Capital funding, Child care, Community development, Emergency
services, Health information technology, Hospitals and clinics, Long-term care,
Schools, Telehealth

For further information please visit: http://www.raconline.org/

Utah: USDA Community Facilities Loan and Grant Program

LENGTH: 356  words

DATELINE: Salt Lake City


Office of Rural Assistance Center, The State of Utah has issued the following
news release:

Sponsor  USDA Rural Development
Deadlines  Applications accepted on an ongoing basis
Contact  For a list of USDA Rural Development State Offices, see
http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/recd_map.html
Purpose

Community Programs, a division of the Housing and Community Facilities Programs,
is part of the United States Department of Agriculture's Rural Development

essential community facilities for public use in rural areas.

These facilities include schools, libraries, childcare, hospitals, medical
clinics, assisted living facilities, fire and rescue stations, police stations,
community centers, public buildings and transportation. Community Programs
utilizes three flexible financial tools to achieve this goal: the Community
Facilities Direct and Guaranteed Loan Program, the Community Facilities Grant
Program, and the Rural Community Development Initiative.
Eligibility

Community Programs provides grants to assist in the development of essential
community facilities in rural areas and towns of up to 20,000 in population.
Grants are available to public entities such as municipalities, counties, and
special-purpose districts, as well as non-profit corporations and tribal
governments.

Loans and guarantees are available to public entities such as municipalities,
counties, and special-purpose districts, as well as to non-profit corporations
and tribal governments.
Geographic
coverage  Nationwide
Amount of
funding  Amount varies. Grants are authorized on a graduated scale. Applicants
located in small communities with low populations and low incomes will receive a
higher percentage of grants.
Application
process  Applications are handled by USDA Rural Development field offices. For a
listing of field offices, see http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/recd_map.html

                               Right Vision News

                           December 6, 2012 Thursday

Pakistan: SBP extends scope of guarantee scheme

LENGTH: 519 words

DATELINE: KARACHI


KARACHI, Dec. 6 -- The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) has allowed the microfinance
banks to extend loans to microenterprises from above Rs150,000 up to Rs500,000
for a tenor not exceeding five years under the credit guarantee scheme,
according to a circular issued on Tuesday.

The SBP has also extended the scope of the credit guarantee scheme by including
the microfinance banks as eligible participating financial institutions in order
to enable microenterprises benefit from this scheme, it said.

The microfinance banks, which have already obtained prior approval of the
central bank to undertake microenterprise lending as per the circular dated
March 16, can apply for the allocation of credit exposure limits under the
scheme, it said.

Earlier the credit guarantee scheme was open to commercial banks only. The
microfinance banks would find great comfort in taking credit risks as they now
enjoy the risk coverage of 40 percent on their loans to microenterprises.

According to the scheme, it is designed to ensure partial repayment of a loan to
motivate lenders to lend to borrowers, which would not have access to credit
under normal circumstances. The growth of small and rural businesses is
imperative for any developing economy. Access to formal finance for this sector
is a major problem, hindering the growth of small and microenterprises,
particularly in the rural areas, according to the circular.

Given the impediments in the way of small and rural enterprises in Pakistan to
raise capital from the capital markets or financing from the financial
institutions, the scheme is supposed to provide help resolve severe credit
rationing.

The scheme is to be used for targeting small enterprises and farmers with
economic landholding, without any specific regional or cluster restrictions,
across the country, it said.

Preference for the use of the guarantee fund would be given to fresh and
collateral-deficient borrowers.

Participating financial institutions will ensure that the guaranteed loans are
not used for the purposes contradicting the objective of the scheme, ie, the
facility will not be used for debt swaps / adjusting an existing loan, buying
company shares or member of a partnership, or financing interest payments, etc.

Instead of evaluation of each and every loan, portfolio (principal amount only)
of loans (extended after allocation of credit guarantee limit) of a
participating financial institution, which meet the given criteria is to be
guaranteed under the scheme to the extent of its allocated credit guarantee
limit, it said.

The SBP/SBP BSC (Bank) will have the right to withdraw its approval of guarantee
if it is discovered at any stage that the borrower was not eligible for
financing under the scheme at the time of the extension of the loan facility, it
said.

In such an event, the participating financial institution will bear 100 percent
of the credit risk of such borrower, it added Published by HT Syndication with
permission from Right Vision News. For any query with respect to this article or
any other content requirement, please contact Editor at
htsyndication@hindustantimes.com

                       St. Louis Post-Dispatch (Missouri)

                            December 10, 2004 Friday
                          FIVE STAR LATE LIFT EDITION

SBA raises small-business loan guarantees -- and fees warns

BYLINE: By SHERA DALIN Of the Post-Dispatch

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C01

LENGTH: 434 words


The newly authorized budget for the U.S. Small Business Administration increases
the amount the government will guarantee on its most popular loan programs but
raises fees for some of those loans.

President George W. Bush signed the federal budget bill Wednesday that contains
$21 billion for SBA loan guarantees. Several changes were made in the SBA's most
popular 7(a) loan program, as well as the 504 loan program. "We are really
well-positioned to put the money out there and help the small-business
community," said Maurice "Moe" Dube, director of the SBA's St. Louis district.
"They have given us a bunch of new arrows in our quiver."

The amount the SBA will guarantee on 7(a) loans is rising to $1.5 million from
$1 million last year. The budget increased the 7(a) program by $3.5 billion over
last year to $16 billion.

To make the loan program self-supporting, the government will raise fees for
each loan it guarantees. The fee on 7(a) loans is estimated to increase to 3.5
percent from 3 percent on the additional $500,000 in guarantees, Dube said
Thursday.

"In signing this bill, President Bush imposed a new tax on our nation's 23
million small businesses," said Rep. Nydia M. Velazquez, D-N.Y., ranking
Democrat on the House Small Business Committee.

"These fee increases are far from modest," she said. "With the recent doubling
of upfront fees anywhere from $1,500 to $3,000, and the restrictions placed on
the program, it is most likely that this program will be less affordable for
entrepreneurs."

Dubé said the increases aren't expected to dissuade entrepreneurs from seeking
loans. Because of a temporary change in federal law, the fees were higher in
October and November, but the number of loans increased 30 percent and the
dollar value grew by 27 percent nationally for those two months, Dubé said.

He noted that the new fees would be a return to those seen in the last fiscal
year, ended Sept. 30.

Another change to the 7(a) program is an increase in the lending limit for the
agency's SBAExpress loans to $350,000 this year from $250,000. SBAExpress, which
was a pilot program last year, now becomes permanent.

The loan limit on SBA's 504 loan will jump to $1.5 million from $1 million. In
special cases, such as loans to rural borrowers, the limit will increase to $2
million from $1.3 million.

For the first time, the SBA will be allowed to guarantee up to $4 million in
loans for manufacturing plants. The change is an attempt by the administration
to spark manufacturing.

"There was no exception for manufacturing facilities previously," Dubé said.
"There was definitely a need out there."

                          The Huntsville Item (Texas)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             July 15, 2010 Thursday

USDA Rural Development to host housing fair

BYLINE: Mary Rainwater, The Huntsville Item, Texas

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 526 words


July 15--RIVERSIDE -- Those who thought they might never fulfill the dream of
owning their own home may still have that opportunity thanks to American
Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA) and a housing program offered through the
USDA Rural Development office.

The USDA Rural Development Sub-Area Office in Huntsville, which provides
services to Walker County, will be hosting a Housing Fair from 10 a.m. to 1 p.m.
Saturday, July 17, at the Riverside City Hall, located at 2352 FM 980 in
Riverside.

During the event, representatives from USDA Rural Development will be available
to provide information on how to obtain 100 percent financing with no down
payment to purchase an existing home or newly constructed home in eligible rural
areas.

Information will also be available on loans and grants for eligible very
low-income individuals and families for home repair projects

The office announced their allocation for direct single family loans and due to
an increased level of funding as a result of the ARRA, the allocation has more
than $63 million available for direct single family loans.

"USDA Rural Development is proud to assist rural Texans in meeting their housing
needs, which is critical to the long term sustainability of our communities,"
State Director Paco Valentin said in a recent statement. "We urge Texans to seek
information about our housing programs and submit applications while this
funding is still available."

In 2009, USDA Rural Development financed more than $63.4 million in repairs for
more than 5,000 rural homeowners, and provided homeownership loans to more than
140,000 rural Americans.

Under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (ARRA), which President Obama
signed into law in February of 2009, USDA provided $10.8 billion in loans and
loan guarantees to more than 87,000 home buyers.

Although all available guarantee funds have been committed to loans this fiscal
year, USDA continues to provide home loan funds through its direct home loan
program.

USDA, through its Rural Development mission area, administers and manages more
than 40 housing, business and community infrastructure, and facility programs
through a network of 6,100 employees located in the nation's capital and 500
state and local offices.

These programs are designed to improve the economic stability of rural
communities, businesses, residents, farmers and ranchers and improve the quality
of life in rural America. Rural Development has an existing portfolio of more
than $134 billion in loans and loan guarantees.

For further information about USDA Rural Development's housing programs in
Texas, visit http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/tx/ or contact the Huntsville Sub-Area
Office at (936) 291-1901, extension 4.

To see more of The Huntsville Item or to subscribe to the newspaper, go to
http://www.itemonline.com. Copyright (c) 2010, The Huntsville Item, Texas
Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services. For more information
about the content services offered by McClatchy-Tribune Information Services
(MCT), visit www.mctinfoservices.com, e-mail services@mctinfoservices.com, or
call 866-280-5210 (outside the United States, call +1 312-222-4544).

Purpose

The Rural Broadband Access Loan and Loan Guarantee Program (Broadband Program)
furnishes loans and loan guarantees to provide funds for the costs of
construction, improvement, or acquisition of facilities and equipment needed to
provide service at the broadband lending speed in eligible rural areas.

The goal of the Broadband Program is to ensure that rural consumers enjoy the
same quality and range of services that are available in urban and suburban
communities. This program aims to lend to entities capable of repaying its loans
and that plan to offer service at a level that keeps pace with technology
upgrades while meeting the demands of customers in rural America.
Eligibility

Eligible entities may be either a nonprofit or for-profit organization, and must
take one of the following forms:

Corporation
    Limited liability company (LLC)
    Cooperative or mutual organization
    Indian tribe or tribal organization
    State or local government, including any agency, subdivision or
instrumentality thereof

coverage  Nationwide

process

                              219 of 998 DOCUMENTS


                           Aberdeen Press and Journal

                             August 15, 2014 Friday

Housing plan gets backing

BYLINE: David Mckay

SECTION: NEWS; OTHER; Others; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 563 words


A proposed housing development that would significantly expand the western
outskirts of Aberdeen has been recommended for approval by council officials.

The plans for 3,000 homes at Countesswells were tabled by a consortium headed by
north-east businessmen Stewart Milne and Ian Suttie.

The £700million project, including primary and secondary schools, shops, leisure
facilities and land for employment use, also has the backing of the UK
Government.

The Treasury yesterday said it has guaranteed an £80million loan to help finance
the development as part of nationwide scheme to boost private investment in
infrastructure.

The 410-acre farmland site lies between Bieldside to the south and Kingswells to
the north.

It is bounded to the east by Hazlehead woods, park and golf courses, and to the
west by Foggieton and Countesswells Wood.

A report to be considered by the council's development management subcommittee
next Thursday recommends the project for conditional approval.

The land is zoned for housing in the local development plan, but the scheme has
met with opposition from community councils in Kingswells, Craigiebuckler and
Seafield, as well as Cults, Bieldside and Milltimber.

Chief among the concerns are the impact on traffic, public transport links, road
layout and management of green spaces.

The council's head of planning, Margaret Bochel, says in a report to councillors
that "supporting infrastructure", including new roads, schools and healthcare
facilities, would have to be provided over the course of the development to meet
the needs of the community.

The report adds that Scottish Government agency Transport Scotland requested
that a condition should be attached restricting the first stage of the
development to 1,000 residential units and requisite retail and office space up
until the opening of the Aberdeen Western Peripheral Route (AWPR).

Ms Bochel adds: "In conclusion, the proposal complies with the land-release
policy as the particular circumstances, in terms of investment in
infrastructure, justify the granting of planning permission."

Ms Bochel recommends approval, subject to agreements on the provision of 25%
affordable housing and developer contributions towards improving the local road
network and building schools, community and healthcare facilities, a library and
sports fields.

Also, no more than 2,000 houses should be occupied until the Jessiefield
roundabout is upgraded - and a public-transport strategy and proposals on
"reducing dependency" on the car would also have to be developed.

Announcing the UK Treasury deal yesterday, Chief Secretary Danny Alexander said
the development would be "fantastic news" for north-east families and the
economy of Scotland generally.

He added: "This is an excellent example of using the strength of the UK's
balance sheet and hard-won credit rating to guarantee and support infrastructure
projects across the country."

Glenn Allison, chief executive officer of the Stewart Milne Group, said: "It is
a critical project for the city over the next 15 years, delivering much-needed
homes and community facilities that in turn will support Aberdeen's economic
growth."

Aberdeen City Council leader Jenny Laing said: "I warmly welcome this important
loan guarantee from the UK Treasury.

This will allow upfront investment in the vital infrastructure which will be
necessary for the development to go ahead."

Agriculture Secretary Announces Electric System Improvements in Eight States

   Sep 05, 2013

   Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced funding for projects in
eight states, including Virginia, to improve electric service for about 10,000
rural residents. Rural Utilities Service Administrator John Padalino made the
announcement on the Secretary's behalf in Norfolk, Va., during the 2013 regional
meeting of the National Rural Electric Cooperative Association.The loan
guarantees are made available through the U.S. Department of Agriculture's
(USDA) rural utilities program and include more than $11 million in smart grid
project funding."These investments will continue to ensure safe, reliable and
affordable service for rural residents, farmers, and commercial and industrial
consumers," Padalino said. "This funding, which is part of the Obama
Administration's vision for a new rural energy economy, includes investments in
smart grid technologies that modernize our nation's electric system and improve
its operation." For example, the Central Virginia Electric Cooperative will use
USDA funding to build 327 miles of line and invest more than $1.1 million in
smart grid technologies across 14 counties. The following is a list of rural
electric utilities that will receive USDA funding, contingent upon the recipient
meeting the terms of the loan agreement. Iowa Midland Power Cooperative

USDA loan guarantees announced today will be used to build nearly 2,000 miles of

technologies nationwide. President Obama's plan for rural America has brought

Agriculture Secretary Vilsack are committed to a smarter use of Federal
resources to foster sustainable economic prosperity and ensure the government is

of programs designed to improve the economic stability of rural communities,
businesses, residents, farmers and ranchers and improve the quality of life in

across-the-board budget reductions mandated under terms of the Budget Control
Act. USDA has already undertaken historic efforts since 2009 to save more than

These reductions have put USDA in a better position to carry out its mission,
while implementing sequester budget reductions in a fair manner that causes as

                            Dayton Daily News (Ohio)

                            July 30, 2008 Wednesday

Piketon plant seeks loan guarantees;
Officials say they are running out of money to build world's most efficient
centrifuges at a cost of $3.5 billion.

BYLINE: By Tom Beyerlein Staff Writer

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. A4

LENGTH: 371 words


The company building the multi-billion-dollar American Centrifuge uranium
enrichment plant in the south central Ohio community of Piketon has applied to
the Energy Department for federal loan guarantees amidst spiraling costs.

A spokeswoman for USEC Inc. declined to specify the size of the loan guarantee
the Bethesda, Md., company is seeking, but the department has been authorized by
Congress to issue up to $2 billion in loan guarantees for advanced facilities on
the "front end" of the nuclear fuel cycle, including uranium enrichment plants.

The guarantees are included in a program designed to help to finance "green"
demonstration projects using new technology until they can be commercialized.
It's uncertain when a screening committee will make recommendations for loan
guarantees for approval by Energy Secretary Samuel W. Bodman.

"Our project is qualified," USEC spokeswoman Elizabeth Stuckle said on Tuesday,
July 29. "I'm confident we'll get one. Our biggest concern is timeliness."

The loan guarantees would provide federal backing for investors should the
project go into default.

USEC officials have said they're running out of money for the centrifuge
project, an update of U.S. government technology developed from the 1960s
through the 1980s. They have been estimating the project will be complete by
2012 at a cost of $3.5 billion - more than double the cost projection of a few
years ago. But Stuckle said the company will disclose Aug. 5 whether the
timetable and estimated costs will change yet again.

The American Centrifuge would satisfy a third of U.S. demand for enriched
uranium for fuel rods and replace USEC's antiquated Paducah (Ky.) Gaseous
Diffusion Plant. USEC says the centrifuges, now being tested in Piketon, would
be the world's most efficient, and are necessary for America's energy security.
Critics have raised questions about the enormous costs for what they say is
unproven technology.

USEC, the privatized spinoff of a former government company, is the only
American-owned uranium enrichment company.

The company has said the centrifuge plant will provide about 400 permanent jobs
in the impoverished Piketon area.

                               The Jerusalem Post

                           January 16, 2008 Wednesday

European Investment Bank launches new instrument to finance transport network

BYLINE: ARI SYRQUIN

SECTION: ECONOMICS; Pg. 18

LENGTH: 1008 words



HIGHLIGHT: WHAT'S NEW IN THE EU. The author is the head of the International
Department at Joseph Shem-Tov Law Firm


Last week the European Commission and the European Investment Bank (EIB) signed
a Cooperation Agreement establishing the Loan Guarantee Instrument for trans-
European transport network projects (LGTT). This new instrument is expected to
facilitate greater participation of the private sector in the financing of
transport infrastructure of European significance, especially for investments in
projects where there is a high level of revenue risk in the early operational
period of a project.

The LGTT, which forms part of the Trans-European Transport Network (TEN) program
and the EIB's Action for Growth initiative, will partially cover this risk and
thereby significantly improve the financial viability of investments. The
capital contribution of Û1 billion (Û500 million each from the Commission and
the EIB) is intended to support up to Û20b. of total capital investment.

How does the LGTT work? The LGTT is an EIB guarantee, the risk capital for which
is jointly provided by EIB and the European Commission, in favor of commercial
banks which will provide stand-by liquidity facility ("SBF") in addition to the
usual project finance funding instruments. In accordance with the European
Commission's report, the SBF can be drawn by the project company in case of
unexpected reduction of traffic income of the project during the initial ramp-up
period of operation in order to assure service of its senior credit facilities.

It is hoped that the SBF, funded by commercial banks, will benefit from a
guarantee from the EIB and could be available for draw down in the initial
ramp-up period only after construction of the project is completed. All
repayments to be made on the outstanding amounts of the SBF (on a cash sweep
basis) are in principle subordinated to the senior loans underpinned by it,
subject to specific needs of a given financial structure.

In accordance with the EC's publication, if at the end of the availability
period there are still amounts outstanding under the SBF (interest, interest
accrued and principal), the LGTT guarantee can be called upon by the SBF
providers. The EIB would pay out the SBF providers and then become subordinated
creditor to the project. Once EIB is creditor to the project, amounts due under
the LGTT will still rank junior to the debt service of the senior credit
facility and would be repaid either on a cash sweep basis based on the post
senior debt service available cash (default solution) or on a fixed
reimbursement profile of the LGTT debt.

The Loan Guarantee Instrument

The investment required to complete and modernize the Trans-European Network is
reported to exceed the capabilities of public funding. For the period 2007-2013
alone, the investment needs for TEN projects is expected to come to some Û300
billion. A significant financial gap in public sector resources is anticipated
and it will only be overcome by mobilizing private investment in large
infrastructure projects. The LGTT - an EIB guarantee for subordinated debt in
the form of a stand-by liquidity facility to be provided by commercial banks -
counters this problem by providing security for the initial traffic revenue risk
over the first 5-7 years of a project's operation. The LGTT assists the projects
in coping with the initial risk while relying on the long-term perspective of
the project being financially viable.

The design of LGTT, by improving the ability of borrower to service senior debt,
is intended to enhance the overall credit quality and thereby encourages a
reduction of risk margins applied to senior loans to the project. These savings
are supposed to surpass the cost to the borrower of the guarantee, resulting in
added financial value for the project. The incorporation of LGTT, by rendering
private sector investment into a project more attractive and therefore less
costly, will thus provide benefits to the society as a whole.

The European Commission reported that the LGTT will complement two other
financial instruments of the European Commission tailored for TEN projects and
aimed at increasing the participation of private capital. The Risk Capital
Facility offers risk capital to investment funds focused on providing equity for
TEN projects, whereas availability payment schemes can benefit from a
construction cost based grant during the operational, post- construction phase
of the project.

Which transportation projects can benefit from the LGTT? Projects, or part of a
project, of common interest in the field of transport in the framework of
decision number 1692/96/EC compliant with Community laws and for which financial
viability is based in whole or in part, on revenues, tolls or other user-charges
based income. The stand-by liquidity facility guaranteed by the LGTT should not
exceed 10 percent of the total amount of the senior debt. The amount of the
guarantee is subject to a maximum ceiling of Û200m. per project pursuant to the
EIB Structured Finance Facility rules ("SFF"). The SFF is said to be the EIB's
main facility for increased risk taking, established in order to support
projects of European importance including large-scale infrastructure schemes.

What risks does the EIB take under the LGTT scheme? Under the LGTT, the EIB has
proclaimed it will accept exposure to higher financial risks than under its
normal lending activities. Effectively, if the EIB guarantee is called upon by
the stand-by liquidity facility providers at the end of the availability period,
the EIB would reimburse the SBF providers and become a subordinated lender to
the project, however it would come ahead of any payment to the equity providers
and related financings. Once the EIB has become a creditor to the project,
amounts due under the LGTT will also rank junior to the debt service of the
senior credit facility. The EIB, by taking such subordinated risk through the
LGTT guarantee, hopes to help the project to handle the revenue risk of the
early years of operation while maintaining the long-term perspective needed to
ensure the project's financially stability.

                             National Mortgage News

                                  July 5, 2010

HUD Key to Construction Deal

BYLINE: Shelly Sigo

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 23 Vol. 34 No. 39

LENGTH: 598  words


Kentucky officials hope a popular federal loan guarantee program will be the
catalyst to resume construction of a $465 million, 62-story skyscraper on the
banks of the Ohio River in downtown Louisville that has been stalled by the
credit crisis.

The Museum Plaza project also would be funded with private equity and public
financing. It is expected to create thousands of badly needed jobs for the
region.

Hoping to kick-start the project, state officials announced last week that they
would apply for a $100 million loan guarantee from the Department of Housing and
Urban Development's Section 108 provision of the community development block
grant program. The CDBG program provides communities with a source of financing
for economic development, housing rehabilitation, public facilities and
large-scale development projects.

Since it was implemented in 1978, the Section 108 program has issued $7 billion
in commitments for projects around the country, many of which used a combination
of public and private financing, federal officials said.

If Kentucky's application is approved it will be the third-largest federal loan
guarantee ever granted. It also will be the first time the state has used
Section 108.

"Tough economic times mean we must be more creative to find funding for
important projects," Gov. Steve Beshear said when he announced the new strategy
to build Museum Plaza. "Applying for this federal loan [guarantee] is a first
step, and while we cannot predict whether it will be approved, my administration
is excited about the potential opportunity to create thousands of jobs and get
Kentucky's economic engines moving again."

Site work began in late 2007 on the 703-foot-tall multi-tower project designed
by Joshua Prince-Ramus, an architect at New York-based REX. It includes office
and residential space, hotels, the University of Louisville's Master of Fine
Arts program, a nonprofit contemporary art museum and a public park.

However, actual building construction never got under way largely because of the
credit crisis, according to Craig Greenberg, an attorney with Frost Brown Todd
LLC and one of the project's four development partners.

"From the beginning this has been a public-private partnership to make this
project a reality," he said. "It has strong support from state, local, and
federal officials as well as the business and labor community. It has enjoyed
that support for years and I think everyone is excited about getting this
project under construction and it becoming a reality."

Developers have already invested $48 million. They expect to obtain a $140.5
million traditional construction loan and to repay the $100 million obtained
under the HUD loan guarantee program, which will be backstopped against default
by state CDBG funds.

Project financing also includes $90 million of tax increment financing bonds,
$45 million of general obligation bonds to be sold by Louisville, $15 million of
revenue bonds secured by pledges of art museum supporters, and $26.5 million
from the university. Discussions about how the university will fund its portion
are still under way, Greenberg said.

Although the financing plan has not been finalized and members of the finance
team are still being selected, he said the goal is to issue debt before the end
of the year and to take advantage of the taxable Build America Bond program.

HUD's Section 108 program will be critical to the financing package. The
Kentucky Department for Local Government plans to submit the application after
holding a public hearing on July 7.

Shelly Sigo is a reporter for The Bond Buyer.
