                          Ocala Star-Banner (Florida)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           November 15, 2011 Tuesday

County considers facility's request

BYLINE: Bill Thompson, Ocala Star-Banner, Fla.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 1042 words


Nov. 15--County commissioners on Tuesday got their first opportunity to vet a
proposed $20 million assisted-living facility slated for the west side of Ocala,
and signaled that county help for the developer in securing funding hinged on
demonstrating whether the project was necessary.

White Coral LLC has proposed a five-story, 120-bed facility with 60 spots for
assisted living patients, 40 units for independent living clients and 20 beds
for Alzheimer's sufferers.

White Coral's project is expected to generate at least 80 jobs. The company
wants to build along Southwest 44th Avenue between State Road 200 and Southwest
20th Street.

Ocala lawyer Steve Gray, who represents White Coral, said the company was lining
up a loan guarantee from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development to
cover $14.8 million it intended to borrow from private lenders.

The company also was putting up $5.7 million of its own.

The company's request to the commission, Gray said, was to guarantee $1 million
of the HUD-backed portion. The Ocala City Council recently did likewise with a
4-1 vote.

Levy County, through an application submitted to Washington through the state,
is preparing to support the bulk of the financing load, Gray added.

Levy would pledge to back the other $12.8 million White Coral plans to borrow.

Gray said Levy County was involved because it does not receive HUD funding and
because its residents would be allocated a certain number of beds within the
facility, if needed. If there was a waiting list, Gray added, Levy residents
would receive first priority because of their community's participation.

White Coral anticipates that the project will take off, Gray noted. Yet if the
firm defaulted on the loan, HUD would cover that and then recoup its money from
the state and the local governments by taking back funding for Community
Development Block Grants, Gray said. That would be repaid over several years.

Commissioners questioned some aspects of the county's commitment, but seemed to
focus most on the occupancy rates at a handful of existing facilities located
around Ocala and The Villages, and how those would be affected by this project.

A handful of residents spoke about White Coral's project. Patricia Reed of
Summerfield said she supported it because the facility would provide care to
low- and moderate-income residents and would enable some county residents to
remain in the area instead of being sent to another county to receive care.

On the other hand, Roger Knechtel of Dunnellon said necessity was the critical
factor in going forward.

"Do we really need this? I smell ... Agenda 21 here," he said. "The state is
going to be getting money from HUD and has to pay it back, and I don't know how
many of these facilities (are) in this state versus all the states in the United
States. This is not the time to do anything like this. ... I think the federal
government is just trying to destroy and bankrupt us."

Commissioners will vote on whether to back the deal at a second public hearing
on Dec. 6.

In other matters Tuesday, the commission:

--Voted 4-1 against the installation of traffic lights and turn lanes at two
intersections along County Road 475.

The county Transportation Department proposed making the CR 475 improvements at
Southeast/Southwest 52nd Street and at Southeast 145th Street. Combined, the
projects would have cost roughly $750,000.

Assistant County Administrator Mounir Bouyounes said that while the volume of
traffic had been dropping along the route, lingering safety concerns had
prompted the request.

McClain, however, argued that the improvements were unwarranted. He noted that
the commission last year rejected a similar plan for Southeast 80th Street and
CR 475, an intersection that was more deserving of improvements than the two
discussed Tuesday. Only Commissioner Kathy Bryant supported the proposal, saying
a fix was needed, particularly at 52nd Street.

--Approved spending $150,000 to pave the main access road for The Refuge, a
long-term residential rehabilitation center located in the Ocala National
Forest.

The center, according to a letter from its founder and CEO, Judy Crane, has
state approval to expand from 60 beds to 75 and to build a 14,400-square-foot
addition.

The Refuge primarily treats drug, alcohol and sex addiction as well as mental
health issues, such as post-traumatic stress disorder.

The group now employs 109 people, Crane wrote, but hopes to hire another 75
workers over the next three years to accommodate the new growth.

The Refuge has operated in Ocklawaha since 2003, leasing 52 acres from the St.
Johns Water Management District. In fiscal year 2010, the Refuge paid the
district $180,000 in rent. Calling the nonprofit group "a reliable tenant and
good steward of the premises," water managers in March extended the group's
lease to 2031.

Crane's organization generates more than $6 million a year serving clients from
around the globe.

According to a report by Rick Michael, the county's economic development
director, the additional jobs -- paying an average of $39,000 a year -- could
create a communitywide economic-impact ripple of more than $40 million over the
next seven years.

"That's a great way for us to be able to use that money that we set aside for
our infrastructure stuff," said McClain, referring to a special economic
development fund the board created for this budget year.

--Backed Sheriff Ed Dean's request to spend savings from last fiscal year on new
patrol cars.

The Sheriff's Office had halted its practice of buying 60 new vehicles a year in
2007 in order to save money as the economy soured.

But with 71 percent of the sheriff's fleet expected to exceed 150,000 miles in
2012, Dean and the board arranged to spend $2 million on new cars.

Dean's agency was able to return almost $2.9 million to the county in funding
that was not spent in fiscal year 2011, which ended Oct. 1. Dean asked that
additional savings also be applied toward the purchase of patrol vehicles.

The Sheriff's Office has already ordered 14 new patrol cars with some of the
funding the County Commission had agreed earlier to spend.

                        The Hawk Eye (Burlington, Iowa)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 20, 2013 Thursday

Keokuk forum tackles rural housing needs

BYLINE: Christinia Crippes, The Hawk Eye, Burlington, Iowa

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 856 words


June 20--KEOKUK -- Iowans can easily define the word "rural," as most of them
live it and see it everyday.

The same is not necessarily true of the United States Department of Agriculture
Rural Development staff.

Though they also tend to live and breathe issues related to the more rustic
areas of the country, defining "rural" is not so easy for the department with
more than a dozen interpretations of the word.

Even if a there isn't a specific number, USDA Rural Development staff has no
doubt the people living outside cities or in small towns have particular needs
that must be addressed differently than their metropolitan neighbors.

The Tri-State Housing Task Force brought together USDA Rural Development and
other officials for a mini-summit on housing needs in southeast Iowa. The summit
was Wednesday afternoon at Keokuk City Hall.

Keynote speaker Tammye Trevino, administrator for the USDA Rural Development
housing and community facilities programs, said one of the biggest housing
challenges for rural America is providing affordable places to live when a
community has a growth spurt.

Whether it's from an in-flux of oil and gas workers or building a new fertilizer
plant, Trevino said it's difficult to provide affordable housing and get it
built quickly.

"That is a challenge, because quick enough is relative," Trevino said after her
speech Wednesday afternoon. "Anytime that you're going to grow that fast, with
that many more homes, you're putting a lot of stress on the counties' and
communities' infrastructure, so that's where the community needs to start."

Among its many housing programs -- the department has about 16 -- Rural
Development also can help rural communities with their infrastructure needs. But
before the communities can address infrastructure, they need a plan for the
future.

"Bottom line, it takes really good strategic planning," Trevino said. "You've
got to know what you want to be when you grow up, and if you can figure that
out, and you can plan toward that, then, you'll be in good shape."

Creative investments

Trevino outlined during her speech several of the 16 housing programs that Rural
Development oversees, including various home loan guarantee programs. She said
popular programs like Self-Help Housing may be phased out, but she said tax
credits are likely here to stay for affordable housing.

She said the Iowa office has been particularly successful, and with less staff.

She said in 2008, the office did $105 million in mortgage financing. In 2012, it
more than doubled to $240 million.

"That's how much more they're doing with 30 percent less staff than they had in
2008," Trevino said. "If it wasn't for this (program), you may not have the
communities you have right now."

She said the loan guarantee program, known as 502 guarantee program, also has
been successful nationally, as it is self-funded. It is authorized for $24
billion and Trevino said the department is set to reach the cap this year.

She said another program that deal with community facilities has also under her
watch become budget negative, meaning that it earns the money it needs to keep
operating without a congressional appropriation.

Trevino said the programs could even become bigger but budget cuts dating back
to 2009 have prevented staff from processing applications any faster. The 30
percent cut in Iowa was done through a voluntary retirement program.

Pat Poepping, a Tri-State Development Summit Steering Committee member, asked if
the programs have a higher or lower success rate, and the impact of the housing
bubble. Without laying out numbers, Trevino said the programs have been
successful and most loans go into default only when a person loses his or her
job.

"Not because they walked away from the home. Not because of strategic default,"
Trevino said, adding that there's not a program Rural Development has to keep
people employed or find new employment.

Defining rural

Elaine Davis, a member of the Quincy, Ill., Housing Authority, asked whether her
community of 40,000 would someday qualify as rural to better serve the region
and its tinier towns.

"I am appealing, because it is very important to the communities that we serve,"
Davis said.

Davis' question led Trevino to explain the numerous definitions of rural and
what members of Congress would consider rural.

Her answer summed up was, "Who knows? Anything is possible."

Trevino said since the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development deals
with communities larger than 50,000, she said it's possible cities under that
amount could one day be rural.

She said, on the other hand, some members of Congress like smaller numbers. Bill
Menner, USDA Rural Development state director for Iowa, added some out east
think that a town of 40,000 would have a single stoplight.

But she said Congress has been asked to consider the question.

"It's really out of our hands at this point, but Congress is going to do
something; I know they are, because everyone has decided they've kind of had
enough," Trevino said.

Gloves are off in bid to help boxing club

LENGTH: 260 words


THE gloves are off for Cheshunt Boxing Club after they vowed this week to fight
on in their desperate quest to improve their cramped facilities.

The club need at least 40,000 to re-develop their overcrowded gymnasium at
Albury Ride, particularly as more and more youngsters are now using the
facility.

So far they have been unable to secure help from bodies like Sport England or
the Lottery board, and last month their application for a loan of 60,000, which
would have been paid back over 20 years, was turned down by Broxbourne Council
because the club could not provide a guarantee on the money.

The Council's grants panel, along with its policy and resources committee, took
into consideration costs of building work, the club's finances and the
possibility of guarantees when making its decision.

Cheshunt ABC, who believe they should be given the necessary money by the
council because of their role in the community, confirmed that they could not
provide a guarantee for the loan.

As a result, the policy and resources committee rejected their application.

Four months ago, the club had their request for a 128,000 cash grant rejected,
as Broxbourne Council felt that other applications better fitted its grants
panel's criteria.

Although they have decided to begin work on their facilities, spending in the
region of 15,000 in the process, Cheshunt ABC know they will need to splash out
a good deal more if they are to achieve their objectives.

But the impassioned plea of one councillor has provided them with a fresh source
of hope.

                                 BusinessWorld

                              May 22, 2009 Friday

SPECIAL FEATURE: SME Financing;
Fishing for funds

BYLINE: Michelle S. Caligan

SECTION: Pg. S2/10

LENGTH: 414 words


The increase in the number of small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in the country
has paved the way for financial institutions to start coming up with their own
crop of loan packages tailored to the specific needs of start-up firms.

Aside from banks who regularly sponsor SME development programs, the Philippine
government has in recent years taken a more active role in ensuring that the
sector gets proper financial aid.

In 2001, it put up the Small Business Corporation (SBC) - merging the
government-managed Small Business Guarantee and Finance Corp. (SBGFC) and the
Guarantee Fund for Small and Medium Enterprises (GFSME) - with an authorized
capital stock of P5 billion and an initial capitalization of P1 billion in the
form of equity investments.

A year later, it helped draft the country's SME Development Plan, which has been
approved for implementation by the Arroyo administration.

Currently, the Wholesale Lending Program for SMEs offered by the state-owned
firm acts as a funding crutch for financial institutions lending to micro,
small, and medium enterprises (mSMEs) - a particularly relevant aid tactic for
small SME conduits operating in the countryside. Participating financial firms
are provided with an Omnibus Credit Line, which allows them to avail of several
credit lines offered by the SBC.

Under the Wholesale Lending Program are the SME FAST (Funding Access for
Short-term Loans) Facility, which, through banks, provides P100,000 to P20
million loans to individual borrowers; and the SME FIRM (Funding Investments in
Regional Markets) Facility, which handles low-interest, medium-term SME loans
for asset acquisition and working capital.

To make SME lending more appealing to banks, SBC's Credit Guarantee Program
offers credit sharing to financial firms, thus lessening the credit risks
inherent in funding start-up businesses. Meanwhile, should SMEs want direct
funding from the SBC, they can apply for a loan through the Retail Lending
Program, which has short-term, medium, term and fixed asset financing packages.

SBC's most transformative scheme, however, is its Micro Financing Program, a
funding relief for micro entrepreneurs who are usually unregistered, have no
tangible business assets, and have limited credit track record, making it harder
for them to file for a business loan should they decide to register and expand
their venture. The program allows micro businesses to apply for loans through
commercial and rural banks and community cooperatives.

                              Daily Deal/The Deal

                          December 14, 2011 Wednesday

Crying Uncle

BYLINE: by Aviva Gat

LENGTH: 1052 words


Big-picture basic research spending boasts a strong federal government
tradition, but the investigations in Washington of two bankrupt companies -
Solyndra LLC and Open Range Communications Inc. - suggest that the American
people are suddenly demanding something new: an investment return on their tax
dollars.  Government spending on a massive scale to win World War II (the
Manhattan Project), to beat a Cold War rival to the moon (the National
Aeronautics and Space Administration) or even to fight a biological foe (the
National Cancer Act in 1971) never stirred public demands that such spending
generate a tangible return on investment.

And why should it? The tacit understanding has long been that the federal
government should invest in fundamental research that no one in the private
sector could or would.   That thinking may have crashed with the Troubled Asset
Relief Program, which clearly galvanized protests from the Tea Party to Occupy
Wall Street over the appearance that the government was bailing out people and
companies that didn't need it.  What's too bad about that perception is how it
has tarred other economic development initiatives. Not unlike the Tennessee
Valley Authority, which the New Deal built to bring power and economic
development to a swath of the impoverished South, the feds are currently trying
to spur broadband installations in rural communities. Open Range Communications
received a $267 million loan from the Rural Utilities Services division of the
U.S. Department of Agriculture in January 2009 to build just such a broadband
network in 546 communities in 17 states over five years.  Open Range, the
largest recipient of funds under the program, never completed the project
because it couldn't get the spectrum licenses.   In fact, when it filed for
Chapter 11 on Oct. 6, it had drawn only $73.5 million of the loan.  The USDA
defends the Open Range loan, asserting that the default rate on its loans is
just 4% of the loans provided. But the House Energy and Commerce Committee has
questioned whether the USDA conducted the correct due diligence before granting
the loans under the program and whether there was any accounting fraud or unfair
contributions from company insiders to the loan providers.  Solar panel maker
Solyndra is also being investigated by the committee. It was awarded a $535
million loan guarantee under the U.S. Department of Energy's Section 1705
program - established by the Obama administration's stimulus package, the
American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 - to construct a second facility
for its photovoltaic solar power systems.  Solyndra was the first to receive
funding from this program in September 2009. (Wind energy company Kahuku Wind
Power LLCwas awarded a $117 million loan guarantee 10 months later.) Solyndra
completed construction of the facility in Fremont, Calif., for which it had
gotten the loan and began production in January.  Solyndra's technology differed
from that of other solar panel makers that used silicon in their products.
(Solyndra's panels are made of cylindrical modules rather than flat panels. The
panels are lighter and easier to install but are more costly.) High silicon
prices made Solyndra's panels cost-competitive, but when those prices sank, so
did Solyndra, and it filed for Chapter 11 on Sept. 6 with $329 million in
losses.  The situation parallels a similar one during the Carter administration.
Gas prices were high in the late '70s, and the U.S. was in the midst of its
second energy crisis. In 1980, President Carter signed the Energy Security Act,
which created the Synthetic Fuels Corp. to provide loans and loan guarantees to
companies developing synthetic fuels.   The act designated $88 billion for fuel
companies with a goal of producing 2 million barrels of oil equivalents by 1990.
The structure resembled the DOE 1705 program that provided funds to Solyndra.
The program was killed in 1985 after synthetic fuels proved "uneconomical" and
their producers remained reliant on government subsidies, according to Energy
Frontiers International, a nonadvocacy energy research association.   Ronald
Bailey, a science correspondent for the libertarian think tank Reason
Foundation, recalls the Great Plains Synfuels Plant in Beulah, N.D., which was
built with a $1.5 billion loan guarantee from Synthetic Fuels. The plant cost $2
billion to complete and began operations in 1984. But when the price of gas
nose-dived, the plant defaulted on its loan, forcing the DOE to pay up.  Bailey,
who has written books about energy and environmental topics and has testified
before the House Subcommittee on Energy and Mineral Resources, notes that the
Solyndra fallout resembles the bitter aftermath of the synthetic-fuels debacle.
"The government is terrible at identifying innovative technology," he says.
"Solyndra is just the latest example of that."  Does that mean that the federal
government should get out of the business of funding basic research?  Not
necessarily. It may just mean a new reality has dawned. Carter-era
synthetic-fuel companies withered and died, often quietly. Bankruptcy today is
more prevalent and public, giving more transparency to government loan programs,
embryonic industries and the companies that sometimes are ruined by the
immaturity of both.  For example, under the 1705 program, which expired Sept.
30, the DOE has provided about $16 billion in loan guarantees to 28 companies.
Only two - Solyndra and Beacon Power Corp. - filed for bankruptcy. One other
recipient,AES Corp., has a subsidiary proceeding through bankruptcy. (The unit,
AES Thames LLC, itself received no government funding.) Yet there's a feeling
the entire program, the entire idea of helping to finance renewable energy
enterprises, has been indicted as flawed.  Gordon Johnson, an alternative energy
research analyst for Axiom Capital Management Inc., isn't wrong when he says,
"The government really does not understand technology."  But what he doesn't say
is that without the government being the lender of last resort for what may be
critical technologies, now-booming industries, from digital electronics to
biotechnology, may not have emerged. If the price for that is a handful of
bankrupt companies and no return on investment, then it may be a small price to
pay.

                       Austin American-Statesman (Texas)

                            November 6, 2011 Sunday
                                 Final Edition

Money at heart of dispute over dueling hospitals in Lakeway

BYLINE: Mary Ann Roser AMERICAN-STATESMAN STAFF

SECTION: MAIN; Pg. A01

LENGTH: 1518 words


LAKEWAY - The last chapter has not been written on Lakeway's decades-long quest
for a hospital, but some key players think they see an ending in sight. In a
saga with this many plot turns, it's hard to be certain.

Creating a hospital in this scenic, affluent community on Lake Travis hasn't
been easy, but Lakeway now has two hospitals close to completion. The bigger
facility, the $210 million Lakeway Regional Medical Center at 3000 RM 620 South
, is slated to open in April, hospital officials said at a forum Tuesday night.
The fate of the other facility just a half-mile away - Lake Travis Transitional
Medical Center at 2200 RM 620 South - is a mystery. No one connected with that
hospital seems to be talking, and no one returned repeated calls or emails from
the American-Statesman.

"Usually companies give us too much information, but this has been an absolute
wall" of silence, said Lakeway Mayor David DeOme , a staunch backer of the
larger, 106-bed Lakeway Regional hospital. "I have a feeling it has something to
do with finances, and they don't want anyone to know."

Hospital financing has been a sore subject in Lakeway. Early on, financial
uncertainty delayed work on Lakeway Regional. When announced in 2008, the
project had an opening date of this year. Finances also figured into a lawsuit
the smaller hospital filed against the government in questioning a record-high
loan guarantee to the larger hospital. Now, financing is a source of speculation
about the smaller hospital's fate.

The 46-bed facility, which also has been called Lake Travis Specialty Hospital,
was supposed to open earlier this year. The building has the necessary occupancy
permits, but "there's no furniture or equipment inside," DeOme said.

The owners of the smaller Lake Travis hospital apparently have been trying to
sell it; St. David's HealthCare was approached, but it declined, a spokeswoman
said. An official with the larger Seton Healthcare Family did not call back, and
Scott & White Healthcare said it had no acquisition plans to announce.

Fight over information

The Lakeway Regional hospital received the biggest-ever loan guarantee that the
U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development had ever given to a for-profit
hospital: $166.9 million. That guarantee "will save an estimated $91.2 million
in interest expense over the life of the loan," said HUD's March 2010 news
release.

The loan matures July 1, 2037, according to the hospital's deed of trust.

Lake Travis hospital officials sought information about the loan, and HUD said
the hospital would have to pay $5,326 upfront for documents. The officials paid
and waited, but no documents came, with HUD citing various reasons, including
needing time to review documents and determining which needed to be kept
confidential. On Dec. 14, the smaller hospital sued, saying HUD was withholding
information about the loan.

Lakeway Regional is "scheduled to be completed two years after Plaintiff's
hospital (and) will serve the community in direct competition with Plaintiff,"
the suit said. With the Lake Travis hospital so near, Lakeway Regional is not
"urgently needed" or in a medically "underserved" area, as HUD requires, the
suit said.

U.S. District Judge Sam Sparks of Austin determined that HUD had to turn over
most of the documents Lake Travis sought. In a Sept. 26 order, he said HUD had
behaved unacceptably and should pay Lake Travis Transitional Medical Center
$10,350 to cover its lawyer fees and $350 in litigation costs.

Lake Travis lawyer S. Abraham Kuczaj III of Austin did not return repeated
calls. Nor did the hospital's manager, Robert Berry, CEO of Pin Oak Management
Co. in Lakeway, or any of the officials with co-owner, Health Care REIT Inc. of
Toledo, Ohio.

Interra Partners LLC of Dallas, which built the hospital and is listed as an
owner by Health Care REIT in a document obtained by the Statesman , declined to
comment through managing partner Bill Hurd.

"Our hospital is finished. " We're just the developer. We built the hospital and
have no comment," Hurd said. He referred questions to Berry.

In a 2009 interview, Berry said the hospital would be aimed at patients who were
recovering from a traumatic injury or had some other serious medical problem and
needed to be hospitalized 25 or more days. He said it would cost $24 million to
build and $5 million to $7 million more to equip.

It would not compete with Lakeway Regional, Berry said then. But later, the
hospital was changed to an acute-care, general-purpose hospital, and competition
was mentioned as a key issue in the suit.

HUD has no comment on the court case, spokesman Lemar Wooley said Friday. He
wrote in an email that Lakeway Regional's loan application "was reviewed and met
our underwriting criteria for providing (Federal Housing Administration)
mortgage insurance."

A magnet for jobs

HUD said in its news release about the loan that it expected Lakeway Regional,
which is part of a development that includes a medical office building, a hotel
and shops, to support 1,871 full-time jobs and provide an annual economic
benefit of more than $308 million.

"The whole face of Lakeway is going to change," said Kenn Renner, a Lakeway real
estate broker who hosted Tuesday's development forum. He and others in the real
estate community expect Lakeway Regional to be a catalyst for jobs and housing
demand.

It will be one of Lakeway's largest employers, DeOme, the mayor, said.

"For every highly paid employee, we end up getting three to four ancillary jobs
in the community to support that," Renner said. "If you had 300 employees,
you're looking at " 1,200 to 1,500 new residents moving in."

HUD released documents to the Statesman on Friday in response to a Freedom of
Information Act request about the loan and the hospital's competitors, which
might also include the Hospital at Westlake Medical Center , St. David's South
Austin Medical Center , Seton Southwest Hospital and other Austin hospitals. But
HUD said it was withholding some documents at the request of Lakeway Regional
that the hospital said would harm its competitive position and other documents
that would hurt HUD's ability to receive candid advice in decision-making, HUD
said in a letter to the Statesman.

Lakeway Regional expects to open with 250 to 275 employees, not counting
doctors, hospital CEO David Kreye said. About 110 to 125 doctors will be on
staff, he said.

Although the city of Lakeway has just 11,300 residents, according to DeOme, the
hospital expects to draw patients from Steiner Ranch, Spicewood, Dripping
Springs and surrounding areas encompassing 90,000 to 100,000 residents, Kreye
said.

A financial feasibility study that Lakeway Regional officials sent to HUD before
it received the loan guarantee paints a more ambitious picture. That document
says the hospital would provide access to health care in a primary service area
of 174,000 residents projected to grow to 243,000 by 2016.

It also said residents "must drive over 20 miles to access services with commute
times often exceeding 40 minutes."

Two smaller hospitals are within 10 to 11 miles of Lakeway Regional: Seton
Southwest Hospital and the Hospital at Westlake Medical Center. The full-service
St. David's South Austin Medical Center is 15½ miles away, according to Yahoo
maps.

DeOme said he sees Lakeway Regional competing with Austin facilities and expects
it to expand quickly. He said he isn't sure how the Lake Travis hospital will
fit in, unless it decides to offer different services.

"You're going to have to have a doggone good business plan to make this thing
work," he said.

'Father of this hospital'

Lakeway Regional will have eight floors servicing all major specialities. It
will have 22 emergency room beds, six operating rooms, an 18-bed intensive-care
unit, and 19 rooms for new moms.

Initially, the hospital was to be mostly owned by doctors, but federal health
care law does not permit physician-owned hospitals. Now, Tennessee-based
Surgical Development Partners and other investors own the facility, Kreye said.

At Tuesday's forum, a question was asked about an investor and former chairman
of the Lakeway Regional board, Dr. Samuel DeMaio, who was investigated by the
Texas Medical Board over allegations that he harmed patients.

DeMaio, who claimed the medical board's investigation was instigated by
competitors of Lakeway Regional to smear his name, is credited by many with
bringing the hospital to the city. He was called "the father of this hospital"
by the mayor. DeOme said people in the community have mixed opinions about
DeMaio, but DeOme doesn't see his involvement as an issue.

The medical board resolved the case against DeMaio, 54, on Friday when it
determined he placed multiple heart stents in certain patients having
"insignificant or only moderate disease." DeMaio, who has relocated to El Paso,
did not receive any serious penalties from the state, such as suspension of his
license.

Kreye said DeMaio would be back soon but "doesn't have a seat on this board."

DeMaio "is a visionary and he's remarkable," Kreye said. "He's the reason this
hospital is here."

maroser@statesman.com; 445-3619

                                January 2, 2013

AEPCO receives funding for improvements

BYLINE: Arizona Range News staff

LENGTH: 510  words


Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack announced funding to modernize and improve the
efficiency of rural electric generation and transmission systems. Several of the
loans contain support for smart grid projects.

"USDA and the Obama Administration continue to fund electric projects to improve
system reliability and efficiency for rural businesses and residential
consumers," Vilsack said. "A strong American economy is contingent upon a strong
rural economy. Infrastructure investments like these will promote job growth."

Secretary Vilsack announced in August that USDA had met its goal to finance $250
million in smart grid technologies in fiscal year 2012. Today's $107.5 million
in loan guarantees includes nearly $3 million in smart grid technologies. The
loan guarantees are provided by USDA Rural Development's Rural Utilities
Service. USDA also funds energy conservation and renewable energy projects.

Several rural utilities will receive USDA funding, which is contingent upon the
recipient meeting the terms of the loan agreement.

In Arizona, Arizona Electric Power Cooperative, Inc. will receive $34,028,000.
Funds will be used to finance generation system improvements for the Apache
Station. The loan includes $2,052,000 in environmental improvements.

The Arizona Electric Power Cooperative, Inc. is located in Benson, and serves
Cochise, Coconino, Yavapai, Graham, Greenlee, Mohave, Pima Santa Cruz, and Pinal
Counties in Arizona as well as Riverside County in California and Grant and
Hidalgo Counties in New Mexico.

Other rural utilities receiving funding are located in Georgia, Iowa, Kansas,
North Dakota and Wisconsin.

For information on Rural Development projects throughout the country, please
visit the agency's new interactive web map at: http://www.rurdev.usda.g
ov/RDSiiccessStories.htm 1. The map features program funding and success stories
for fiscal years 2009-2011.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities. USDA's
investments in rural communities support the rural way of life that stands as
the backbone of our American values

Obama and Vilsack are committed to a smarter use of Federal resources to foster
sustainable economic prosperity and ensure the government is a strong partner
for businesses, entrepreneurs and working families in rural communities.

USDA, through its Rural Development mission area, administers and manages
housing, business and community infrastructure programs through a national
network of state and local offices. Rural Development has an active portfolio of
more than $174 billion in loans and loan guarantees. These programs are designed
to improve the economic stability of rural communities, businesses, residents,
farmers and ranchers and improve the quality of life in rural America.

The price of Solyndra, Open Range

LENGTH: 1053 words


Big-picture basic research spending boasts a strong federal government
tradition, but the investigations in Washington of two bankrupt companies --
Solyndra LLC and Open Range Communications Inc. -- suggest that the American
people are suddenly demanding something new: an investment return on their tax

                                American Banker

                          February 18, 2009 Wednesday

SBA Rules May Hamper Loan Efforts

BYLINE: Emily Flitter

SECTION: WASHINGTON; Pg. 1 Vol. 176 No. 32

LENGTH: 1089  words


WASHINGTON - Provisions in the stimulus package President Obama signed Tuesday
are designed to spur Small Business Administration lending, but recent guidance
from the agency may undercut those efforts.

The stimulus package tries to make SBA lending more attractive for banks by
providing relief from guarantee fees, more protection against losses on the
loans, and a new facility to improve the secondary market for the loans. But
bankers argue that the SBA is jeopardizing those gains with new standard
operating procedure guidelines that, for the first time, will cap the amount of
financing lenders may offer on certain loans.

Though the agency has pledged to revisit the guidelines in light of complaints,
it has an extensive to-do list, including making changes required by the
stimulus package, and many lenders are worried.

"This cap will eliminate a lot of opportunities to buy businesses, and it will
reduce jobs," said Scott Harvey, the executive vice president and SBA manager of
the $69.4 million-asset Fortune Bank in Seattle.

Under the guidelines, released Feb. 12 and scheduled to take effect March 1, the
SBA set a $250,000 cap on the goodwill value for loans to purchase an existing
business.

Goodwill - the portion of a business with intangible value - makes up a large
part of the value of certain types of businesses, such as medical and veterinary
practices, and other types of businesses that do not have expensive equipment
but generate significant cash flow.

Bankers argue that the cap was too low and instituted without any basis.

"The anger comes from the out-of-right-field, seemingly arbitrary cap," said
Lynn Ozer, an executive vice president at Susquehanna Bank, a unit of the $7.48
billion-asset Susquehanna Bancshares Inc. in Lititz, Pa. "It just came out of
the blue, and there are many lenders who do business acquisitions exclusively,
and there are many industries where the financing of goodwill is what people
sell."

The goodwill cap could discourage lenders from making SBA loans, according to
Ms. Ozer, a former SBA loan officer. Susquehanna will not give up the line
entirely, but "it's going to severely hamper the kinds of loans we do."

Jim Hammersley, the director of the SBA's loan division, said in an interview
that the agency was revisiting the cap in light of lenders' complaints and was
aiming to issue new guidance before March 1.

"The message on the goodwill issue is that we're taking a look at the comments
that we've received that our $250,000 ceiling is too low," Mr. Hammersley said.
"We are certainly sensitive to the times and that business acquisition is
growing - many folks that are being laid off ... may be looking to purchase a
business. We expect to come up with a plan that we think deals prudently with
this particular issue."

The SBA will have to solve that problem and complete the formidable task of
writing implementation guidelines for the stimulus provisions.

The stimulus package provides $69 million for the SBA to expand its staff and
marketing, including $20 million that must be spent on improving lender
oversight and streamlining lender processes.

Additional appropriations will help lenders reduce the fees the SBA charges for
each loan it guarantees. The SBA must first eliminate the fees for borrowers;
then it can begin to use leftover funds to subsidize the guarantee fees for
lenders with assets under $1 billion. Loans made by bigger lenders have their
guarantee fees waived last.

"This is probably the best we could have hoped for in this atmosphere," said
James Ballentine, the director of housing, community, and economic development
at the American Bankers Association. "Clearly, both the Congress and the
administration recognized that the SBA can play a vital role in this situation."

Still, some SBA lenders saw a problem with the structure of fee eliminations.

"They got it backwards," because fees for lenders should have been eliminated
first, Mr. Harvey said. "If there isn't any money to reduce the fees paid by the
lenders, then there isn't any incentive for the lenders to make these loans, and
if you have a borrower who doesn't have to pay a fee but can't get a loan, what
good is it?"

Tony Wilkinson, the president of the National Association of Government
Guaranteed Lenders, said the stimulus language is vague but encouraging - one
section seems to say the SBA should eliminate guarantee fees for all lenders and
borrowers until the money runs out.

Another provision increased the guarantee on SBA loans to 90%. (Loans of
different sizes currently have guarantees of 75% or 85%.) Many lenders are
pleased with the increase, but others say it could foster irresponsible lending.

"I was making SBA loans back in 1981, back when there used to be a 90% guarantee
, and there were lenders that pushed the envelope, and the SBA default rates
were much higher," Mr. Harvey said. "And to tell you the truth, there are people
out there who are greedier now than they were back in 1980."

Still, he said, the provisions will have a positive effect on SBA lending.
"These changes, I think, will help lenders either get into the program or expand
their programs."

One of the hardest parts of the stimulus language to address may be the various
new facilities the law describes.

Lenders making loans through the 504 program, which deals only with loans for
fixed assets such as land or machinery, will now be able to sell the
non-guaranteed portions of their loans through a secondary market facility to be
established by the SBA.

Another provision would allow lenders making the most common type of SBA loans,
7(a) loans, to offer deferred-payment loans to borrowers who are behind on
payments on other loans.

The mechanics of the programs have yet to be defined by the SBA.

Participants in the secondary market for SBA loans are set to get help, too.

The law calls for the establishment of a lending authority at the SBA that will
make loans to broker-dealers who buy the loans, pool them, and sell them to
investors. Broker-dealers have struggled recently to find buyers for their
loans, and observers said the program could help them get their inventories
moving again.

"I view it as a very good development," said Scott Taylor, a vice president in
Memphis for Shay Financial Services Inc.

But questions remain about how the SBA will implement its secondary market
lending facility and how it will obtain the funds to lend to broker-dealers. If
the agency cannot borrow cheaply enough, the prices of its loans to
broker-dealers may be too high to attract much interest.

                                American Banker

                               February 18, 2009

SBA Rules May Hamper Loan Efforts.

BYLINE: Emily Flitter

SECTION: Pg. 1 Vol. 176 No. 32 ISSN: 0002-7561

LENGTH: 1089 words



HIGHLIGHT: Washington


WASHINGTON - Provisions in the stimulus package President Obama signed Tuesday
are designed to spur Small Business Administration lending, but recent guidance
from the agency may undercut those efforts.

The stimulus package tries to make SBA lending more attractive for banks by
providing relief from guarantee fees, more protection against losses on the
loans, and a new facility to improve the secondary market for the loans. But
bankers argue that the SBA is jeopardizing those gains with new standard
operating procedure guidelines that, for the first time, will cap the amount of
financing lenders may offer on certain loans.

Though the agency has pledged to revisit the guidelines in light of complaints,
it has an extensive to-do list, including making changes required by the
stimulus package, and many lenders are worried.

"This cap will eliminate a lot of opportunities to buy businesses, and it will
reduce jobs," said Scott Harvey, the executive vice president and SBA manager of
the $69.4 million-asset Fortune Bank in Seattle.

Under the guidelines, released Feb. 12 and scheduled to take effect March 1, the
SBA set a $250,000 cap on the goodwill value for loans to purchase an existing
business.

Goodwill - the portion of a business with intangible value - makes up a large
part of the value of certain types of businesses, such as medical and veterinary
practices, and other types of businesses that do not have expensive equipment
but generate significant cash flow.

Bankers argue that the cap was too low and instituted without any basis.

"The anger comes from the out-of-right-field, seemingly arbitrary cap," said
Lynn Ozer, an executive vice president at Susquehanna Bank, a unit of the $7.48
billion-asset Susquehanna Bancshares Inc. in Lititz, Pa. "It just came out of
the blue, and there are many lenders who do business acquisitions exclusively,
and there are many industries where the financing of goodwill is what people
sell."

The goodwill cap could discourage lenders from making SBA loans, according to
Ms. Ozer, a former SBA loan officer. Susquehanna will not give up the line
entirely, but "it's going to severely hamper the kinds of loans we do."

Jim Hammersley, the director of the SBA's loan division, said in an interview
that the agency was revisiting the cap in light of lenders' complaints and was
aiming to issue new guidance before March 1.

"The message on the goodwill issue is that we're taking a look at the comments
that we've received that our $250,000 ceiling is too low," Mr. Hammersley said.
"We are certainly sensitive to the times and that business acquisition is
growing - many folks that are being laid off ... may be looking to purchase a
business. We expect to come up with a plan that we think deals prudently with
this particular issue."

The SBA will have to solve that problem and complete the formidable task of
writing implementation guidelines for the stimulus provisions.

The stimulus package provides $69 million for the SBA to expand its staff and
marketing, including $20 million that must be spent on improving lender
oversight and streamlining lender processes.

Additional appropriations will help lenders reduce the fees the SBA charges for
each loan it guarantees. The SBA must first eliminate the fees for borrowers;
then it can begin to use leftover funds to subsidize the guarantee fees for
lenders with assets under $1 billion. Loans made by bigger lenders have their
guarantee fees waived last.

"This is probably the best we could have hoped for in this atmosphere," said
James Ballentine, the director of housing, community, and economic development
at the American Bankers Association. "Clearly, both the Congress and the
administration recognized that the SBA can play a vital role in this situation."

Still, some SBA lenders saw a problem with the structure of fee eliminations.

"They got it backwards," because fees for lenders should have been eliminated
first, Mr. Harvey said. "If there isn't any money to reduce the fees paid by the
lenders, then there isn't any incentive for the lenders to make these loans, and
if you have a borrower who doesn't have to pay a fee but can't get a loan, what
good is it?"

Tony Wilkinson, the president of the National Association of Government
Guaranteed Lenders, said the stimulus language is vague but encouraging - one
section seems to say the SBA should eliminate guarantee fees for all lenders and
borrowers until the money runs out.

Another provision increased the guarantee on SBA loans to 90%. (Loans of
different sizes currently have guarantees of 75% or 85%.) Many lenders are
pleased with the increase, but others say it could foster irresponsible lending.

"I was making SBA loans back in 1981, back when there used to be a 90% guarantee
, and there were lenders that pushed the envelope, and the SBA default rates
were much higher," Mr. Harvey said. "And to tell you the truth, there are people
out there who are greedier now than they were back in 1980."

Still, he said, the provisions will have a positive effect on SBA lending.
"These changes, I think, will help lenders either get into the program or expand
their programs."

One of the hardest parts of the stimulus language to address may be the various
new facilities the law describes.

Lenders making loans through the 504 program, which deals only with loans for
fixed assets such as land or machinery, will now be able to sell the
non-guaranteed portions of their loans through a secondary market facility to be
established by the SBA.

Another provision would allow lenders making the most common type of SBA loans,
7(a) loans, to offer deferred-payment loans to borrowers who are behind on
payments on other loans.

The mechanics of the programs have yet to be defined by the SBA.

Participants in the secondary market for SBA loans are set to get help, too.

The law calls for the establishment of a lending authority at the SBA that will
make loans to broker-dealers who buy the loans, pool them, and sell them to
investors. Broker-dealers have struggled recently to find buyers for their
loans, and observers said the program could help them get their inventories
moving again.

"I view it as a very good development," said Scott Taylor, a vice president in
Memphis for Shay Financial Services Inc.

But questions remain about how the SBA will implement its secondary market
lending facility and how it will obtain the funds to lend to broker-dealers. If
the agency cannot borrow cheaply enough, the prices of its loans to
broker-dealers may be too high to attract much interest.

Schumer, Gillibrand Announce the Village of Attica to Receive $160,000 in
Federal Funding - Investment for New Ambulance

LENGTH: 308  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Senator Gillibrand, U.S Government has issued the following news
release:

United States Senators Charles E. Schumer and Kirsten E. Gillibrand announced
that the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Rural Development Program will award
the Village of Attica a $160,000 Community Facility Loan and Grant.
Specifically, this $136,000 loan and $24,000 grant will go towards the purchase
of a new ambulance to serve the local rural area and improve emergency response
and safety.

"With this investment, Attica first responders can focus on their important work
knowing that they have a new ambulance and reliable tools at their disposal in
case of emergencies, "said Senator Schumer. "I applaud the USDA for investing in
rural communities through the Community Facility Program. This loan and grant
will preserve quality of life for Wyoming county residents and businesses,
improve safety and encourage further investment in the region."

"This is an important investment for the Village of Attica," said Senator
Gillibrand. "It's our responsibility to ensure our first responders have the
most up-to-date equipment and vehicles to serve our communities.  The new
ambulance will help the Village of Attica upgrade their emergency response
vehicles so that their first responders can respond to emergencies in the
community more efficiently and effectively, and help save more lives."

USDA Community Facilities Programs provide loans, grant and loan guarantees for
essential community facilities in rural areas. Priority is given to health care,
education and public safety projects. Typical projects are hospitals, health
clinics, schools, fire houses, community centers and many other community based
initiatives. The funding is part of the USDA Rural Development annual budget.

For further information please visit: http://www.gillibrand.senate.gov

                                 The Bond Buyer

                            August 3, 2016 Wednesday

States Face Deadline in $4.5B Program for Electric Vehicle Stations

BYLINE: Jim Watts

SECTION: INFRASTRUCTURE Vol. 1 No. 34555

LENGTH: 838  words


DALLAS - States only have until Aug. 20 to designate highway corridors where
electric vehicle charging stations can be built under a new administration
program that will provide $4.5 billion of loan guarantees to public-private
partnerships and other collaborative efforts to develop and deploy a network of
such stations.

The loan guarantees are part of an ambitious multi-faceted approach to getting
more electric vehicles on U.S. highways. The efforts include a coalition of
state and local governments that will partner with the federal government to
purchase electric vehicles at discounted rates as well as the deployment of fast
charging stations along major highway corridors.

The Energy Department opened an existing loan guarantee program for renewable
energy projects to include $4.5 billion for electric vehicle charging
facilities, including hardware and software.

"Loan guarantees can be an important tool to commercialize innovative
technologies because these projects may be unable to obtain full commercial
financing due to the perceived risks associated with technology that has never
been deployed at commercial scale in the United States," the White House said in
a statement announcing the new program.

Tesla, General Motors, Ford, Nissan, BMW, Daimler, Duke Energy, and Consolidated
Edison are part of the effort to encourage development of rapid charging
stations.

The Transportation Department has asked state and local officials to determine
where the charging stations should be built by designating routes where drivers
would be able to find electric vehicle charging stations as well as facilities
dispensing hydrogen, propane, and natural gas.

Determining the placement of recharging facilities will help determine the type
of P3s that could be needed to implement the network by 2020, the White House
said.

States must submit their initial applications for corridor status to the Federal
Highway Administration by Aug. 20. Establishment of the corridors is required by
the five-year Fixing America's Surface Transportation (FAST) Act.

The growth in electric vehicle charging stations is a looming opportunity for
public-private partnerships, said Albert E. Dotson, Jr. and Eric Singer of the
Bilzin Sumberg law firm in Miami.

"State and local governments will no doubt be procuring fleets of electric
vehicles in the near future, and concessions for rapid charging stations, along
with restaurants and other services to keep drivers occupied while their
vehicles charge, will be needed along highways throughout the country," they
said.

Although governments are just beginning to plan for these procurements and
facilities, Florida's P3 law lets interested private sector partners get ahead
of the process by submitting unsolicited proposals, Dotson and Singer said.

"In many cases, the right P3 structure and procurement approach, along with the
right private partner, will permit state and local governments to move forward
with electric vehicle adoption and infrastructure right now," they said.

ChargePoint, a California-based maker of electric vehicle charging stations,
said it would commit up to $20 million per year toward deployment of a national
P3 network of charging stations as part of the White House initiatives.

"ChargePoint will work with the Department of Transportation, other federal,
state and local government agencies, and private entities to determine the
optimal location for such high-speed charging stations and to secure financing
from private entities and through public-private partnerships," said company
president Pasquale Romano. "We need a network of charging stations in our
communities and along our nation's interstate highways."

The loan guarantees and the other initiatives will prompt the construction of
more charging stations, which will encourage Americans to buy more electric
vehicles and reduce the national dependency on fossil fuels, said White House
senior advisor Brian Deese.

"There's a lot more to do in this space," Deese said. "The initiatives serve the
goal of providing consumers with more comfort that they will be able to move
across regions and across the country in their electric vehicles."

There were only 500 fueling stations for electric vehicles in 2008 but more than
16,000 now while battery costs have fallen by more than 70%, he said.

There are currently almost 500,000 electric vehicles in the U.S., with
California having the most, compared to more than 250 million gasoline and
diesel cars and trucks, said Lynn Orr, undersecretary for science and energy at
the Energy Department.

One goal of the new initiatives is to find out how to build charging stations
that can fill up an electric vehicle with enough juice in 10 minutes to go 200
miles, Orr said.

President Obama set a goal during his 2008 campaign of 1 million plug-in
vehicles on the road by 2015.

More than 66,000 electric cars have been sold in the first seven months of 2016,
according to the Electric Drive Transportation Association, along with 161,000
hybrid gasoline-electric cars.

                              The Herald (Harare)

                           January 12, 2012 Thursday

Empowerment Graduates Urged to Mobilise Own Funds

LENGTH: 366 words


THE empowerment training programmes being run by Zanu-PF for its youths do not
necessarily automatically guarantee the graduates funds, the director for
indigenisation and economic empowerment in the party has said.

The party has traditionally carried out empowerment training programmes for
youth and community development. However, with the concurrent implementation of
the indigenisation programme, the two are being viewed as combined.

In an interview with the Herald Business, the director of indigenisation and
economic empowerment in the party, Mr Kurai Masenyama, said the misconception
was causing problems because the trainees were expecting funding as soon as they
graduated.

"Zimbabwe has a high literacy rate, but is rather limited in terms of the
requisite economic/business skills, hence we carry out skills training in this
respect for our youth members.

"In our view, empowerment comes in two forms, training and finance. It is
unfortunate, however, that people have begun to assume that as soon as they
receive the training they automatically get access to funding, which is not the
case.

"Training itself is a form of empowerment," he said.

Mr Masenyama added that companies in compliance with the indigenisation
programme also hoped the training would capacitate the youth with know-how on
how to benefit from some outcomes of the indigenisation programme such as
community share ownership schemes that are being set-up.

Youths, however, can individually apply for funding under the Youth Development
Fund, which as at the close of last year had benefited over 650 youths and youth
organisations/companies from across the country.

The fund, which was set up by the Government through the Ministry of Youth
Development, Indigenisation and Empowerment, is administered through youth
empowerment facilities managed by a number of local banks.

The youth empowerment facility provides funds for capital expenditure loans and
project finance, and working capital finance including short-term loans, debt
factoring, order finance, invoice discounting and guarantees.

The funds are essentially bank loans at an interest rate of 10 percent per annum
and are repaid as per loan disbursement agreement.

MassDevelopment Gets $4M Federal Grant for Charter Schools

BYLINE: Paul Burton

SECTION: REGIONAL NEWS Vol. 1 No. 1

LENGTH: 209  words


The Massachusetts Development Finance Agency has received a $3.9 million U.S.
Department of Education grant to help charter schools obtain facilities under
the credit enhancement for charter schools facilities program.

MassDevelopment, the state's finance and development agency, has received $19
million through three grant rounds of this program, and will help charter
schools by issuing guarantees on a portion of a loan or bond made to a school to
improve its facility.

With its own resources, these grants, and private sources to provide loan
guarantees for Massachusetts charter schools, MassDevelopment has a fund of more
than $25 million for this guarantee program.

The credit enhancement program awards grants based on a competitive preference
priority that rewards applicants for targeting funds to areas with the greatest
need for public school choice.

MassDevelopment has used its guarantee program for Massachusetts schools that
include Abby Kelley Foster Charter Public School in Worcester, Cape Cod
Lighthouse Charter School in East Harwich, Christa McAuliffe Regional Charter
Public School in Framingham, and Rising Tide Charter Public School in Plymouth.

The agency spent $2.3 billion for businesses, nonprofits, and communities in
fiscal 2013.

                                  May 9, 2014

USDA announces effort to cut energy costs for farmers, ranchers, rural small
businesses;
Up to $12.3 Million in Grants and $57.8 Million in Loan Guarantees Available In
Rural Energy for America Program

BYLINE: The News-Democrat staff

LENGTH: 803  words


Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced that USDA is seeking
applications from rural small businesses and agricultural producers for funding
to make energy efficiency improvements or to install renewable energy systems.

"Developing renewable energy presents an enormous economic opportunity for rural
America," Vilsack said. "This funding will help farmers, ranchers and rural
small business owners incorporate renewable energy and energy efficiency
technology into their operations, create jobs and help America become more
energy independent. When small rural businesses and farmers cut their energy
costs with cleaner and more efficient energy, we are both helping their bottom
lines and reducing the amount of greenhouse gas pollution that affects our
climate.".

The funding announced today is being provided through USDA's Rural Energy for
America Program (REAP). Investments from programs like REAP help support the
true engine of America's economic growth - a thriving middle class. REAP is one
of many USDA programs and initiatives to support an expanded domestic energy
economy. In addition to helping to increase renewable energy production, USDA
makes investments in the bioeconomy, provides support for the emerging biobased
products industry, supports new technologies, and supports energy efficiency
improvements.

REAP funding has helped farmers expand renewable energy use in recent years. The
new Census of Agriculture shows the number of farms utilizing renewable energy
production has doubled in the last five years. More than 57,000 farms reported
using a renewable energy system in 2012, while 23,451 operations reported doing
so in 2007. Solar panels accounted for 63% of renewable energy systems on farms,
with 36,331 farms reporting their use.

REAP funding is an example of the many ways that USDA is helping revitalize
rural economies to create opportunities for growth and prosperity, support
innovative technologies, identify new markets for agricultural producers and
better utilize our nation's natural resources.

Created by the 2008 Farm Bill, REAP was reauthorized by the recently passed 2014
Farm Bill. For fiscal year (FY) 2014, USDA plans to award up to $12.3 million in
grants and $57.8 million in loan guarantees. Additional REAP funds provided by
the Farm Bill will be made available with a subsequent notice. USDA is accepting
applications for: Renewable energy system and energy efficiency improvement loan
guarantee and grant combinations Renewable energy system and energy efficiency
improvement loan guarantees; and Renewable energy system and energy efficiency
improvement grants.

Renewable energy system and energy efficiency improvement grants.

Requests for grants may not exceed 25 percent of a project's cost - either for
stand-alone grant requests or for grants combined with loan guarantees.

Since the start of the Obama Administration, REAP has supported more than 8,200
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects nationwide. During this period,
USDA has provided more than $264 million in grants and $212 million in loan
guarantees to agricultural producers and rural small business owners.

Cozy Acres Greenhouse in North Yarmouth, Maine, used a $48,750 REAP grant to
help offset the cost of installing a solar and geothermal system in new
greenhouses. Owners Jeff and Marianne Marstaller needed to expand
their'greenhouse operations and were determined to do so in a cost-effective
'arid energy-efficient way. They teamed up with USDA Rural Development to fund a
geothermal system to provide heat for the greenhouses and solar photovoltaic
panels that help offset their electricity needs. The greenhouses were completed
in fall 2013. The Marstallers plan to market their locally grown herbs and
vegetables to area restaurants and farmers markets.

Information on how to apply for REAP funding and on the application deadlines
(which vary by project type) is available on page 25564 of the May 5, 2014
Federal Register.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way -
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities. USDA's
investments in rural communities support the rural way of life that stands as
the backbone of our American values.

USDA is an equal opportunity provider and employer. To file a complaint of
discrimination, write: USDA, Office of the Assistant Secretary for Civil Rights,
Office of Adjudication, 1400 Independence Ave., SW, Washington, DC 20250-9410 or
call (866) 632-9992 (Toll-free Customer Service), (800) 877-8339 (Local or
Federal relay), (866) 377-8642 (Relay voice users).

                               SUNDAY MAIL (QLD)

                             August 13, 1989 Sunday

MONEY DRY-UP PUTS SUNS' RISE IN DOUBT

SOURCE: QNP

BYLINE: BUTTS T

LENGTH: 419 words


Money dry-up puts Suns' rise in doubt By TERRY BUTTS THE Townsville Suns' bid to
join the National Basketball League next year is in doubt after contractors
walked off the job at the $7 million Sundome stadium project last week.

Backers have now appealed to the State Government to guarantee a loan for the $3
million needed to complete construction.

The 6000-seat Sundome is one of the requirements for Townsville to gain entry to
the NBL.

Foundations had just been completed when workers were moved off the site on
Friday.

The managing director of Miller and Baldwin Construction, Mr Arthur Baldwin,
said money had ""dried up".

The Sundome is owned by the Townsville basketball community, but its
construction is underwritten by the Townsville Suns' franchise holder Shine On.

Shine On chairman Mr John Lyons called an emergency meeting on Friday afternoon
and called on the State Government to guarantee a loan to finance construction.

""I telephoned Mr Ahern and he promised he would put the issue to Cabinet on
Monday," Mr Lyons said. ""We hope to have an answer by the end of the week."

Mr Lyons told Mr Ahern that, while the Suns would be the stadium's anchor
tenant, it was a venue for the whole community.

Mr Lyons said Shine On was considering three options to raise the $3 million
needed.

They were: to obtain a loan with a State Government guarantee; to sign a loan
and marketing deal with Metway Bank; to borrow the money on the commercial
market.

He said the most attractive proposal was a Metway Bank deal backed by the State
Government.

The Metway Bank package deals with marketing and sponsorship benefits as well as
the loan.

""We're embarrassed about the delay, but we're trying to do the best deal for
Townsville Basketball Incorporated, which will eventually control the stadium,
and the community," he said.

""The Sundome is not just for basketball; it's for the community.

It can be used for anything from theatre to indoor rodeos, trade shows, seminars
and educational purposes.

""It will be a facility no less important in Townsville than the Gabba and Lang
Park are to Brisbane and that is why we have approached the Government to
provide a guarantee similar to the support they were given.

""The Sundome is no less deserving."

Mr Lyons said Shine On and its shareholders had ploughed $400,000 into the
construction of the Sundome.

The Townsville City Council had waived costs of almost $200,000 in work carried
out on the complex, he said.

                         Indianapolis Business Journal

                                 April 18, 2005

City ups charter aid;
Loan program to help schools land financing for facilities

BYLINE: ANDREA MUIRRAGUI DAVIS ADAVIS@IBJ.COM

SECTION: Vol. 26; No. 6; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 913 words


Indianapolis leaders are lending a helping hand and the city's strong credit
rating to charter school operators intent on building a different kind of
educational environment, often from scratch.

Charters receive tuition support payments from the state, but unlike other
public schools, they do not get any tax revenue for their buildings.

The facility issue is a big issue, said Mayor Bart Peterson, the only municipal
leader in the country with the power to grant charters. If we are committed to
seeing growth in charter schools, it is important to find a way to get past
that.

Enter the Indianapolis Bond Bank, which will administer the loan program. Backed
by $ 2 million in private guarantees and the heft of the city's pledge, it will
set up a $ 20 million line of credit with Bank One and make loans to individual
charter schools.

This is a godsend, said Reid Litwack, board president at KIPP Indianapolis, a
charter school that will apply for a loan to add onto its rented space in an
Indianapolis Housing Agency community center. If we didn't have this program, I
honestly don't know what we'd do.

Schools can borrow up to $ 750,000, and repay the loans with interest over five
to seven years. They also will contribute to two reserve funds, creating a
self-perpetuating safeguard against default.

Baltimore-based Annie E. Casey Foundation and New York-based Local Initiatives
Support Corp. are starting the first reserve with a pair of 10-year, $ 1 million
guarantees. Money will change hands only if a loan is not repaid.

We hope we don't ever have to draw on that, said city charter schools Director
David Harris. We want to be conservative so there won't be defaults.

Schools will be required to deposit one year's worth of payments into the first
reserve over a period of years. They will contribute the same amount to the
second reserve when the loan is closed.

Indianapolis' loan guarantee is essentially the back-up plan to the back-up
plan's back-up plan. The City-County Council would be asked for an appropriation
to repay the debt only if the two reserves are depleted.

Still, that pledge was key to getting the program off the ground, Harris said,
because it lowered interest rates and made the program more affordable.

Facility financing is a challenge for charter schools nationwide, as new often
grass-roots organizations mobilize to find new ways to deliver education. Their
startup status poses a problem for many schools, and the fact that state funding
doesn't start flowing right away complicates matters.

Facilities are the most significant problem facing charter schools around the
country, said Greg Richmond, president of the Virginia-based National
Association of Charter School Authorizers. And it is the one most outside the
control of the folks trying to start the school.  If you have to use everything
you have just to stay afloat, you're probably not going to be able to get money
for a building.

Time solved the problem for Irvington Community School, a Ball State
University-sponsored school that welcomed its first students in 2002 in space
borrowed from a neighborhood church.

In January, it moved into a $ 4.2 million facility on almost four acres thanks
to a loan from Old National Bank backed by LISC and a Massachusetts-based
charter support organization.

Two years ago, we would have been laughed out of the [bank], said school
President Tim Ehrgott. We had no history, no credit. But we've been able to get
to the point where people took us seriously.

Others have had more difficulty.

Mayor-sponsored Charles A. Tindley Accelerated School delayed opening for a year
after its plans to lease a former Cub Foods store in the Meadows fell through.

When you're starting a new school you're a new entity with zero credit, said
Marcus Robinson, Tindley's principal and CEO. People are hesitant to even lease
you space without collateral.

Tindley found a savior in Health & Hospital Corporation of Marion County, which
floated a $ 4 million municipal bond to help the school acquire and renovate the
one-time grocery store. It opened last year.

The city's loan program will provide a similar lifeline for those who aren't as
lucky, Robinson said.

Indiana charters can borrow money from the state's Common School Fund to cover
initial operating expenses, but not capital costs. Lawmakers considered a
measure this year that would have allowed the state to use the fund's interest
balance to match federal facility grants, but the bill didn't get far.

NACSA's Richmond called Indianapolis' solution very creative.

Authorizers usually have not played significant roles in solving the facility
financing issue, he said. But it looks like the attitude toward that is starting
to change.

Indeed, Harris hopes the loan program is imitated elsewhere as the charter
movement continues to pick up steam.

This is a way to break down barriers and get more schools open, the city charter
director said. We'd like to create a climate that is more hospitable for
charters.

Harris and others have been working with the help of a $ 1.6 million grant from
the Richard M. Fairbanks Foundation to encourage successful charters to
replicate their programs in Indianapolis. Finding an answer to the facility
question helps, he said.

The growth of charters has been on a good pace, concurred Peterson, who has
authorized a dozen schools since 2001. It's likely to drop off if the facility
issue isn't addressed.

Tuskegee Council still discussing urgent care commitment

BYLINE: The Tuskegee News staff

LENGTH: 443  words


A second public hearing will be conducted by the Tuskegee City Council to
discuss a request for the City to guarantee a $75,000 portion of a loan to
support an urgent care facility for the community.

That hearing will be held at 6:30 p.m. during the Tuesday, April 28 regular
meeting of the City Council. A initial hearing on the issue that lasted 90
minutes was held at the April 14 Council meeting.

The Utilities of Board of Tuskegee has already agreed to guarantee $75,000 of an
overall loan that would be obtained from PNC Bank in Tuskegee by the Medical
Clinic Board of Tuskegee.

The overall loan needed for the start-up costs for the urgent care center
located in the old Comprehensive Health building in Tuskegee would be for
$250,000.

Dr. Karl Sterlin, who would operate the urgent care business in the building
owned by Dr. Fazle Matin, is expected to pledge $50,000 of his own money to
secure the loan with the $150,000 guaranteed by the UBT and Council at $75,000
each.

A financial plan for the urgent care facility projects that after several months
operation fueled by the startup loan, the business should begin making a profit
and be self-sustaining.

Council member At-Large Tony Haygood expressed several concerns about the
economic projections. Also a member of the UBT, Haygood was the only member of
that board voting against guaranteeing the $75,000.

In other business at the April 14 meeting:

The council received information that the old Salem Nursing Home that was closed
because of financial issues and purchased by Clarence Ball will be given to the
City. Ball also owns Magnolia Nursing Home in Tuskegee and several other homes
in the state. His corporation will retain the 122 beds that went with Salem
Nursing Home.

Ball has plans to expand Magnolia Haven and build a new facility near the
eastern portion of Macon County to utilize those beds.

An organization called the House of Moses has requested that the City allow the
property to be used by the group to provide housing for homeless veterans.
Consideration of that request is in the early stages.

Council approved a letter of intent from Pleasant Paper Company to locate in the
Tuskegee Commerce Park. The letter assures that the company would have a
location once it moves forward with financing for a business that would take raw
material and make paper products such as toilet paper and paper towels. No
details were provided about the number of employees or start-up date for the
company.

City Manager Harvey Smith said night clubs in the City were in compliance with
the ordinance governing them with the possible exception of getting all security
personnel certified by the State.
