                              The American Banker

USDA Guarantees Ignite Banks' Rural-Area Lending;
Obscure program furthers economic development by way of movie theaters, health
clinics, service stations

                           April 18, 2001, Wednesday

BY BEN JACKSON



The Department of Agriculture's lending to movie theaters, factories, and gas
stations has risen 43.4% in the past five years.

That's no misprint.

Though better known for its lending to farmers and ranchers, the department has
steadily bulked up its Business and Industry Guarantee Loan Program.

The program lends to any rural business that gives economic opportunity to
people living in areas with populations of less than 50,000.

Since fiscal year 1996 the program has grown from $699.6 million to $1.03
billion. The agency has budgeted almost $1.56 billion for it in 2001.

"This is a rural economic development program to create and save jobs in rural
areas," said Gerald Townsend, director of community and business programs in the
department's Rural Business and Cooperative Service in Illinois. An agency
report boasts that its programs created or saved more than 29,000 jobs last
year.

The agency's growing commitment to the program is good news for banks that
otherwise might be hesitant to lend in slow-growing rural markets.

About 400 banks now participate in the program, and more are clamoring to get
in, according to Bill Hagy, acting administrator of the Rural Business and
Cooperative Service.

The only problem, according to bankers and other observers, is that the business
and industry loan program gets too little funding from Congress.

At the end of fiscal year 2000, 376 loan guarantees totaling $906.5 million went
unprocessed because funding had run out.

"The demand has continued to increase so that we have almost as much demand as
amounts outstanding," Mr. Hagy said.

Why has demand exploded in the past five years?

First, the agency increased the amount that could be extended to one borrower
from $10 million to $25 million.

Then, in 1996, it began a concerted marketing effort and streamlined its
processes. Finally, it broadened the kinds of eligible businesses to include
hotels and motels.

Now just about the only screening requirement is that the business borrower must
be at least 51%-owned by a U.S. citizen.

The program guarantees up to 80% of a bank's loss if a loan defaults. It also
gives banks increased liquidity and fee income, as well as more flexibility in
the loans they can make.

Liquidity and Fee Income

The guarantee loan program helps banks increase liquidity because they can sell
the guaranteed portion on the secondary market.

Moreover, the guaranteed portion does not count against a bank's lending limit.

Butte Community Bank in Chico, Calif., has 24 of the program's loans in its
portfolio and plans another 10 this year. Glenn Rilinger, vice president of the
$220 million-asset bank, said the guarantees have helped Butte broaden its
portfolio.

"For a small bank our size, we have a legal lending limit based on our capital.
With the guarantee at 80% or 90%, we can leverage ourselves to fund projects
beyond that limit," Mr. Rilinger said.

Butte made its first such guaranteed loan in 1996 after the department's
marketing campaign made it aware of the program, he said.

Though Butte and other banks sell the guaranteed portion of the loans, they
retain the loan servicing and thus fee income.

In addition, banks are not required to back the guaranteed portion with loan
-loss reserves.

As a result, said Dennis McMillan, senior vice president of $1.3 billion- asset
Busey Bank in Urbana, Ill., return on equity has gone as high as 30% on some
guaranteed loans.

Mr. McMillan said that Busey, which uses the program mainly to lend to rural
manufacturers, has made several million dollars of guaranteed loans and is
currently working on one for $500,000.

His goal is for all of Busey's 10 commercial lenders to make a loan guaranteed
under the program this year.

Patrick Kerrigan, program manager for the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corp.,
which helps banks sell the guaranteed portion of these loans, said that banks
regularly earn returns of 15% to 25% on the agency-guaranteed loans.

"They get liquidity, they get fee income, and they get a nice return on
investment," Mr. Kerrigan said.

Loan Flexibility

Liquidity and fee income aside, Mr. Rilinger at Butte said he likes the
flexibility offered by the business and industry loans.

One Small Business Administration criterion, he said, "is that it has to be a
for-profit business. The USDA doesn't have that requirement."

Mr. Rilinger added that before Butte began using the USDA program it did not
make many loans to nonprofits. "We would not have the terms they needed and
maybe not want to be involved."

He said that nonprofits often are funded by donations that fluctuate annually,
making the credit risk too high for the bank's loan criteria.

But with the guarantees Butte has loaned to such projects as a foster care
agency and a low-income health clinic. These nonprofits are eligible so long as
they further the agency's mission of creating or saving jobs in rural areas.
Butte also has used the program to lend to movie theaters and storage
facilities.

Thomas G. Zernick, president of the $4.8 billion-asset Republic Bank in Lansing,
Mich., said the business and industry program has allowed Republic to extend the
terms it offers to customers and offer loans for projects like gas stations.

Joe O. Knight, president of the $200 million-asset Heritage Bank in Neligh,
Neb., said the guaranteed loans shore up Heritage's loan packages.

"If we look at a business and it doesn't have a substantial amount of equity
going into it, then we will go and get a guarantee," he said.

Heritage began participating in the program six years ago. Since then, Mr.
Knight estimated, the bank has made $1.25 million of guaranteed loans to
borrowers ranging from owners of a Subway sandwich shop to employees of an auto-
parts dealership who needed funds to buy out the owner. He estimated that
Heritage will add $500,000 of such loans to its portfolio this year.

Mr. Knight said the only drawback to processing the agency-guaranteed loans is
paperwork. So on loans of up to $100,000 he uses the SBA's low-documentation
loan program, and on those of more than $100,000 he recommends the business and
industry program.

Steven J. Pricco, director of government-guaranteed lending at the $11.9
billion-asset Michigan National Bank in Farmington Hills, said he had heard from
a previous boss that the paperwork for business and industry loans was
"cumbersome" and therefore had formed a bad impression of the program. "My boss
had done a deal with the USDA and vowed never to do it again," he said.

But by the time he joined Michigan National in 1997 the agency had streamlined
the process, and the bank has been a customer ever since.

Mr. Hagy of the Rural Business and Cooperative Service acknowledged that the
paperwork was onerous, and he credits the streamlining efforts for improving
participation.

"I think we went from 18 forms to six forms," he said.

The Problem

"The biggest issue we have with the USDA is that we can't get enough funding
nationally," Republic Bank's Mr. Zernick said. "We run out of money in Michigan
by the summer."

Though Congress continues to increase funding for the business and industry
program, demand has never been higher.

Simply put, lenders prefer the security of the guarantee when making loans in
rural markets.

Mr. Pricco of Michigan National advised borrowers to submit applications by May
to avoid being left out.

The agency's own representatives said the program could use more support from
Congress.

Mr. Hagy said that, though the amount pledged for guarantees may be close to
$1.6 billion in 2001, the actual amount spent on the program is just $13.4
million.

"We don't see anything happening where the demand will be less in the next few
year," Mr. Hagy said.

Mr. Townsend, the program's Illinois representative, said the USDA actively
promotes the program to banks because it is cheaper for the government to
guarantee a loan than to make one.

"We're so tight on resources out there we need the partnership with banks," he
said.

               National Post (f/k/a The Financial Post) (Canada)

                             June 21, 2011 Tuesday
                                Toronto Edition

Cityto take over financially troubled Etobicoke hockeyarena; Arena on verge of
defaulting on $35.5M in loans

BYLINE: Natalie Alcoa, National Post

SECTION: TORONTO; Pg. A12

LENGTH: 573  words


Mayor Rob Ford's executive committee voted to take over a financially troubled
hockey arena in Etobicoke that had been run by the Lakeshore Lions Club, and
took steps to curtail its practice of acting as a loan guarantor.

The Lakeshore Lions Arena, practice rink for the Toronto Maple Leafs and Marlies
and home of the Hockey Hall of Fame archives, is on the verge of defaulting on
various loans, $35.5-million of which is backstopped by the city.

City staff recommended seizing control of the facility, also known as the
Mastercard Centre for Hockey Excellence, in order to prevent the default, which
would put the city on the hook. The intent is to find new operators or owners.
If approved by council, the city will establish a new city services corporation
called the Lakeshore Arena Corp. to run the arena, and assume its $43million
debt. The executive also authorized a line of credit of $1-million for the
corporation to help with cash flow during slower periods.

The arena brings in about $3.7-million in revenue, but that's not enough to keep
it afloat. Rising interest rates, plus second-floor space that has never been
rented out, tipped the scales against the Lions financially, staff said.
"Sometimes people's dreams exceed their ability to pay for it and that's the
situation we find ourselves in here. But this still is a grand facility," Deputy
Mayor Doug Holyday told the committee.

Other members of the executive were visibly irked by the turn of events and
questioned staff as to why they were, in the words of Councillor David Shiner
(Willowdale), being asked to "absolve" the Lions of their management
responsibilities. He convinced his colleagues to strip the interior and exterior
of the arena of Lions signage. A plaque commemorating the group's historical
contributions will be displayed.

"There has to be a price for making a mistake," said Mr. Shiner. "They dropped
this in the city's lap because we trusted them for $35-million and they couldn't
find a fix for it themselves."

That set the stage for a debate on loan guarantees, with Budget Chief Mike Del
Grande arguing the city should stop doing it altogether. The city is currently
guaranteeing $244.5-million worth of capital loans for organizations that
promote sports, culture and community-based activities such as the Evergreen
Brickworks, Artscape, Bixi, Toronto's parent company and Ricoh Coliseum. Build
Toronto, the city's real estate arm, has the largest loan guarantee, valued at
$160-million.

"We don't have people coming here for their mortgages," said Mr. Del Grande.
"I'm saying we can't continue the way we're going. We just got stung on the
Lions arena . Why should the taxpayer be responsible for loan guarantees for
private organizations? They shouldn't be."

The executive voted to phase out existing capital loan guarantees for non-city
agencies, boards and commissions, as they expire.

The executive committee's decision does not affect guarantees of operating lines
of credit to cultural organizations. The Toronto Symphony Orchestra, for
example, has a $3-million line of credit guaranteed by the city; the Toronto
Philharmonia has defaulted on its $250,000 line of credit.

Councillor Denzil MinnanWong, a member of the executive, said groups can still
ask for loan guarantees. "It would depend upon the application, who the group
was, how solid they were and the benefit to the city," he said.

                          The Globe and Mail (Canada)

                              Correction Appended

B.C. First Nations eye LNG equity stakes;
Not satisfied with mere jobs, say aboriginal leaders who are seeking backers in
the Far East and loan guarantees in Ottawa

BYLINE: SHAWN McCARTHY

SECTION: REPORT ON BUSINESS: CANADIAN; ENERGY; Pg. B4

LENGTH: 641 words

DATELINE: GATINEAU, QUE.


First Nations leaders in British Columbia are seeking multibillion-dollar loan
guarantees from the federal government to enable them to take ownership stakes
in various liquefied natural gas projects being planned in the province, and
have also travelled to China and Japan looking for backers.

The bid to raise financing comes as the Assembly of First Nations launches an
effort to forge an aboriginal national energy strategy, which would be based on
treaty rights, sustainable development and the need for impoverished communities
to benefit from the massive resource development that Canada expects over the
next decade.

"What is absolutely clear is that unless First Nations are included as full
partners in development, the prospects for projects proceeding are negligible,"
said Dave Porter, chief executive of British Columbia First Nations Energy and
Mining Council.

He said aboriginal communities will resort to the courts if Ottawa presses ahead
over their objections with pipeline projects such as Enbridge Inc.'s Northern
Gateway.

But Mr. Porter said there is an opportunity for industry to partner with First
Nations, especially on proposals to develop shale gas fields in northeastern
B.C., and build liquefaction plants on the coast to ship the LNG to Asia. There
are a dozen projects under consideration, and the British Columbia government is
eager to have at least five approved by the end of 2015.

Ottawa has supported Newfoundland and Labrador's Lower Churchill project with a
$5-billion loan guarantee, and Mr. Porter said the Harper government has
described resource projects in B.C. as being in the national interest as the
country looks to diversify its energy export market away from a near-total
reliance on the United States, to access fast-growing Asia.

"If these projects are deemed to be in the national interest, then surely we're
going to see a positive response," Mr. Porter said. "Because in my view, Canada
will not reach its full economic potential until it reconciles the place of
First Nations, which means direct involvement in joint planning, joint
decision-making, and the sharing in the benefits. And that means more than jobs
and contracts, it means ownership."

Spokesmen for Natural Resources Minister Joe Oliver were unable to comment late
Wednesday on the B.C. First Nations' request.

Some B.C. aboriginal communities are already pursuing ownership interest in LNG
projects.

The Haisla First Nation is working with three separate projects Kitimat, run by
Chevron Corp. and Apache Corp.; the project led by Royal Dutch Shell PLC, and
the B.C./ LNG project led by Malaysia's Petronas.

At a conference across the river from Ottawa, AFN leaders said aboriginal
communities need their own national energy strategy that would give them a road
map for dealing with government and industry on resource development, similar to
the provincial effort led by Alberta Premier Alison Redford.

"We want to find a way to articulate the leadership's view and vision of how
they want to be involved in resource development in Canada, and how we see
resource development incorporating our view on issues such as consultation and
managing the lands and sustainability," said Richard Nerysoo, president of the
Gwich'in tribal council in the Northwest Territories and co-chair of the AFN's
economic development committee.

But the AFN chiefs face their own internal challenges as they look to become
partners in oil and gas development.

The push for LNG development is raising fears about fracking in northeastern
B.C.

Activist Caleb Bain warned that aboriginal communities are threatened by
large-scale development of shale gas, with hydraulic fracturing posing a threat
to local water sources.

He urged the AFN chiefs to focus any national strategy on renewable energy
development, rather than fossil fuels.

published.

                         Telegraph Herald (Dubuque, IA)

                             March 3, 2011 Thursday

Bernard, Sherrill receive community grants

SECTION: A; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 115 words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture Office of Rural Development has awarded
grants to two local Iowa communities through the Community Facility Grant
Program.

Bernard will receive $5,530 to purchase a generator to power water and sewer
systems during a power outage and to equip the fire and rescue departments.

The Sherrill Fire Department will receive $5,700 to purchase 15 new sets of
firefighting bunker gear and $6,400 to purchase a cardiac defibrillator.

According to the Department of Agriculture, the Community Facilities Program
provides grants, loans and loan guarantees to assist in the development of
essential community facilities in rural areas and towns of up to 20,000 in
population.

                Intelligencer Journal (Lancaster, Pennsylvania)

                           February 4, 2009 Wednesday

Manheim Hears Plan For Project

BYLINE: Rochelle A. Shenk, Correspondent

SECTION: B; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 377  words

DATELINE: Lancaster, PA


BY ROCHELLE A. SHENK

Correspondent

Manheim Borough Council reviewed Manheim Borough Authority's plans for financing
the project to upgrade its wastewater treatment facility Jan. 27.

Kathleen Gray, the authority solicitor, gave the update of the project. She
explained upgrades for the plant are needed to comply with new regulations that
will take effect in 2010 for the Chesapeake Bay Tributary Strategy.

Mayor Randy Kreiser said, "The authority is in a tough spot that's not of their
making. The plant project has to be done. The regulations are being imposed by a
higher level of government."

The cost of the upgrades is estimated at $10 million, and the authority is
planning to submit a grant application to the state Department of Community &
Economic Development and Department of Environmental Protection to help defray
the cost of the upgrade.

An eligibility requirement for this funding is that the facility must serve more
than one municipality. The authority serves approximately 2,300 homes and
businesses in Manheim Borough and customers in parts of Penn and Rapho
townships.

Gray said the authority also must show that it has matching funds available, so
it will be looking at proposals for a $5 million loan that's guaranteed by the
borough. She said it is common for municipalities to guarantee loans made by
municipal authorities.

"If the borough doesn't guarantee the loan, most likely the banks won't agree to
it and the project cannot be done, which means that the authority won't be in
compliance with DEP regulations and DEP will come down on them," she said.

The deadline was Jan. 29 for loan proposals. The funding package will be
submitted to council for approval this month and then submitted to the state.
The authority expects to hear the results of the grant funding by late summer.
In the meantime, plans for the plant upgrade are being completed and are
expected to be put out to bid this spring.

"The $5 million loan will be needed not only for the grant application but also
as a bridge loan," Gray said. She said when the authority receives word about
the grant, it will review the financing plan for the project and a rate increase
may be needed. She promised to keep council updated on the grant process and any
proposed rate increase.

                  The Press-Republican (Plattsburgh, New York)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            November 9, 2010 Tuesday

Funding gives boost to Essex County businesses

BYLINE: Dan Heath, The Press-Republican, Plattsburgh, N.Y.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 728 words


Nov. 09--CHESTERFIELD -- Three businesses in Essex County have received USDA
grants and guaranteed loans for energy-efficiency projects.

U.S. Rep. Bill Owens joined U.S. Department of Agriculture Rural Development
Energy Coordinator Scott Collins Monday at Essex Box and Pallet in the Town of
Chesterfield to announce the funding.

ESSEX BOX AND PALLET

Essex Box and Pallet will get a $225,000 grant through the U.S. Department of
Agriculture Rural Development's Rural Energy for America Program. The USDA also
guaranteed a loan from Champlain National Bank for $450,000. And the Essex
County Industrial Development Agency provided Essex Box and Pallet with a
$225,000 loan.

Owners Michael and Colleen Lemza will use the $900,000 to expand their
pallet-manufacturing business to include wood-pellet production.

The pellets would be made from sawdust and wood residue by-products from the
pallet-making process.

"It's been a long process getting to this point," Mr. Lemza said.

Collins said the Rural Energy for America Program is funded through the 2008
federal Farm Bill. It allows eligible farms and rural small businesses to get
funds to improve energy efficiency.

"This project fits that to a T."

Collins said he's excited about the project. Local production of wood pellets
could help lower heating costs for area residents, he said.

Essex Box and Pallet has 12 employees now, and Mr. Lemza said they are likely to
add two when the pellet manufacturing starts. The company could eventually add
up to eight workers if demand requires.

"Our goal is to produce pellets by the end of May or early June," Mr. Lemza
said.

Owens said this is a great example of collaboration between the public and
private sectors. It is also a way to take advantage of the many opportunities
for bio-mass energy production available in the Adirondacks, he said.

"This is proof these kind of projects are going forward and creating jobs."

Essex County IDA Co-Executive Director Carol Calabrese said the agency provided
funding through the Essex County Economic Development Revolving Loan Fund.

"We've been working with Michael and Colleen for the past 2 1/2 years on this
project," she said.

The use of a waste by-product for energy is a fabulous example of green energy,
Calabrese said.

"This is the truest form of green I can think of."

Chesterfield Town Supervisor Gerald Morrow said most people don't realize the
obstacles the Lemzas faced as they worked to expand their business. It was done
despite the difficult economic climate in Essex County, New York state and the
Adirondack Park, he said.

"Essex County and the Town of Chesterfield owes them a debt of gratitude."

WILLSBORO SCHOOL

Collins also announced a $600,000 loan guarantee to Stonebrook Properties.

Stonebrook owner Eli Schwartzberg plans to convert the former Willsboro School
building into Champlain Valley Senior Community, a 62-room assisted-living
facility.

The loan guarantee will be used to install a wood-pellet boiler to heat the
facility.

Schwartzberg said the availability of high-quality wood pellets produced 20
minutes away will save him a lot in transportation charges.

"I'm going to be a local customer for this (Essex Box and Pallet) project."

He said renovations should start within three months and be done by late 2011 or
early 2012.

The project also previously received a $5.3 million loan guarantee through the
USDA Business and Industry Loan program.

It is an ideal location, Schwartberg said, because it's within easy walking
distance to the library, restaurants and churches. It is also a short ride to
catch the Essex ferry to Burlington.

ESSEX FARM

The third announcement was for a $40,780 USDA grant to Essex Farm.

It will be used to install a 25-kilowatt solar photovoltaic system at the farm.

"All told, we have had a pretty significant impact in Essex County through this
program this year," Collins said.

Hoeven Announces $5.5 Million in USDA Loans, Grants to North Dakota

LENGTH: 388  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the Senator John Hoeven, U.S Government has issued the following news
release:

Senator John Hoeven today announced that the U.S. Department of Agriculture
(USDA) is awarding $5.5 million in loans and grants to six North Dakota
organizations. The funds are made available through USDA's Community Facilities
program, which provides loans, loan guarantees and grants to local governments
and nonprofits to construct, enlarge or improve community facilities for health
care, public safety and public services in rural areas and towns with
populations up to 20,000.

"We are experiencing tremendous growth across North Dakota and we continue
working to invest in important infrastructure to keep our communities vibrant,"
said Hoeven. "These USDA grants will help to construct and renovate community
buildings to meet the needs of the people they serve."

The loans and grants are awarded as follows:

Candeska Cikana Community College - a $4,491,250 loan to construct a
centrally-located new Head Start facility and a $145,302 grant to construct the
second phase of the campus' cultural center, which will be used to house
artifacts and hold community events
    Maddock Opera House - a $226,900 loan and a $50,000 grant to renovate the
top floor and stairway
    Fort Berthold Community College - a $145,302 grant to add a greenhouse
addition
    Sitting Bull College - a $145,302 grant to construct the second phase of the
campus' paving and lighting project, which will connect the northeastern and
southeastern portions of the campus
    Turtle Mountain Community College - a $145,302 grant to upgrade and replace
roofing on the campus' medical building
    United Tribes Technical College - a $145,302 grant to renovate two streets,
correcting drainage problems on campus

As a member of the U.S. Senate Agriculture and Appropriations Committees, Hoeven
continues working to support rural development programs, which promote
infrastructure investment in and help grow North Dakota's rural communities. The
senator also served on the Senate-House Conference Committee that negotiated the
final version of the new five-year farm bill which reauthorized and strengthened
programs in support of rural communities.

                            Buffalo News (New York)

                            August 2, 2007 Thursday
                                 SOUTH EDITION

Ice arena is closer to reality

BYLINE: By Karen Robinson - NEWS STAFF REPORTER

SECTION: LOCAL; Pg. B3

LENGTH: 295 words


The proposed ice arena in East Aurora got a significant financial boost
Wednesday when it received a $4 million federal loan guarantee that local
organizers hailed as a critical step in moving the project forward.

"This is a tremendous milestone for us," said Anthony DiFilippo IV, president of
the Aurora Ice Association that first proposed the project seven years ago.
"This loan commitment and guarantee moves us much closer toward making the Time
Warner Cable Ice Centre a reality."

The office of Sen. Charles E. Schumer, D-N.Y., announced the federal loan
backing that was awarded through the federal Department of Agriculture's Rural
Development program as a community-facility guaranteed loan.

"This is great news for East Aurora," Schumer said in a prepared statement. "Not
only will local students find a safe haven for socializing, exercise and
recreation, but also the rink will offer services for adults, high schools and
the physically challenged. As the rink attracts business from across the region
by drawing in customers and hosting tournaments, it will serve as an economic
boost for East Aurora and all of Erie County."

The $4 million -- loaned through Citizens Bank, with 90 percent of it guaranteed
by the federal government -- accounts for nearly half of the $8.65 million
project calling for a 68,000-square-foot indoor ice arena with two sheets on
Riley Street, just off Main Street, in the heart of the village.

Despite the significance of the loan and federal backing for the project, which
has been in the making since 1999, the not-for-profit Aurora Ice Association
still must raise about $3.5 million before construction can begin on the rink,
said Carol Halter, project executive director for Aurora Ice Association.

                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                      April 14, 1991, Sunday, City Edition

Playing hardball to lure spring training

BYLINE: KEN MORITSUGU; VICTORIA WHITE

SECTION: CITRUS TIMES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1322 words

DATELINE: INVERNESS



For years, spring training was a low-budget affair played in old wooden stadiums
with splinter-filled seats.

    Those days are fading fast. Spurred in large part by developers, city and
county governments are building multimillion-dollar stadiums to lure teams to
their communities.

    Spring training has become big business. Teams want more than a place to
play ball. They want state-of-the-art stadiums and a larger share of the
revenues to help offset what remains a money-losing venture for them.     Local
governments face difficult decisions on how much they are willing to spend for
the entertainment and economic benefit that spring training only promises to
deliver.

    "Spring training in the past was exactly that," said John Wendel, a Lakeland
sports lawyer. The only purpose was "getting the players ready for the season.
But today, the spring training games have taken on a life of their own."

    So have the related lease negotiations. A case in point is Citrus County's
hot and cold relationship with the Cleveland Indians in its ongoing effort to
lure the team here.

    Here is a look at some of the negotiating points.
 Guarantees "wishful thinking'


   Both sides are looking for what appear to be unprecedented economic
guarantees in the lease. Citrus County wants assurance that it won't have to dip
into property tax revenue to cover the stadium's operating expenses.

    The Indians want at least 5,000 fans to attend each game. While minimum
attendance guarantees have been part of regular season deals, sports lawyers
said they have never heard of one in a spring training lease.

    "I think that's wishful thinking" by the Indians, said Don Miers, manager of
Osceola County's stadium in Kissimmee, where the Houston Astros train. "I don't
see how you can ever do that."

    The Indians initially wanted the county to guarantee that the team would
receive at least the dollar equivalent generated by 5,000 fans a game.

    When the county commissioners balked, the Indians' representative suggested
that the private sector could make that guarantee. That has happened in some
packages offered to sports teams for the regular season, lawyers said.

    In Phoenix, the business community formed a non-profit corporation that made
an attendance guarantee to help lure the former St. Louis Cardinals football
team to that city, said Rick Hillhouse, a sports attorney who represented
Arizona State University, where the Cardinals now play.

    "It simply comes down to reaching out into the community and saying how
badly do you want these people to come here," said Joe Garagiola Jr., a Phoenix
sports lawyer and chairman of the Arizona baseball commission. "You as the
business community stand to benefit from the team being in the community, but
you're going to have to put your money where your mouth is."

 Other areas dip into the coffers


   Citrus County's demand that its property taxes remain untouched may derive
from the experience of other spring training hosts.  Several local governments
said they routinely use property tax or tourist tax revenues to help pay
operating costs.

    Plant City dips into its general fund each year to make up a deficit of $
35,000 to $ 70,000 at the Cincinnati Reds spring training facility, according to
city manager Nettie Draughon.

    Sarasota expects to pull $ 167,000 out of its general fund this year to help
pay the $ 400,000 operating costs of the Chicago White Sox stadium, said Pat
Calhoon, sports facilities manager for the city.

    Osceola County makes up a $ 500,000 annual shortfall with tourist tax
revenue, Miers said.

    "We lose money on paper, however it's no big deal when you're pumping $
15-million (annually) into the local economy," he said.  Also, Miers noted, the
county is providing entertainment to residents.

    For Dunedin, baseball is not a money loser. Unlike many other spring
training deals, the team the Toronto Blue Jays pays the cost of maintaining the
facilities.

    The city also had an advantage in owning an existing Florida State League
stadium. The facility had to be upgraded at a cost of more than $ 2-million, but
that's much less than building even a low-end stadium from scratch.

    Revenues from the games cover the city's operating expenses and the annual
payments on the loan for stadium construction costs.

    "Our objective was to make it self-sufficient so we have not raised any
taxes to pay for it," said City Manager John Lawrence.

 Dividing the revenues


   The rising popularity of spring training has turned it into an attractive
revenue source for teams. With cities and counties competing to be spring
training venues, the teams have been able to extract a higher share of the
revenue and better facilities as well.

    "I think in years past, teams just didn't focus that closely on spring
training," Garagiola said. "Now they're saying, well shoot, if we get 100,000
people going through here, the whole gross on this thing's going to jump up over
a million dollars, and if there's that kind of money being generated around
here, maybe we ought to take some of it when we leave."

    The revenue sources include ticket sales, scoreboard and outfield fence
advertising, food anddrink sales, souvenir and program sales  and media
broadcast rights.

    Sometimes, the city or county is allowed to put a surcharge on the ticket
price to raise more revenue.

    About the only thing that's decided is broadcast rights: The teams always
seem to get all the media money. The division of the remaining revenues varies
considerably from lease to lease.

    In some leases, the local governments don't rely solely on stadium revenues
for funds. Instead, the team pays a flat rent and turns over a percentage of the
revenues on top of that. The Minnesota Twins, for example, will pay Lee County $
200,000 this year.

    A flat rent is less risky than a revenue percentage. If several games are
rained out or canceled by a strike, governments relying on a share of the
revenues will get less money.

    Because of last year's baseball strike, Dunedin had to borrow money from a
self-insurance fund to cover its stadium loan payments, Lawrence said. Lee
County uses the Twins annual payment to help pay off its $ 15.6-million stadium.


    "We wanted a guaranteed thing," said Jim Lavender, director of the county
planning and construction division. "Even if there's no spring training, they
pay."

 Getting the ball rolling


   In Citrus County's negotiations, the Indians drew up the first draft of the
lease. That may have saved the county some attorneys' fees, but it left the
commission with a proposal it was unhappy with.

  "To take the upper hand, I would have asked you for $ 40,000 or $ 50,000" for
fees, assistant county administrator Steve Wylie told commissioners Tuesday. "We
can throw the document away and pay (sports attorney) Mr. (David) Cardwell to
write a new one (but) that's very expensive."

    Instead, the commissioners opted to have Cardwell respond. In a letter to
the Indians representative last week, he raised numerous objections to the
proposed lease.

    In Dunedin, the city drew up the initial draft, but many of its proposals
ended up on the cutting room floor after negotiations, Lawrence said.

    Somebody always has to start the ball rolling by writing a draft, Garagiola
said. "It's who wants to start the clock running on their lawyer first."

    Both he and Hillhouse praised the Indians' setting the tone of the
negotiations by taking the initiative.

    "The first document that gets put into play is pretty much the core of what
you end up with," Garagiola said.

New LEADER loan fund scheme to help organisations

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 77

LENGTH: 263 words


A new (EURO)25m Community LEADER Loan Fund to assist community based
organisations participate in the new LEADER programme is being launched by Clann
Credo, Ireland's largest provider of finance for community based organisations.

The Fund, formally launched by Heather Humphreys, Minister for Arts, Heritage,
Regional, Rural and Gaeltacht Affairs,, will provide both matching and bridging
loan facilities, specifically geared to the needs of rural groups and
initiatives.

The event was attended by Frank O'Brien, Chair Louth Leader Partnership and
Councillors Emma Coffey and Conor Keenan.

Uniquely the new scheme will require no personal guarantees from community
organisations applying for loan facilities.

Other major features of the new LEADER loan scheme include: * No formal
application form, the process is based on the original LEADER application *
Interest rates are fixed on loans up to five years * Early repayment or extra
payments options with no penalty - including for fixed rate loans * Regionally
based staff with expert local knowledge and experience who provide a one-to-one
service in finalising the loan process with each community organisation *
In-depth advice and free financial health check provided for all applicants,
based on Credo's unequalled 20-year experience in community loan provision.

Clann Credo will be publicising the new loans widely over the coming months and
will be working with local LEADER and community based organisations to ensure
that the maximum benefits can be obtained from the overall LEADER programme. See
also www.clanncredo.ie.

                                  Manila Times

                            July 12, 2006 Wednesday

BIG DEAL SARIAYA PORT PUZZLE

BYLINE: By Dan Mariano

LENGTH: 956 words


THE media and business circles are abuzz with talk about mounting agitation in
the farming and agricultural trading sectors. Disgruntlement is focused on a
P1.6-billion loan unilaterally guaranteed by the government-owned Philippine
Export Import Credit Agency (PHILEXIM).

The loan was used to build a giant post-harvest facility-which turned out to be
a port in far-flung Sariaya, a sleepy town right in the heart of insurgent
country, several kilometers away from where NPA mouthpiece Gregorio Rosal,
a.k.a. Ka Roger, makes his satellite phone calls to media interviewers.

The Sariaya port project was funded by a consortium of banks, which include the
United Coconut Planters Bank, Equitable Bank and ABN-Amro. Praise, er, press
releases had trumpeted the port as the future "grains transshipment hub for the
Philippines and Asia." According to farmers and agricultural traders, such a hub
should contain storage and shipment facilities where they could bring their
corn, rice, tapioca and other farm produce for distribution and/or forward
shipment.

On the surface, this seems like a laudable project. It also appears the
government was right in providing sovereign guarantee to a project that would
make it easy for Filipino farmers to distribute and sell their produce. In
addition, what could earn foreign currency for the country are the grains
traders of other Asian countries who could be invited to store their produce at
Sariaya for onward shipment across the Pacific Ocean to the Western Hemisphere
and elsewhere.

The bright prospects notwithstanding, the postharvest facility has come under
grave doubt. Anxiety over the project appears to be anchored on two major
concerns.

First, who would use a port facility located in a town that has no support
infrastructure? Sariaya is so inaccessible that farmers and traders from other
parts of the country would think twice, maybe thrice, before bringing their
produce there for storage and transshipment.

And if Filipino grains traders would be reluctant to use it, can you imagine how
Thai, Vietnamese, Malaysian and Chinese agri-businessmen would feel? If farmers
from Mindanao would rather not bring their produce to Sariaya, would an
agricultural trader from, say, Kuala Lumpur ship his produce to the
out-of-the-way municipality in a rebel-infested region of the Philippines?

Second, if the port fails to generate local and regional patronage, would not a
loan default be probable? If that happens, who would be left holding the bag?
Since it is a government-guaranteed loan, would not we taxpayers be made to
shoulder the apparent imprudence of PHILEXIM?

PHILEXIM is under the supervision of the Department of Finance; its chairman is
Finance Secretary Margarito Teves.

Mindanao farmers have already relayed their objections to the Sariaya port via
the press. Bringing their produce to faraway and NPA-infested Sariaya-prior to
distribution to the rest of Luzon-is risky enough for them; it would also be
very expensive.

Some quarters want to give the project the benefit of the doubt. If the project
proponents are to be believed, the Sariaya port could transform the country into
an important center of agricultural trading in the Asia-Pacific region. They say
the port could handle very large vessels, referred to as "Cape-size" ships.

The promotional points are valid, but farmers have raised questions about those
giant vessels, too. They say grains traders do not really use such ships because
they are too big and too expensive for their requirements.

Cape-size ships are normally used for transporting oil, cars and heavy
machinery-not grain and similar produce. The port proponents' spin on those
vessels has, in fact, backfired.

It has aroused suspicions that the remote Sariaya port was not really built for
farmers and the agriculture sector, but for the power plants in Pagbilao,
Quezon. And if that was the real intention, then the conditions of the loan and
the guarantee may be up for potential violation.

What farmers and traders know is that the banks lent money, which PHILEXIM
guaranteed, for the construction of a postharvest facility.

Postharvest facilities are supposed to benefit farmers. That may have been why
the government was willing to unilaterally guarantee the P1.6-billion loan-in
behalf of the agriculture sector. However, this same sector now seems leery to
use the facility. And with the target beneficiaries appearing reluctant to use
the post-harvest facility, two other sectors have become very nervous.

The bankers, for one, do not want to see a major default on such a huge loan,
which becomes due in about three years. A default would have disastrous
consequences on the entire banking community. Yet, the Sariaya port has not even
inaugurated its services.

Just as jittery are taxpayers who ultimately foot the bill when a
government-guaranteed loan goes kaput and into default. Right-thinking citizens,
of course, do not want the project to fail. Since it has already been built from
the proceeds of a government-guaranteed loan, they hope that the Sariaya port
would become what the proponents promise it would one day be. But that day
should fall within the repayment period so we taxpayers can sleep in peace.

Teves-along with Agriculture Secretary Domingo Panganiban-should explain why the
government has backed a project that offers so much promise but has been
received with suspicion by its supposed beneficiaries. It is important to help
farmers and agricultural traders understand why sleepy Sariaya was chosen as the
site for this P1.6-billion project.

We also need to hear the two Cabinet members "express confidence" that the loan
would be repaid on schedule and that we, taxpayers, would not be made to carry
yet another financial burden.

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                       June 13, 2005 Monday Home Edition

Golf course needs bailout;
Loan in default; residents may pay

BYLINE: KEVIN DUFFY

SECTION: Metro News; Pg. 1D;

LENGTH: 830 words


Taxpayers could be on the hook if a Fayette County golf course that got an
unusual federal loan guarantee is sold on the courthouse steps in Fayetteville
next month.

Wyant Golf Enterprises, a nonprofit that operates the Palmer Course at Starr's
Mill, has defaulted on its loan payments. So the lender, Heritage Bank,
announced a foreclosure sale July 5 at the county courthouse.

If the bank sells the course, formerly known as Whitewater Country Club, for
less than the debt, taxpayers could end up reimbursing the bank for 90 percent
of the loss.

But it's uncertain whether that will happen.

A group of well-heeled homeowners interested in buying the course had three
separate meetings Friday with Wyant CEO John Boykin, Heritage Bank and Canongate
Golf Club, which owns more than a dozen courses, including the three in nearby
Peachtree City.

The Palmer Course is located in the posh Whitewater Creek subdivision, where
homes sell in the high six figures. Denise Minear, the Whitewater homeowners
association president, said she is confident that a foreclosure sale can be
prevented.

"I truly think that we can put something together to avoid that," she said.
Canongate wants to lease the facility for two years before possibly buying it,
Minear said. Thus far, though, no agreement has been struck that would head off
the sale.

If the sale occurs, Heritage Bank could end up being the high bidder and own the
course, which also would mean no taxpayer bailout.

"Ninety-nine percent of significant commercial properties are taken back by the
lender," said Robert Morgan, the lawyer hired by the bank to conduct the
foreclosure sale. The reason is that the higher bidder has to have cash.

"Who's going to be standing around with $6 million in cash or even $2 million in
cash?" Morgan asked.

Boykin borrowed $6.04 million from Heritage in 2003 to buy and upgrade the
course between Peachtree City and Fayetteville.

The 16-year-old course was designed by golfing great Arnold Palmer but
deteriorated until Boykin made improvements.

"I call this a Mercedes neighborhood with a Chevrolet golf facility," he said
last year.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture's Rural Development branch guaranteed 90
percent of Boykin's loan. The feds will back a loan for a recreational facility
in a rural area --- even an upscale rural area --- provided it's open to the
public and the operator is a nonprofit or an Indian tribe.

A golf course attracts businesses and residents and creates jobs, explained
Arthur Garcia, former administrator of the USDA's Rural Housing Service.

Boykin, who has been involved in the golf business for more than 30 years,
wouldn't discuss his financial problems.

"I don't talk about loan payments," he said. "As far as we're concerned, the
golf course is in great condition." Selling it, he said, "is just a choice we've
made."

Heritage Bank, Canongate and Rural Development would not comment. Rural
Development says less than 2 percent of its loans turn bad.

The feds are guaranteeing loans for nine golf course projects across the
country, including two in Georgia, said Tim McNeilly with Rural Development's
public affairs office. The other Georgia project is a course in Columbia County
near Augusta set to open next month.

In Fayette, homeowners at a recent meeting were pitching a plan to get 300
people to pledge $350 monthly to assume Wyant's loan payments and head off a
sale.

"This is a chance for us to own and operate this club," David Harris, a former
pilot, told the crowd. "This is a very unique opportunity. Time is of the
essence. We really need to get hard pledges on a piece of paper to take to the
bank."

But later at the Friday meeting, Heritage Bank said it would need more money
than that, Minear said. "We were kind of blindsided," she said.

For years, the public golf course has disappointed homeowners wanting more
privacy in their gated community.

Robert Brooks, founder of the Hooters restaurant chain, is a former owner who
battled with residents of Whitewater Creek, home to more than 300 families.
Homeowners sued him and sought the help of the Fayette County Commission to
limit access to their community, without success.

The federal loan guarantee means the course will remain open to the public, at
least part of the time.

As a nonprofit, Wyant Golf Enterprises was supposed to donate surplus cash to
local charities, but "that hasn't worked," Greg Dunn, the County Commission
chairman, said. Dunn is on Wyant's board of trustees.

Competition, the course's location, cheap greens fees and even Boykin's
personality have conspired to hurt the Palmer Course.

"John's a very driven person," said David Simmons, another Wyant trustee. "He
just didn't click with the people out here."

Harris, who's pushing member ownership, said there's plenty of golf on the
Southside, so the Palmer Course has to be exceptional if it's ever going to get
out of the rough.

Enterprises, got a federal loan to work on the Palmer Course at Starr's Mill.

                       The Janesville Gazette (Wisconsin)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           February 14, 2012 Tuesday

Janesville City Council approves incentives for SHINE

BYLINE: Marcia Nelesen, The Janesville Gazette, Wis.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 653 words


Feb. 14--JANESVILLE -- The city of Janesville and SHINE Medical Technologies are
in business after a council vote on Monday approved a $9 million development
agreement.

SHINE CEO Greg Piefer said amid celebration outside council chambers that he
understands why some members of the community might be uncertain about his
company's proposal.

"It's got the word 'nuclear' in it, which is a scary word for a lot of people,"
Piefer said, pledging to get offer more answers for those interested in hearing
them.

City officials have been working on the SHINE project for two years, and Piefer
urged residents to trust them. Piefer praised city officials and said he is
already spreading the word to other interested businesses about how easy it was
to work with them.

The development agreement reached Monday includes $5 million in incentives and
$4 million in a loan guarantee to private investors.

SHINE would make isotopes that would be used in more than 30 different medical
diagnostic imaging procedures.

The 4-1 vote came after a lengthy public hearing and a question-and-answer
period between company officials and council members.

Council members Yuri Rashkin, who voted no, and Tom McDonald, who abstained,
said they did so because the public did not have adequate time to digest the
development agreement. Russ Steeber, Kathy Voskuil, Deb Dongarra-Adams and Sam
Liebert all voted yes.

McDonald said the council has been working on the agreement for two years but
the public had less than a week to review it.

"Two weeks from now, I very well may have voted in favor of this project," he
said.

Piefer said his board of directors needed an answer Monday or he might have been
directed to look at locating in another community.

"I want nothing more than for it to succeed, but somebody has to be fiscally
conservative in this whole mix," Rashkin said. "This is a big gamble."

Councilman Russ Steeber said the vote will define Janesville's future and the
council must be bold and look at the big picture.

"In the long run, the city, the region and the state will benefit from what
we're doing tonight," he said.

Most of the residents who spoke before the vote urged the council to use caution
in the development agreement. They cited environmental concerns, the use of
precious farmland for the project and the cost of the incentives.

Julie Backenkeller asked why the city has to guarantee $4 million in loans for
the project's private investors.

"Why would the taxpayers want to take this risk?" she asked. "I realize we want
to create jobs, but something's not right."

Backenkeller noted the city would run utilities past vacant land to get to the
SHINE facility and warned residents about increased utility costs.

Also, if SHINE is unable to raise enough money to open its facility,
Backenkeller wondered if it would it come back and ask the city for more.

Tim Weber, a local builder, said Janesville needs SHINE to begin its path back
toward becoming the thriving community it once was.

"Is there a risk? Yes, but there always is," he said. "I guarantee you that Mr.
Piefer is refining his business model to ensure success."

Piefer and his team answered questions about the radioactive byproduct, which
would be produced in small amounts. They also stressed the type of uranium used
in production is not the kind used to make nuclear weapons.

While his product is still conceptual, the individual pieces of the production
have all been successfully completed, Piefer said.

When asked why his company needed the $4 million guarantee, Piefer said he
really likes Janesville and wanted to locate here. But it all came down to
competition, and there were four aggressive communities courting the company.

The guarantee is what Janesville needed to do to be competitive, he said.

SBP to make banking services accessible to all: Qasim

LENGTH: 492 words

DATELINE: Pakistan


Pakistan, Sept. 25 -- The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) is committed to use all
possible means to make the banking services accessible to all segments of the
society. This was stated by Managing Director of SBP Banking Services
Corporation Qasim Nawaz while inaugurating a two-day Banking Exhibition in
Gujranwala on Friday, according to a SBP statement released here.

Qasim Nawaz highlighted various initiatives taken or being taken by the State
Bank to facilitate the underserved sectors of the economy in the field of
agriculture, SME (small and medium enterprises) and microfinance which include
ongoing review of policy and regulatory environment to promote SME, agriculture
and micro finance as a viable and mainstream business activity for banking
industry.

In addition, the Central Bank is also undertaking review of existing Prudential
Regulations for SME Financing to develop separate Small Enterprises & Medium
Enterprises. When implemented, this exercise will facilitate small enterprises'
access to bank credit and consequently raise their share in bank loans, he
added.

There is also a move to introduce Credit Guarantee Scheme for Small & Rural
Enterprises (CGS) to share credit risk with banks (upto 40%) with the objective
of increasing banks lending in neglected sectors/ areas. Around 2,000 accounts
have been issued guarantee under CGS. Rs 925 million have been disbursed to
small and rural enterprises under CGS and SBP shares risk worth Rs. 392.5
million with commercial banks for their lending to this sector, he maintained.

Qasim Nawaz said that introduction of Microfinance Credit Guarantee Facility was
also under study for resolving liquidity problems for Microfinance
Banks/Microfinance Institutions. Ten MFBs/MFIs have been provided funding
facilities worth Rs. 2.8 billion under the scheme by banks. SBP BSC has provided
guarantee cover of Rs. 805 million for the lending by commercial banks to
MFB/MFIs.

Moreover, crash training programme will be conducted for the SME and agricutlure
credit officers of banks. Special capacity building programmes for MFBs/MFIs and
Islamic banks are also in the pipeline.

The finance institutions will also be given access to electronic Credit
Information Bureau (CIB) MFIs to assess the credit worthiness and to avoid over
indebtedness of small borrowers, the MD added.

He said linkages will be establlished with all the key stakeholders both at
country level as well as the district/region level to adopt a collaborative
strategy to help facilitate the entrepreneurs and rural communities in accessing
financial services from banks. He was hopeful that the Banking Exhibition at
Gujranwala would go a long way in improving access to finance to the lower

                              The Washington Post

                    June 20, 1979, Wednesday, Final Edition


U.S. Outlines Plan to Improve Rural Transit

BYLINE: By Keith Richburg, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: First Section; A4

LENGTH: 367 words


The Carter administration yesterday announced a package of grants, loans and new
projects aimed at improving public transportation in isolated rural communities.

The plan, disclosed amid much fanfare by three Cabinet secretaries in ceremonies
at the White House, is part of President Carter's forthcoming "comprehensive
rural development policy" that will be introduced later this month, according to
presidental aide Jack Watson.

The transportation segment of that comprehensive plan contains some new
programs, but has the overall effect of consolidating the already existing 114
federal programs currently providing transportation assistance to rural areas.

In the transportation plan, the General Services Asministration and the Defense
Department have agreed to give "several hundred excess or surplus vehicles" to
rural areas, while 1,500 Comprehensive Employment and Training Act workers will
be trained as drivers, mechanics and dispatchers in 13 demonstration states.

Also in the plan was an agreement among several aviation and business regulatory
agencies to target more than $200 million in grants, loans and loan guarantees
to commuter airlines serving rural areas and to small community airports to
upgrade their facilities.

A similar grant and loan package was included for the rehabilitation and repair
of abandoned or seldom used railroad branch lines, at an estimated cost of
$30,000 per mile of track.

The final portion of the rural transportation plan is series of federal
incentives for van pooling and ride sharing.  The incentives listed included an
Energy Department guarantee of 100 percent of needed gasoline for all registered
van pools during shortages, and Transportation Department efforts to find
"reasonably priced" insurance for van pools.

Administration officials, at a White House press briefing before the official
announcement, were reluctant to put a final price tag on the new rural
transportation plan, since most of the money was being redirected from existing
programs.

"It's not new money.  It's money that's being refocused based on these new
priorities," said Larry Gilson, the associate assistanto the president who
conducted the briefing.

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                           November 14, 2006 Tuesday
                                  Main Edition

OUR OPINIONS: USDA has no business doing loans

BYLINE: MAUREEN DOWNEY; Staff

SECTION: EDITORIAL; Pg. 10A

LENGTH: 385 words


The U.S. Department of Agriculture's barmy decision to label a luxury golf club
an "essential" community facility deserving of public assistance shouldn't be
surprising. This is the federal agency that once toyed with classifying ketchup
as a vegetable.

Unfortunately, while the 1981 ketchup caper only left the USDA red-faced, the
golf course fiasco has cost taxpayers more than a million dollars. After the
owner of the former Whitewater Country Club near Peachtree City defaulted on a
USDA-backed loan, taxpayers had to pay $1.8 million to a local bank and four
other note holders.

The USDA has moved far afield; its fundamental mission used to be improving
American agricultural productivity, but now it's apparently also improving the
American quality of life. The agency has opted to do so by guaranteeing loans
--- 553 since 1990 --- for essential community projects that it believes will
energize local economies and enhance rural areas. Those projects include nursing
homes, hospitals, schools and the occasional golf course.

The first questions that Congress ought to ask are why the Rural Development
Branch of the USDA defines any golf course as "essential" and how the Whitewater
Country Club in suburban Fayette County counted as rural development.

When businessman and golfing expert John Boykin came to the USDA's Rural
Development Branch in 2003 with ambitious plans to revitalize a grand 18-hole
course surrounded by swank homes, the agency consented to guarantee 90 percent
of his $6 million loan. Less than a year after Boykin got his money, he stopped
paying on the loans because the golf club was struggling.

Last year, the bank repossessed the course and sold it to a company that
reopened it as private golf club. The sale price did not cover the original
costs, forcing the USDA bailout.

Many federal agencies focus on economic development and community building, but
only one is vested with the responsibility to root out mad cow disease and
monitor bird flu in commercial poultry. Congress ought to suspend this flawed
USDA loan guarantee program until the agency can prove that it's necessary,
beneficial and consistent with its core agricultural mission.

--- Maureen Downey, for the editorial board (mdowney@ajc.com)

                                US Official News

                          February 11, 2015 Wednesday

President's Budget Emphasizes Fuel Cycle, Used Fuel Programs

LENGTH: 898  words

DATELINE: Washington


Nuclear Energy Institute has issued the following press release:

The Department of Energy's fiscal 2016 budget proposal seeks to re-impose a
multibillion-dollar tax for the cleanup of three DOE-owned uranium enrichment
facilities, a move the nuclear energy industry deplores as redundant and unfair.
But other aspects of the budget are more in line with industry goals.

This year marks the sixth time the Obama administration has requested
reinstatement of the decontamination and decommissioning tax, even though
Congress has consistently turned it back.

"We recognize that the federal government has significant budget pressures, but
reinstating unjustified taxes on utility rate payers who have met their funding
obligation while the government has failed to meet its own is outrageously
unfair," NEI Senior Vice President for Governmental Affairs Alex Flint said.
"The uranium enrichment D&D tax proposal should be dead on arrival in Congress."

In other areas, the budget requests $62 million to continue supporting
certification and licensing assistance for the small reactor design being
developed by NuScale under a cost-share public-private partnership with DOE.

The overall fiscal 2016 budget proposal for DOE's Office of Nuclear Energy is
$907.5 million. The request is 9 percent higher than the $863 million requested
for fiscal 2015 and slightly below the $913.5 million enacted by Congress.

The Nuclear Regulatory Commission budget proposal of $1.03 billion is 1.7
percent higher than the enacted budget. Ninety percent of NRC's budget is
recouped via fees from the nuclear energy industry.

Flint said the NRC's oversight priorities merit "close scrutiny" by Congress,
given the industry's strong safety performance and the fact that utilities'
plans for new nuclear generating capacity are still being shaped by the
recession's lingering effects.

"We urge Congress to insist upon NRC adherence to its principles of good
regulation so that nuclear energy facilities can most safely and effectively
meet their customers' need for reliable, clean air power supplies," Flint said.
The industry's priority to ensure public safety "is being challenged by the
surplus of nonessential regulations and directives the NRC has imposed over the
past decade," he said.

Most DOE programs only saw modest changes. However, the administration requested
$217.7 million for fuel cycle R&D, a $20.7 million increase from the $197
million enacted for fiscal 2015.

The budget also zeroes out DOE and NRC programs to train the next generation of
nuclear industry workers and advance nuclear energy education, a move Flint said
makes "no sense." It would eliminate university programs that support
scholarships, fellowships and junior faculty at four-year institutions and
community colleges. The administration has consistently cut these programs,
though Congress has just as consistently provided about $5 million annually.
Used Nuclear Fuel

The administration is requesting $108 million to develop one or more facilities
for used fuel and high-level radioactive waste management using consent-based
siting as recommended by the Blue Ribbon Commission on America's Nuclear Future
in 2012. This represents a significant boost from the $79 million proposed for
fiscal 2015. An additional $3 million is proposed to fund research into disposal
options for some of DOE's high-level waste and used fuel. The administration
included no funds to continue the Yucca Mountain licensing process but proposes
using $24 million from the Nuclear Waste Fund for generic process development
and other non-R&D activities related to used fuel storage, transportation and
disposal.

The administration requests $345 million to continue construction of DOE's Mixed
Oxide Fuel Fabrication Facility in South Carolina, a turnabout from the fiscal
2015 proposal to put the facility into cold standby while DOE researched options
for disposal of surplus plutonium. Congress last year turned back the idea and
funded the facility's continued construction. The MOX fuel, which would be
fabricated from recycled surplus defense-origin plutonium and uranium, is
potentially a fuel for the domestic nuclear energy industry.
Loan Guarantees

Funding for DOE's loan guarantee program remains consistent in this budget
request, with $18.5 billion authority. Last year DOE finalized the first nuclear
energy-specific loan guarantee of  $6.5 billion to Southern Co. and its partners
to help finance the construction of two new reactors at the Plant Vogtle site in
Georgia.

Loan guarantees are not an actual appropriation and, therefore, do not represent
an outlay of taxpayer dollars when the projects they support are successfully
completed. The guarantees aim to boost investor confidence and allow worthy
projects to obtain financing on more reasonable terms that ultimately will lower
the cost of electricity generated by the projects. For nuclear power projects,
recipients must pay a substantial origination fee, negotiations over which
delayed final approval for the Southern Co. loan guarantee.

The accompanying chart shows DOE's budget numbers in categories relevant to the
nuclear energy industry. It will appear in Nuclear Energy Overview periodically,
revised to follow the federal appropriations process through the year.

                               The New York Times

               September 4, 1981, Friday, Late City Final Edition

AILING STEEL PLANT RECOVERS

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS

SECTION: Section D; Page 1, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1651 words

DATELINE: MONESSEN, Pa.


For John Durkin, a longtime steel executive, it has meant 12-hour days in a new
career, when all he had in prospect was the hope of early retirement. For James
A. Sepesky, the Mayor of this city, it has meant adding to services rather than
dealing with a fiscal crisis.

These two men, as well as 13,000 other residents in this community, which lies
30 miles south of Pittsburgh along the Monongahela River, have been involved in
a joint effort of Government and industry the likes of which the steel industry
may never see again.

The project - the addition of a new rail mill at an old steel plant to make it
more competitive - was made possible by Government loan guarantees, most of
which came from a Federal agency that the Reagan Administration is moving to
phase out.

To the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the plant's owner, as well as to
union leaders and state officials, the project represents a model of a how
Government cooperation with private enterprise can revitalize ailing plants.

Competitors Critical

Some other steel companies, however, such as United States Steel, Bethlehem and
CF&I, considered the project unfair to them and challenged it in court. The
modernized plant, they say, will put their mills, built in the 1920's, at a
disadvantage.

The Wheeling-Pittsburgh plant, begun at the turn of the century, employs about
2,000 workers and has long been the keystone of the local economy. Four years
ago, the company, which was suffering heavy losses because of the industry's
depressed order rate, considered closing the plant.

The city and the workers faced the shock of a major shutdown that has struc k su
ch steel cities as Youngstown, Ohio; Johnstown, Pa., and Lackawann a, N.Y.

But Dennis J. Carney, who took over in 1976 as president of Wheeling-Pittsburgh,
the nation's ninth-largest steel company, began a major effort to save the plant
by enlisting the help of politicians, union and community leaders and Federal
agencies.

Loan Guarantees Set Up

Under a Carter Administration program granting $500 million in loan guarantees
to help the steel industry, Wheeling-Pittsburgh was able to put together a plan
to revitalize the plant.

Management received $100 million in loan guarantees from the Economic
Development Administration and another $40 million from the Farmers Home
Administration, and a $10 million loan from the Pennsylvania Industrial
Development Authority. The money was used to build a rail mill at the plant and
to help bring it into compliance with pollution standards.

The loan guarantees were the largest made under the steel program and were a
major example of President Carter's efforts to help revitalize obsolescent
industrial areas.

The program, however, was cut back severely in the last year of the Carter
Administration, which became concerned that the Federal Government would be
drawn into providing still larger loan guarantees to save other major
industries.

U.S. Program Reduced

President Reagan sought to dismantle the Economic Development Administration. It
has survived in much smaller form under the budget reconciliation bill, with the
authority to provide up to $163 million in loan guarantees. And the maximum
amounts to be granted to any company are now in the range of $1 million to $2
million.

Last week Mr. Durkin, the 47-year-old manager of Wheeling-Pittsburgh's new mill,
was preparing to bring the mill's computerized equipment to full production by
next month.

''This is the most advanced mill in the world,'' Mr. Durkin said as he stood on
a catwalk in the white building and watched a red-hot 78-foot rail go through
the final rolling.

The mill, which was built under the technical supervison of Japan's Nippon Steel
Corporation, uses rolling equipment from Kawasaki Heavy Industries and obtained
additional technology from France.

When the mill reaches its full production o f 400,000 tons a year and employs
about 300 workers, it is expected to provide the plant with a new and
competitive rail product. The older finishing mills were phased out in the
1960's and the plant h as been shipping steel blooms and slabs to other steel
works for fin ishing.

It is hoped that the new finishing mill will secure the jobs of the 2,000
workers who make iron and steel in the blackened blast furnaces and basic oxygen
furnaces, some of which date back to before World War II.

The success of the rail mill, he said, depended on whether customers became
convinced that it could turn out a high-quality product, particularly in the
longer 78-foot rails that most railroads need for the high-speed trains being
developed.

Plant Still Has Problems

In an interview in the company's headquarters, Mr. Carney, who joined the
company in 1974 and became chairman in 1978, stressed that Wheeling-Pittsburgh
and the mill still faced major problems.

Without the new rail mill, he said, there was no doubt that the entire plant
would have been closed by now. ''You have to take the risk,'' he said, referring
to the company's modernization effort.

He said that his company and most other steel producers were still at a
disadvantage in relation to steelmakers in Japan and South Korea as far as
obtaining capital was concerned.

He estimated that Wheeling-Pittsburgh would need to spend from $400 million to
$600 million in the next 10 years to further upgrade its plants.

The company last June announced that it would install two continuous casters -
which cast molten steel into slabs for finishing - at a cost of $140 million,
one at its Monessen plant and the other at its major steelmaking plant in
Steubenville, Ohio.

While financing for the casters has been obtained, the company nonetheless
continues to have difficulty in raising necessary capital, he said.

Larger U.S. Effort Asked

From his viewpoint an even larger Federal effort was needed.  ''You can't win
the game with free enterprise anymore,'' he said, adding that t he industry
could not hope to stay competitive without help from the Government.

With the Reagan Administration going in the opposite direction, he said, his
main hope was to find a cash-rich company that would take over
Wheeling-Pittsburgh and help it get the money needed for modernization.

As far as the workers and townspeople are concerned, there is a feeling that
there is a good chance for success.  In a walk down Schoonmaker Avenue, one of
the city 's main streets, a visitor can still see scenes reminiscent of Edward
Hopper's paintings. Victorian and frame houses on small lots are hemmed in by
telephone poles and power lines. Old men and women sit silently in windows and
on the steps of red brick apartment buildings.

Monessen has been losing population. From l8,000 people in 1960, the city has
shrunk to 13,000. This has partly been the result of the phasing out of the
finishing mills and the cutback of operations by such other employers as
American Chain and Cable.

''Things have just turned around,'' said Mayor Sepesky, who took office in 1977,
at the height of the uncertainty.  He noted that several years ago stores were
closing along Donner Avenue, the older shopping area whose backdrop is the blast
furnaces and basic oxygen furnaces of the plant. In the past, fumes and
pollution spewed down on the street from the plant.

Part of the revitalization of the mill included an agreement reached with
Federal and state regulatory agencies to bring the plant into compliance with
air and water standards.

John Croussouloudis, the owner of the Keystone bakery, said there had been a
major improvement in the air. The addition of the rail mill, he added, has had
an encouraging effect on business owners, some of whom have opened new stores in
the abandoned storefronts.

''You need some kind of incentive''' he said of the Federal effort in building
the rail mill. ''Without the E.D.A. help,'' he said, ''we'd be another town you
could write about like towns were 50 years ago. We'd be just another dirty steel
town.''

Wheeling Seeks a Merger

Dennis J. Carney, the chairman of the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation,
said in an interview that he had talked to Japanese and Korean steel producers
about the possibility of taking over his company, but that none had shown
interest.

M r. Carney said the Japanese response had b een, ''We don't need youto come
in'' to the American market. He added that the trigger price mechanism was not a
strong enough protectioni st measure to worry the Japanese. Under the trigger
mechanism foreign producers cannot sell steel in the United States below certain
pric es without risking an investigation by the Treasury Department.

Mr. Carney said that if the United States established more severe protectionist
measures some of the Japanese producers ''would come down on their knees pretty
quickly'' and seek a merger.

He said that the company had hired Lehman Brothers two years ago to seek a
partner but that it had been unable to find one. To save money, Mr. Carney said,
the steel producer no longer retains Lehman, but has pursued the merger effort
itself.

Although he has talked to some domestic companies, he said, he would prefer to
merge with one of the low-cost Japanese or Korean steel producers to gain access
to their technology and low-cost steel products.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
