JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans. Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community

promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization. Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service. Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

Merit Promotion only for current Alabama USDA Rural Development employees.
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Occasional Travel
 1 - 5 nights.

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

US Citizenship is required.
 A 1-year probationary period is required.

DUTIES:
Back to top

Serve as an Area Specialist, with responsibility for assisting the Area Director
in leading USDA, Rural Development efforts throughout Alabama.
 Make and service routine and non-complex individual and group loans, loan
guarantees, and grants under the various USDA Rural Development loan, loan
guarantee and grant program authorities including Community, Business and
Cooperative, and Housing Programs.
 Provide credit and technical assistance for rural people and communities within
a specified geographic area.
 Provide information on agency programs to representative of business and
community groups and oversees construction management to assure structures are
built in accordance with approved plans and specifications.

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:
Back to top

Specialized experience is required to qualify for this position. Specialized
experience is experience which is typically in or related to the position to be
filled and which has equipped the applicant with the particular knowledge,
skills and abilities to successfully perform the duties of the position. To be
creditable, specialized experience must have been equivalent to at least one
year in the next lower grade level in the normal line of progression for the
occupation in the organization.

GS-9: Experience that demonstrates knowledge and understanding of mortgage or
commercial loan making/ servicing and credit principles and practices in order
to assess the fundamental soundness of business and/or community facilities
loans and to independently examine applications, supporting documents, and
credit reports, and maintain servicing activities on small commercial loans.
Experience may have been gained in work equivalent to furnishing information to
borrowers and applicants on loan programs, eligibility requirements, financial
and credit requirements; analyzing information provided by loan applicants,
determining eligibility for commercial loans, and making loan recommendations to
a senior employee; assisting senior level employees in initiating action to
graduate borrowers who are eligible for other credit sources; and participating
in providing credit counseling to all borrowers and debt adjustment services.

GS-11: Experience that demonstrated thorough knowledge and understanding of
complex mortgage or commercial loan making/ servicing and credit principles and
practices in order to assess the fundamental soundness of business loans and
loans to corporate and/or municipal entities and to independently examine
applications, and corporate financial documents, and maintain servicing
activities on a variety of commercial loans. Experience may have been gained in
work equivalent to reviewing and passing upon applications for a variety of
commercial loans or by servicing a commercial loan portfolio of a bank or other
loan association; performing financial analysis of commercial concerns for
investment purposes; appraising real estate and business property to determine
property valuation; or similar work.

GS-12: Experience that demonstrated a comprehensive knowledge and understanding
of the technicalities of commercial financing and credit and skill in directing
and evaluating employees. Experience may have been gained in work equivalent to
reviewing and passing on applications for the most complex business and/or
municipal transactions or by servicing a commercial loan portfolio of a bank or
other loan association; providing financial management guidance to borrowers in
ascertaining and analyzing the many and often obscure facts regarding corporate
borrower's financial capacity; evaluating the general economic and financial
conditions that affect the organization/government's risk in granting,
guaranteeing or insuring loans; and participating with overall office management
by providing guidance and direction to lower level employees.


o CONFIDENTIAL FINANCIAL DISCLOSURE REPORT: If selected, you will be required to
submit Form OGE-450 within 30 days of your initial appointment date, and
annually thereafter. Selectee is subject to financial Disclosure Requirements in
accordance with 5 CFR, Part 2635, Sub part E regarding business or personal
transactions with applicants, borrowers, or business contacts who have or who
are seeking business with this Agency. Selectee must be able to obtain and
maintain a security clearance. If selected you will be subject to a National
Agency Check and Inquiry (NACI) and a credit report.
o Have your salary sent to a financial institution of your choice by Direct
Deposit/Electronic Funds Transfer.
o Selectee must be able to obtain and maintain a security clearance. If selected
you may be subject to a National Agency Check and Inquiry (NACI) and a credit
report inquiry.
o To be eligible for appointment to this position, the new hire must be cleared
to come on board once the results of the fingerprint check, review of the
OF-306, Declaration for Federal Employment, and the candidate's Electronic
Questionnaires for Investigations Processing (eQIP) entries have been reviewed
and determined to be satisfactory. This position requires a favorable credit
check as part of the background investigation.
HOW YOU WILL BE EVALUATED:

You will be evaluated based on your qualifications for this position as
evidenced by the education, experience, and training you described in your
application package, as well as the responses to the Occupational Questionnaire
to determine the degree to which you possess the knowledge, skills, abilities
and competencies listed below:

*Knowledge of Housing, Commercial and Community Programs loan and/or grant
making requirements.
*Knowledge of Housing, Commercial and Community Programs servicing requirements.

*Knowledge of Building Standards, Costs, Specifications and Contracts.
*Program Administration/ Project Management.
*Oral Communication.
*Written Communication.

Questionnaire, to ensure you meet the job requirements and assess your ability
to perform this job. Before any certificate can be issued to the selecting
official, the resume and supporting documents are reviewed by an HR Specialist
to ensure that (a) minimum qualification requirements are met and (b) the resume
supports the answers provided to the job-specific questions. Your answers will
be verified against information provided in your online resume and application.
Be sure that your resume clearly supports your responses to all the questions
addressing experience and education relevant to this position.

Applicants who meet the basic minimum qualification requirements and are
determined to be among the best qualified candidates will be referred to the
hiring manager for consideration. Non-Competitive candidates need to meet
minimum qualification requirements to be referred.

Note: If, after reviewing your resume and / or supporting documentation, a
determination is made that you have inflated your qualifications and or
experience, your score can / will be lowered to more accurately reflect the
submitted documentation. Please follow all instructions carefully. Errors or
omissions may affect your rating. Deliberate attempts to falsify information may
be grounds for not selecting you.

Please read the entire announcement and all the instructions before you begin.
The following instructions outline our application process.

You must complete this application process and submit all required documents
electronically by 11:59 p.m. Eastern Time (ET) on the closing date of this
announcement.
 We are available to assist you during business hours (normally 8:00 a.m. - 4:00
p.m., Monday - Friday). Applying online is highly encouraged. If applying online
poses a hardship, please contact our office during business hours well before
the closing date for an alternate method. All hardship application packages with
supporting documents must be submitted no later than noon on the closing date of
the announcement in order to be entered into the system prior to its closing.
 This agency provides reasonable accommodation to applicants with disabilities
on a case-by-case basis; contact us if you are requesting this.

Step 1: Create a USAJOBS account (if you do not have one) at www.usajobs.gov. It
is recommended that as part of your profile you set up automatic email
notification to be informed when the status of your application changes. If you
choose not to set up this automatic notification, then you will have to log into
your USAJOBS account to check on the status of your application.


Step 2: Create a resume with USAJOBS or upload a resume into your USAJOBS
account. Customize your resume to ensure it documents duties and accomplishments
you have gained that are directly related to this position in order to verify
that qualifications are met. Your resume must support your responses to the
online questionnaire (you may preview the online questionnaire by clicking on
the link at the end of the How You Will Be Evaluated section of the job
announcement).

Step 3: Click "Apply Online" and follow the prompts to complete the Occupational
Questionnaire and attach any additional documents that may be required.
You can update your application or documents anytime while the announcement is
open. Log into your USAJOBS account and click on "Application Status." Click on
the position title, and then select "Update Application" to continue.
NOTE: Verify that uploaded documents from USAJOBs transfer into the Agency's
staffing system. Once in the Agency's staffing system you will have the
opportunity to upload additional documents. Uploaded resumes must be less than
3MB and in one of the following document formats: GIF, JPG, JPEG, PNG, RTF, PDF,
or Word (DOC or DOCX).


REQUIRED DOCUMENTS:

A resume should be provided. It should include relevant work experience
(start/end dates stated in month/year, description of duties and salary),
applicable education at a minimum, and your contact information. For current or
previous Federal employees, it should also include the Pay Plan, Series and
Grade for each work experience entry.
 For current or previous Federal employees, please attach a copy of your most
recent SF-50 or agency notification of personnel action form that provides
current position, grade level, and duty location.

A complete Application Package must be submitted and received prior to 11:59,
ET, on the closing date. The following documents are required for your
application package to be complete. Our office cannot be responsible for
incompatible software, illegible fax transmissions, delays in the mail service,
your system failure or downtime, etc. Failure to submit required, legible
documents may result in loss of consideration.

Resume that includes the following information: 1) personal information; 2)
education; 3) work experience including the work schedule and hours worked per
week as well as dates of employment; and title, series and grade if applicable;
4) supervisor's phone number and e-mail address for each work period listed and
whether or not we may contact them for reference checks; and, 5) other
qualifications.

Other required documents as applicable:

Current/Former Career/Career-Conditional: Most recent non-award Notification of
Personnel Action (SF-50 or equivalent) showing that you are/were in the
competitive service, highest grade (or promotion potential) held on a permanent
basis, federal status, position title, series and grade AND most recently
completed performance appraisal (dated within 18 months) showing the official
rating of record, signed by the supervisor, or a statement as to why the
performance appraisal is unavailable. Do not submit a performance plan.
 CTAP/ICTAP: Certification of Expected Separation, Reduction-In-Force Separation
Notice, Notice of Proposed Removal, or appropriate OPM/Agency certification; AND
most recent performance evaluation; AND SF-50 demonstrating your separation or
the position from which you will be separated.

Alabama: Loan Specialist (General) Job Announcement Number:AL-MPP-2014-4593

LENGTH: 2850  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of Personnel Management has issued the following job announcement:

Job Title:Loan Specialist (General)

Department:Department Of Agriculture

Agency:Agriculture, Rural Housing Service

Job Announcement Number:AL-MPP-2014-4593
SALARY RANGE:
 $47,923.00 to $90,344.00 / Per Year
OPEN PERIOD:
 Friday, April 04, 2014 to Monday, April 14, 2014
SERIES & GRADE:
 GS-1165-09/12
POSITION INFORMATION:
 Full-Time - Permanent
PROMOTION POTENTIAL:
12
DUTY LOCATIONS:
 1 vacancy - Camden, AL View Map
WHO MAY APPLY:
 Current permanent USDA Rural Development employees with competitive status,
within the state of Alabama and USDA CTAP eligibles.
SECURITY CLEARANCE:
 Q - Nonsensitive
SUPERVISORY STATUS:
 No
JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans. Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization. Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service. Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

Merit Promotion only for current Alabama USDA Rural Development employees.
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Occasional Travel
 1 - 5 nights.

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

US Citizenship is required.

                        The Bemidji Pioneer (Minnesota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             June 18, 2013 Tuesday

Apartments to be built: South shore land to be bought for $350,000

BYLINE: John Hageman, The Bemidji Pioneer, Minn.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 628 words


June 18--BEMIDJI -- A new apartment building is slated for the city's south
shore.

A Grand Forks, N.D., developer will pay the city of Bemidji about $350,000 for a
piece of land near the Sanford Center, contingent on the signing of a negotiated
purchase and development agreements.

Representatives of Northridge Hospitality Management came before the Bemidji
Economic Development Authority on Monday night with their proposal.

They anticipate constructing a four-story building with 50 to 60 units, mixing
efficiency, two-bedroom and three-bedroom units. They also plan on underground
parking.

A final design has not yet been presented.

Jon Miskavige, president of Northridge, said the apartment will appeal to young
professionals and families.

"It's going to compliment what's already here," Ryan Carlson, vice president of
operations for Northridge, said.

The developers offered about $3 per square foot, which turns out to be about
$350,000 for the 2.67 acres of land located on the west side of the Sanford
Center parking lot. City councilors, acting as the BEDA, discussed the offer
behind closed doors before accepting.

Miskavige said they originally considered building a hotel in Bemidji. But with
the Country Inn & Suites already being proposed for the south shore, they
reconsidered.

He said the Sanford Center is a "major catalyst" for development in Bemidji.

"We took a liking to the area," Miskavige said.

Bonding for Carnegie

The City Council signaled its support for seeking state bonding money for
restoring and moving the historic Carnegie Library building.

Councilors approved on a 6-1 vote to apply for $800,000 from the state for the
project. The additional $800,000 volunteer fundraisers expect to need for the
building will be raised from donations and grants, $500,000 of which they
already have in pocket.

The Save the Carnegie Committee will not seek more money from the council, said
committee member Cathy Marchand. The council has already dedicated $100,000 for
the project.

Several councilors said the building is important to Bemidji and its history.

"I think that building is more than just bricks," Ward 5 Councilor Nancy
Erickson said.

Ward 2 Councilor Roger Hellquist was the only dissenting vote. He cited other
community needs, such as a detox center, that aren't being considered for
bonding money.

"There are definitely some needs in the community," Ward 1 Councilor Michael
Meehlhause said. "Right now though, you look around and this is a project that
the community has really rallied behind."

Fundraisers have been seeking money to restore the building, which is more than
100 years old, and move it away from State Highway 197.

Hotel agreement

Councilors unanimously agreed Monday to amend the terms of a revolving loan fund
request for a hotel development attached to the Sanford Center.

The council agreed to the terms of a $400,000 gap financing loan last year.

Those funds would be for construction of the walkway between the Country Inn &
Suites and the Sanford Center, which the developers would not own.

The council amended the terms Monday to remove Kraus-Anderson and the PRS Family
Trust as guarantors of the loan.

Tiffany Fettig, business loan consultant for the Headwaters Regional Development
Commission, said those terms weren't set in stone when the council first agreed
to the loan.

There is still a corporate guarantee from the development firm Bay Ridge
Properties International and personal guarantees from the developers themselves.

Fettig said "all indications are" the developers of the Country Inn & Suites
will meet a July 15 deadline to line up their finances for the project.

                                  Oman Tribune

                            March 20, 2014 Thursday

SME firms set to get funding boost shortly

LENGTH: 551  words


Jeta Pillai MUSCAT A government programme that guarantees 50 per cent of a loan
to small and medium enterprises (SMEs) and currently available from only two
banks, will be available from almost all banks in the coming months, Acting CEO
of Public Authority for SME Development (Pasmed) Khalifa Said Al Abri told Oman
Tribune, here, on Wednesday. Currently this loan facility is available only from
Bank Muscat and Oman Arab Bank, but "we want to expand and are in discussions
with all banks in Oman and it will be available from all those who agree to
join," he said on the sidelines of the Oman Economic Forum. Under this facility
the government guarantees 50 per cent of a loan of up to 250,000 rials to SMEs.

Access to finance is one of the troubles faced by SMEs in Oman. The average
credit share of SMEs is only 2 per cent in the Gulf Cooperation Council
countries, while it is 22 per cent in high income countries and 8 per cent in
Middle East and North Africa. Al Abri said, following the decision at the SME
Development Symposium at Bahla in 2013, the Central Bank of Oman (CBO) has asked
banks to increase loans to SMEs to 5 per cent of their outstanding credit by
December 2014. In keeping with the Royal Decree establishing it in 2013, Pasmed
will also open branches outside Muscat, "in places like Sohar, Sur and Salalah
in the future," he said. They were also setting up incubators in Muscat and
other cities where small businesses are given space, technical and
administrative help till they stabilise and are in a position to shift out. He
said new awards for entrepreneurs will be announced soon and the function will
take place in January 2015. There are about 100,000 SMEs in Oman but some of
them may be dysfunctional. So a new database is being developed to get the
correct picture, so far about 2,000 SMEs have been registered, Al Abri added. In
the coming months, Pasmed will also be working with the Ministry of Higher
Education in instilling an entrepreneurial culture among youngsters, helping
SMEs with their business plans, marketing and promotion through exhibitions. CEO
of Al Raffd Fund Tariq Bin Sulaiman Al Farsi said they have dispersed 2.14
million rials so far for 114 projects. The fund was established in June 2013
with the objective of financing SMEs. There are four categories that get
funding: entrepreneurs; jobseekers; lawyers, doctors, rural women and social
security dependants. The fund will soon have a mobile branch that will take
services to the interiors, he added. Future plans include that for sectors like
tourism, agricultural seasonal credit and green economy. Former South Korean
Minister of Knowledge Economy Sukwoo Hong said, Oman, which is making a strong
effort to encourage businesses, must examine it from the eye of companies.
Government officials, he said, must have business minds and procedures must be
simple. He emphasised on the role of leadership in execution. After the Korean
war it was said the country would take 'a hundred years to recover'. It had a
low per capita income, no natural resources and in 1970s its soldiers fought in
the Vietnam war. But later, people saved and built the country's infrastructure
which was the foundation of the country's industry which in turn became the
foundation of the Korean economy.Oman Tribune

                          Business Day (South Africa)

                                 March 17, 2010
                              Business Day Edition

Absa launches 110% loan

BYLINE: Thabang Mokopanele

SECTION: ECONOMY, BUSINESS & FINANCE

LENGTH: 581  words


Absa launches 110% loan

Bank sought guarantee mechanism for affordable-housing market

BANKING group Absa has launched a 110% home loan for people who earn less than
R15 142 a month.

The 110% proposition will boost affordability and accessibility to home loan
finance by not requiring borrowers to pay a deposit. The loan also includes bond
costs, which are normally about 4% of the purchase price of a property.

Luthando Vutula, managing executive of Absa Home Loans, says: "The partial
guarantee to Absa on the MyHome product has the added benefit of an HIV/AIDS
voluntary counselling, testing and treatment programme and borrower education.

"The borrower education programme is specifically designed for customers who are
buying a home for the first time. The programme teaches home loan customers on
all aspects of homeownership."

Vutula says the HIV/AIDS programme is managed by Absa's external partners and
includes voluntary home-based counselling and HIV/AIDS testing and a managed
treatment programme including antiretroviral treatment where prescribed.

As part of this product, Absa has sourced appropriate insurance so that home
loan instalments are covered in the event of a customer being unable to work due
to an AIDS-related disease.

"Absa has recently intensified its focus on the affordable-housing market. The
plight of many lower-income earners (in their) inability to access housing is
well recognised within the bank. In fact, the bank has been investigating for a
number of years a guarantee mechanism to help lower-income earners afford bonds.
This is based on a similar methodology to the one mentioned by the president in
his state of the nation address," says Vutula.

With the advent of the MyHome product and the expected R1bn guarantees to be
provided by the government, Absa believes it can supply about R20bn for end-user
financing by 2014.

The bank has also embarked on an ambitious project in conjunction with the
national and provincial departments of human settlements as well as targeted
municipalities to accelerate housing delivery by providing an end-to-end housing
solution.

This project is part of the government's Breaking New Ground (BNG) programme,
which seeks to provide affordable housing through an integrated approach geared
at promoting the quality of housing delivery.

The BNG replaces the Rural Development Programme.

As a result of this strategic partnership, Absa has merged its affordable
housing component - the End-User Finance, Development Company, the House
Empowerment (which focuses on project sponsoring) and Development Finance arms
into one business unit.

Absa is spearheading this programme through its housing delivery projects such
as the Olievenhoutbosch initiative, with Chief Albert Luthuli, Kagiso, Klarinet
and Knysna earmarked as follow-up developments.

Through its affordable housing development arm DevCo, Absa acquires land by
either purchasing it or partnering with the government to work on a common
housing development.

The bulk of the funding for these developments is provided by Commercial
Property Finance (CPF) with DevCo and CPF acting as feeders to Absa Home Loans.

All the housing projects are designed to accommodate schools, health facilities,
open public spaces, religious facilities, industrial and commercial
opportunities to encourage a quality work-life-play environment and integrated
communities.

The programme is expected to deliver about 100000 housing opportunities, of
which 65000 have already been created.

                                US Official News

                            June 19, 2013 Wednesday

Sires Introduces Bill to Revitalize Parks and Strengthen Urban Communities

LENGTH: 461  words

DATELINE: Washington


Office of the  House of Representative Albio Sires, U.S Government has issued
the following news release:

Today, Congressman Albio Sires introduced the Community Parks Revitalization
Act.  This legislation is modeled after the Urban Revitalization and Livable
Communities Act, which he introduced in the 111th and 112th Congresses with
strong bipartisan support.  The Community Parks Revitalization Act would create
federal, matching grant programs and secured loans to revitalize parks and park
infrastructure.

"In New Jersey's 8th district, our parks and green spaces play a key role in
creating vibrant, livable communities where people want to live and businesses
want to invest," said Congressman Sires. "With most Americans living in urban
and metropolitan regions, it's critical that we provide communities with the
tools they need to create new or rehabilitee existing parks and recreation
spaces."

This legislation would provide three types of federal grants and technical
assistance programs which must be matched with local funds.  Rehabilitation and
construction grants would aid local governments in rebuilding and expanding new
and existing parks and recreational facilities, while innovation grants would
address personnel, facility, equipment, and supply needs for parks and
recreation facilities.  In addition, the innovation grant would provide funds
for new or existing programs that provide opportunities for returning veterans
and active duty military and their families, or programs that provide
constructive alternatives for at-risk youth.  Lastly, recovery action program
grants would promote development of local park and recreation recovery action
programs by involving the community and youth to develop priorities and goals.

New to the Community Parks Revitalization Act is an innovative financing
mechanism that would establish a program for secured loans and loan guarantees
for the development of parks and recreation infrastructure.  This program,
modeled after the popular Transportation Infrastructure Innovative Financing Act
(TIFIA), would allow either large scale projects such as trail systems, or
multiple communities bundling multiple projects together, to take advantage of
low cost financing.

"At a time when many Americans are affected by deteriorating community
infrastructure, this bipartisan legislation would help to create jobs, reduce
crime, and create healthy, vibrant neighborhoods," said Sires.  "I have always
been a strong supporter of creating livable communities, and public parks and
recreation facilities help us achieve that important goal by improving health,
revitalizing local economies, and creating neighborhoods where people want to
live and work."

For further information please visit: http://sires.house.gov

                                US Official News

                             October 7, 2016 Friday

Utah: Seven Foundations Facilitate $400 Million in USDA Loans to CDFIs

LENGTH: 361  words

DATELINE: New York



 Salt Lake City: Foundation Center, The State of Utah has issued the following
news release:


 Through the collaboration, twenty-six CDFIs across the country will receive
Community Facilities grants ranging from $800,000 to $50 million to provide
long-term low-interest loans to organizations working to build, acquire,
maintain, or renovate essential community facilities; build the capacity of
local service providers; and/or finance critical services such as education,
health care, and infrastructure. The funds are being disbursed in partnership
with the Uplift America Fund, a $22 million initiative launched by MBRF with
additional support from the Ford, Heron, Northwest Area, Winthrop Rockefeller,
Bank of America, and JP Morgan Chase foundations. Designed to strengthen the
nonprofit lenders' position as borrowers, the grants can be used either as
reserves -- CDFIs will be required to hold $1 in reserve for every $5 they
borrow -- or for capacity-building initiatives. In addition, private financial
institutions led by Bank of America will provide loan guarantees of up to $100
million for the first five years of the program.


 "The unique partnership that has been established through the Uplift America
Fund and Community Facilities Relending Program will help us provide essential
services and improve quality of life in low-income, rural communities by
providing much-needed, long-term capital," said Michelle Mapp, CEO of the South
Carolina Community Loan Fund, which will use its Uplift America grant to
increase lending in the state's rural counties, many of which have poverty
levels of between 20 percent and 30 percent.
 "With vast expertise about the areas they serve, community development
organizations are uniquely positioned to tailor place-based solutions," said
Mary Reynolds Babcock Foundation executive director Justin Maxson. "Grants from
the Uplift America Fund enable these lenders to attract more federal dollars in
the short term, while building their capacity to address rural economic
challenges for the long term."

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           October 8, 2014 Wednesday

Scranton moves to reverse defaulted parking authority debt

BYLINE: Jim Lockwood, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 653 words


Oct. 08--To help restore Scranton's battered creditworthiness, the city and its
parking authority are planning to satisfy two defaulted bank loans that stem
from a larger default in 2012 on authority debt, officials said.

The city plans to have the newly reorganized parking authority issue up to $4
million in revenue notes to repay loans from Pennstar Bank and Landmark
Community Bank, and then pay this new debt with parking meter revenue, according
to Mayor Bill Courtright, city Business Administrator David Bulzoni, and
authority member Tom Borthwick.

The authority lost control of the garages to a court-appointed receiver in 2012,
after the former city council allowed a default of authority debt that the city
guarantees. SPA was no longer able to pay back loans, and the two banks filed
separate lawsuits against the authority.

Mr. Courtright's July recovery plan calls for the "monetization" of SPA's five
parking garages through a sale or lease to reduce the amount of SPA debt the
city guarantees, and restructuring the remaining "stranded" SPA debt.

However, the two delinquent bank loans likely would be black marks for potential
garage purchasers or investors, the officials said. Satisfying the loans would
remove such roadblocks and help repair the city's overall relationship with the
financial community, they added.

"By us making good on the parking authority (loans), that will show the
financial community we're serious about fixing this problem," Mr. Courtright
said.

Mr. Bulzoni said of the initiative, "It cleans up that defaulted mess that was
inherited" by the new administration and council that took office in January.

Mr. Borthwick, a new authority member, said, "Banks right now are not too keen
on lending to the city. If the institution (city government) that started this
cascade of problems is seen as getting its act together, maybe we'll see a
better day" for the city.

Pennstar, which loaned the authority $800,000 in 2009, received a judgment last
year against the authority for $565,322 in principal and prejudgment interest of
$58,738, with an interest penalty of 10.75 percent per year on the principal,
according to court documents.

Landmark had loaned the authority $2.9 million in 2011, and the outstanding
principal at the time of default was $2.6 million. Landmark has not sought a
judgment but the lawsuit remains pending.

Mostly inactive since the default, the authority reorganized Sept. 2 with
members retained or appointed by Mr. Courtright. On Sept. 24, the authority
approved a resolution to issue revenue notes of up to $4 million.

"The money would go to the banks (Pennstar and Landmark) to repay amounts they
had to charge off" from the unpaid loans, Mr. Bulzoni explained. "It's
satisfying debt that's been delinquent for a few years, to repair the
relationship with the banking community."

The $4 million in new debt would be backed by a pledge of repayment from money
the city receives from parking meters.

City Council is expected to vote Thursday on introducing a measure to authorize
paying the authority's new debt with the parking meter revenues, Mr. Bulzoni
said.

Contact the writer: jlockwood@timesshamrock.com, @jlockwoodTT on Twitter

Rejected commuter tax discussed

Scranton City Council met privately in an executive session Tuesday to discuss
potential legal options regarding the recently rejected commuter tax, officials
said.

Council President Bob McGoff and members Joe Wechsler, Bill Gaughan and Wayne
Evans, as well as council solicitor Amil Minora, administration solicitor Jason
Shrive and city Business Administrator David Bulzoni met privately for around 40
minutes.

Mr. McGoff said afterward, "The discussion was about the Act 205 commuter tax
ruling and possible legal options going forward."

-- JIM LOCKWOOD

                              The Washington Post

                    November 12, 1999, Friday, Final Edition

Greater Southeast's Fate Still Undecided; Legal Wrangling Over Bankrupt Hospital
Should Be Resolved Within a Week

Avram Goldstein, Washington Post Staff Writer

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B04

LENGTH: 867 words



The federal courthouse was closed and quiet for the holiday yesterday, with the
exception of a small, stuffy courtroom where dozens of testy lawyers and
executives spent all day arguing the fate of the only D.C. hospital east of the
Anacostia River.

Within a week--perhaps today--100,000 District residents who live near
cash-starved Greater Southeast Community Hospital will find out whether the
35-year-old facility is to be rescued or shut down so its land, buildings,
supplies and equipment can be offered for sale like salvaged auto parts.

If U.S. Bankruptcy Judge S. Martin Teel Jr. opts for liquidation, 1,100
employees will be thrown out of work, and Southeast Washington residents will
have to travel much farther to reach a full-service hospital. District
officials, who two months ago stopped the flow of taxpayer money keeping Greater
Southeast afloat, are standing by with an $ 800,000 plan to transport patients
out if the hospital closes.

Neighborhood health-care activists are keeping a courtroom vigil and hoping that
doesn't come to pass.

Greater Southeast has agreed to be purchased by Arizona-based Doctors Community
Healthcare Corp., which assured Teel that it has the financial backing to pay $
21 million for the facility and intends to complete the transaction by January.
Greater Southeast officials had resisted the firm's overtures beginning last
winter, but when city financing evaporated in September, Doctors Community
became their last hope.

They aren't the only ones who have changed their minds and shifted positions
almost daily.

The 280-bed hospital's creditors are owed $ 70 million, and only a week ago they
unanimously favored liquidation as the best way to recover the most money from
the bankruptcy process.

But this week, the creditors broke into factions. Those with the strongest legal
guarantees of recovering their money--a financing subsidiary of Daiwa Bank of
Japan that would recoup $ 11 million and the District government, which was
entitled to a $ 3.1 million loan repayment--are pushing for approval.

The unsecured creditors, including holders of $ 45 million worth of municipal
bonds sold by Greater Southeast, are trying to derail the sale. As one lawyer in
the case put it, those creditors are struggling with the fact that they will be
"getting a haircut" from a sale that will leave little in the pot for them to
split.

To help settlement talks along, Mayor Anthony A. Williams (D) and leaders of the
D.C. Council and the D.C. financial control board sacrificed the city's
guarantee of recovering its $ 3.1 million loan in order to entice Doctors
Community to stay in the deal.

The talks almost succeeded yesterday. Several lawyers said the creditors were
within $ 300,000 of compromising, but the talks pulled apart before the hearing.

The creditors who favor liquidation called expert witnesses to testify that the
hospital and related assets are worth $ 26 million and to portray the buyer as
unreliable.

"There is no way Doctors [Community] can close this transaction," said Bernard
A. Katz, a certified public accountant. He predicted that the buyer's lender,
National Century Financial Enterprises, would use loopholes to back out of the
deal after it learns how bad things are at the hospital.

But in a telephone cross-examination from his office in Dublin, Ohio, National
Century Chairman Lance Poulsen told Teel that even if the hospital's financial
situation is found to be worse than it seems, he still would be ready to provide
the entire financing.

Time after time, he enunciated the amount of his firm's loan pledge to Doctors
Community: "Twenty . . . one . . . million . . . dollars."

Attorneys for the hospital, Doctors Community and Daiwa argued that even if the
facility is liquidated, there would be no bonanza for creditors. Whatever sum
they recovered would be reduced by $ 16 million before creditors would get a
dime because of laws requiring two months' severance pay to all employees, among
other things.

The creditors dispute the accuracy of that number.

After the hearing, Doctors Community chief executive Paul R. Tuft said he hopes
the judge will decide the matter today.

"We want to do the deal. We have a firm commitment to do the deal," he said.
"The liquidation scenario doesn't hold water. We made a compelling case to move
forward and save the hospital for the community."

Time is running out for the hospital. Next Thursday is payday, and the patient
census is declining. It fell from 172 last week to 140 Wednesday, partly because
D.C. emergency medical services officials on Monday diverted ambulances from
Greater Southeast's emergency room out of concern that the hospital might close.

However the case ends, the lawyers already have run up enormous bills. At
individual rates exceeding $ 300 an hour, one consultant estimated that court
hearings are costing $ 8,500 an hour in attorneys' fees.

The creditors' attorneys recently budgeted $ 1.5 million in legal fees just for
November and December, according to a source, and Teel will have to decide how
much of that to award.

Whatever fees the judge grants will come from the estate.

JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

Full-time - Permanent
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Occasional Travel
    Occasional travel may be required.

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

US Citizenship is required.
    Selective Service Registration is required for males born after 12/31/1959.

    Time-in-grade must be met by the closing date of this announcement.
    Relocation expenses will not be paid.
    Must submit Form OGE 450 within 30 days of appointment.

DUTIES:
Back to top

The Loan Specialist (Commercial), Community Programs Specialist assists the Area
Director in leading Rural Development efforts throughout the State. The
incumbent is recognized as an expert by making and servicing complex and
difficult loans, loan guarantees and grants under Rural Utility Service and
Community Facility authorities and provides credit and technical assistance to
Rural America, business concerns, local governments, and communities within the
geographical limits of the state.

Assists in the development and implementation of Rural Development's marketing
program for the service area under the supervision of the Area Director.
Develops and maintains relationships with community officials, organizations,
and individuals to assist in marketing Rural Development programs and services.

Assists in planning and participates in, activities, conferences, and events
that market Rural Development programs and services. Maintains a basic knowledge
of all Rural Development programs and services to be able to assist all internal
and external customers. Provides input into increasing the effectiveness of
Rural Development's marketing program.

Serves as a technical expert on processing and servicing Community Programs'
loan and grants. These programs include loans and loan guarantees for water and
wast disposal, community facilities, enhancement of private credit structures
for the creation of employment, business development, and pollution abatement.
Provides advice and assistance on a variety of loan making and servicing
methods, analysis of borrowers records and operations, rural development, and
handling of legal and problem cases, etc. Recommends action to higher
supervisory levels for applications and/or servicing problems that exceed
delegated authority.

Gives guidance to borrowers in carrying out approved management practices,
including proper use of credit, income and other financial resources.

experience at the GS-7; or its non-Federal equivalent that demonstrates a

work OR possess a Master's or equivalent graduate degree OR two (2) full years

                           Philippines Daily Inquirer

                            December 2, 2014 Tuesday

The promise of LGU bonds

LENGTH: 935  words


What do the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco, the Eiffel Tower in Paris, and
the Taipei 101 Tower (one of the tallest buildings in the world) have in common?
Answer: These world landmarks were financed wholly or partly by municipal bonds.
These are debt securities that local government units (LGUs) issue to raise
money for public projects, such as public markets, fish ports, bus terminals,
hospitals, lowcost housing, and other special projects. When you buy a municipal
bond, you are lending money to the LGU that issued the bond. In return, the
borrowing LGU promises to pay you a specified amount of interest, usually
semiannually, and return your money at a specified maturity date.

Most Philippine LGUs have yet to discover bond financing as a way to raise funds
to finance needed local infrastructure projects, especially income generating
ones. And yet, local government bonds have been around for centuries elsewhere.
In the United States and other mature economies, municipal bonds, also known as
"munis," account for a major portion of all bond issuances in their capital
markets. In the United States, for example, about $366billion worth of municipal
bonds were issued last year, and a total of $3.7 trillion were outstanding and
actively circulating. Local projects financed through municipal bonds amounted
to 2.5 times more than those funded out of the federal budget.

Among our betterknown municipal bondfinanced projects is the Caticlan Jetty
Port, familiar to anyone who has been to the resort island of Boracay. To
construct this facility, the province of Aklan floated P40million worth of bonds
in 1999. Subsequent municipal bond floats in the country include those for
Tagaytay City's P220million convention center and Antipolo City's P400million
commercial complex.

Aside from floating municipal bonds, an LGU has several options for funding a
local infrastructure project. It may, of course, use its internal revenue
allotment (IRA) from the national government, or its locally generated revenues
such as real property taxes and local business taxes. Or it may secure a loan
from a government financial institution (GFI) like the Development Bank of the
Philippines or the Land Bank of the Philippines. For the GFI, the loan is
virtually free of risk because the LGU's IRA normally becomes a direct
collateral for the loan. This means that in the event of default, the GFI may
intercept the borrower LGU's IRA fund releases from the Department of Budget and
Management.

Still another option is for the LGU to go via the publicprivate partnership
(PPP) route, also known as the buildoperatetransfer (BOT) mode. Here, a private
firm finances and constructs the facility and is given the right to operate it
and collect user fees to recover its investment and earn a reasonable profit.

Each financing mode above has its own advantages and disadvantages depending on
the peculiar circumstances and the nature of the projects to be financed.

From a broader perspective, a particular appeal of municipal bond financing is
the way it helps widen and deepen the capital markets. In particular, it expands
the range of choices of investment instruments available to savers and
investors. For one thing, municipal bonds can help channel rural savings and
overseas workers' remittances toward development of the localities where their
families reside, giving them a direct stake and involvement in improving their
own communities. Tagaytay City deliberately allotted a portion of the bond float
for its convention center to small savers, thereby enabling its citizens to have
a direct stake in the facility.

Abroad, municipal bonds are a popular investment instrument for small and large
savers alike, especially because their earnings are usually tax exempt. Such tax
exemption is desirable and necessary to offset the added transaction costs
(underwriting fees, guarantee fees, and other costs) associated with floating a
local bond, as against simply taking a GFI loan. Without such exemption, LGUs
are likely to favor bank loans, and investors would have little incentive to buy
the bonds over alternative interestearning assets like Treasury bills, trust
accounts and mutual funds. Not surprisingly, the main buyers so far of our
municipal bonds have been the big banks themselves, making the bond issues no
different from a syndicated loan to the LGU. Furthermore, many of the bond
issuances are being prepaid before maturity by the issuing LGUs and converted to
loans by GFIs, who are happy to push more loans with riskfree clients such as
LGUs. But such practice undermines the capital marketdeepening effect of
municipal bonds.

In reality, we have yet to see our government pursue a policy of promoting
LGUbond financing. For the reasons described above, there should be. A basic
requirement is that the tax exemptions commonly given elsewhere be also granted
on LGU bond earnings here. It also requires that there be a good credit rating
system for LGUs, and a good LGU credit guarantee mechanism in place. Both are
already being partly fulfilled by the LGU Guarantee Corporation, but needs
further expansion to widen its scope and coverage. And for LGU bonds to be
instrumental in deepening our capital markets, we need to have a wellworking
fixed income exchangei.e., the counterpart of a stock market for trading
fixedincome assets like bonds. Some baby steps have been made in these
directions in the past years, but it's time to make greater strides so that
through better local resource mobilization, we can help fill our glaring
infrastructure gap both at national and local levels.

                           Free Press Journal (India)

                           January 30, 2013 Wednesday

Govt will recommend SC status for Sen community: CM

BYLINE: FPJ Bureau

LENGTH: 551  words


BHOPAL: The Chief Minister Shivraj Singh Chauhan announced a number of
facilities for the Sen Community members, traditionally engaged in hairdressing,
at the " Kesh Shilpi Panchayat" at the Chief Minister's house here on Tuesday.

He said that sports will be specified for hairdressers in urban and rural areas.
Hairdressers will be imparted training in modern techniques while women
belonging to the community will also be encouraged to receive formal training as
beautician. The government will facilitate the community's youths in obtaining
loans for self- employment.

Financial assistance will be also be ensured for loans from Rs. 50 thousand up
to Rs. 2 lakh. Bank guarantee, loan subsidy and margin money will also be given
to loan seekers.

The State Government will provide land and requisite funds for construction of
memorial of Saint Sen Maharaj at his birthplace Bandhavgarh in Umaria district.
The teachings and spiritual literature Sen Maharaj will be published.

Chauhan said that a proposal will be forwarded to the Centre urging it to enlist
Sen Community as scheduled caste. Chauhan said that hairdressers' families will
be covered under ' Deendayal Antyodaya Upchar ojana' and State Illness Fund.
Their children will be given scholarship from first standard on wards. Loan
guarantee will also be extended for higher studies. Coverage of Janshree
insurance scheme will also be available. The Chief Minister felicitated Jai
Narayan Bhati, who holds world record in the art of hair dressing.

Describing members of Sen community as honest and hard working, Urban
Administration and Development Minister Babulal Gaur said that the State
Government was working for the poor, farmers and deprived sections that need
social protection. Minister of State for Urban Administration and Development
Manohar Oontwal read out a message of Swami Achalananda Maharaj.

Chauhan refused to accept the demand for government land for ' Dharmashala'. He
said the Supreme Court's decision had barred giving government land to any
community without proper guidelines.

The government is in the process of preparing guideline for land allotment at
present. Chauhan also announced to provide benefit of mukhyamantri kanyadan
yojana- Rs 15000 to each couple getting married under the scheme- to all married
couples who will take part in community's mass marriage function. If at least
five marriages are performed at a time, then they will be entitled for the
benefit.

Members of Sen community from different parts of the state raised demand for
representation in government and assembly tickets to some of its leaders. They
said, the community was deprived of its right and honour only because of lack of
representation in the system. Sen community has six lakh families with 18 lakh
voters in the state. The government has so far marginalised them.

Besides demanding to incorporation in scheduled caste list from their present
status as Other backward classes ( OBC), they said most of the castes which were
enlisted as backward in 1945, were included in scheduled caste but the union
government denied the statue to Sen community on the ground that they were not
untouchability.

Community's national vice- president Subhash Verma, Heeralal Shrivas, state
president Nandkishore Verma and Raghuveer Shrivas spoke on the occasion.

                       Charleston Gazette (West Virginia)

                            May 28, 2014, Wednesday

Staats project gets more support

BYLINE: Caitlin Cook, Staff writer

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. P1C

LENGTH: 521 words


Plans to renovate and redevelop the historic Staats Hospital on Charleston's
West Side received some extra backing from the Charleston Area Alliance Tuesday.

Alliance board members voted to guarantee a $155,000 loan from First Bank of
Charleston to Bullock Properties LLC, which is redeveloping the building.

"When you have that kind of facility, which is in grave condition, it takes a
community approach, Charleston Area Alliance President Matt Ballard said. "Us
guaranteeing the loan gives the private bank some additional security and risk
mitigation they would not have otherwise.

The Alliance's guarantee will be secured by a second lien on the property and/or
a personal guarantee from one or more members of the Bullock family.

Ballard said his group listed the vacant building as its most endangered
building last year, and it was listed by the Preservation Alliance of West
Virginia in 2012 as one of the state's most endangered structures.

The structure was built in 1922 by the Staats brothers, one of whom was a
doctor, and designed by John Norman, one of West Virginia's first registered
black architects.

Tighe Bullock, 24, of Bullock Properties, told the Gazette earlier this month
the Elk River and Interstate 64 create "a mental barrier between the West Side
and downtown Charleston. Bullock said he wants more connectivity between the two
and sees the West Side's potential as "an expansion of the downtown. "Phase one
of the project entails providing a sound roof for the building, replacing all
windows, a new facade. David Hardy, an Alliance board member and Kanawha County
Commission, said there's a night and day difference to having developers who
have "skin in the game.

"It's a real shot in the arm for the West Side of Charleston and West Washington
Street. We feel confident we have the right developers, Hardy said. "This
building was owned by an out-of-state company in Florida who bought it in a tax
sale in 2010, who had no interest in it.

Developers will work from the bottom up making the first floor, street-front
space a priority. Developers expect phase one to be complete by November 2014.
They expect the first floor to be open for class B office space or retail by
Feb. 1, 2015.

No Alliance members opposed the guarantee, but Hardy objected to discussing the
loan guarantee in closed session, saying it was not necessary.

A variety of community organizations are providing funds for the $520,000
project.

The Charleston Urban Renewal Authority is leading the way with a $230,000 loan.
In addition to guaranteeing the project's private bank loan, the Charleston Area
Alliance gave a $15,000 grant. Two $20,000 Facade grants were also provided.

The Bullock family contributed $80,000 toward the purchase of the building.

"You can't just find one person that is going to show up and write a check for a
million dollars to renovate a building in that condition, Hardy said. "You have
to bring together grant money, some public money but you have to have the
private money too. And this project has the private money and a proven track
record.

Reach Caitlin Cook at caitlin.cook@wvgazette.com or 304-348-5113.

KARACHI, Sept. 24 -- The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) is

areas. Around 2,000 accounts have been issued guarantee under CGS.

Rs 925 million have been disbursed to small and rural enterprises under

for their lending to this sector, he maintained.

and agricutlure credit officers of banks. Special capacity building

from banks.

                                American Banker

                               May 7, 2007 Monday

In Focus: Bill Would Lift Muni Role for Small Banks

BYLINE: Steven Sloan

SECTION: WASHINGTON; Pg. 1 Vol. 172 No. 87

LENGTH: 1217  words

DATELINE: WASHINGTON


The Federal Home Loan banks moved a small step closer last week toward winning a
power they have sought for nearly a decade: the ability to guarantee tax-exempt
bonds.

Legislation introduced last week in the House would allow community banks to
help finance local projects, such as a new hospital wing, and earn more fee
income in the process.

Critics, including private bond insurers, contend that giving the Home Loan
banks the authority to issue "standby letters of credit" for tax-exempt bonds is
a power grab that would hand their business to a government-favored institution.

The Home Loan banks counter that the prime beneficiaries would be small and
rural communities.

"This is not as though we're going to be assisting JPMorgan rebuild New York
City," said John Price, the president and chief executive of the Home Loan Bank
of Pittsburgh. "We are mandated by Congress to help smaller community banks do
more community development work. ... I'm simply closing the loop and saying,
'Give us this tool in our arsenal.' "

The three-sentence tax bill introduced by Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich., faces
substantial hurdles, but it would help cash-strapped local governments, its
author said.

"At a time when many municipal budgets are stretched, it is important that we
allow the Federal Home Loan banks, through their member institutions, to help
communities construct water treatment facilities, build new fire stations, add a
wing to a public hospital, or improve needed recreational facilities," Rep.
Levin wrote in an e-mail to American Banker. "The needs are almost limitless,
but resources unfortunately are not, and this legislation will help those scarce
resources go farther."

The tax-exempt bonds could prove a new revenue source for the Home Loan banks
and their members. Other government-sponsored enterprises, including Fannie Mae
and Freddie Mac, already have the authority to issue credit enhancements similar
to a standby letter of credit. Bond issuers vie for these instruments because it
makes their fund-raising efforts cheaper.

Under current law, community banks have the power to issue a letter of credit,
which commits the bank to repaying a debt if the issuer defaults. The problem
for many institutions is that they typically do not have a strong enough credit
rating for a letter to offer significant savings for the project, making it less
attractive for a bond issuer.

But each Home Loan bank has a stellar credit rating, which it could pass on to
its member banks if Rep. Levin's bill were approved. As a result, the Home Loan
bank could confer its credit rating on the debt issuer, which would be able to
raise money at lower interest rates and under flexible terms.

Community and Home Loan banks both stand to gain from such an arrangement,
because they can charge fees to back the bond. Industry representatives said the
bill would help both banks and their communities.

"These transactions with local municipalities can be very important to the
health of the community, and that's very critical to the bank," said Steve
Verdier, a lobbyist for the Independent Community Bankers of America.

But critics of the legislation, including private insurers, argue that it would
give the Home Loan banks an unfair advantage over the private sector. They say
that the only reason the Home Loan banks have such a strong credit rating is
because of a belief that the federal government would bail them out in the event
of a failure.

"The private sector ... fully serves the public municipal bond market," Gary
Dunton, the president and CEO of MBIA Inc., said last month at an American
Enterprise Institute conference on the topic. "Our guarantees have helped
thousands of municipalities to build infrastructure and services to taxpayers at
significantly reduced costs."

Still, MBIA's most recent annual report said that just 7.2% of its business
stemmed from deals of less than $10 million - the very bonds the community and
Home Loan banks hope to pursue.

Other observers say they are wary of letting another GSE grow beyond its
original housing focus. Such growth landed Fannie and Freddie in accounting
scandals and sparked GSE reform efforts.

"It gets to the question of should the GSEs be granted additional power," said
Bert Ely, an independent consultant in Alexandria, Va., and a frequent GSE
critic. "There are more important fish for the Federal Home Loan banks to fry.
... They just don't need it."

The technicalities of tax policy come into play in this debate. Congress gave
Fannie and Freddie, along with several other GSEs, specific authority to back
tax-exempt debt in 1984, but the Home Loan banks were left off the list.

That setup prompted the Internal Revenue Service to argue that Congress did not
want the Home Loan banks to have that authority. As a result, the IRS required
the Home Loan Bank System to convert any bonds it backs into taxable debt.

Mr. Price argues the interpretation has put the system at a disadvantage as its
community development requirements have grown in the past two decades. "It's not
only an oversight, but it's awkward. It's an asymmetry in our mission versus our
authority," he said.

The Home Loan banks have issued standby letters of credit for taxable debt since
1983 and won approval to back tax-exempt housing bonds in 1989. They also can
back public units of deposit, such as a payroll account for a public school
system. The value of letters in these three categories at the 12 banks totaled
$20 billion on Dec. 31, accounting for 2% of the Home Loan Bank System's total
assets.

While the standby letters of credit may not take up much room on the banks'
books, the business grew 84.5% last year.

The Home Loan Bank of Cincinnati issued the most standby letters of credit; its
total grew 26.8% last year, to $6.5 billion. In its annual report, the bank
attributed its growth to new business from one member that needed backing for a
public unit of deposit. A spokesman for the bank would not identify the member.

Despite such growth, most Home Loan bank officials say they doubt a flood of new
business would come their way if Rep. Levin's legislation were approved.

"I don't think this is going to be a blockbuster business, but there would be
demand among local governments," said Alfred DelliBovi, the president and CEO of
the Home Loan Bank of New York.

Even if demand is low, supporters of the legislation say it would be a success
if it helped just a few local projects get off the ground.

"There's no interest or need to get into the bigger deals," said Charles
Samuels, a lawyer in the Washington office of Mintz Levin Cohn Ferris Glovsky &
Popeo PC, who represents groups supporting the bill. "Even if it's just a few
institutions each year, it's worthwhile to have this opportunity."

Still, the bill could have a hard time gaining traction in Congress. Lawmakers
have considered similar proposals twice in the past decade, and the Treasury
Department opposed the idea during the Clinton administration. But Mr. Verdier
said lawmakers are catching on that the legislation is good politics.

"Banks can fund these essential infrastructure projects, and ... [lawmakers]
might even get invited to a ribbon-cutting ceremony. This is helping the home
folks at no cost to anybody," he said.

                     News-Journal (Daytona Beach, Florida)

                           February 22, 2011 Tuesday
                                 Final Edition

MONEY TO GROW Loan programs provide businesses with working capital

BYLINE: CLAYTON PARKBUSINESS WRITER, CLAYTON PARK - BUSINESS WRITER

SECTION: SECTION A; Pg. 6A

LENGTH: 840  words


After getting turned down for business loans by several big banks, DeLand car
dealer J. Brendan Hurley decided to give a small local bank a try.

Pinnacle Bank in Orange City in March agreed to lend $560,000 to Hurley through
a U.S. Small Business Administration program in which the federal agency
guarantees a large portion of the loan amount.

That SBA loan enabled Hurley to expand his business by adding Dodge to the
Chrysler-Jeep dealership he already operated.

Within just a few months of receiving that loan, Hurley had added several
workers, thanks to a doubling of his dealership's service volume. A Wall Street
Journal article in August about the SBA's 7(a) loan program included comments by
Hurley about his experience.

The fact that I had a commitment from Pinnacle sealed the deal to get the Dodge
franchise," he told The Wall Street Journal. David Bridgeman, Pinnacle
president, said the SBA's loan programs have allowed his bank to continue
issuing loans to area businesses at a time when many community banks are
refraining from making commercial loans because of the economy and pressure from
federal regulators on banks to increase their capital levels.

The beauty of the SBA's 7(a) program for community banks "is that the (SBA's)
guaranteed portion of the loan does not count against your capital ratios,"
Bridgeman said. "Without having a tool like the SBA, you're limited in what you
can do."

The flip side, Bridgeman said, is the extensive reporting requirements and
restrictions for banks that come with agreeing to become a SBA lender.

In 2009, Pinnacle issued 11 SBA 7(a) loans worth a combined $3 million, up from
just two loans each in 2007 and 2008. Last year, that number increased to 16 SBA
loans by Pinnacle, worth a combined $4.6 million, according to the SBA, whose
fiscal year runs from Oct. 1 through Sept. 30.

Through the first three months of fiscal 2011, Pinnacle has already issued five
SBA loans worth nearly $1.5 million.

Hurley, in a phone interview, said he used money from his SBA loan last year to
build a new storage/parking facility and to purchase the equipment and parts he
needed to add the Dodge dealership. He said he is in the process of securing a
second SBA loan from Pinnacle, this time for $4 million.

Bridgeman said the second loan from his bank to Hurley likely also will be an
SBA 7(a) loan.

Hurley plans to use the proceeds to begin construction of a new building for his
three dealerships that will be nearly three times the size of his present
1970s-era building.

The 14,000-square-foot building, which Hurley hopes will be completed by early
July, will include a larger car showroom and customer lounge, and will enable
him to hire an additional 20 workers.

Hurley Chrysler Jeep Dodge employs 38 workers, up 10 workers from a year ago, he
said.

SBA 7(a) loans are intended for use in either establishing a new business or in
assisting an existing business to make an acquisition, expand and/or to cover
its continuing operations, according to the agency's website.

The proceeds, according to the SBA, cannot be used to refinance existing debt,
effect a partial change in ownership or a change that will not benefit the
business, reimburse funds owed to any owner or investor, repay delinquent state
or federal withholding taxes, or for a "non-sound business purpose."

Under the 7(a) program, SBA offers to guarantee up to 85 percent of loans under
$150,000 and up to 75 percent of loans over that amount, up to $5 million, with
the lending bank assuming the risk for the rest of the amount.

SBA 504 loans are designed to help businesses acquire major fixed assets for
expansion or modernization.

SBA 504 loans don't involve a guarantee from the SBA, however, according to
SBA's website, the federal agency purchases a second mortgage that covers up to
40 percent of the project cost. A loan secured from a private-sector lender with
a senior lien covers up to 50 percent of the project cost. A contribution from
the borrower of at least 10 percent covers the remainder of the project cost.

Intracoastal Bank in Palm Coast issued seven SBA 504 loans last year worth a
combined $4.7 million and, so for this year, has three applications for 504
loans totaling $3.7 million, said bank president Bruce Page.

We plan on continuing to put a greater emphasis on our 504 program," Page said.

So far, Intracoastal, a bank launched in 2008, has stayed away from issuing SBA
7(a) loans, although Page added: "We constantly are evaluating our products and
services."

Conversely, while Pinnacle has one of the more active SBA 7(a) lenders in the
Volusia-Flagler area, it didn't issue a single 504 loan last year.

That might change this year, Bridgeman said. "We will now be looking at both
products based on the specific loan request and what is best for the borrower
and the bank."

All SBA lending is about one thing and one thing only: that's job creation,"
said Larry McDermott, a vice president of business development at Intracoastal
Bank. "You cannot qualify for an SBA loan without agreeing to create jobs."

                           Star News (Wilmington NC)

                          November 30, 2005, Wednesday

Historic church site saved; Foundation, BB&T team up on loan effort

SECTION: New Hanover County Neighbors; Pg. 4

LENGTH: 380 words


The Historic Wilmington Foundation has a history of using creative strategies
such as preservation easements or moving houses to save threatened historic
properties.

Recently the group announced a partnership with BB&T to help Central Missionary
Baptist Church save its parsonage at 716 Red Cross St. through a loan guarantee.

The historic house sat unused and deteriorating for years as the church wrestled
with ways to restore the asset. Now church trustee board members Eva Williams,
Paul McGill and Margaret Peoples are excitedly watching as the old house is
restored for new use as a rental property.

Eva Williams, the chairwoman of the trustee boardj, said, "The project is a
realization of a 10-year dream. Historic Wilmington and BB&T have come to our
rescue, and our members are grateful."

The church will use the income from the rental of the rehabilitated house to
provide additional money to restore and maintain the historic church building,
which has also been listed in the past as a threatened site by Historic
Wilmington.

The trustees also thanked the city's Code Enforcement staff for allowing them
the time to develop a workable plan to save the historic house.

Historic Wilmington Foundation's Urban Properties Committee, lead by Michael
Murchison with aid from committee member Matt Scharf worked with BB&T's
small-business banker Cheryl Cooper to put together a loan for the church. The
loan has normal underwriting, but Historic Wilmington Foundation brought its
financial strength to the package to guarantee the loan during the very critical
construction phase.

"I love to make this kind of loan because it reinvests in our community, and it
helps renew a neighborhood," Cooper said.

"Historic Wilmington is excited that its revolving fund will assist Central
Missionary Baptist," said George Edwards, Historic Wilmington Foundation
executive director.

"The foundation has saved dozens of houses over the years with this fund, and it
is wonderful to be able to leverage our strength to help the church. This kind
of loan guarantee may take us in a new direction with community and neighborhood
revitalization," Edwards said.

For more information on this program, call Cheryl Cooper at 798-3101 or George
Edwards at 762-2511.
