JOB SUMMARY:

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) Rural Development Agency serves rural
communities throughout the country by investing in their communities through
housing and utility infrastructure, by increasing economic opportunity, and by
improving the quality of life for all rural Americans.  Rural Development
provides over 40 loan and grant programs in the Rural Housing and Community
Facilities Services, Rural Business and Cooperative Services, and Rural
Utilities Service. Rural Development supports a positive work environment and
promotes diversity and inclusion for nearly 5,000 employees.

Rural Development is a dynamic organization recruiting for employees who possess
the energy, compassion, and commitment to serve those in rural communities and
will enjoy working in a fast paced and results driven organization.  Our
commitment is to expand economic opportunity and quality of life in all of rural
America by providing financial programs to support essential public facilities
and services such as water and sewer systems, housing, health clinics, emergency
service facilities and electric and telephone service.  Rural Development offers
a friendly and professional working environment and such excellent benefits as:
a generous salary, alternative work schedules, paid vacation and sick leave,
paid holidays, retirement and supplemental savings plan, a wide array of health,
dental, vision, and life insurance plans, flexible spending accounts, and
long-term care insurance.

Full-time - Permanent
TRAVEL REQUIRED

Occasional Travel
    Occasional travel may be required.

RELOCATION AUTHORIZED

No

KEY REQUIREMENTS

US Citizenship is required.
    Selective Service Registration is required for males born after 12/31/1959.

    Time-in-grade must be met by the closing date of this announcement.
    Relocation expenses will not be paid.
    Must submit Form OGE 450 within 30 days of appointment.

DUTIES:
Back to top

The Loan Specialist (Commercial), Community Programs Specialist assists the Area
Director in leading Rural Development efforts throughout the State. The
incumbent is recognized as an expert by making and servicing complex and
difficult loans, loan guarantees and grants under Rural Utility Service and
Community Facility authorities and provides credit and technical assistance to
Rural America, business concerns, local governments, and communities within the
geographical limits of the state.

Assists in the development and implementation of Rural Development's marketing
program for the service area under the supervision of the Area Director.
Develops and maintains relationships with community officials, organizations,
and individuals to assist in marketing Rural Development programs and services.

Assists in planning and participates in, activities, conferences, and events
that market Rural Development programs and services. Maintains a basic knowledge
of all Rural Development programs and services to be able to assist all internal
and external customers. Provides input into increasing the effectiveness of
Rural Development's marketing program.

Serves as a technical expert on processing and servicing Community Programs'
loan and grants. These programs include loans and loan guarantees for water and
wast disposal, community facilities, enhancement of private credit structures
for the creation of employment, business development, and pollution abatement.
Provides advice and assistance on a variety of loan making and servicing
methods, analysis of borrowers records and operations, rural development, and
handling of legal and problem cases, etc. Recommends action to higher
supervisory levels for applications and/or servicing problems that exceed
delegated authority.

Gives guidance to borrowers in carrying out approved management practices,
including proper use of credit, income and other financial resources.

QUALIFICATIONS REQUIRED:
Back to top

To qualify at the GS-9: Applicants must possess one (1) year of specialized
experience at the GS-7; or its non-Federal equivalent that demonstrates a
knowledge of commercial, community and/or other types of technical loans,
competence in reviewing loan application packages for commercial and/or other
bank loans and taking action within delegated loan approval authority;
competence servicing a loan portfolio of a bank or loan association or similar
work OR possess a Master's or equivalent graduate degree OR two (2) full years
of progressively higher level graduate education leading to such a degree or
LL.B. or J.D., if related.

To qualify at the GS-11: Applicants must possess one (1) year of specialized
experience at the GS-9; or its non-Federal equivalent that demonstrates a
working knowledge and understanding of commercial loan making/servicing and
credit principles and practices in order to assess the fundamental soundness of
commercial loans and to examine applications, supporting documents, and credit
reports, and maintain servicing activities on a variety of commercial loans of
large-scale. Experience may have been gained in work equivalent to reviewing and
passing upon applications for a variety of loans or by servicing a loan
portfolio of a bank or other loan association OR possess a Ph.D. or equivalent
doctoral degree OR three (3) years of progressively higher level graduate
education leading to such a degree or LL.M. if related.

To qualify at the GS-12: Applicants must possess one (1) year of specialized
experience at the GS-11; or its non-Federal equivalent that demonstrates
thorough knowledge and understanding of commercial loan making/servicing and
credit principles and practices in order to independently assess the fundamental
soundness of loans and to independently examine applications, supporting
documents and maintain servicing activities on a variety of commercial loans.
Experience may have been gained in work equivalent to reviewing and passing upon
applications for a variety of loans or by servicing a loan portfolio of a bank
or other loan association; performing financial analysis of commercial concerns
for investment purposes; appraising real estate to determining property
valuation; or similar work. NOTE: There is no education substitution for
experience at the GS-12 level.

Undergraduate and Graduate Education : Major fields of study - finance, business
administration, economics, accounting, insurance, engineering, mathematices,
banking and credit, law, real estate operations, statistics, or other fields
related to the position, such as agriculture, agricultural economics, farm,
livestock or ranch management, or rural sociology.

                     The Mecklenburg Times (Charlotte, NC)

                              May 11, 2010 Tuesday

Soaking debt: U.S. National Whitewater Center in Charlotte strives to overcome
past woes

BYLINE: Caitlin Coakley

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 1347  words


Discussing features he's adding for the summer season, U.S. National Whitewater
Center Executive director Jeff Wise exuded gleeful optimism.

Of the 40-foot bungee plunge called Mega Jump: "You'll free-fall, then it'll
catch you the last five feet. It's pretty cool - It'll scare the daylights out
of you. "

Of the new aerial challenge on the Adventure Course, an obstacle course: "It's
on a continuous belay system, once you're clipped in, you can route all the way
through, walking along a cable with a series of challenges associated with it. "

Wise's sunny outlook suggests that the storm has passed. In February, lenders
forgave two-thirds of the center's $38 million debt, leaving Wise with only
$12.4 million to repay.

But when asked about the center's financial difficulty, Wise abruptly clouds up.

"We're done with that story. We've told it a million times," he said, sounding
exasperated. "At this point, we're ready to move on and talk about something
else. "

Wise's frustration reflects the weight of the public scrutiny he has faced for
the nonprofit center, which was paid for by borrowing $38 million and backed by
a $12 million loan guarantee from Charlotte, Mecklenburg County, Gaston County,
Gastonia, Belmont and Mt. Holly. Mecklenburg County has the largest financial
commitment at $1 million each year for seven years.

Since its opening in 2006, the Whitewater Center's revenues have grown, but so
have its expenses. For the fiscal year ending in 2007, the facility posted a
$1.3 million loss, which grew to $2.1 million in 2008. Last year's losses were
$936,970, and revenue fell by $1.3 million, which Wise attributed to the slow
economy.

The losses are stark compared with the $36.5 million annual revenue forecasted
in the economic impact study presented to the local governments back in 2003.
John Connaughton, an economist from UNC Charlotte, who put together the study,
said the estimates were based on the business model provided by Wise, but
Connaughton said he couldn't remember the specifics.

Wise acknowledges miscalculations in the beginning, the most significant being
the estimate of rafters, who generate the most revenue for the park. Instead of
making up half the park's business, rafters account for only one of every six of
the park's attendants.

It's that steep discrepancy that leads some, including Mecklenburg County
Commissioner Bill James, a longtime critic of the center, to argue that the
governments involved have been gullible.

"Mr. Wise, I don't think he came at this thinking, 'I'm going to snooker the
government,'" James said. "but I do think he drank the Kool-Aid, and he bought
into a bunch of estimates that were completely out of whack. "

Value

Despite the center's shortfalls in the past, some supporters still argue it has
great value for the community.

North Carolina state Rep. Ruth Samuelson, R-Charlotte, one of the original
advocates of the Whitewater Center when she was a member of the Mecklenburg
County Board of Commissioners, was impressed by the uniqueness of the vision for
the center, as well as the value.

When Wise first pitched the plan to the board, Mecklenburg County was looking
into building a county park on the land it owned (the current site of the
Whitewater Center), but had been told by the Parks and Recreation Department
that it would cost $7 million to $10 million to develop the park.

"The deal that was being offered by the Whitewater gave us a better facility for
the same or less money, even if it had financial difficulty," she said.

The idea of taking on a loan guarantee rather than paying $7 million sweetened
the deal, though she said she was prepared to pay the full $7 million, and she
had some suspicions that the early projections may have been overly rosy.

"It's certainly frustrating, and I wish that things had gone more smoothly," she
said, "but I think there'll come a time when all this is behind us and we're
glad (the center) is there. "

Mecklenburg County Commissioner Vilma Leake, however, cringes when she sees the
amount of money being sent to the center, money that could be providing jobs, or
supporting the community's seniors, or maintaining the libraries.

"I certainly hope that (the center's board of directors) will be cognizant of
the situation that the county and the community (are) in economically when we
are in need of jobs, support, and the library," she said.

Wise is aware of the criticism. He knows that a lot of people perceive that the
money he has been receiving from the local governments is a bailout.

"That's just not accurate," he said, an edge in his voice. "A bailout means the
government had to step in and cover an unanticipated loss. In this case, the
government was a partner on the front end. "

What's next

The park remains $12.4 million in debt, of which up to $8.6 million will be paid
with the governments' guarantee.

The park is on county land under a lease that allows the nonprofit to own all of
the improvements provided it continues to operate as a whitewater park. If the
park defaults on its debt after the subsidies run out, the bank would have the
choice of writing off the remaining debt and allowing the center to continue
operating, or foreclosing on the loans.

From there, the bank may either appoint someone new to run the facility or allow
the center to become county property.

Commissioner James said he suspects that when the current subsidies are up, the
center will return to the local government to ask for an extension, which he
said he will oppose. Although Wise said he is confident he will be able to pay
off the debt in five years, critics are still skeptical, none more so than
James.

"Bullcrap," said James of Wise's optimism. "There's no way it's going to be paid
off. "

But Wise is not without supporters. Jennifer Roberts, chairman of the
Mecklenburg County Board of County Commissioners, admires the evolution of the
center's business plan since the beginning.

"They've added attractions and amenities, they've changed their pricing plans,
and I think they have tweaked it with expert advice, so it's a pretty strong
model," she said. "I'm pretty confident in their ability. "

In 2009, Wise changed the way people pay for their visits. Rather than offering
a menu of individual activities at different prices, the center sells an
all-day, full access to every activity pass for $49, the same price people paid
for only rafting in 2008.

"The pass concept worked great for us last year," Wise said. "I wish we had done
it from the start, but sometimes you have to do things the wrong way before you
figure out the right way. "

2010, Wise said, has shown promise so far: The first two-and-a-half months of
2010 showed attendance up 80 percent over last year, and this year's first
Whitewater River Jam event on May 6 was the busiest the center has had, Wise
said.

Plus, the newly added features will serve the center's effort to appeal to
families: the minimum weight is 45 pounds for both the Mega Jump and the aerial
challenge part of the Adventure Course. The center is also designing a new brake
system for the Mega Zip, in which riders are harnessed and slide down a 1,123
foot zip line, so that the minimum weight will drop from 90 pounds to 45 pounds.

But while he said he does expect some of the new features to bring in more
customers, Wise knows it's not a cure-all for the center's slow start.

Then again, he argues, he's not looking for a cure.

"There is no magic bullet for anything," he said. "I can't say, 'We tried A, and
A didn't work, so now we're going to do B and it's going to work. ' If I said
that, it'd be a lie. "

It's Business 101, Wise says: Starting a business includes a risk. Not
everything will go according to plan. The best a business can do is to learn and
keep going forward, which is what Wise repeatedly said the center will be doing.
Despite the skeptics, Wise said he thinks the business has been successful.

"It's really become the go-to place when you want to go be active outside," he
said. "People say, 'What are you going to do to make this place successful?' and
it's like, 'How do you define success?'"

                       The Daily Gleaner (New Brunswick)

                              May 5, 2009 Tuesday

Government investment helps with the flow of a steady pay cheque

BYLINE: GREG BYRNE For The Daily Gleaner

SECTION: OPINION; Pg. C7

LENGTH: 692  words


I recently visited the Moncton office of an Ontario company that has made the
smart decision to expand in New Brunswick.

With help from Business New Brunswick, land title insurer First Canadian Title
recently announced its plan to hire 50 skilled workers in Moncton, building on
its current workforce of 28.

As I stood in the downtown office building that will house many of these new
workers, I was surrounded by dozens of people who already work there.

These women and men are confident, energetic and looking forward to a prosperous
future. In speaking with many of them, I heard words of hope, encouragement and
inspiration.

As minister of Business New Brunswick, I know that good, solid jobs give New
Brunswickers the confidence they need to invest in themselves and their
communities.

As a government under the leadership of Premier Shawn Graham, we understand that
investing in opportunities for people to earn a steady pay cheque is fundamental
to building a self-sufficient New Brunswick.

This is why we have made the economy, along with creating and maintaining jobs,
our top priorities.

Our work is paying off. In New Brunswick last year, we created nearly 1,700 new
jobs, and prevented more than 4,000 jobs from being lost during the fallout from
the world financial crisis.

In 2008-2009, we provided New Brunswick's business community with more than $147
million in loans, loan guarantees, equity investment, forgivable loans and other
forms of financial help.

This money was invested in small, medium and large companies in every sector of
the economy, assisting in expansions, new startups, productivity improvements
and energy refits in every corner of our province.

We helped modernize mills in Nackawic, St. Leonard, Edmundston, Saint John and
Kedgwick, making them more energy efficient and productive.

Our investments helped Ganong Brothers Ltd. add 50 people to its existing
300-strong payroll and expand its candy factory in St. Stephen.

Our efforts convinced Prudential Consulting Ltd. to locate in Saint John, with
commitments to hire 150 people throughout the province.

We worked with manufacturer Floating Pipeline Co. to buy new equipment and hire
an extra 50 people to expand its 16-member workforce in Saint John.

In March, Primus Telecommunications Canada Inc. announced plans to relocate its
entire customer contact business from Mumbai, India to Edmundston - bringing 112
jobs to Northwestern New Brunswick.

Our $3 million investment in NB Growth, a program designed to support small and
medium-sized businesses through expansion and job grants, helped create and
maintain 730 jobs at 77 companies across New Brunswick.

This support went well beyond direct assistance and helped these companies
leverage an additional $11 million in outside investment.

We are also helping companies get through the credit crunch, protecting jobs and
companies for when the economy rebounds.

When Canada's lending institutions slammed the doors shut on profitable New
Brunswick companies last fall, we helped pry them open again by offering loan
guarantees.

We backstopped credit for companies with contracts in the hopper and people on
their payroll, saving hundreds of jobs in the process.

Our government has a balanced approach to economic development.

Our aggressive investment strategy is working and our support for local
companies is making a difference in the lives of working New Brunswickers.

We are creating an unparalleled business climate through tax reform.

New Brunswick's corporate tax rate will fall from 12 per cent to 8 per cent by
2012, the lowest in Canada. We raised the income limit for small businesses from
$400,000 to $500,000, among the highest in Canada.

These tax changes will make this province a more attractive place to live and
earn a living.

New Brunswickers can be confident this government is doing everything possible
to create opportunity and eliminate barriers to growth.

Together, we can seize these opportunities and move toward our goal of self-
sufficiency by 2026.

Greg Byrne is the minister of Business New Brunswick and the MLA for
Fredericton-Lincoln. We invite your input. Send your comments to
letters@dailygleaner.com

                              The American Banker

Chrysler's Banks Resist New Unsecured Credit, but Compromise Still Is Possible

                           January 9, 1980, Wednesday

By GARY M. HECTOR

DATELINE: NEW YORK


Chrysler Corp.'s banks remain strongly opposed to providing additional unsecured
credit to the beleagured company, discussions with bankers and financial
analysts confirmed this week.

The goal that banks lend $400 million of new money to Chrysler, set in the
Chrysler loan guarantee legislation, has virtually no support among bankers.
Some concede, however, that a compromise credit facility or commitment of some
amount might be worked out as negotiations continue over the next few months.

In simplest terms, most bankers are convinced that they would be better off if
Chrysler failed today than if it failed a year or two from now, and they are
loathe to commit themselves unless the government rescue package insures that
the company will survive.  A number of bankers doubt they will ever be convinced
that the government plan will work.

Most lenders have been studying the loan guarantee legislation for the last
three weeks to determine how much authority the government loan guarantee board
will have to shift the burden of providing new money to Chrysler among the
various parties with a stake in the company's future.  Some bankers believe that
the board has sufficient flexibility to fill Chrysler's needs without any new
commitments from the banks.

Even if the banks can avoid lending new money to Chrysler, they will lose under
the terms of the loan guarantee program.  Right now they are the senior
creditors and the company's assets are unencumbered.  Before the commitments can
be pieced together to bail Chrysler out, the outstanding claims of the banks
will have to be subordinated to the U.S. government, and the banks will be asked
to approve asset sales and liens on the company's properties.

The banks will also be asked to give up $100 million of interest or principle,
which one banker said would be "an outright gift."

In addition, one interpretation of the loan guarantee legislation concludes that
the banks will have to raise their commitments under existing credits back to
levels in force prior to Oct. 17.

This would mean that the domestic revolving credit commitment to Chrysler, now
negotiated down to under $500 million, would rise to the full $567.5 million.
The letter of credit facilities of a group of Japanese banks would also have to
be returned to the pre-Oct. 17 level.  Certain loans or credit commitments that
expired between that date and the end of 1980 would also have to be replaced.
Bank Commitments Expand

Once again, there is flexibility in the legislation in that it allows money from
one bank to be replaced by money from another party.  But the total commitment
from the banking community will expand above the level at which it settled
during much of the winter.

Another problem is that money raised from asset sales and new loans will be used
to support Chrysler's day-to-day operations.  This will include expenditures,
such as advertising costs to promote Chrysler's name, that will not be
recoverable in the event of bankruptcy.

Given Chrysler's projections for 1980, equity in the company will be reduced by
at least $500 million during the next year, with a resulting deterioration in
the coverage of the company's debt in the event of bankruptcy.

Bankers are also arguing persuasively that Chrysler neither needs nor could
possibly pay back the amount of debt provided under the guarantees.  "There is
no way they could ever repay their loans if they borrowed over $2 billion," one
banker said.

The company originally requested only about $1.2 billion in aid, but a
combination of deteriorating economic conditions and fear that Chrysler might
need more money than the government offered prompted Congress to raise its
offer.

While Chrysler remains optimistic about its chances of cementing the $2.0
billion in private commitments that it needs, Lee lacocca, Chrysler's chief
executive, told Congress early last year that the company might have
difficulties raising $900 million in new money - a far more modest sum than the
current required amount.

In the few days since legislation was approved by Congress, Chrysler has managed
to negotiate a $243 million concession from the United Auto Workers, and is
beginning to hammer out the details of commitments from other parties.

The complexities of patching together $2 billion of commitments are expected to
affect each portion of the package as Chrysler continues it negotiations in
coming months.  It is understood that many of the concessions will be arranged
conditionally and put in place only after the full commitment is cemented.

An important unknown in Chrysler's future is the temper of the three-man board
that will oversee the completion of the loan guarantee program.  If these
individuals are willing to accept credit commitments or concessions that will
not be honored until Chrysler regains a modicum of health, then the package
might be put together quickly, with little or no immediate increase in the
exposure of Chrysler's creditors.
Increasing Political Pressure

Banks will face increasing political pressure as other pieces of the credit
package which may affect their stance on new money are arranged.  One banker
said he expects the industry will not bend to political pressures, even though
the chairman of the Federal Reserve will sit on the three-man loan guarantee
board.  Other observers speculate that the banks may be taking a hard line early
in the negotiations in order improve their bargaining position in the later
stages of negotiations.

Bankers reached this week said that conversations between the banks and Chrysler
continue, but so far no specific proposals have been presented by the auto
maker.  No meetings are planned, but bankers expect Chrysler to informally
present details on its progress within a week or two.

                            Global Capital Euroweek

                                  May 2, 2003

Asia Loans

SECTION: ASIA

LENGTH: 1848 words


AUSTRALASIA

Australia

Arrangers Bank of America (Australia), National Australia Bank, RBS Australia
and WestLB (Sydney) have closed the A$1.25bn 15 year fundraising for Westlink
Motorway Partnership.

The deal was oversubscribed with a further nine banks committing to the
facility. As a result, a general syndication is not needed.

Lenders earn a margin that steps up over the life of the loan, starting from a
low of 150bp and rising to a high of 200bp over BBSY.

The facility takes the form of a construction facility for the first 3-1/2
years; thereafter it converts to a term loan for the remaining 11-1/2 years.

Proceeds finance the construction of the 39km Western Sydney Orbital road
project on a build, operate, own and transfer basis that will link Hume Highway,
south of Sydney, with Pennant Hills road and the F3 freeway in the north of
Sydney.

The total project cost will be A$1.5bn, of which the federal government will
provide A$356m. Details and allocations are being finalised with signing
scheduled to take place mid-May.

New Zealand

John Fairfax Holdings is acquiring INL's publishing businesses for NZ$1.188bn.

The takeover will be partly funded through a share placement of NZ$341m. A
syndicated loan will be mandated later this month.

INL's businesses include two metropolitan papers, two national newspapers, seven
regional dailies and 53 community publications.

Telecom Corp of New Zealand's$325m three year fundraising will close either
today (Friday) or on Monday. The deal was scheduled to close on April 30 but was
extended due to Easter.

ASIA

China

Standard Chartered has completed a HK$750m 3-1/2 year term loan for Shanghai
Jing Fu Property, an SPV in China guaranteed by Edward Wong Development Co, Shui
On Co and Shun Hing Holdings.

The arranger contributed HK$300m.

Participants are Hang Seng Bank (Shanghai), Wing Hang Bank and Development Bank
of Singapore (Shanghai) committing HK$150m apiece.

Proceeds are for the development of a commercial property project in Shanghai.

Hong Kong

Hang Lung Properties is forming an arranger group for its planned Hong Kong
dollar refinancing.

The exact amount of the facility has not been finalised but bankers suggest that
it is likely to be upwards of HK$3bn.

Bankers say that the structure of the deal is likely to be similar to the HK$4bn
five and seven year transaction that was syndicated in May last year.

A formal mandate should be awarded in mid-May.

Bankers working on the Hong Kong dollar credit for China Resources Holdings are
working on the information memorandum for the deal. Launch has been slated for
some time in the next two weeks.

Arrangers BayernLB, Crédit Lyonnais and National Australia Bank have launched a
HK$450m two year fundraising for Inchroy Credit Corp.

Invitations were sent out offering banks a margin of 27bp over Hibor and front
end fees on three levels.

Co-arrangers contributing HK$80m or more gain 30bp, lead managers providing
HK$50m-HK$70m are paid 26bp and managers lending HK$20m-HK$40m receive 24bp.

This is the borrower's first loan since a HK$1.5bn three year facility that was
completed by arranger BA Asia in August 1999.

That deal was priced at 115bp all-in for top tier commitments - substantially
more than the 42bp on offer from this transaction. Bankers point out that the
larger size and longer tenor plus the prevailing economic conditions must be
taken into account when comparing the two facilities.

Proceeds will refinance an existing Hong Kong dollar CD issue and provide funds
for general working capital. Responses are due by May 14.

Indonesia

State oil and gas company Pertamina has awarded a mandate to BNP Paribas to
arrange a project financing for its gas pipeline project in Java.

A commercial loan portion that will fund up to 30% of the cost with the
remainder to be provided by JBIC.

Proceeds are for the development of the Pagardewa gas pipeline that will connect
Sumatra to Java.

Korea

The$100m one year term loan for KorAm Bank, being arranged on a best efforts
basis, has so far received commitments from BayernLB, Commerzbank, Standard
Chartered, Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp, UniCredito and Union Bank of
California.

Three more banks are considering joining the facility which may take the size to
around$150.

m The borrower last tapped the market in December with a$100m two year term loan
arranged by Crédit Lyonnais, Natexis Banque Populaires, Standard Chartered and
Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp. Banks received a margin of 24bp and a top
participation fee of 22bp.

Proceeds for the latest facility are for general corporate use, with responses
due in early May.

Malaysia

IOI Corp Bhd's Eu230m five year deal has received an encouraging response from
the market with arranger Citigroup already receiving a number of written
commitments.

Responses are due next week.

Philippines

Bids were due earlier this week for the$200m loan deal for Philippine National
Oil Corp that will be guaranteed by the Republic of the Philippines.

Bankers say the borrower was looking for a three or five year financing.

The borrower recently received government approval to refinance an existing$175m
facility that funded the expansion of the Malampaya gas project.

A mandate will be awarded in a couple of weeks.

Bankers are waiting to hear if the government of the Philippines is going to
proceed with the proposed bond and loan facility for Psalm. Bids were submitted
over three weeks ago and no response has been forthcoming.

Some loan syndicators have suggested that the borrower may be considering its
options following the sovereign downgrade to BB by Standard & Poor's on April
24.

Taiwan

World Peace Industrial has granted a mandate to Chinatrust Commercial Bank to
arrange a NT$1bn three year revolving credit.

The borrower is involved with distribution, sales and marketing of electronic
components and devices.

Banks will receive a margin of 95bp over the secondary CP fixing rate. Fees are
being decided.

Proceeds are for working capital purposes with launch scheduled for mid-June.

Chinatrust Commercial Bank has been awarded the mandate for a NT$1.638bn
fundraising for Mercuries Data Systems.

The facility is divided between a NT$1.046.5bn three year, five month
performance bond guarantee facility, a NT$91.5m five year, five month
performance bond guarantee facility both paying a guarantee fee of 75bp and a
NT$500m three year, five month revolving credit that offers a margin of 80bp
over the CP fixing rate.

The borrower last tapped the market in December with a NT$1bn club facility
arranged by Hua Nan Commercial Bank, International Commercial Bank of China,
Shanghai Commercial & Savings Bank, Taiwan Co-operative Bank and Taipei Bank.
The facility was divided between a NT$500m five year term loan and a NT$500m
five year guarantee facility that pays fee of 70bp.

Banks received a margin of 70bp over the CP fixing rate for the first year which
stepped up to 110bp for the remaining four years of the loan. For the guarantee
facility lenders were paid a guarantee fee of 70bp.

Proceeds from the latest facility are to fund the construction of a
communications system for the Taiwan railway.

The deal will be launched in mid-May.

Arranger Chinatrust Commercial Bank has launched the NT$2bn three year term loan
for Universal Scientific. The facility was increased from NT$1.5bn after the
borrower cancelled its second fundraising of the year, a$45m deal that was to
have been arranged by Citigroup.

Banks earn a margin of 95bp over the CP fixing rate. Co-arrangers lending
NT$400m or more earn 10bp; senior managers pledging NT$300m-NT$399m receive 5bp;
and managers investing NT$200m-NT$299m gain 3bp.

Proceeds are for working capital purposes. Responses are due on May 23.

The NT$9bn fundraising for Tung Tsang Development is nearing closure after a
syndicate of 20 banks joined Bank of Taiwan. Among the participants are First
Commercial Bank and Kaohsiung Commercial Bank.

Proceeds are for the development of a shopping centre in Kaohsiung. Details and
final allocations are being finalised before the deal is signed in mid-May.

Arranger Citibank (Taipei) has received commitments from 14 banks totaling
$140.5m for the$120m five year financing for ASE Test Finance.

A handful of stragglers are still waiting for internal credit approval. Once
these have joined the facility will be closed.

The NT$5bn five year guarantee facility for Pou Chen Corp has been completed.
The deal was oversubscribed and increased from NT$3.5bn.

Arrangers include Bank of Taiwan contributing NT$600m, First Commercial Bank
taking NT$550m and BNP Paribas committing NT$250m.

Co-managers are International Commercial Bank of China and Standard Chartered
providing NT$500m apiece, and Chang Hwa Commercial Bank, Land Bank of Taiwan and
United World Commercial Bank of Taiwan lending NT$400m each.

Managers are Industrial Development Bank of China, Hua Nan Commercial Bank, Bank
of Taipei and Co-operative Bank of Taiwan taking NT$300m apiece and Shanghai
Commercial & Savings Bank pledging NT$200m.

Signing is tentatively scheduled to take place in Taipei on May 9.

Thailand

There are conflicting stories about the mandate for the$300m loan-style FRN for
Kingdom of Thailand.

Some bankers say a mandate has been awarded while others say a group of banks
including HSBC and Deutsche Bank are close to the deal.

RFPs were sent out over two weeks ago and a formal mandate was scheduled to be
awarded this week.

BLCP Power's $1.2bn equivalent project financing is making progress after nine
banks including Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp, ANZ Investment Bank, BNP Paribas,
Crédit Lyonnais KBC Bank, Fortis Bank, NordLB, SG Asia and WestLB were awarded
the mandate for a$500m offshore 16 year term loan.

The facility is divided into a$500m offshore portion that will include partial
funding from the Asian Development Bank for political risk insurance, a$500m
equivalent onshore tranche to be arranged by a group of Thai banks and a$200m
equity portion provided from the sponsors of the project, Banpu Coal and CLP
International.

JBIC will also provide funding for the project after the loan agreement signing
date, which is slated for the end of June.

Proceeds are for the development of a 1350MW coal fired power station in Map Ta
Phut.

ABN Amro, Standard Chartered and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking Corp have been awarded
a mandate to arrange a $37.5m financing for Laem Chabang Power Co, a wholly
owned subsidiary of Sime Darby. The arrangers are working on the structure of
the deal before launching to general syndication next week.

INDIAN SUBCONTINENT

The borrower last tapped the market with a $126.6m five year LC facility in
October last year. The response to the transaction was strong with arranger
Standard Chartered Bank receiving commitments in excess of$250.

                       St. Paul Pioneer Press (Minnesota)

                          September 29, 2011 Thursday

Fighting triggers civil war fears in Syria

BYLINE: Pioneer Press

SECTION: NATIONAL

LENGTH: 899 words


Syrian troops fought intense battles Friday with hundreds of fellow soldiers who
have turned their weapons against the regime of President Bashar Assad,
revealing the increasingly militarized nature of an uprising started months ago
by peaceful protesters.

Across the country, tens of thousands of demonstrators took to the streets as
they do each Friday, braving gunfire by government forces who have waged a
relentless crackdown. At least 11 protesters were killed and scores were
wounded, human rights groups said.

Opposition activists and the government confirmed a fourth straight day of
battles in Rastan, just north of the central city of Homs. The fighting is some
of the most intense since the outpouring against Assad's regime began in
mid-March.

The army defections as well as reports that once-peaceful protesters are
increasingly taking up arms to fight the 6-month-old government crackdown have
raised concerns of the risk of civil war in a country with a deep sectarian
divide.

Rights groups ask Libyans to end prisoner abuse

TRIPOLI, Libya - Human Rights Watch called on Libya's new rulers to stop armed
groups from rounding up suspected Moammar Gadhafi supporters and abusing them,
saying Friday that some detainees reporting beatings and electric shocks had the
scars to prove it.

The treatment of prisoners has become a litmus test for the transitional
government as it tries to rein in young men who fought in the civil war that
ousted Gadhafi and now refuse to lay down their weapons.

The New York-based rights group said it had visited 20 detention facilities in
Tripoli and interviewed 53 inmates, including 37 Libyans and 16 sub-Saharan
Africans.

Obama: Afghan withdrawal on track

WASHINGTON - Citing "huge challenges" ahead, President Barack Obama said he
still intends to withdraw 33,000 troops from Afghanistan by next year and said
the administration's strategy for winding down the war remains unchanged.

Obama made his declaration in a letter to congressional leaders Friday. The
letter accompanied a semiannual report assessing the administration's policy
toward Afghanistan and Pakistan.

The letter reports improvement in the fight against al-Qaida, as well as a
reversal in the Taliban's momentum in Afghanistan and headway in the training of
Afghan security forces.

Car bomb in Iraq kills 17 at funeral

BAGHDAD - A car bomb exploded Friday near a Shiite mosque south of Baghdad where
mourners had gathered for a funeral, killing 17 people, Iraqi officials said.

The explosion triggered new anger at Iraq's leaders and their armed forces, who
soon will take over responsibility for the country's security on their own as
U.S. troops rapidly leave the country.

Violence has dropped since the height of Iraq's bloodshed a few years ago, but
Iraqi forces have failed to stop attacks that continue to claim lives daily.

4 more solar loan guarantees OK'd

WASHINGTON - The Energy Department on Friday approved four more solar energy
loan guarantees worth nearly $5 billion, hours before a controversial loan
program was set to expire.

Energy Secretary Steven Chu said the department completed deals on four
projects, including two that were sold late this week by Arizona-based First
Solar Inc., a major solar manufacturer that had been seeking three federal loan
guarantees for projects in California.

The sales were announced Friday, along with the loan guarantees.

Potter e-book store opening delayed

LONDON - "Harry Potter" fans will have to wait a bit longer to buy the magic
tales in electronic form.

The creators of the online Potter portal said Friday that the launch of an
e-book store has been pushed back to next year.

The seven "Harry Potter" books had been due to go on sale this month,
exclusively through the "Pottermore" website.

The site is a combination of virtual encyclopedia, role-playing game and online
community for fans of author J.K. Rowling's boy wizard.

Perry touts record, bludgeons rivals

ATLANTA - Rick Perry said Friday that anyone with doubts about how he would
govern as president should simply look at Texas.

In his first domestic policy speech as a candidate for the White House, Perry
touted his record on taxes, health care and the environment during a decade at
the helm of the Lone Star state. But he used the brief outline of his tenure to
bludgeon his political rivals.

Perry drew a stark contrast between his record and that of Mitt Romney, his main
GOP opponent, and raised the specter of the health care law Romney ushered
through as governor of Massachusetts.

Legal drug injection site OK, court says

VANCOUVER, British Columbia - North America's only legal drug injection facility
saves lives and should stay open, Canada's Supreme Court ruled Friday.

The court's decision could facilitate the eventual opening of other facilities
in different cities, but the court's ruling applied only to the site in
Vancouver.

The facility called Insite was promoted by its founders as a safe, humane space
for drug abusers. Canada's Conservative government said it aids drug abuse, but
the court ruled the government should stop interfering in the controversial
clinic.

As of 2009, there were 65 injection facilities in 27 cities in Canada, Australia
and western Europe, according to the Canadian Medical Association Journal.

The World Health Organization has called them a "priority intervention" in
slowing the spread of AIDS via infected needles.

-- From news services

                                Kolkata Edition

Centre Plans Loan Melas to Boost Growth

BYLINE: SANGITA MEHTA MUMBAI

SECTION: FRONT PAGE

LENGTH: 590 words


Prime Minister Manmohan Singh's government is nudging state-run banks to dole
out at least.10,000 in unsecured loans to landless labourers to boost
consumption in rural areas which bankers say reminds one of 'loan melas' of the
1980s that crippled the industry.Public sector banks should also accelerate
distribution of Kisan Credit Cards to farmers who have not defaulted in the past
as it could fuel demand for goods and keep the rural economy humming even as
price rise eats into their earnings."Each bank will also work out a scheme of
providing savings or overdraft facility to families which do not have land,but
live in rural area," a letter to banks from a bureaucrat in the finance ministry
says.These loans should be for "personal consumption purposes" and based on
"personal guarantee" from a fellow villager.The UPA government is using PSU
banks to improve welfare of the rural population besides central welfare schemes
like MNREGA,a guaranteed employment programme.The slowing growth rate is making
the government to use non-traditional channels to keep the economy growing since
there is little room for monetary and fiscal measures.It is also asking banks to
play the mediator's role in getting clearances for projects from state
governments."Farmers have this psychological feeling that eventually there will
be a waiver of loans and they resist making payments in the same hope," said an
official of a state-run bank who did not want to be identified due to
sensitivity of the matter.Waiver Aims to Weed Out Money Lenders from the System
"Anything that is imposed on banks turns out to be a sticky loan," he added.The
UPA government,in its previous term,waived farm loans worth more than.40,000
crore before elections in 2009.The Congress-led governments in the past under
Indira Gandhi had also doled out loans that turned sticky.Janardhana Poojary,a
junior finance minister in the Indira Gandhi Cabinet in the 1980s,conducted '
loan melas' across the country that gave away loans to villagers without
guarantees.The barrister's socialist programme weakened the banking industry.The
government itself had to bail out these banks with taxpayers' money.But in a
poor country like India where more than half of the population lives with less
than.100 a day,welfare schemes such as these may keep the economy oiled.Also,the
fleecing by money lenders makes it essential for the government to push through
such schemes."The aim is to weed out money lenders from the system since they
are charging exorbitant rates from the segment of people who do not have access
to formal banking services," says RK Bakshi,executive director of Bank of
Baroda."Secondly,the purpose is also to provide means of earning to those who
are financially excluded." Government owned banks due to their extensive branch
network in rural India have over 80% market share in agri-loan
business.However,the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) data shows lending to
agriculture fell 11.8% in July 2011 on a yearon-year basis against 19% in July
2010.The ministry has said the loans can be given for meeting consumption
purpose based on personal guarantee given by villagers.As of March 2011,banks
provided overdraft facility of.198 crore to only 42 lakh no-frill account
holders.The letter to banks also says: "non-defaulting farmers has to be given
KCC by October 15 and the list of farmers without KCC will be made available at
the local district office of each village." By the end of March 2011,banks
issued.22.48 lakh KCC for an outstanding amount of.1,438 crore.

                      The Guelph Mercury (Ontario, Canada)

                           September 16, 2013 Monday
                                 First Edition

No assets to offer as collateral for dome loan, soccer says

BYLINE: Chris Herhalt, Mercury staff

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 453 words


Guelph Soccer doesn't want to be attached to a loan being renegotiated to save
the indoor soccer dome at Centennial Park because it has no meaningful assets to
offer as collateral, the not-for-profit's chair says.

Dave Tack confirmed Guelph Soccer spent $800,000 of its own money on building
and maintaining the soccer dome from 2007 to 2010, and about $210,000 in the
last three years helping another not-for-profit it set up, Guelph Community
Sports, meet its obligations.

"Guelph Soccer can't keep doing that," Tack said.

Guelph city council voted unanimously last Monday to order city staff to
renegotiate the deal on a $500,000 loan between Guelph Community Sports, Royal
Bank of Canada and the city, to extend its terms by five years and add Guelph
Soccer as a guarantor or co-signer.

Extending terms of the loan would lower the monthly payments enough to allow
Guelph Community Sports to meet all of its obligations without assistance from
Guelph Soccer.

Tack said council and city staff made several assertions last Monday that were
inaccurate.

Despite what was said, Tack said Guelph Community Sports made its August payment
on the outstanding loan.

"We continue to go into a deficit position with Guelph Soccer every month it
takes to resolve this," Tack said.

Tack added that Guelph Soccer first approached the city for advice on what do in
October 2012 and hoped the issue would be resolved by last July.

And only Tack sits on both the boards of Guelph Community Sports and Guelph
Soccer, contrary to what was stated in council.

Watching last Monday's meeting on television, Tack said he felt as though the
attitude on council was that Guelph Community Sports and Guelph Soccer had
approached the city with cap in hand, but there is less, not more risk if the
loan terms are extended.

"If the loan defaults today, it's $500,000 on the city," Tack said.

"But if the loan gets extended, every day the operation continues it's less of a
burden and risk for the city," Tack said.

"I don't blame the city for wanting all kinds of guarantees, but we're already
$1 million into this. I don't know how much further into this we could be."

Tack said that fundraising and sponsorship negotiations for the dome's turf
replacement, a $300,000-$350,000 project scheduled for 2018, will start this
winter.

As for a $1.2 million dome replacement, scheduled for 2023, Tack questioned
whether a new dome was even necessary once all debts on the facility have been
paid off.

"Why do we have to assume this inflatable facility has to be maintained for
life?" Tack said, adding that future indoor soccer matches could be played at
the Royal Distributing Athletic Performance Centre in Marden or at the
University of Guelph's indoor turf facility.

                        The Jamestown Sun (North Dakota)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            April 8, 2009 Wednesday

City Council supports hospital request

BYLINE: Toni Pirkl, The Jamestown Sun, N.D.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 786 words


Apr. 8--On a vote of 4-1, the City Council approved a certification of community
support for Jamestown Hospital's USDA loan application Tuesday at a special
meeting.

Once approved the USDA guarantees $40 million in a low-interest loan to build a
new hospital. Plus, another $8 million will be allocated in a direct USDA loan.
Both will finance construction a new regional medical facility in Jamestown.
Alan O'Neill, vice president of finance at James-town Hospital, said the cost of
building the new facility is estimated at $51.5 million, which means $3.5
million will need to be raised elsewhere.

Mayor Clarice Liechty, who was the lone vote against, said she had seen no
evidence of the "significant community support." The calls she has received do
not support the move, she said. However, she acknowledged she had heard from two
who do support building a new hospital at its planned location. The new hospital
will be built along Interstate 94 at the Highway 281 Bypass.

Liechty said she was called an "obstructionist" by one caller.

The significant community support is needed to access federal funding, O'Neill
said. The support is in reference to the fact that Jamestown Hospital is the
only hospital in town and, he said, is "providing a necessary service" to the
community.

The 45-minute meeting focused primarily on the hospital's plans and its
reasoning regarding a new facility. Most of the questions came from the mayor.
When other councilmembers said that the meeting was about certification for a
loan application, not about the project, Liechty said there may be people in the
audience who had questions as she did.

Referring to the need for a new facility, O'Neill read a letter from Dr. Robert
Wells, chief of the medical staff at Jamestown Hospital. In it, Wells said there
has been a significant shortage of physicians nationally, which is expected to
worsen as baby-boomers retire. At the same time, recruiting and keeping
high-quality physicians in Jamestown has gotten more difficult.

"This has forced us to consider ways in which we may become more competitive in
bringing doctors to Jamestown -- and keeping them here," Wells wrote.

A new state-of-the-art medical facility will not only provide high-quality
medical care, he said, but would be beneficial in attracting physicians to
Jamestown. The mayor questioned how a new hospital would bring in new doctors.

"Physicians are definitely attracted to the physical plant," said Dr. David
Plocher, a Minneapolis physician and consultant on the interior design and
layout of the new facility. Plocher has been gathering input from local
physicians on what they want to see in the facility.

Connie Krapp, vice chairman of the James-town Hospital Board of Trustees, said
the process to build a new hospital and its location was discussed for several
years by the board.

"We talked profoundly and repeatedly on the future of health care, particularly
rural health care," Krapp said. "The paradigms are changing in the health care
industry."

She said the board recognizes a new facility would be regional, especially as
small-town medical facilities lose doctors and services. That means the new
state-of-the-art hospital would be serving at least 65,000 people from the
region. Krapp said it's one of the reasons the congressional celegation supports
it.

"We're important regionally in the health care industry," she said. "We're
looking at a greater community than just Jamestown."

At one point, Councilman Pat Nygaard interrupted the mayor's questions, saying
"I'm not happy about the location either. I'd prefer it to stay downtown, but
according to the architect it's not possible. The project is going forward and
it's in everyone's best interest that we help them secure funding."

After the mayor's questions continued regarding the clinics' participation, the
medical office building and handling the debt load for a new hospital,
Councilwoman Kelani Parisien called the question.

"The issue before us is specifically the funding," Parisien said. "I don't see
any reason we should stand in the way of you accessing federal funding."

Parisien, Nygaard and Councilmen Ken Schulz and Charlie Kourajian voted in favor
of granting the certification.

tonip@jamestownsun.com

                     News-Journal (Daytona Beach, Florida)

                           December 19, 2009 Saturday
                    Flagler/palm Coast News-tribune Edition

Geithner unveils exit plan for TARP

BYLINE: AARON LONDON, AARON LONDON - STAFF WRITER

SECTION: SECTION B; Pg. 1B

LENGTH: 536  words


Emergency intervention by the federal government staved off a collapse of the
financial system, but that cannot go on forever. Still, the government can't
just pull the plug on its assistance to banks and other financial services
firms, either. Instead, a coordinated strategy is required.

That was the message delivered earlier this month to the Congressional Oversight
Panel by Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner. A copy of Geithner's prepared
remarks is available online at treasury.gov.

After briefly outlining the government response to the financial crisis,
Geithner said there is still work to be done.

We need to continue to find ways to help mitigate foreclosures for responsible
homeowners and to get credit to small businesses," he said. "We also must
maintain the capacity to address potential threats to our financial system,
which could undermine the recovery we have seen to date."

Geithner outlined four elements to ending the Troubled Asset Relief Program, the
primary governmental vehicle for propping up banks and other financial services
firms and stabilizing the financial system.

The first is to continue the policy of winding down other programs created to
meet the financial crisis, including the Money Market Guarantee program, the
Temporary Liquidity Guarantee Program and some Federal Reserve Board credit
programs.

With respect to (the Troubled Asset Relief Program), support for large financial
institutions is coming to an end," Geithner said.

The next step is to focus more directly on consumer and small- business issues,
Geithner said. That includes working to help consumers avoid foreclosures,
promoting initiatives to provide capital to small and community banks and
possibly increase the government's commitment to the Term Asset-Backed
Securities Loan Facility, a program that has improved stability in
securitization markets that help facilitate consumer and small-business lending.

Geithner pledged that beyond the commitment to stabilize and encourage consumer
and small-business lending, the government would not use remaining Emergency
Economic Stabilization Act funds "unless necessary to respond to an immediate
and substantial threat to the economy stemming from financial instability." The
act -- also known more popularly as the "stimulus package" -- has been a
cornerstone of the government's response to the financial crisis and subsequent
economic recession.

Geithner said the government needs to maintain the capacity to respond to
threats to the financial system, and he recently extended authority granted to
the Department of Treasury under the stimulus package to intervene in the
financial system.

The final piece of the exit strategy outlined by Geithner focuses on management
of equity investments made through the bailout program.

We will exercise our voting rights only on core issues such as election of
directors, and not interfere in the day-to-day management of individual
companies," he said.

In conclusion, Geithner warned the oversight panel of the dangers of pulling
government support for the economy too quickly.

History suggests that exiting too soon from policies designed to contain a
financial crisis can significantly prolong an economic downturn," he said.

                       Weekend Courier (Perth, Australia)

                              July 4, 2008 Friday
                                   1 Edition

$75m for spending on town

SECTION: Pg. 1

LENGTH: 358 words


Budget will deliver on promises, mayor says

KWINANAs Looking Forward Campaign moved another step ahead after Kwinana Town
Council approved spending $75m, including $46m capital expenditure, to deliver a
range of new infrastructure projects in the 2008/09 budget.

The budget provoked heated debate before it was approved 6-2 at the special
meeting on Wednesday night. With residents facing a 6 per cent rates increase,
some councillors disagreed with the inclusion of millions of dollars of loans
for projects without detailed costing or guarantee of grant funding.

Kwinana Mayor Carol Adams said the budget would deliver on councils promises to
provide improved infrastructure for the Kwinana community.

This budget starts Kwinana down a path where we can provide an improved level of
service to our current and future residents, and also guarantees our long-term
sustainability, she said.

Kwinana Progress Association president Steve Hesse said he was concerned about
the impact a 6 per cent rate increase would have on residents.

Why are we paying now for what has been neglected in Kwinana for the past 20
years? he said. It is ok for some, but other people in the community, such as
pensioners, are struggling to pay their rates.

Cr Adams said for residents on the minimum rate the increase equated to an extra
$20 for the year.

We will be providing almost 80 per cent more funds to develop services and
facilities in exchange for a 6 per cent residential rate increase, she said.

Industrial ratepayers will face an increase of 8.5 per cent, including a 1.5 per
cent streetscape beautification levy.

Cr Glen Bersan argued he did not believe industry would agree to a 1.5 per cent
levy for streetscape beautification, when funds collected from a 2.6 per cent
levy introduced a few years ago remained unused.

The council will generate nearly $17.2m rates income in the next financial year
and raise loans of up to $14.5m.

This includes $2.5m for Rockingham Road Streetscape Beautification, $4.5m for a
Knowledge Centre, $1.1m for Wellard Community Centre, $1.5m for a youth
facility, $1.5m for Orelia Oval Pavilion and $1m for Administration Centre
renovations.

                              The Nation (AsiaNet)

                           January 10, 2008 Thursday

New financing scheme for small farmers

BYLINE: OUR STAFF REPORTER

LENGTH: 604 words


KARACHI - State Bank of Pakistan has developed a Financing Scheme on group-based
methodology for the small farmers involved in crop and non-crop activities in
order to improve the access to finance to such farmers who are unable to meet
adequate collaterals requirements of commercial banks. SBP said that under the
scheme, the banks would provide loans to the members of small farmers' group for
crops and non-crop activities, based on their cash flow under joint cross
guarantee of group members.

The scheme covers all areas of the group-based financing methodology including'
group formation, roles & responsibilities of members, bank & group coordinator,
size and tenure of loans, documentation and other related matters. However,
financing to small farmers under the scheme shall be subject to compliance with
SBP regulations on agriculture financing.

It may be pointed out that under group-based lending programs; loans are given
to individuals through a peer group. In this case, group members guarantee
repayment, of each other's loans and collateral is generally not used but peer
pressure and collective responsibilities generated by the group take their
place.

However, the exact amount of loan will be determined by the bank based on
genuine requirements and cash flow of the applicant. Maximum period of loan
should be fixed as per Prudential Regulations repayment schedule may be set as
per production cycle of the crop/non-crop activities being financed or revolving
credit facility for three years subject to mandatory clean up of entire
liabilities (both principal and mark up) once in a year or cash flow of the
borrower in case of non-crop activities.

Banks are advised that they should have detailed understanding and information
about the borrower's business and his/her assets as well as his/her capacity to
effectively use and repay the loan. Moreover, under the scheme the loan can be
extended for working capital requirement of the farming community both for crop
as well as non- crop activities.

Banks can also provide term loan facility to small farmers for making different
types of improvements in the land, construction of sheds/ ponds, development of
orchards/nurseries, purchase of livestock, farm implements, machinery, tube
wells, generators etc.

Banks are advised to arrange insurance of the amount of loan disbursed for crop
and non-crop activities (wherever available) and life insurance of the borrower
to safeguard the interest of the borrower and the bank, in case of losses due to
natural calamity or event beyond the control of the borrower. In addition, where
the agricultural loans have been extended for specified purposes, the banks/DFls
are advised to ensure that the loans have been utilized for the same purposes
for which they were obtained.

For this purpose, the banks/DFls may consider it prudent to make payments
directly to the suppliers wherever appropriate.

However, this provision will not apply on farmers who are provided loans under
Revolving Credit Scheme. It may be pointed out that the outreach of agricultural
credit is limited to the extent of about 2m borrowers as against total farmer's
population of 6.6m. Majority of the country's farmers i.e. 84% comprises of
small farmers and rely on informal sector credit at exorbitant rates to meet
their agricultural credit requirements.

One of the main reasons of the financial exclusion of these small farmers has
been their inability to provide collateral to banks. It is expected that the
problem of financial exclusion will be mitigated with the introduction of
group-based financing scheme for small farmers.

                         Deming Headlight (New Mexico)

                            January 30, 2007 Tuesday

USDA Rural Development Renewable Energy Workshops

BYLINE: For the Headlight

SECTION: LOCAL

LENGTH: 486 words


To be Held in Rural New Mexico

For the Headlight

ALBUQUERQUE   USDA Rural Development State Director Ryan Gleason announced that
Rural Development will present a series of workshops designed to teach
individuals and businesses located in rural communities how to access financing
for renewable energy projects.

In making the announcement, Gleason said, "Although most people don't realize
it, rural America is playing a vital role in moving our nation away from the
dependence on foreign oil as our primary source of energy." Gleason added, "We
have seen increased production and development of alternative power sources such
as ethanol, biofuels and wind energy in rural communities, farms, and ranches
across the nation."

Currently, the U.S. Department of Agriculture Rural Development offers financing
for eligible renewable energy and energy efficiency projects with both grants
and guaranteed loans through its 9006 program. This program funds grants and
loan guarantees to eligible rural small businesses, farmers, ranchers and other
agricultural producers to assist in purchasing renewable energy systems and
making energy efficiency improvements.

Under the 9006 program, USDA Rural Development will guarantee a loan of up to
$10 million. For renewable energy systems, the minimum grant request is $2,500
and the maximum is $500,000. For energy efficiency improvements, the minimum
grant request is $1,500 and the maximum is $250,000. However, no more than 25%
of an eligible project costs can be in the form of a grant.

Renewable energy systems include biofuels, wind, solar, geothermal and
hydrogen-based projects using commercially proven technology. Energy efficiency
projects include improvements to a facility, building or process that reduce
energy consumption such as upgrading electric motors in equipment, more energy
efficient lighting, insulation, and upgrading electrical or heating systems.

More information on both components of the 9006 program can be found at:
http://www.rurdev.usda.gov/rbs/farmbill .

USDA Rural Development will host workshops in February and March of 2007 in New
Mexico to provide producers and rural businesses with information on what is
available and how to make an application for assistance. Rural areas include any
area other than cities or towns of greater than 50,000 population and the
immediate and adjacent urbanized areas of the cities or towns. Eligible small
businesses include sole proprietorships, partnerships, corporations and
cooperatives that meet the Small Business Administration's (SBA) small business
size standards.

The application process has been simplified, with projects under $200,000
eligible for a streamlined submission process.

Dates and times for the workshops will soon be announced. Interested parties can
request application material or participants can learn more and register for
these workshops by calling Rural Development at (505) 761-4953.

                     The Glenville Democrat (West Virginia)

                                November 5, 2015

USD A Provides Funding for Over 1,100 Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency
Projects Nationwide

BYLINE: The Glenville Democrat staff

LENGTH: 785  words


Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack today announced that USDA is awarding loans
and grants that will help more than 1,100 rural small businesses and
agricultural producers reduce energy usage and costs in their operations. The
funding is for energy efficiency improvements and/or renewable energy systems.
USDA is financing projects in every state, as well as in the Virgin Islands, the
Western Pacific and the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico.

"More rural business owners and ag producers are incorporating energy-saving
measures into their business plans," Vilsack said. "These actions improve an
operation's bottom line and help reduce its carbon footprint. This funding will
help incorporate renewable energy and energy efficiency technology and reduce
energy costs. But beyond the local benefits seen by a company saving energy
costs and the global benefits of reducing carbon emissions, this funding will
also create American jobs by supporting energy production and efficiency
installations that are made in rural America."

USDA is providing $102 million in loan guarantees and $71 million in grants for
1,114 projects financed through the Rural Energy for America Program (REAP).
Among the projects, nearly $6 million is being awarded for 17 anaerobic
digesters in California, Maine, Massachusetts, Michigan, New York, North
Carolina, Ohio and Washington. In total, these projects are expected to generate
and/or save 906 million kilowatt hours (KWh) of energy -- enough to power more
than 83,675 homes for a year and cut carbon pollution by an estimated 455,000
metric tons. That is the equivalent of taking more than 131,500 cars off the
road for a year.

The owners of Parker Farms in Ripley, Tenn., are receiving a $45,000 REAP grant
to help finance the installation of a 50 kilowatt solar system that, was
installed late last year. The system has lowered the grain farm's average
monthly electric bill by $800 -- from $1,140 to $340. That is a savings of
nearly $10,000 a year. The solar system covers more than 70 percent of the
farm's annual electric costs. Parker Farms participates in the Tennessee Valley
Authority's (TVA) Green Power Providers program and sells 100 percent of its
solar electricity to TVA at a premium.

Fresh Air Energy XVI, LLC is receiving a $3.8 million loan guarantee to finance
a 6.5 megawatt solar array in Greene County, North Carolina. The project is
expected to produce enough energy to power 1,000 average-sized homes for a year.
This is one of several loans the company is receiving to expand the use of solar
energy in the state.

In Pearl City, Hawaii, the owner of the wholesale bakery "The Patisserie, Inc."
is being awarded a $256,000 loan guarantee and a

$128,000 grant to install a photovoltaic system. It is-expected to generate
172,000 kilowatts of energy annually and reduce energy use by nearly 40 percent.

Congress created the REAP program in the 2002 Farm Bill. Because of the success
of the program, Congress reauthorized it in the 2014 Farm Bill with guaranteed
funding of at least $50 million annually for the duration of the five-year bill.
The 2014 Farm Bill builds on historic economic gains in rural America over the
past seven years while achieving meaningful reform and billions of dollars in
savings for taxpayers.

Since the start of the Obama Administration, REAP has helped finance 10,753
renewable energy and energy efficiency projects that have reduced energy costs
for rural businesses nationwide. During this period, USDA has provided almost
$360 million in grants and $430 million in loan guarantees to agricultural
producers and rural small business owners. When operational, these projects will
generate/save an estimated 8.4 million megawatt hours -- enough to power more
than 760,000 homes for a year and reduce greenhouse gas emissions by almost 5
million metric tons of carbon dioxide. That' s the equivalent of removing more
than 1 million cars from the road.

Funding of each award announced today is contingent upon the recipient meeting
the terms of the loan or grant agreement.

In addition to the grants announced today, USDA is reminding eligible recipients
that the department is accepting applications for future REAP funding. For
application deadlines and details on how to apply, contact a USDA state energy
coordinator, or see page 60349 of the October 6 Federal Register.

President Obama's plan for rural America has brought about historic investment
and resulted in stronger rural communities. Under the President's leadership,
these investments in housing, community facilities, businesses and
infrastructure have empowered rural America to continue leading the way --
strengthening America's economy, small towns and rural communities.

                       Marlborough Express (New Zealand)

                              March 4, 2016 Friday

'Giving away ratepayer guarantees'

BYLINE: ELENA MCPHEE

SECTION: NEWS; NATIONAL; Pg. 3

LENGTH: 591 words


A Marlborough councillor is furious the council has again been asked to stump up
for Blenheim's new ASB Theatre.

Jessica Bagge said the Marlborough District Council should consider independent
advice before guaranteeing another loan for the $23 million theatre.

It was not prudent to simply rely on financial information provided by the
Marlborough Civic Theatre Trust, Bagge said.

A meeting would be held on Monday for councillors to decide whether to guarantee
an ASB Bank loan of $1.5m.

"They're giving away ratepayer guarantees left and right," Bagge said.

The trust needed the loan to complete the theatre by opening night on March 16.

An agenda prepared for the meeting recommended the council took "long-term
views" and guaranteed the loan.

Bagge said the agenda was "slanted and emotive" in favour of the trust.

"We need neutral experts who can give us apolitical advice," Bagge said.

"I'm tired of this 'trust my mate' routine."

The trust already had a $3.1m loan facility from the ASB Bank, guaranteed by the
council behind closed doors last year.

The council was also guarantor for a $500,000 loan from the Canterbury Community
Trust.

Bagge said Mayor Alistair Sowman told the council last April the build was fixed
at $21.5m.

Council chief executive Mark Wheeler, who prepared the agenda, said the report
for Monday's meeting was factual.

"If they don't get the funding, they will run out of money," he said.

The council could have the financial report reviewed, but it could take weeks
and be very expensive, he said.

Wheeler was convinced the financial information was "robust", he said.
Councillor Jamie Arbuckle said councillors had been asking for financial updates
about the theatre for years, but this was the first time a full report was
available.

The request for a guarantee was a shock, but councillors had no choice but to
vote for it.

It was like a "gun to your head", Arbuckle said.

He said the council's governance of the project needed to be reviewed.

Bagge said she was not convinced the trust was spending money on "must-haves",
such as a $183,000 stage lift before a kitchen. Theatre trust chairman Kevin
Moseley said the stage lift was planned at the start of the project, but it was
unclear if it would go ahead after the Christchurch earthquakes.

The trust made the decision to install the lift because it would have cost up to
$70,000 to fill in the hole, only to open it up again.

Neighbouring organisation Clubs of Marlborough would provide catering until the
kitchen was finished, Moseley said.

Nearly $2m had been raised in fundraising since September.

"We are still raising money, and we haven't stopped," Moseley said.

Total fundraising for the project had reached nearly $8m.

Enough money to complete the theatre had been pledged, but the trust would
receive the money over the next 10 years, Moseley said.

Bagge said there seemed to be no end in sight to expenditure on the theatre.

She applauded the council's decision not to exclude the public from the meeting
on Monday.

Councillor David Oddie said the council was "between a rock and a hard place".

The council did not have all the information to make a decision yet, but he was
confident it would be available on Monday, he said.

Councillors Graeme Barsanti and Jenny Andrews said they supported the theatre.
The Christchurch earthquake was a "game- changer" for the building, which no-one
asked for, Andrews said.

                      The Guelph Mercury (Ontario, Canada)

                            September 6, 2013 Friday
                                 First Edition

Indoor soccer dome in money trouble;
Loan default could leave taxpayers on hook for $500,000, report says

BYLINE: Chris Herhalt, Mercury staff

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. A1

LENGTH: 561 words


The not-for-profit group behind a struggling indoor soccer dome that sits unused
five months per year has asked the City of Guelph for a helping hand.

Without changes, the current arrangement between Guelph Community Sports, the
City of Guelph and a bank could leave taxpayers on the hook for $500,000 should
the not-for-profit default on payments on a loan, a recently released city staff
report suggests.

Guelph Community Sports is a non-profit group set up by the soccer club to build
and operate the dome.

The club is the main tenant, but the dome is open to the public and other sports
leagues.

City staff recommends Guelph Community Sports extend the repayment schedule of a
bank loan from to 15 years from 10, and add Guelph Soccer, a separate
not-for-profit entity, as another guarantor.

Guelph Soccer's executive director Christy Rumfeldt said that although Guelph
Soccer will agree to guarantee Guelph Community Sports some revenue by promising
to rent the dome's space for the next 10 years, it will not allow itself to be
made a guarantor on the loan.

"We're not going to be on the hook," Rumfeldt said. "We also have to protect our
membership."

She added that under no circumstance would soccer registration fees increase as
a result of any administrative or financial changes being discussed regarding
the indoor soccer dome. The matter goes before Guelph city council on Monday.

In 2006, a group of local sports clubs led by Guelph Soccer asked the city to
help them build a "multi-use artificial field facility."

The city responded by granting the groups a 25-year lease on a parcel of land at
Centennial Park, with an option to renew for another 25 years, plus $100,000 to
service and grade the parcel of land.

To avoid development charges and property taxes, the city structured "the
arrangement as a municipal capital facility" and co-signed and guaranteed a
$900,000 bank loan to fund the soccer dome's operation.

Guelph Soccer Club is the primary tenant of the facility, and Rumfeldt said it
"oversees day-to-day facility operations."

Because there is no air conditioner installed at the dome, city staff report the
turf has sat unrented during the warmer months. This has "in effect lowered
revenue and cash-flow projections," the staff report stated. Guelph Community
Sports has been able to make payments on the loan thus far, whittling down the
remaining balance to $500,000, with help in the form of an interest-free loan
from Guelph Soccer.

But now, even Guelph Soccer has indicated to the city it can no longer "cover
the annual cash shortfall" between expected and actual revenues at the dome.

Making matters worse, the dome's artificial field turf will require replacing
within the next five years, at a cost of $350,000. And the dome itself will need
replacing within the next 10 years, at a cost of $1.2 million. City staff
reports that both of these "substantial infrastructure life cycle replacements"
are "currently unfunded."

Rumfeldt said Guelph Community Sports and Guelph Soccer Club could pay for at
least the looming artificial turf replacement through fundraising.

"That's something that's tangible. It's something that our membership will
support because they will want to have this."

But Rumfeldt said replacing the dome will require collaboration between the
city, Guelph Soccer, and other sporting organizations.

cherhalt@guelphmercury.com
