                         St. Petersburg Times (Florida)

                      May 23, 1992, Saturday, City Edition

New loans approved for Key Center

BYLINE: KEN MORITSUGU

SECTION: CITRUS TIMES; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 401 words

DATELINE: CRYSTAL RIVER



The Key Training Center has been approved for $ 600,000 in loans through the
Farmers Home Administration to build a thrift shop and employment training
center for its mentally retarded clients.

    The center plans to build an 8,000-square-foot building on 3 acres next to
its retail plant nursery on State Road 44, said Chet Cole, executive director of
Key Training Center.

    The front half of the building will house a thrift shop, similar to the
center's other three thrift shops around the county. The shops raise money for
its programs.

    In the rear, about 30 clients will work on crafts and process goods coming
into the thrift shop for sale. The building also will have a job service office
to help handicapped people find jobs.

    "It's going to enable our folks to have jobs in the community," Cole said at
a news conference Friday at the nursery. He said he hopes to have the new
building open by early next year.

    Farmers Home approved a $ 550,000 loan with a 5.75-percent interest rate for
the project about a month ago. The money comes from a program that helps develop
facilities to provide essential services in rural communities.

    On Friday, Farmers Home presented a letter of commitment to guarantee a $
50,000, 9-percent loan to Key Training Center from SunBank & Trust Co. The money
will be used to purchase equipment for the employment training center.

    The second loan is the first in Florida under a 3-year-old program in which
a private financial institution makes the loan, and Farmers Home commits to
reimburse up to 90 percent of the loan amount if the borrower defaults.

    The federal guarantee helps financial institutions make loans to needy
organizations that otherwise might not get them, said Jim Cherry, state director
for Farmers Home.     "By SunBank coming in and being willing to do this, that
allows us to use that $ 50,000 somewhere else in the state," he said.

    Farmers Home has introduced a similar guaranteed loan program for housing
for moderate-income people. The first home built in Florida under the program,
completed in March, was in Citrus County, too.

    Crystal River Bank made the 9-percent mortgage loan for the $ 48,000 home on
N Conant Avenue, which, coincidentally, is close to the planned site of the new
Key Training Center building.

                        THANET YOUTH & COMMUNITY CENTRE

                           Manila Times (Philippines)

                           September 15, 2006 Friday

BSP EXEMPTS GOCCS FROM DOSRI LENDING RULES

BYLINE: Likha C. Cuevas

LENGTH: 407 words


THE Monetary Board (MB), the policymaking body of the Bangko Sentral ng
Pilipinas (BSP), has decided to exempt loans and other credit accommodations by
government banks to government-owned and -controlled corporations (GOCCs) from
the ceilings imposed on unsecured loans to directors, officers, stockholders and
their related interests (Dosri).

Specifically, the MB said the loans for relending to other participating
financial institutions or end-users (as part of the national government's
lending program) and loans to rediscounting facilities and guarantee programs
that extends credit to agricultural sector and micro, small and medium
enterprises (MSMEs) are exempted from the ceiling.

At present, the aggregate ceiling of 15 percent of the bank's total loan
portfolio or 100-percent networth, whichever is lower, is imposed to limit total
outstanding loans to all Dosri.

Total unsecured loans to each Dosri, on the other hand, should not exceed 30
percent of their respective total loans, other credit accommodations and/or
guarantees. Total unsecured loans to all Dosri should not exceed 30 percent of
the aggregate Dosri ceiling or the outstanding loans, other credits and/or
guarantees, whichever is lower.

The total secured and secured Dosri loans extended to GOCCs should not exceed
the individual ceiling, which limits the total outstanding loans to each of the
bank's Dosri to their respective unencumbered deposits plus the book value of
their capital contribution to the lending bank.

Because of these limits, state banks like the Development Bank of the
Philippines and the Land Bank of the Philippines are constrained in extending
loans to GOCCs that are tasked to implement infrastructure projects and social
services.

Under the revision, loans extended by government banks to GOCCs to serve the
credit needs of agribusiness, especially in the rural areas, and MSMEs are now
exempted from the 30-percent ceiling on unsecured loans.

However, the unsecured loans would still be counted for complying with the
individual and aggregate ceilings on total loans to Dosri. Unsecured loans would
also be deductible from regulatory capital for the computation of capital
adequacy calculation.

"This is to ensure that national government objectives can be pursued within the
context of financially viable banking institutions without sacrificing
prudential requirements as well as conformity with international best
practices," the BSP said.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                        Contra Costa Times (California)

                            February 5, 2010 Friday

Boxer, Fiorina tend to their East Bay flocks

BYLINE: By Josh Richman Oakland Tribune

SECTION: POLITICS; My Town; Alameda; News; Local

LENGTH: 555 words


Republican U.S. Senate candidate Carly Fiorina visited Oakland on Friday to talk
about veterans issues, just after incumbent U.S. Sen. Barbara Boxer visited
Fremont to talk about green jobs.

But the word on many lips at both events was "Baaaaaa."

Fiorina released a Web video Wednesday taking GOP primary challenger Tom
Campbell to task as a "FCINO," or a Fiscal Conservative In Name Only. The ad
attacks his record as state finance director under Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger,
and his support of temporary tax hikes rather than draconian cuts alone to close
last year's enormous budget deficit.

But the national buzz over the ad has been less about the video's message and
more about its imagery, including a man in a sheep costume with glowing red
eyes, crawling around in a pasture among real sheep. Campbell and a third GOP
primary candidate, Chuck DeVore, quickly pounced on the bizarre imagery, as did
political pundits far and wide.

"I'm glad people are laughing at the ad. It's a funny ad. But I also think half
a million people have watched the ad," a decidedly unsheepish Fiorina said
Friday. "No one has disputed the facts."

"People can interpret that ad however they like," she added. "I think you'll see
our campaign communicating with voters in hopefully a very memorable,
entertaining and different way."

Meanwhile, Boxer, D-Calif.   whom Fiorina hopes to challenge and unseat in
November's general election   was in Fremont to visit Solyndra Inc., which is
using a $535 million federal loan guarantee it received through last year's
economic-stimulus legislation to build a solar-panel manufacturing plant.

"My opponents are fighting over 'demon sheep' and I am fighting for jobs in
California, and that's what I'm going to continue to do," Boxer said.

Fiorina seemed to please most of the two dozen veterans gathered at the
Warehouse Bar and Grill by saying she opposes closing the Guantánamo Bay, Cuba,
detention facility for terrorism suspects, and opposes trying such people in
civilian courts.

"We don't have to prove to these people that our system of justice works," she
said. "An enemy combatant has not earned the rights of an American citizen."

But she got a wide range of responses to her stance that the "don't ask, don't
tell" policy on gays in the military should be repealed if military leaders say
so. She said it seems a shame that patriots can't serve without lying about who
they are, especially in time of war.

Similarly, the veterans seemed split over her support of President Barack
Obama's decision to lift his predecessor's ban on news photography of slain
troops' coffins as they return to the United States.

Earlier Friday afternoon, Boxer had a private briefing and a manufacturing-floor
tour with Solyndra executives, discussing how the federal loan guarantee is
letting the company build a second manufacturing plant for its thin-film,
tube-shaped solar modules that maximize energy output while minimizing
installation costs. The new plant, just down Kato Road from the existing one and
twice as large, is projected to create 3,000 temporary construction jobs and an
estimated 1,000 long-term production jobs.

"This is our future. This is the platform that's going to launch us into being
the world's economic leader" for years to come, Boxer said.

Read the Political Blotter at www.ibabuzz.com/politics .

                            The Times of India (TOI)

                              July 26, 2013 Friday

Hudco loan for fishermen's houses

SECTION: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM

LENGTH: 174 words


THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The cabinet on Wednesday accorded sanction to the state
coastal development corporation for sourcing a loan of Rs 150 crore under
government guarantee from the Housing and Urban Development Corporation (Hudco)
to roll out a housing project for fishermen community.

A release from fisheries and port development minister said Hudco had earlier
suggested that it was willing to sanction a loan of Rs 150 crore for the purpose
if the government gave a repayment guarantee.

Official estimates say there are 25,000 fishermen families without proper
housing facilities. The housing project is part of a Rs 3,000-crore project
submitted by the corporation to the government.

Of Rs 350 crore needed for the first phase of the welfare works, Rs 200 crore
will be sourced from the National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development
(Nabard) and the rest from Hudco. The housing scheme envisages providing flats
to 11,000 fish workers once the respective local bodies hand over the land to
the corporation.

                   The Record-Eagle (Traverse City, Michigan)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                           August 18, 2010 Wednesday

Federal loans allow local company to add jobs

BYLINE: Art Bukowski, The Record-Eagle, Traverse City, Mich.

SECTION: BUSINESS AND FINANCIAL NEWS

LENGTH: 484 words


Aug. 18--TRAVERSE CITY -- Millions of dollars in U.S. government-backed loans
will allow a Traverse City manufacturer to expand, diversify and add more people
to its payroll.

"For us, it's a very, very important thing to give back to our community, and
how we do that is providing manufacturing jobs," said Dodd Russell, president of
Skilled Manufacturing Inc.

U.S. Department of Agriculture officials on Tuesday announced a total of nearly
$7.8 million in guaranteed loans to SMI. The loans, issued by the Bank of
Northern Michigan and backed by the USDA, will allow the company to restructure
its debt and buy additional equipment. The plant shifted into the aerospace
industry two years ago and produces components for various military and civilian
aircraft.

The company also plans to add 25 more jobs at its facility on Aero Park Drive in
Traverse City, Russell said. It's already hired 50 new workers and also is
sub-contracting work to other area parts suppliers.

U.S. Sen. Carl Levin, who attended Tuesday's announcement, said it's important
for government to support manufacturers across the nation.

"Government must work as a partner with manufacturing," Levin said. "If we're
going to have a strong manufacturing base, it's not just going to come out of
thin air."

State and local governments also are helping out the company. The Michigan
Economic Growth Authority in December approved a state tax credit of $571,210
for Skilled Manufacturing apread over the next seven years.

The city commission last fall approved a 12-year industrial facility tax
abatement worth more than $13,700 per year in local property-tax reduction. The
city also approved a 6-year personal property-tax abatement on new equipment
worth almost $26,700 per year.

USDA officials said the agency is stepping up its activity in Michigan with a
flurry of business and industrial loan guarantees, along with other federal
funding for housing and public infrastructure projects like water and sewer
upgrades. The USDA also has money available for renewable energy projects and
value-added producer grants.

State Director James Turner said in a recent interview the USDA approved $12
million in business loan guarantees in Michigan last year and plans to
distribute around $109 million in 2010. The department has spent more than $1.5
billion in Michigan since the fall of 2008.

"We are open for business," Turner said.

Business editor Bill O'Brien contributed to this report.

                        The Daily Record (Baltimore, MD)

                            December 28, 2007 Friday

News Summary - 12/28

BYLINE: Staff and wire reports

LENGTH: 1425  words


Coca-Cola eyes Honest Tea

Coca-Cola Co. is close to making an investment in Bethesda-based soft drink
maker Honest Tea for an undisclosed amount, according to a published report. The
move, reported by Beverage Digest, would allow Coca-Cola to expand its beverage
selection amid slumping cola sales. Honest Tea makes organic tea drinks, as well
as juices and a line of beverages for children. In its eighth year in business,
Honest Tea posted $13.5 million in annual sales. The company would join Coke's
line of noncarbonated beverages in North America, including Glaceau's Vitamin
Water, Fuze and Campbell's.

Novavax flu trial

Rockville-based Novavax Inc. announced favorable interim results from a Phase
I/IIa human clinical trial of its flu vaccine candidate. In the initial stage of
this study, 70 healthy adults 18 to 40 years of age received two doses of the
H5N1 VLP (non-adjuvanted pandemic influenza virus-like particle) vaccine
candidate or a placebo. The goal was to evaluate safety and immunogenicity, or
the ability to provoke an immune response. The interim results indicate that the
vaccine was well tolerated in all study groups.

Baltimore Main Streets expand

To provide even greater support to the city's smaller commercial districts, the
Baltimore Development Corp. said it plans to expand the Baltimore Main Streets
program in 2008. In preparation for that expansion, the program will host two
application workshops. The first will occur on Jan. 7, from 6:00 to 8:00 p.m. at
the Baltimore Museum of Industry at 1415 Key Highway. The second workshop is
scheduled for Jan. 8, from 1:00 to 3:00 p.m. at Maryland Nonprofits, 190 West
Ostend Street. The Main Street approach is a comprehensive strategy for
commercial district revitalization.

USEC applauds Congress

USEC Inc. commended Congress and the administration for their strong support for
the renaissance of the nuclear power industry through the loan guarantee program
administered by the U.S. Department of Energy, included in the omnibus
appropriations legislation (H.R. 2764) signed Wednesday by President George W.
Bush. The legislation includes loan guarantee authority for up to $38.5 billion
in energy projects, including $18.5 billion of loan guarantees for nuclear power
facilities. USEC, a Bethesda-based global energy company, intends to pursue a
DOE loan guarantee for construction of its American Centrifuge Plant in Piketon,
Ohio.

Women entrepreneurs square off

The deadline for women entrepreneurs to enter Rockville Economic Development
Inc. 's fifth annual Start Right! Women's Business Plan Competition is Jan. 28.
The competition is open to 51 percent women-owned businesses in Maryland,
Washington and Virginia that have been in business for no longer than two years.
This year's first-place winner will receive $10,000 (sponsored by Eagle Bank)
and nine months of a customized virtual office solution (provided by The
Intelligent Office). The second-place winner will receive $5,000 and six months
of a customized virtual office solution. Winners will be selected by a panel of
judges on Feb. 29.

'Art of Healing'

In celebration of the official spring 2008 opening of The Cancer Institute at
St. Joseph Medical Center, cancer patients, survivors and caregivers of all ages
are invited to submit original artworks about their journeys through the cancer
experience for a juried art exhibit entitled, "Journeys Through Cancer: Art of
Healing and Hope. " Entries must be postmarked by Feb. 8. Artwork that is
accepted will be exhibited at The Cancer Institute at St. Joseph Medical Center
and will be open to the public from April 3 to May 11.

UM grants

Bethany Lee, an assistant professor at the University of Maryland School of
Social Work, has been awarded a $25,000 grant from The Woodbourne Center to
evaluate their programs and services. The Woodbourne Center is one of the oldest
child-welfare organizations in the country. John Belcher, a professor at the
University of Maryland School of Social Work, received a two-year grant totaling
$40,702 from the University of Baltimore, given by the Lily Foundation, to
explore how faith communities understand their practical theology in regard to
their work in the world and how it plays out in the stewardship of their
organizations.

Tourism award

The Carl M. Freeman Companies, owners of the Historic Tidewater Inn in Easton,
have received the Maryland Tourism Council 2007 Tourism Impact Award. The Impact
Award is given to recognize a business or individual that has had a major impact
on the tourism industry in Maryland in the past year. The Freeman Companies,
headquartered in Olney, have been recognized for their efforts in restoring the
Historic Tidewater Inn. The inn has been a significant part of the Talbot County
landscape, and investing in its restoration and preserving it to its original
beauty has helped to ensure that Easton and Talbot County remain an integral
part of the Maryland tourism community.

AAMC hospitalist program

Anne Arundel Medical Center, based in Annapolis, has expanded its hospitalist
program to include obstetricians, physicians specializing in the care of women
during pregnancy and childbirth. The AAMC hospitalist program was first
developed in the late 1990s. Hospitalists are employed, hospital-based
physicians who care for patients when hospitalized and also serve as consultants
to the emergency department. These physicians work in cooperation with a
patient's primary care physician and may provide patient care in emergency
situations when the private physician is not immediately available. Hospitalists
can admit patients into the hospital, consult on patients in need of surgery or
other acute care, and answer medical questions from family members.

Goldseker boosts EBDI

The Goldseker Foundation has awarded East Baltimore Development Inc. a one-year
$200,000 grant for core operating support. EBDI has recently celebrated its
fifth anniversary and is well under way in its redevelopment of 88 acres in East
Baltimore. The relocation of residents in Phase I to allow for the demolition
and rebuilding of the community took three years and required unprecedented
cooperation between federal, state and city governments; significant support
from private foundations and investment from the private sector; and ongoing
engagement with the local community. East Baltimore Development Inc. is a
private nonprofit organization that is helping transform historic East Baltimore
into a mixed-income community.

Inmate stabbed at Jessup prison

JESSUP &mdash; A Division of Correction spokeswoman says an inmate has been
stabbed at the Jessup Correctional Institution. It happened around 5:40 p.m. in
a common area at the facility in Anne Arundel County. Division spokeswoman
Danielle Wilmsen says the 55-year-old man was stabbed in the torso and was
conscious when he was taken to Shock Trauma with injuries that were not thought
to be life-threatening. She says he is listed in stable condition. Wilmsen says
the circumstances surrounding the stabbing, including how it happened and who
was involved, are under investigation. She says the inmate who was stabbed is
serving a life sentence for murder that began in 1983.

Released rape suspect found in La.

BALTIMORE &mdash; A rape suspect mistakenly released in Anne Arundel County has
been arrested in Louisiana. Anne Arundel County police say the St. Charles
Parish Sheriff's Department arrested Ronald Moore on Christmas Eve. He will be
returned to Maryland. Moore was linked to a 1999 rape in Glen Burnie using DNA
samples while he was in prison on a burglary conviction. But state correction
officials released him in November because the state overlooked a county judge's
order to hold him. In the 1999 case, police say Moore entered a woman's Glen
Burnie home, raped her and shocked her with a cattle prod. The victim's
two-year-old child was inside at the time.

Poser seeks credit card numbers

BALTIMORE &mdash; Several Carroll County businesses have been contacted in the
past few days by a man claiming to be a sheriff's deputy in need of credit card
account information for some customers. The county sheriff's office says the
calls were made to Pizza Hut restaurants in South Carroll and Finksburg.
Officials say the employees did not supply the customer information. The
sheriff's office says a caller posing as a Westminster police officer tried the
same scam at a Westminster restaurant, but the employees also refused to give
out the information. Similar calls were made in August to at least four
businesses in Aberdeen.

                        The Atlanta Journal-Constitution

                              July 10, 2011 Sunday
                                  Main Edition

Biz Voices;
Business balloon loans due

BYLINE: Jerry Chautin; For the AJC

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. 2D

LENGTH: 784 words



HIGHLIGHT: SBA helps community bank customers. Refinancing program provides
safety net for qualified owners.


"There are $171.4 billion in nonresidential commercial bank loans maturing in
2011," said Eric Gerard, spokesman for Trepp LLC, a research company that is
keeping track of nationwide commercial real estate loans on a potential
collision course to massive foreclosures. He says in 2012 "that number will jump
to $179.6 billion."

The problem started because banks made three- to five-year, highly leveraged
loans during the real estate boom, anticipating that the borrowers could easily
refinance as values continued to increase. Unfortunately, the Great Recession,
together with the Great Real Estate Meltdown, drastically changed the
arithmetic. More specifically, real estate values have plummeted, borrowers'
credit ratings declined and loan-to-value percentages required by bankers have
dropped from 80 percent before the meltdown to 70 percent and lower in today's
lending environment.

Providing a safety net for qualified small-business owners, the U.S. Small
Business Administration implemented a temporary initiative to refinance
ballooning mortgages coming due during 2011 and 2012, or until its
loan-guarantee allocation is used up.

"The SBA 504 refinance program can help community bank clients by providing
access to fixed-rate, long-term financing when a borrower's current lender is
unable to extend similar terms conventionally," Charles Yorke, president of
Atlanta's Cornerstone Bank, said in an email. "The 504 program provides up to 90
percent LTV and can help borrowers get their high-leverage loans refinanced on
reasonable terms."

Reasonable terms means up to 20 years with a 5.58 percent, effective
fixed-interest rate for July. Ten-year loans are 4.49 percent.

Unlike the basic 504 program, this temporary refinancing initiative does not
have a job-creation requirement. But business owners are required to meet SBA's
definition of "small." Examples of maximum size are revenues of $10 million for
limited-service restaurants, $30 million for hotels and 500 employees for
manufacturers. Size limits are listed by industry at tinyurl.com/3r4adow.

Additionally, multi-tenant investment properties do not qualify unless the
borrower occupies at least 50 percent of the building. "This program is designed
primarily for borrowers who used the original loan to finance owner-occupied
real estate," says Neil Stevens, executive vice president of Johns Creek-based
KeyWorth Bank. Businesses such as skating rinks, nursing homes and self-storage
facilities may qualify if the borrower runs them instead of leasing them to an
operator.

Stevens notes that the refinancing initiative can help his borrowers that have
balloon mortgages coming due. He says lenders could "better serve its clients by
providing them with loans that otherwise may not qualify due to loan value
limits."

The program requires the borrowers to have an excellent payment history on their
existing loan. Furthermore, their cash flow must be sufficient to make payments
on the proposed debt service. Projected cash flow based upon an improving
economy might be accepted.

The 504 loans have two parts. Typically, a lender makes a 50 percent first
mortgage and SBA guarantees a subordinated debenture for 40 percent similar to
making a second mortgage. The combination of the two is limited to 90 percent of
value or 100 percent of the ballooning mortgage balance being refinanced,
whichever is less. The total funding is limited to approximately $10 million. It
can go higher if the lender is willing to risk more than 50 percent of value on
its participation. Manufacturing facilities are eligible for larger loans
because SBA's maximum debenture can be increased from $5 million to $5.5
million.

SBA-licensed certified development companies coordinate the process with the
borrower, first mortgage lender and SBA. "CDCs work closely with SBA and private
sector lenders to provide financing to small businesses through the 504 Loan
Program," writes Charles Green in his "The SBA Loan Book." The Atlanta resident,
author and former bank president adds, "There are about 270 CDCs nationwide, and
each are generally restricted to specific geographic areas." He answers
questions at charlesgreenco.com.

The Georgia District SBA ranks statewide CDCs in its May newsletter. Go to
tinyurl.com /3u7z6po and scroll down to "504 Loan Program --- Georgia CDC
Rankings." The SBA posted a "Fact Sheet" about 504 refinancing at tinyurl.com
/4jqwc8f.

Contact your banker or the closest CDC to start the process.

Jerry Chautin's 30-year corporate and entrepreneurial career was in business
lending, commercial real estate lending and mortgage banking. He is a volunteer
business mentor with Atlanta SCORE. Email atlanta.score.org or call
404-331-0121.

                        The Balochistan Times (AsiaNet)

                            December 19, 2008 Friday

SBP Governor launches key microfinance sector development initiatives

LENGTH: 1166 words


KARACHI: Governor State Bank of Pakistan, Dr. Shamshad Akhtar here on Friday
launched important initiatives for the growth and development of microfinance
sector.  The event was attended by all stakeholders including donors,
Presidents/CEOs of Commercial/Microfinance Banks, and representatives of the
Pakistan Microfinance Network and Pakistan Bankers Association.  These measures
are expected to ease liquidity constraints of microfinance providers in view of
the tighter liquidity conditions and sudden spike in inflation which has
severely affected the poor and marginalized segments of the society.  SBP has
launched three facilities to support the microfinance sector: (i) The
Microfinance Credit Guarantee Facility. (ii) The Institutional Strengthening
Fund. (iii) The Improving Access to Finance Services Fund.

Dr Akhtar said these initiatives are part of the GBP 50 million Financial
Inclusion Program (FIP) supported by the UK Department for International
Development (DFID) and an endowment fund worth dollars 20 million under the
ADB's Improving Access to Financial Services Program.

The Microfinance Credit Guarantee Facility is expected to increase the flow of
credit to microfinance sector.  The facility aims to incentivize banks/DFIs to
channelize funds to MFBs/MFIs for on lending to low income segment of the
population.  The facility will provide credit guarantees of up to 40 percent of
the funding provided by Banks/DFIs and aims to develop market and graduate poor
borrowers to mainstream financial service providers.

Banks/DFIs will lend to MFBs at the SBP policy discount rate plus 200 bps. The
funds channelized under facility to MFBs /MFIs shall be deductable from Demand
and Time Liabilities of the banks/DFIs for the purpose of SLR and CRR
calculation.  The facility will be established at State Bank of Pakistan (SBP)
with the help of the UK Government Financial Inclusion Program grant funds
equivalent of up to GBP 10 million to be used as the guarantee fund.

She said the State Bank has issued necessary guidelines for operationalizing the
facility which were finalized after due consultation with stakeholders.

The MCG facility is expected to help raise local currency funds for eligible
MFIs/MFBs. The loans portfolio under the guarantee scheme will be administered
by banks. The facility will also help building links between micro borrowers and
formal financial institutions.

The familiarization of the bank with the client should eventually lead to the
"graduation" of the borrower.  The facility shall provide partial Guarantees to
minimize the perceived risk premium by covering part of the losses incurred on
funds made available to MFBs/MFIs with the advantage of leveraging the guarantee
fund a number of times while keeping the incentive for banks/DFIs to collect the
loan.  The lending of MCG facility will help these institutions to play their
role in the growth of micro credit more effectively, SBP Governor said.

SBP Governor , Dr Shamshad Akhtar said the Institutional Strengthening Fund is
designed to build capacity of the microfinance sector.

The fund is expected to enhance potential for growth and create depth in
outreach by improving human resource quality, service delivery and increasing
service availability to potential microfinance clients.

It was established at the State Bank under the UK Government's Financial
Inclusion Program that involved funds equivalent to Pound Sterling 10 million
for institutional strengthening.

The fund will provide grants for capacity building to generate on-lending
resources through commercial sources, equity investments or deposit mobilization
strategy through improvement in management, governance, internal controls and
functions.  She said the fund will also provide grants for employing cost
reduction mechanisms for increasing outreach in rural and remote areas through
product innovation, development or use of technology. In addition, the fund will
provide grants for business development services to MFI clients or improving
quality of services; and developing capacity for transformation of MFIs into
licensed microfinance banks.  SBP has developed detailed guidelines, selection
criteria and application format for ISF. The fund will primarily focus on
institutions that are already regulated, or are in the process of seeking a
license or have solid plans for restructuring in the near future, Dr Akhtar
said.

SBP's regulatory oversight will ensure transparency and good governance
practices, which will ultimately lead to greater investment in the microfinance
industry. Moreover, ISF is capped at dollars one million per year per grantee
and subject to at least 25% matching grant from the grantee.  Grants may be made
on an annual basis and institutions that qualify for funding in a year may also
qualify for funding in another year subject to good performance and submission
of another successful proposal through the approved application procedure.  The
SBP Chief said the Improving Access to Financial Services is also designed to
enhance capacity of the microfinance sector and promote financial literacy.  The
fund has been established at the State Bank with help of an endowment of dollars
20 million under the ADB-supported Improving Access to Financial Services
Program (IAFSP).

The fund will provide benefits for and have positive impacts on rural and urban
communities, in particular the poor and the women.

These benefits are quantitative and qualitative in nature and include (i)
capacity building and training of financial services providers to promote
expansion into rural areas; product and service innovation, including savings,
remittances and Islamic financial services; adoption and integration of new
technologies and applications for improving access to financial services; (ii)
capacity building and training of Government and regulatory authorities to
support development of an inclusive financial sector and implementation of
measures under the Program; and (iii) literacy programs (financial and basic)
conducted by or on behalf of financial services providers for clients and
potential clients to improve access to financial services and the utilization of
finance.

The Governor mentioned that in Pakistan there are about more than 30 million
people living below the poverty line. Despite the consensus that microfinance is
an effective tool to alleviate poverty, the gap between demand for and supply of
financial services for the poor and marginalized segments of population is very
wide.  The current microfinance outreach of 1.8 million customers is limited to
only around 5% of the potential market. The SBP and the Government of Pakistan
are committed to increasing the number of microfinance borrowers to 3 million by
the end of 2010 and 10 million by 2015 as documented in the national
Microfinance Strategy adopted in 2007.  In order to achieve the outreach target
the microfinance industry would need substantial additional funding, said Dr.
Akhtar.

                      Hamilton Spectator (Ontario, Canada)

                    November 18, 1995 Saturday Final Edition

Taxpayers bail out science fair: Prestigious student fair can't repay $150,000
loan guaranteed by region

SOURCE: THE SPECTATOR

BYLINE: By Ken Peters

SECTION: METRO; Pg. B1 / FRONT

LENGTH: 430 words


The International Science and Engineering Fair at Copps Coliseum in May cost
regional taxpayers $300,000.

That's twice as much as regional council hoped the tab would be.

The region gave a $150,000 grant to the prestigious science fair, which
attracted 6,500 high school students from around the world. The region also
guaranteed a $150,000 line of credit, to be repaid from any revenues over the
fair's $1 million budget.

But there won't be any payback.

"The International Science and Engineering Fair 1995 did not achieve projected
revenues of $1 million, as the donations from corporations and foundations were
lower than projected," a regional staff report revealed this week.

Regional politicians learned the fair raised $956,000, reporting a $34,000 loss.

"November has not been a good month," said Ancaster Councillor Ann Sloat,
chairman of the region's finance committee.

Earlier this month, regional council learned the Hamilton Philharmonic
Orchestra's Sweet Dreams Lottery, which it had guaranteed, ended up with a
$57,000 loss. That forced the region to ante up another $277,000 line of credit
to keep the debt-ridden orchestra, which has a $1.2 million accumulated deficit,
in business until the end of the year.

There was more bad news this week when Hamilton East Community Services pulled
the plug on the Lakeland Pool. That left regional taxpayers soaked for $78,000
in back realty taxes.

"I think we are taking too many risks. I consider it my money because I pay
taxes and I want to be careful with it," Mrs. Sloat said.

She said finance staff are preparing a policy that would see regional council
only provide financial guarantees when some form of collateral is provided.

"I want security for future loans," Mrs. Sloat said.

Burned, but far from broke, finance committee members offered yet another
financial guarantee this week, a $290,000 loan guarantee to the Armenian
Community Centre.

Hamilton Councillor Tom Jackson said the latest guarantee is similar to the
$100,000 provided the Japanese Cultural Centre over a year ago.

He said the full amount, with interest, is expected to be repaid by next fall.

Even Mrs. Sloat said she has some confidence with the assistance for the
Armenian Culural Centre.

She said if the centre defaults on the loan, which would be used to renovate the
Barton Street East centre, the region would take possession of the facility,
which would be worth $540,000.

That recommendation will be considered by regional council on Tuesday night.

                         The Daily News of Los Angeles

                             July 29, 2010 Thursday
                                 VALLEY EDITION

Panel urges $4.4M for Chinese automaker coming to L.A.

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. A11

LENGTH: 402 words


A city panel recommended Wednesday awarding $2 million in federal grants and
authorizing $2.4 million in loan guarantees to a Chinese automaker that is
locating its U.S. headquarters in Los Angeles.

Under the proposal recommended by the City Council's Housing, Community and
Economic Development Committee, BYD Corp. would receive $2 million in grants to
refurbish a 30,000-square-foot facility at 1800 S. Figueroa St., where it would
become part of Auto Row.

In addition, the Community Redevelopment Agency would provide lease guarantees
of $2.4 million over the next 10 years to the owners of the property if BYD
fails to remain in the building.

The incentives package still must be approved by the full City Council.

During Tuesday's debate, City Councilman Tony Cardenas complained that BYD
received preferential treatment from CRA executives because of the involvement
of the Mayor's Office in luring the Chinese manufacturing giant to Los Angeles.

But Calvin Hollis, chief operating officer of the CRA's real estate economic
development office, said he helped marshal through the BYD deal because of its
potential to help transform the region's economy.

"This is a strategic opportunity for the city to attract a major corporation,"
Hollis said. "This is a growth company that is starting small, but we have a
chance of attracting the next level of financing."

Cardenas said he has lost a number of business opportunities in his district
because entrepreneurs had to deal with CRA staffers who lacked the authority to
make critical decisions.

"When I tell people we'll bring the CRA in, they roll their eyes and say
'Thanks, but no thanks,"' Cardenas said. "My point is, they (CRA officials) pay
attention when the mayor calls."

However, Councilman Herb Wesson disputed Cardenas's account, saying he had no
difficulties with the agency and brought Hollis in to serve as "the closer" on a
number of projects.

BYD's announcement that it would locate its headquarters in Los Angeles was the
culmination of an 18-month effort by Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa and other top
city officials.

The manufacturer of electric cars, solar panels, batteries and other electronics
is expected to open its office in January, employing up to 150 people in its
first year. BYD plans to manufacture electric vehicles beginning in June 2013
but has not yet announced where it will build the assembly plant.

                  Long Island Business News (Long Island, NY)

                               February 27, 2009

N.Y. 's Sen. Schumer: Stimulus helps small biz

BYLINE: David Reich-Hale

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 559  words


Sen. Charles Schumer on Friday said the $787 billion stimulus signed earlier
this month by President Barack Obama includes $730 million in new funding for
small business assistance programs.

New York's senior senator said the money would go a long way toward helping
struggling Long Island firms survive the economic crisis.

Here is a breakdown, direct from Schumer's Long Island office:

Temporary SBA Fee Relief: As a result of the financial crisis and the recession,
small business lending in the SBA's flagship loan programs - 7(a) and 504
programs - is in a freefall.   The bill allocates $375 million to allow for
temporary waivers or reductions in the fees the SBA charges to lenders and
borrowers in the 7(a) and 504 loan programs.   When determining the amount and
structure of the waivers/reductions, the bill requires the SBA to give borrowers
and smaller banks priority in receiving fee relief.

Temporary Increase in SBA Guarantee Levels: The bill allows the SBA to - on a
case by case basis - temporarily raise the guarantee level (up to 90%) for 7(a)
loans, other than loans made through the SBA Express program.   Currently, the
maximum guarantee levels are 75 percent for loans over $150,000, and 85 percent
for loans of $150,000 or less.   The increased guarantee will provide a higher
level of protection for risk-weary small business lenders who have tightened
their lending standards considerably in the wake of the credit crunch.

Business Stabilization Program: The bill will also help banks provide relatively
small, short-term loans to small business borrowers experiencing immediate
financial hardship. Specifically, the new program will temporarily allow the SBA
to (i) fully guarantee "stabilization" loans that cannot exceed $35,000, and
(ii) fully subsidize a small business borrower's interest payments on the
stabilization loan.   A borrower does not have to begin repaying the
stabilization loan until 12 months after receiving it, and the loan must be paid
in full within 5 years.

Microloans: The bill appropriates $30 million for the SBA's microloan program,
with $24 million dedicated to microloan technical assistance, and $6 million for
new microloans.   By way of background, the microloan program provides very
small loans to qualifying micro-businesses (typically businesses with fewer than
10 employees) by making funds available to non-profit, community-based lenders.

504 Program Improvements: With credit standards tightening, many credit-worthy
small businesses have been denied new or additional loans for facility upgrades.
The bill would allow a small business to refinance its existing loan through a
504 loan if at least 50 percent of the proceeds from the new 504 loan will be
spent on qualifying expansion projects. In addition, the bill expands the
universe of expansion projects that would qualify for a 504 loan.   Current law
requires the creation of one job for every $65,000 loaned; the bill reduces that
amount to $50,000.

Oversight and Implementation of Stimulus Measures: The bill allocates $25
million for the additional resources that the SBA will need to properly
implement the stimulus measures. The bill appropriates $10 million specifically
for the SBA Inspector General's oversight of SBA stimulus funds. The bill also
requires a GAO report on the SBA's progress in implementing the stimulus
measures.

                              The Washington Post

                      June 21, 1982, Monday, Final Edition

SECTION: Business & Finance; International Lending; Pg. 29

LENGTH: 969 words


Bank May Use Variable Rates

World Bank officials said last week that they will borrow about $1.5 billion in
the U.S. market in the year starting July 1 through a new type of variable-rate
debt issue, if member countries of the international agency give their approval
soon.

World Bank deputy treasurer Hans Hittmair said that if the World Bank goes to a
variable-rate borrowing operation, the agency also will adopt major changes in
its lending operations. New authorized credits to developing countries also
would be approved on a variable-rate basis, with the interest rates on such
loans to be adjusted every six months to reflect trends in interest rates
generally.

The major changes in World Bank borrowing and lending operations require the
approval of member governments. The bank's board of executive directors
representing both industrial nations and developing countries is expected to
decide next month whether to authorize the changes.

Recent agreements by international lending and financial institutions:

Export-Import Bank

* The bank will extend a direct credit of about $8.4 million to support the
export sale of U.S. goods and services for a can-making facility on the island
of Luzon in the Philippines. U.S. sales for the project total $19.7 million. The
project consists of the design, engineering, construction, installation and
start-up of a new two-piece can manufacturing plant. American Can Co. will
coordinate the purchases and provide equipment and services from its plants in
Hanover, Pa., Niagara Falls, N.Y., and Waukegan, Ill. The purchaser will make a
$2.9 million cash payment and will obtain private financing of $8.4 million,
without the guarantee of the Export-Import Bank.

* The Eximbank will assist Galadari Hotels (Lanka) Ltd. in the construction of a
500-room hotel in Colombo, Sri Lanka. Bechtel International of San Francisco
will serve as project manager; William Tabler, a New York architectural firm,
will provide technical services, and Graham-Solano of Boston will provide
interior decorating services. Other U.S. firms will supply mechanical and
electrical equipment, hotel furnishings and other services. The bank will lend
$6.9 million at 10.75 percent interest per year and $4.3 million at 12 percent
interest. The borrower will make a $2.6 million cash payment and will obtain
$3.5 million in funds from private sources, without Eximbank's guarantee.

* General Electric and General Motors will supply $42.8 million in diesel
electric locomotives, components and spare parts for the Mexican railway
Ferrocarriles Nacionales de Mexico. The Export-Import Bank will lend $18.2
million at an annual interest rate of 12 percent to NAFINSA, Mexico's principal
development company, which will borrow an equal amount from a private source,
without the bank's guarantee. NAFINSA will also make a $6.4 million cash
payment.

* The bank has authorized a $30 million credit to Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, a
Brazilian government-owned conglomerate and one of the world's largest producers
of iron ore. The credit will support an export value of $70.6 million,
consisting of major components for 70 locomotives, mining equipment and related
items. The equipment will be used in a $5 billion iron ore project. The borrower
will pay 12 percent interest per year on the bank loan, will make a $10.6
million cash payment and will obtain a $30 million private loan, without the
bank's guarantee.

* Helikopter Service A/S of Oslo, Norway, a privately owned corporation serving
Norway and North Sea offshore transportation, is purchasing two Boeing Vertol
model 234 Chinook helicopters and related goods and services. The aircraft will
cost $41.4 million and will be delivered in March 1983. Boeing facilities in
Pennsylvania, Washington and Connecticut are expected to receive about 300,000
hours of direct employment, and additional employment should be generated in
sub-supplier plants. The helicopters will be financed with an Export-Import Bank
loan of $31.1 million, a $6.2 million cash payment and a loan of $4.1 million
from a private source, without the bank's guarantee.

World Bank

* The bank and its affiliate, the International Development Association,
approved $186.6 million in loans last week to the Phillipines, Colombia,
Pakistan, the Central African Republic and Yemen. Most of the credits will be
for agriculture-related ventures. The Phillipines will receive a $71.1 million
World Bank loan for irrigation projects to help small-scale farm operators
increase food crops. The other loans were $53 million to Colombia for public
water supplies, schools, electric power lines and other facilities to serve both
rural and urban communities; $38.5 million to Pakistan to increase fertilizer
production by about 178,000 tons a year following the modernization and
expansion of existing facilities; $18 million to the Central African Republic
from the IDA for highways and repair of gravel roads, and $6 million to Yemen
from the IDA for agriculture research projects. The bank loans are at 11.6
percent annual interest, plus loan service charges. The IDA credits are
interest-free, except for small administrative fees.

Inter-American Development Bank

* The bank has made a public offering of 100 million Dutch guilders of its
10-year bonds in the Netherlands. The bonds carry an annual interest rate of 10
3/4 percent and are priced at 99 percent. The issue, equivalent to about $38.5
million, is the fifth public bond issue placed by the bank for its capital
resources in the Netherlands market. The offering is being underwritten by a
syndicate led by the Algemene Bank Nederland, N.V., and will be dated July 5,
1982. The loan will be redeemed at par in five approximately equal annual
installments on July 15 of the years 1988 to 1992.

                        Tohono O'odham Utility Authority

USDA Invests More Than $200 Million in Electric Infrastructure Improvements in
Five States

   May 20, 2016

   Agriculture Secretary Tom Vilsack celebrated the 80th anniversary of the
Rural Electrification Act (REA) and announced funding to build and upgrade rural
electric infrastructure in five states."Eighty years ago today, President
Roosevelt signed the law which charged USDA to provide electric power to rural
America," Vilsack said. "Today's investments continue a part of USDA's mission
that has brought reliable, safe and affordable electric power to America's
farms, ranches and rural communities, improved the quality of life for rural
residents, increased farm productivity and made America the breadbasket to the
world. Continuing to invest in rural electric infrastructure will help keep our
economy strong."USDA is providing $202 million in loans for six projects in
Arizona, Georgia, Kansas, Kentucky and North Carolina. The funding is
administered through the Electric Program of USDA's Rural Utilities Service, the
successor to the REA. The Electric Program makes loans and loan guarantees to
non-profit and cooperative associations, public bodies and other utilities. The
loans finance the construction of electric distribution and generation
facilities in rural areas. Today's investments demonstrate USDA's commitment to
mitigating climate change and promoting a clean-energy economy. This month, the
Department is examining what a changing climate means to agriculture and how
USDA is working to reduce greenhouse gases. East Kentucky Power Cooperative,
Inc. has been selected to receive a $131.8 million USDA loan to acquire the
Bluegrass Generating Facility, a natural gas-fired power plant. North Carolina's
O2 EMC Portfolio 1, LLC is receiving a $4.5 million loan to construct a 3
megawatt solar farm. In Arizona, the Tohono O'Odham Utility Authority will
improve 80 miles of line with a loan of nearly $8 million. The utility will use
$775,000 of the loan to invest in smart grid technologies. Smart grid increases
the reliability of electric power by helping utilities better manage power
distribution and improve operational efficiencies. It includes metering,
substation automation, computer applications, two-way communications, geospatial
information systems and other improvements. Georgia's Slash Pine Electric
Membership Corporation will use a $9 million loan to improve 248 miles of line
and make other system improvements, including $1 million for smart grid. The
Kansas Electric Power Cooperative, Inc. is receiving a $43.1 million loan to
make system improvements to the water reactor at the Wolf Creek Generating
Station and a $5.2 million loan to fund improvements to the facility's
below-ground water piping.

                           Ruidoso News (New Mexico)

                            August 13, 2015 Thursday

Major broadband coming to Mescalero

BYLINE: By Dianne Stallings dstallings@ruidosonews.com @RuidosoNews on Twitter

SECTION: NEWS

LENGTH: 895 words


Persistence and a good plan moved Mescalero Apache Telephone Inc. to the front
of the line for financing by the U.S, Department of Agriculture of a
multimillion dollar broadband communication system.

Officials from the Rural Development Division of the USDA were in the area
Thursday to present a certificate of obligation to officials of MATI and the
Mescalero Tribal Council, representing the $5.397,000 obligation by the Rural
Development's Rural Utilities Service's Telecommunications Loan Program and the
Substantially Underserved Trust Land Program.

The project on the reservation that abuts Ruidoso is the first in the nation to
be obligated, which allows MATI officials to take advantage of low interest
dollars. With the loan, MATI can upgrade specific portions of its copper cable
facilities with fiber, primarily aimed at the homes of 1,178 telephone customers
and 500 data customers currently served by the company, which is a wholly-owned
corporation of the tribe that operates one exchange serving the reservation. The
proposed improvements, which could take up to two years to construct and
install, primarily will be located in the more densely populated areas of
Mescalero, including the Geronimo, Pena, Goat Summit and Carrizo housing cores.

"Broadband access is important to our rural communities," Brandon McBride, RUS
administrator, said Wednesday during an interview in Ruidoso. "It's important in
terms of having new educational opportunities. It can improve rural health care
and it also is important for local businesses to being able to compete in the
global market place. It will allow Mescalero to provide fiber to the homes of
many of its customers and that will improve broadband services for them."

For those receiving the fiber facilities at home, children with schoolwork will
be able to go on-line and do homework, he said.

"In some cases, distance learning opportunities are available once we improve
broadband access," McBride said. "A lot of times, local schools can connect with
colleges and universities outside of the area to provide those kinds of
programs."

Electronic health records can be accessed and physicians practicing in rural
hospital can consult with doctors in larger hospitals in urban areas, he
said.The processGodfrey Enjady, who heads MATI, applied for the loan through the
USDA's traditional telecommunication infrastructure loan program, McBride
said."We were able to use our authorities through SUTA, and their loan came
through, and we were able to process that," he said. "It is a good project and a
good proposal."

Terry Brunner, USDA Rural Development State Director, said, "From the New Mexico
side, they were really persistent. They had the idea early and worked a lot with
USDA over the last few years to put the project at the front of the line. It is
a really nice commentary on the quality of work being done by the Mescalero that
they are the first in the gate for this program."

The program is subject to annual review and funding by Congress, McBride said.

Statements of support for the Mescalero project were issued by U.S. Sens. Martin
Heinrich and Tom Udall, Democrats from New Mexico and U.S. Rep. Steve Pearce, a
Republican who represents the Second Congressional District, sent a
representative to the ceremony Thursday. They noted that SUTA is a provision in
the 2008 Farm Bill, which amended the Rural Electrification Act of 1936. The
provision gave the Rural Utilities Service new tools to finance improvements in
electric, telecommunications and water and sewer infrastructure in underserved
tribal communities.USDA's area investment

Over the past six years, the USDA has invested $8.2 million in Lincoln County
housing, Brunner said.

"Out of $8.2 million, there were some direct loans, three to potential home
owners at 3.3 percent interest and about 12 home repairs for homeowners in at
the low income level, who can come in and apply," he said. "We also have done 50
or so loan guarantees, where a lender makes the loan and we back it up with
government guarantees. It's popular, because it is for moderate to low income."

The housing figure jumps to about $40 million, if Otero County is thrown into
the mix, he said.

"We've been trying to shed some light on that so people understand the impact
Rural Development has had on the area," Brunner said. "We financed a lot of
sewer lines to homes along the highway in Mescalero (about $4 million for the
system).

"Proper sewage treatment is really important, especially in New Mexico where we
have so many people on domestic wells. If you have good sewer treatment, you can
get them off septic systems and prevent leakage into ground water resources. You
not only provide a crucial service, but protect groundwater and keep it safe
from contamination."

Brunner said he planned to tour McBride through the regional Wastewater
treatment plant constructed by the village of Ruidoso and city of Ruidoso Downs
to serve the area. The USDA financed $8.7 million of the $32 million cost of
that plant.

"It's all necessary, if you are going to have economic development," McBride
said. "You have to have safe drinking water, affordable housing and
increasingly, we're seeing that broadband access is key to attracting economic
development. As Lincoln County continues to grow and develop, it's important we
have that nice infrastructure in place for the community."

                     The Telegraph-Journal (New Brunswick)

                            April 25, 2009 Saturday

Quebec to loan Alcoa $50 million to save jobs; Labour Unionized employees also
agree to reduce hours by 15 per cent

BYLINE: Ross Marowits THE CANADIAN PRESS

SECTION: BUSINESS; Pg. C5

LENGTH: 601  words


The Quebec government has joined workers, suppliers and the city of Baie Comeau
in helping American aluminum producer Alcoa (NYSE:AA) to withstand the economic
slowdown by agreeing to a $50-million loan to preserve jobs.

The five-year, low-interest loan comes more than a year after the province
provided $228 million in loan guarantees toward Alcoa's US$1.2-billion
modernization project.

The aluminum business has taken a big hit since Alcoa committed to one of the
largest private investments in Quebec in years.

Aluminum prices have plunged as demand, particularly in the automobile and
construction sectors, has plunged amid the global economic slowdown.

Quebec Finance and Economic Development Minister Raymond Bachand applauded Alcoa
for preserving its plans for Quebec and said the provincial government loan will
help the company to withstand the economic slowdown.

"It ensures the prosperity of Alcoa's different plants and gives it the means to
overcome the storm with strength and courage," he stated Friday.

The government hasn't attached any additional conditions to the loan beyond
minimum employment levels required as part of the March 2008 loan guarantee.

Alcoa spokesman Pierre Despres said the Pittsburgh-based mining giant may have
been forced to take "extreme measures" such as the closure of a series of giant
aluminum potlines at the North Shore smelter if the government hadn't provided
help.

"We want to protect the level of employment. That's in our mind key for the
future of the plant to keep our employees working," he said in an interview.

The government assistance comes a couple of weeks after unionized employees at
Baie Comeau and two other facilities agreed to reduce weekly work hours by up to
15 per cent.

Local union president Denis Berube thanked workers for accepting changes that
will help all employees at the plant along with everyone in the region.

The city, 400 kilometres northeast of Quebec City, also agreed to reduce
municipal taxes and suppliers trimmed their costs by up to 15 per cent.

"It's a collective effort of all the stakeholders in the plant," Despres said.

The Baie Comeau smelter uses an inefficient Soderberg technology.

Preliminary work has begun to upgrade the facility, including the closure of
several aluminum potlines. But the major projects to boost capacity by 110,000
tonnes to 548,000 tonnes are slated to begin by the end of 2010 and be completed
in five years.

As a result of the modernization commitment, Alcoa renewed its power contracts
for 25 years with Hydro-Quebec for 1,562 megawatts of electricity for the
Baie-Comeau smelter and others in Deschambault and Becancour.

Quebec's financial assistance, which isn't directly related to the
modernization, will be administered by Investissement Quebec.

With 1,550 employees, Alcoa is the largest employer in the North Shore
community. The smelter produces 437,000 tonnes of aluminum annually.

Alcoa Canada president Jean-Pierre Gilardeau said the government loan positions
the 52-year-old smelter to turn a profit once the economy turns around.

"This gesture allows us to anticipate the future with confidence," he said.

Meanwhile, about 275 workers at Alcoa's smelter in Becancour stand to be laid
off for an indeterminate period of time by the end of the month because
employees refused to cut work hours to help trim costs.

Despres declined to comment on the union's claim that the move is part of
Alcoa's "hidden agenda."

A mediator had recommended unionized employees work just 36 hours weekly and
that two years be added to their collective agreement.

                                 Guelph Tribune

                           September 17, 2013 Tuesday
                                  ONT Edition

Soccer dome stays afloat

SECTION: Pg. 0

LENGTH: 545  words


City council has unanimously approved a strategy for dealing with the financial
woes of the sports dome that opened in 2008 at Centennial Park.The deal
"stabilizes the situation" and gives city staff more time to work with other
parties to "minimize long-term risk," Mayor Karen Farbridge said at the end of a
council debate on the issue last week.The city, which agreed in 2006 to co-sign
and guarantee a 10-year loan of up to $900,000 to build the facility, is on the
hook for $500,000 if Guelph Community Sports defaults on the loan.Guelph
Community Sports, the not-for-profit organization that controls the facility,
approached city hall last fall to tell city officials about the financial woes.A
proposal made in May for dealing with the problem "fell apart" because the bank
that holds the loan wouldn't agree, said Peter Avgoustis, manager of business
services in the city's community and social services department.The potential of
default on the loan led to a meeting on Aug. 1 in Farbridge's office, where the
deal recommended to council last week was worked out.The deal calls for a
five-year extension of the bank loan, in order to reduce monthly payments by
fifty per cent. It also imposes several conditions, including conditions for
dealing with the need for future capital expenditures at the dome - namely, a
$350,000 replacement of the artificial field turf by 2018 and a $1.2-million
replacement of the air-supported dome structure covering the field by
2023."These conditions give us the time we need" to deal with these future
capital replacements, said Colleen Clack, the city's general manager of culture
and tourism.

The deal gives the city time to have a "broader conversation" about recreational
needs in different parts of the city, she told council.Guelph Soccer Club Inc.,
a not-for-profit sports organization, has been covering the facility's annual
shortfall for the past five years through an interest-free loan to Guelph
Community Sports. But Guelph Soccer has indicated it can no longer cover the
annual cash shortfall, and no money has been set aside for the future capital
replacements, says a city staff report.Avgoustis told council that the dome,
built without air conditioning, operates only from mid-September to mid-April.He
said it's not clear that a good business case could be made for air conditioning
the dome to extend its use, because "people want to be outside" in the summer
and the city's sports fields are cheaper to rent than the dome.Guelph Community
Sports and Guelph Soccer are separate legal entities and keep separate books,
Avgoustis said.The original intention of having a variety of sports use the dome
hasn't worked out as planned, although "I don't think they (Guelph Soccer) are
trying to monopolize the time" available in the dome, he said.One of the
conditions of the deal approved by council last week requires Guelph Soccer to
sign a 10-year field rental agreement with Guelph Community Sports, to ensure
the dome keeps its anchor tenant.City hall also looked at the option of taking
over the dome and contracting its operations to Guelph Soccer. Officials also
looked at providing an annual subsidy until 2018 to help pay off the loan, which
Avgoustis said would have cost the city about $70,000 a year.

Hudson consultant, Miami firm merge

The Hackett Group, a management consulting firm in Hudson, has merged with
Miami-based AnswerThink Consulting Group. Gregory P. Hackett said he will remain
president of the Hackett Group, now a subsidiary of AnswerThink, which
specializes in systems integration. Mr. Hackett said he expects to boost Hackett
Group's employment to 70 from 30 in the next several years as a result of new
business generated by the merger. The Hackett Group specializes in helping firms
reduce the cost of staff functions such as finance and human resource
management.

David Prizinsky

Firm plans $18M retirement home

American Retirement Corp. of Nashville plans to build an $18 million,
two-building retirement community in Cleveland Heights. The complex would be on
20 acres on Mayfield Road formerly occupied by the Montefiore Home. The
Montefiore Home now is located in Beachwood on Cedar Road. The Tennessee
company's project will include the construction of a three-story, 120-resident
assisted living building and a two-story, 34-resident home for patients
suffering from Alzheimer's disease and dementia. The buildings will comprise
120,000 square feet.

Raquel Santiago

SBA's Cleveland office sets loan records

The Cleveland district office of the U.S. Small Business Administration set
records for the number of loans and loan amounts guaranteed in the fiscal year
ended Sept. 30. SBA district director Gilbert Goldberg said the agency
guaranteed 966 loans totaling $157.4 million during the period, eclipsing the
previous record of 963 loans totaling $136 million set in fiscal 1995. Mr.
Goldberg attributed the record to the continued strong economy in Northeast Ohio
as well as the agency's efforts to cut red tape. He said 22 loan guarantees were
issued in the last two days of the fiscal year due to use of the agency's
preferred lending and fast-track lending programs, which are designed to reduce
paperwork.

Tom Ford

Software distributor expands into Mich.

Microtek Controls Inc., a Twinsburg software distributor, next month will open
three offices in Michigan. The offices will be in Ann Arbor, Detroit and Grand
Rapids. The Michigan offices should add $3 million in sales for the company,
which has annual sales of about $5 million from operations in Ohio, Pennsylvania
and West Virginia, said Microtek spokesman Dennis Nordquest. Microtek resells
Wonderware Industrial Software, a computer program that creates graphical images
of industrial operations and allows managers to control equipment from remote
locations. Mr. Nordquest said the company in the past year has doubled its
employment to 16. It expects to hire five to 10 technical sales employees to run
the new Michigan operations. The company also is expanding its Twinsburg
operations by 50% to 4,000 square feet.

Jennifer Beauprez

Coin laundry chain spins into Cleveland

SpinCycle Inc., a coin-operated laundry store chain in Scottsdale, Ariz., has
acquired Cleveland-based Sud-Z Laundries, an 11-store coin laundry chain with
stores in Cleveland and Detroit. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. The
acquisition gives SpinCycle a total of 61 laundries in Ohio, Illinois, Maryland,
Michigan, Minnesota, New Mexico, Pennsylvania and Texas. "The Sud-Z acquisition
gives us a critical mass in an important market for us," said Patrick Clifton,
chairman and chief executive of SpinCycle. "Now we have geographic continuity
between our Midwest stores in Chicago and (Minneapolis/St. Paul) and our East
Coast operations in Philadelphia and Baltimore." Mr. Clifton said the Sud-Z
stores will be converted into SpinCycle outlets by year's end.

Angela Y. Hardin

Delivery service grows with first retail outlet

Bonnie Speed Delivery Inc. in Cleveland is expanding its business with the
opening of its first retail outlet. The store, called One Hour Package Delivery
Service, will open next Thursday, Oct. 30, in the atrium of the BP America
Building on Public Square. Bonnie Speed said the store will enable customers
without company accounts to arrange for quick delivery service. The store
initially will have a three-person staff, said Renee Cline, Bonnie Speed's
director of sales. She declined to disclose sales expectations for the store.
Bonnie Speed offers local and long-distance package deliveries, same-day air
service and shipment of large freight in the Midwest and the eastern United
States.

Gorkha Brewery empowers local community at Mukundapur

BYLINE: HIMALAYAN NEWS SERVICE

LENGTH: 198  words


KATHMANDU: Aimed at economic empowerment of the local community, Gorkha Brewery
initiated Micro Finance Project in Mukundapur-6 in 2010.

Gorkha Brewery partnered with a local bank to provide loan facility for the
purchase of mature milk yielding cows or buffaloes, on a group guarantee to
families with an annual income of less than $1,000. In addition, 50 per cent
rebate on the loan processing and insurance costs were also provided. Recently,
as the agreement stated, Gorkha Brewery reimbursed the interest paid by
borrowers at the end of the term on completion of payment of their EMI.

A total of 110 borrowers have availed the credit facility till date. A group of
75 borrowers received interest payback in the beginning of this year while a
group of 35 remaining borrowers received the interest payback this week.

Philip Norley, MD of Gorkha Brewery, speaking during loan disbursement
programme, said, "By empowering local communities, our CSR activities are
changing lives."

Srijana Regmi, local borrower, said, "This is one of a kind economic project
wherein I bought two cows with the loan and now in three years, I have 20 cows.
I am very thankful to Gorkha Brewery for helping us."

                   The Times-Tribune (Scranton, Pennsylvania)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            October 9, 2014 Thursday

Scranton business administrator has been key player in city finances

BYLINE: Jim Lockwood, The Times-Tribune, Scranton, Pa.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 441 words


Oct. 09--Scranton Business Administrator David Bulzoni had a front-row seat to
city finances before he took the city job in January.

He worked for Landmark Community Bank when it loaned the Scranton Parking
Authority $2.95 million in 2011. Unlike authority bonds that are guaranteed by
the city, the Landmark loan was not backed by the city.

When the former city council forced SPA into default in mid-2012, the Landmark
loan, and an unrelated loan from a separate bank, went unpaid by the authority
and became delinquent.

As Mayor Bill Courtright's business administrator, Mr. Bulzoni has been an
architect of the city's new recovery plan. One facet involves selling or leasing
the authority's five parking garages, but the delinquent bank loans could be
roadblocks to this plan. As a result, the city plans to have SPA incur up to $4
million in debt to pay back the two delinquent bank loans, and the city would
use parking meter revenue to pay this new SPA debt.

Mr. Bulzoni said of being on both sides of the Landmark loan -- first with the
bank providing the loan to SPA and now with the city aiming to satisfy the loan
-- "It has no relevance to me at this point other than from the perspective of
the city and trying to create a cleaner credit picture for the city. It's just a
matter that has to be cleaned up."

Efforts to contact Mr. Courtright on Wednesday were unsuccessful. SPA board
member Tom Borthwick said, "Dave was never on the side of defaulting or allowing
this to occur. It (satisfying the loan) is just about making good with the
banks."

Containing the cost of defending against a lawsuit brought against the authority
by Landmark also is a consideration, he said. While the city did not guarantee
the Landmark loan, the city and authority are trying to act in good faith to
satisfy the delinquency, and such a step also would help repair the city's
damaged creditworthiness to hopefully open avenues for financing and new loans,
he said.

The Landmark loan to SPA became an issue in early 2012 in the feud between
former Mayor Chris Doherty and the council led by Janet Evans. At that time, the
mayor sought a $2.75 million tax-anticipation note from Landmark to pay daily
bills and payroll, and the bank in return wanted the city to guarantee the SPA
loan. Council refused and likened that condition to being "held hostage," and
said if the bank made a bad loan to SPA the city should not get stuck holding
the bag.

                            Global Capital Euroweek

                                  June 9, 2016

USAID backs Ukraine and Tunisia bond plans

BYLINE: Francesca Young

SECTION: UKRAINE USAID,TUNISIA USAID

LENGTH: 566  words



HIGHLIGHT: Ukraine and Tunisia have signed agreements with the US for a combined
$1.5bn of bond guarantees.


Ukraine and the US have settled on a further $1bn of loan warranties, to be used
on a five year Eurobond issue.

Ukraine's Ministry of Finance said that it anticipated a "record low expected
interest rate of not higher than 2% per annum "" the lowest interest rate in the
history of Ukraine" for the bond.

The guarantee is Ukraine's third USAID loan warranty. The previous two enabled
it to tap the international capital markets for $2bn, via $1bn 1.847% 2020s in
2015 and $1bn 1.844% 2019s in 2014. Citi, JP Morgan and Morgan Stanley placed
the 2020s and Citi and JP Morgan placed the 2019s.

Finance minister Oleksandr Danylyuk signed the agreement, along with US
Ambassador to Ukraine Geoffrey Pyatt and Joel Sandefur, representative of the
USAID mission.

The loan warranty agreement is a part of the bilateral and multilateral economic
support for Ukraine which includes a four year IMF extended fund facility
programme.

"It reflects increasing support for the economic reforms pursued by the
Government of Ukraine," said the Ukraine Ministry of Finance. "The agreement is
aimed to support economic reform programmes of Ukraine which are also supported
by the IMF, USAID and other members of the international community. It should
also facilitate access of Ukraine to the international capital markets."

The ministry said the funds raised would provide social aid to its most
financially vulnerable citizens to protect them against economic impacts
including rising gas prices.

A DCM official in London said that to his knowledge no banks have yet been
mandated for the new USAID backed Eurobond and that the timing of the deal was
unclear. "The timing will probably be dependent on the IMF programme," he said.
"I can't see them printing it until the next tranche is released."

One analyst expects a July agreement for the release of the next credit tranche
from the IMF. Jerome Vacher, an IMF representative in Ukraine, said that the IMF
would assess the state of reforms delivered over June.

USAID has also extended a $500m guarantee that will enable Tunisia to access
affordable financing from the international capital markets, after plans for
standalone access were put on hold in April.

This will be Tunisia's the third loan guarantee from the US. USAID offered $485m
of backing in 2012 and $500m in 2014. The 2014 guarantee was used to back a
$500m 2.452% 2021 via Natixis and JP Morgan and in 2012 Tunisia used it to issue
a seven year bond at 1.686%.

In January 2015, Tunisia placed its first standalone bond since the Arab Spring
to a strong reception. The $1bn 5.75% 10 year bond drew a book of over $4bn and
was earmarked as a big step in Tunisia's financial rehabilitation.

But hopes for independent access to the markets were dashed earlier this year
and Tunisia postponed a euro denominated bond sale in April. The roadshow was
planned to take place between April 21-26 via Natixis, Commerzbank and JP
Morgan.

In May the executive board of the International Monetary Fund approved a 48
month extended arrangement under its Extended Fund Facility with Tunisia for
$2.9bn to support the country's economic and fiscal reform programme.

"Tunisia has managed to preserve macroeconomic stability and initiate fiscal and
banking reforms in a context marked by a prolonged political transition,
spillovers from the crisis in Libya, and numerous exogenous shocks, including
terror attacks," the IMF said.

                               The Economic Times

                            January 23, 2015 Friday

Make loans affordable for students in Budget 2015 to boost 'Skill India': Ninad
Karpe, Aptech

SECTION: FINANCE

LENGTH: 268 words


NEW DELHI: If the government wants to meet its ambitious plan to boost skill
development in the country, it should make provisions for accessible and
affordable loans to students in the upcoming Union Budget 2015, says Ninad
Karpe, MD and CEO, Aptech Ltd.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi is keen to take forward this initiative as part of
his vision of creating "Skill India" and recently reviewed the program at a
high-level meeting.

"The government should create a credit guarantee fund similar to one created for
MSME sector in India so that banks can finance education loans without any
collateral from students, says Karpe. "For rural students, banks should offer
loans at concessional rate and with 100% guarantee from the trust. Also, in case
of default, the trust will need to pay 75% of the loan to banks," he adds.

Lack of finance is a major obstacle in fully harnessing the potential of young
population of the country

Karpe, the head of a global education company says that the government should
mandate the Mahila Bank to finance education loans of girls pursuing higher or
vocation education, particularly in rural areas, as gender bias in the society
keeps them out of education ambit due to unavailability of finance for
education. The bank was started in 2013 by the previous government to cater to
lending needs, predominantly for women.

"The self help groups should guarantee micro-finance facility to underprivileged
students," says Karpe, adding that a provision like this in the upcoming budget
by the government would gauge the needs of millions of students.
