                     The Post-Star (Glens Falls, New York)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                            April 17, 2014 Thursday

Wastewater, and how to get money flowing, topics at roundtable

BYLINE: Amanda May Metzger, The Post-Star, Glens Falls, N.Y.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 970 words


April 17--QUEENSBURY -- Local business, government and education leaders shared
thoughts on how U.S. Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand, D-N.Y., can help with job creation
in the North Country at a roundtable discussion Wednesday at SUNY Adirondack.

Among the top concerns were infrastructure updates and expansion, and most
importantly, who will pay for them.

"What stifles the growth is the limited infrastructure and specifically the
water and wastewater. If we don't have those two going to our industrial
development areas, we're not going to see any industrial commercial
development," said Queensbury Supervisor John Strough.

Money is needed to study a regional approach to infrastructure expansion, then
to construct it, he said.

If the work is government-funded, taxpayers foot the bill, but Gillibrand said
she wants to ease the local property tax burden by dipping into the larger pool
of federal tax dollars that get distributed to states for such projects.

Gillibrand is cosponsoring a bipartisan bill that would streamline federal
funding to states for low-interest loans on infrastructure projects.

"We want to get more money flowing from Washington to New York so that we can
offset the local needs, because property taxes are never going to be able to pay
for all these sewer needs," Gillibrand said.

She quoted from an Environmental Protection Agency study that pegged the cost of
Warren County's wastewater system needs alone at $100 million.

The bill is called Building and Renewing Infrastructure for Development and
Growth in Employment Act, and it was introduced late last year in the Senate by
a Democrat from Virginia. The legislation seeks to establish an Infrastructure
Financing Authority as a wholly owned government corporation.

This entity would provide direct loans and loan guarantees for building and
maintaining transportation, water and energy infrastructure systems. The bill
would require that the projects cost at least $50 million, or $10 million for
rural projects. It would establish an Office of Technical and Rural Assistance
to help state and local governments and parties in public-private partnerships
to develop and finance projects.

"It will allow the federal government, not necessarily to give the money, but to
do loan guarantees or facilitating types of investments," Gillibrand said.

Strough noted that even with low-interest loans, taxpayers carry the burden,
citing Moreau's recent $14.1 million sewer district expansion, which was voted
down by residents within the project's boundaries who would have been saddled
with the debt service.

Moreau Supervisor Preston Jenkins, who was in the audience at the roundtable
discussion, said Moreau has benefited from federal dollars distributed through
the state Environmental Facilities Corp. for interest-free loans for water
projects.

"The plan we just voted down was through the Environmental Facilities Corp., and
that was federal money (distributed through the state), loaned at an interest
rate of 50 percent, the going rate," Jenkins said. "I have to admit that if it
had passed, it would have been a very difficult thing at that point. We
obviously had a lot of issues -- primarily most of the yes votes came from
commercial and a lot of the negative came from residential who said, 'Why me?' I
always said that was a good point."

Moreau has also had instances where developers foot the bill for infrastructure
expansions. Jenkins said Moreau is exploring whether its sewer needs can be paid
for out of the state's funding for communities within prison closure areas.

Also related to infrastructure, Washington County's Economic Development
Coordinator Laura Oswald noted that six businesses in Salem closed recently
because of septic issues resulting from flooding. She said she'd like to see an
expansion of a tax credit for redevelopment and renovation of clusters of
historic buildings.

"A lot of these smaller villages have fairly historic main streets," Oswald
said.

EDC Warren County president Ed Bartholomew talked about grant funding obtained
by local regional groups that has been useful in undertaking studies, outlined
the need for capital funds for Glens Falls' aging wastewater treatment plant and
getting broadband service to areas of northern Warren County and Washington
County that are underserved.

Bartholomew also asked for Gillibrand's assistance in working with farming
communities to find additional markets and ways to market local farm products
and provide funding for regional tourism efforts. He said her support for tax
credits for housing development "would be critical."

General Electric plans to begin its departure from Fort Edward, taking with it
about 200 jobs, in the first quarter of next year. Bartholomew said he's looking
for support in transferring the 37-acre property to a third party, a
collaboration between EDC Warren County and others, to redevelop the site.

Gillibrand is co-sponsoring the Brownfields Utilization, Investment, and Local
Development Act of 2013, currently in the Senate Committee on Environment and
Public Works.

The legislation would amend the Comprehensive Environmental Response,
Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 by making more entities eligible for
brownfields revitalization funding. If passed, qualified community development
entities, tax-exempt charitable organizations and other entities would be
eligible.

"Those brownfield dollars can be very flexible. That's great for us because it
can be part of the whole redevelopment effort anyone can apply for," Gillibrand
said.

Gillibrand also discussed low-cost capital offerings of the Export-Import Bank
of the United States, such as insurance to guarantee payment of exports.

                     The Santa Fe New Mexican (New Mexico)

                            March 17, 2007 Saturday

FIRM ABANDONS BID FOR TILAPIA FARM

BYLINE: ANNE CONSTABLE

SECTION: MAIN; Pg. A-6

LENGTH: 545 words


Senate tables bill to provide $30 million in loans for project in Southern New
Mexico

A director of the NM Tilapia Corp. said Friday that the new company is giving up
plans to build a fish-processing facility in Southern New Mexico.

Johnny Cope, a Hobbs businessman, pal of Gov. Bill Richardson and chairman of
the

New Mexico Transportation Commission, said the project

fell through when the Senate

late Thursday indefinitely

tabled a bill to appropriate

$30 million in state funds to guarantee loans for the fish farm.

Cope claimed the project would have provided 1,500 jobs in Hidalgo County, which
has a high unemployment rate, and would have eventually generated $100 million
in gross receipts tax revenue.

"We just didn't have enough information for something that big so late in the
game," Sen. William Payne, R-Bernalillo, said of the company, which was
incorporated last November.

Payne said he didn't learn about the project until Thursday night. "I'm not
saying I'm against it," Payne said. "But it would have been nice if we had an
industry brief saying, 'This is where we've done projects. This is our market
history.' "

Payne, a Navy SEAL, said he has seen tilapia farming operations in Asia, where
the fish is a staple, and said a lot of technical issues need to be resolved.
"If we're going to do this (guarantee loans), we would want to know a whole lot
more about who is involved."

The project only surfaced at the start of the legislative session and never went
through the financial vetting process that takes place between legislative
sessions. The Legislative Finance Committee's first fiscal impact report on the
bill described the mechanism as "highly irregular."

The bill would have appropriated $30 million to guarantee loan bonds for
projects authorized under the Statewide Economic Development Act, enacted in
2003 to provide capital for businesses in rural and underserved areas at
favorable rates.

The bill, introduced in the Senate by Sen. Ben Altamirano, D-Silver City, would
have allowed gross receipts tax revenues to be pledged for economic-development
bonds issued to guarantee loans. According to New Mexico Finance chief executive
Bill Sisneros, it would help put New Mexico on a more even footing with its
neighbors in competing for projects.

Public Regulation Commission records list the NM Tilapia Corp.'s president as
Richard Millman of Santa Fe and secretary/treasurer as Damon Seawright, who also
is vice president of AmeriCulture, a three-year-old Hidalgo County company that
currently produces Nile tilapia fingerlings for growers and researchers. The
plan was for the NM Tilapia Corp. to acquire AmeriCulture and become a
full-scale food-processing facility.

The new company employed a star-studded cast of lobbyists who included former
Gov. Toney Anaya, Richard Barros, Mark Duran, Luke Otero, former House Speaker
Raymond G. Sanchez and Joseph M. Thompson.

Cope said Friday that the company couldn't return next year with a
public-financing proposal because the land wouldn't be available.

Hidalgo County, according to the company, is an ideal place to grow tilapia.
Geothermal waters of the area can be used as a growth medium for the fish, and
the fish farms can be heated at a much lower cost using geothermal heat rather
than fossil fuels.

                                US Official News

                              May 17, 2016 Tuesday

USDA Lowers Cost to Refinance Rural Housing Loans

LENGTH: 473  words

DATELINE: New York



 Phoenix: U.S Department of Agriculture, The State of Arizona has issued the
following news release:



 USDA Rural Housing Service Administrator Tony Hernandez today announced a
series of changes that will make it faster and cheaper for homeowners to
refinance USDA mortgages.





 "These changes reaffirm the Obama Administration's com itment to middle-class
Americans, and I am pleased that we continue to provide affordable housing to
support thriving economies in rural com unities," Hernandez said. "Helping
homeowners refinance their homes to reduce their monthly payments and take
advantage of low interest rates will bring increased capital to rural residents
and the com unities where they live and work."



 The changes take effect June 2, 2016 and apply to mortgages issued through USDA
and those where USDA has issued a loan note guarantee.



 Homeowners current on their mortgages for the past 12 months will no longer be
required to secure an appraisal, provide a credit report or undergo a
debt-to-incom  calculation when they refinance for a 30-year term. These changes
will save time and money.



 USDA began testing these changes in a 2012 a pilot program that was later
expanded to include 34 states and Puerto Rico. To date, nearly 9,500 homeowners
have refinanced their mortgages. Some borrowers saved as much as $600 a month.
The average savings is around $150 per month.



 The streamlined rules are consistent with banking industry lending standards.
These refinanced loans, like all USDA Rural Development housing loans, meet
rigorous underwriting standards and are made only to qualified borrowers. The
Department of Housing and Urban Development and Department of Veterans Affairs
have similar programs for the Americans they serve.



 Interested homeowners with USDA loan guarantees should contact their lender
about refinance procedures. Homeowners with USDA Direct loans should contact a
USDA housing specialist.



 For additional details on these new changes, please see page 26461 of the May 3
Federal Register. To learn more about USDA housing programs, please contact a
housing specialist at your nearest USDA Rural Development office. A list of
State offices is available at: http://www.rd.usda.gov/contact-us/state-offices.



 Since 2009, USDA Rural Development (#USDARD) has helped 1.1 million rural
residents buy homes; invested $11 billion to start or expand 103,000 rural
businesses; funded nearly 7,000 com unity facilities such as schools, public
safety and health care facilities; financed 185,000 miles of electric
transmission and distribution lines; and helped bring high-speed Internet access
to nearly 6 million rural residents and businesses. For more information, visit
www.usda.gov/results.



 In case of any query regarding this article or other content please contact:
editorial@plusmediasolutions.com br/>

                             National Mortgage News

                                August 26, 1996

Southwest Business Corp. Has Interim Flood Effort

SECTION: SPECIAL REPORT; Flood Compliance; Pg. 33

LENGTH: 812 words

DATELINE: San Antonio, TX


Southwest Business Corp.'s Interim Flood Program has been called the most
popular in the industry.

SWBC executive vice presidents Joyce White and Tony Hart are the architects of
the original service in this specialty, and Ms. White explained, "when flood
compliance first became an issue for lenders in the late 1980's, there was no
program outside the N.F.I.P. which would allow lenders to quickly and easily
order interim insurance to cover loans with lapsed flood insurance."

In 1985, Ms. White and Mr. Hart put together the first lender's forced insurance
facility for WNC Insurance Services, using underwriters at Lloyd's of London.

In 1987, together with Electronic Data Systems, they conducted the first
complete audit of a lender portfolio to identify loans in Special Flood Hazard
Areas.  The lender was City Federal Savings Bank, a New Jersey-based thrift with
a nationwide portfolio of approximately 75,000 loans.

The review of the portfolio used the EDS database of flood policies to identify
properties in or near an SFHA.  Borrowers were notified and disputed properties
were then hand mapped.

In its 12-year history as a forced-flood facility, Southwest Flood Insurance
Services has developed an expertise based on conducting more than 300 portfolio
audits.

It has interface capabilities with a variety of outsourcing systems and offers
extensive blanket guarantees against uninsured flood losses, covering the
mortgage portfolio during and after a review.

For lenders who want to avoid the expense of hand mapping an entire portfolio,
the review method Ms. White and Mr. Hart devised remains the most popular.

That basic system has evolved into the use of a database plus hand mapping to
insure the accuracy of notification to the borrower.

"Now when a borrower is notified of the flood insurance requirement on the
property, the notification includes specific flood zone, community number and
map panel information," she said.

"Disputes are handled by the mapping vendor who reviews tax maps and survey
information and contacts local flood officials to confirm the correctness of the
determination."

With an estimated 60% market share, Lloyd's - through its vendors WNC and SWBC -
is the leader among the three private-sector private forced-flood facilities
(Lloyd's, American Security, and Safeco Select).  The average rate of coverage
for the three is 85 cents per $ 100 of coverage, against $ 1.25 to $ 3.00 per $
100 for the mortgage portfolio protection program offered lenders through the
National Flood Insurance Program.

Ms. White said that higher cost plus the additional difficulty in placing
coverage and the absence of any portfolio coverage guarantees makes the MPPP
program a distant fourth in popularity among lenders.

Ms. White said all major flood determination vendors warranty their accuracy
backed by indemnity insurance, usually for $ 10 million.  The vendors also will
assist in the FEMA appeal process which NFIRA allows.

The SWBC/Lloyd's program offers higher coverage than NFIP, $ 300,000 vs. $
250,000.

In addition to flood risk portfolio analysis and audits, the SWBC/Lloyd's
program offers a full range of flood services, including flexible coverage and
rates, 60-day binders, coverage for non-escrowed loans, coverage for both
residential and commercial properties, complete EDI capabilities for maximum
streamlining, fully guaranteed flood zone certifications, transferable life-of-
loan coverage for the entire portfolio, and the ability to insure properties in
communities that do not participate in the NFIP.

With several years of input from lenders before flood regulations were tightened
in 1994, Ms. White said lenders have no horror stories to tell about flood
insurance snafus.

The biggest compliance issue currently has to do with consumer loans (second and
third loans, equity loans, and equity lines of credit).

"Those portions of the portfolio have been pretty much ignored," she said.  "The
question is how best to cover these loans with average balances under $ 25,000.
Lenders are looking at the cost and coverage of blanket flood insurance for the
outstanding balance of the total equity line."

She said lenders also are seeking regulatory approval of this approach as the
most logical for interim coverage.

"The assumption is that there is probably a first mortgage with a flood policy
in place, so the placement of a second policy could make the coverage
contributory and possibly insufficient to cover all of the borrower's
outstanding balances."

Because both Fannie and Freddie now require full replacement cost coverage for
both hazard and flood, Ms. White says, "approximately half of our clients have
started to force place flood at the hazard insurance amount in an effort to
comply."

Condominiums present many unresolved problems with both hazard and flood
insurance.

                       The Daily Record (Baltimore, MD.)

                           September 8, 1995, Friday

Osiris Closes on $ 4.7M From State, City to Build New Headquarters

SECTION: Pg.  1

LENGTH: 186 words


Osiris Therapeutics, a biotechnology startup with plans to build a headquarters
in Fells Point, yesterday announced it completed a $ 4.7 million financing
arrangement backed by the State of Maryland and the City of Baltimore. The
company will receive loans totaling $ 4.7 million from Whiting-Turner
Contracting Co., which is preparing the Osiris facility, and Signet Bank. The
Baltimore and Maryland governments also provided grants totaling $ 750,000. Loan
guarantees covering the $ 3.6 million in loans will be provided by the Maryland
Industrial Development Financing Authority. Osiris is moving its headquarters
from Cleveland, Ohio to the former Belt's Corp. facility in Baltimore.
Renovations of the building and construction of laboratory space is scheduled to
be completed by December. In the interim, Osiris will occupy laboratories at
Baltimore City Community College. In addition to the construction financing,
Osiris has received equity investments totaling $ 900,000 from the state and
Baltimore City. Osiris is developing cell therapy products to regenerate tissue
damaged by disease or injury.

LOAD-DATE: September 8, 1995

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

                                American Banker

                           September 14, 2007 Friday

FHLB Bill Cosponsor Sought

BYLINE: Steven Sloan

SECTION: WASHINGTON; Pg. 3 Vol. 172 No. 178

LENGTH: 185  words


More than a dozen trade groups, including the American Bankers Association and
the Independent Community Bankers of America, are courting Senate Finance
Committee Chairman Max Baucus to cosponsor legislation that would let the
Federal Home Loan Banks back tax-exempt bonds.

Allowing such use of the banks' letters of credit "will provide an additional
credit enhancement option as issuers work to structure cost-effective financing
on projects like water treatment facilities, fire stations, long-term care
facilities for the elderly, medical clinics, school buses, bridges, and other
infrastructure improvements," the groups wrote in a letter to the Montana
Democrat. The letters "will provide an additional opportunity for these
institutions to serve the communities they call home while also keeping the LOC
fees in the local and regional economy."

Legislation that Sen. John Rockefeller, D-W.Va., introduced last month would
allow the banks to guarantee tax-exempt bonds. Rep. Sander Levin, D-Mich.,
introduced similar legislation in the House in May.

                           Greeley Tribune (Colorado)

                 Distributed by McClatchy-Tribune Business News

                             April 27, 2008 Sunday

BRIEF: Grover gets USDA grant

BYLINE: Greeley Tribune, Colo.

SECTION: STATE AND REGIONAL NEWS

LENGTH: 217 words


Apr. 27--The town of Grover has received an $18,270 Community Facility Grant
from U.S. Department of Agriculture's Rural Development.

Mike Bennett, state director for Colorado Rural Development, presented the
ceremonial check to town officials. It was part of more than $8 million in loan
and grant funding to several northeast Colorado entities.

Grover, in northeast Weld County, will use the grant to buy a tractor for snow
removal and moving services for the community. The funding, according to Bennett
and town officials, will allow the town to replace Grover's current tractor
which is more than 50 years old.

Under the Water and Environmental Program, USDA Rural Development provides
loans, grants and loan guarantees for drinking water, sanitary sewer, solid
waste and storm drainage facilities in rural areas and cities and towns of
10,000 or less, Bennett said in a press release.

                              Chicago Daily Herald

                           November 30, 2010 Tuesday
                                   L2 Edition

Fair seeks millions in loans

BYLINE: By Mick Zawislak mzawislak@dailyherald.com

SECTION: NEWS; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 550 words


Federal loans and guarantees are needed to right the ship and help the new Lake
County fairgrounds reach its potential, officials say.

"This loan is really the primary step in the fair?s rehabilitation and
advancement into a modern fair and exhibition center," said Rudy Magna, attorney
for the Lake County Fair Association.

The application pending before the U.S. Department of Agriculture would, in a
sense, clean the slate for the group, but maximizing the use of the facilities
at Peterson and Midlothian Road will become the top priority to pay the debt.

"There's going to need to be more and better at the fair than there has been in
the past," Magna explained Monday during a required public hearing for the USDA
community facilities loan program.

The fair group is seeking up to $7.5 million to repay debts owed to contractors,
pay off and convert a short-term construction loan, and complete an exhibition
center.

While there is substantial value in the land and facilities at Peterson and
Midlothian roads, the fair is strapped for cash. Magna said a recent appraisal
valued the facilities at $23.5 million, down from a pre-recession $31 million.

"You can't pay bills with dirt," he said before the hearing.

The association had a tentative deal to sell some of the property for $3
million, which would have taken care of most of the obligations, but the buyer
backed out because of the economy, Magna said.

The property now is regarded as significant

collateral for what would be the first USDA community facilities loan in Lake
County. Those loans are made to communities or nonprofit groups in rural areas
and towns up to 20,000 in population.

Mounting debt has become an issue for the association, which in 2009 moved from
its longtime home at routes 45 and 120 in Grayslake about four miles south to
the new site in the village.

Magna acknowledged there has been "some pain, some disappointment," since.

"The move was a good move. Cash flow-wise, it just didn't turn out as originally
anticipated," he said.

Frustration came to a head Nov. 16, when the fair board was assailed for what
association member Greg Koeppen described as a financial disaster.

Board President David DeYoung resigned a few days later and was replaced last
week by fair board member Mike Richards.

The fair association owes $2.3 million in principal and interest on a
construction loan, which is due, and about $4 million to contractors, Magna
said. Another $1 million will be needed to complete a 15,000-square-foot events
center and other work.

The exact amount to be borrowed is being finalized. About a third would be a
direct loan from the USDA. The rest would be borrowed from Ridgestone Bank in
Schaumburg, with the USDA guaranteeing 90 percent.

"The taxpayers of the United States are not being put at risk," Magna said. "The
value is here."

The fair association would have two loans with one payment and a 40-year term.
Cash flow would be monitored monthly, rather than quarterly, and the loan would
include a reserve so the fair would not immediately be under the gun.

The USDA loan has a current interest rate of 3.75 percent. The rest of the
amount borrowed would be at market rate.

"For most organizations, our loans are really the best rate you can get," said
Joan Mussina, public information coordinator for the USDA.

Illinois: Ground Broken for First BUILT in Cook Economic Development Project

LENGTH: 309  words

DATELINE: Springfield


Cook County has issued the following news release:

Cook County Board President Toni Preckwinkle joined a number of local and
federal officials Wednesday in breaking ground for infrastructure improvements
that are key to revitalization of the Cullerton Avenue Industrial Area in
Franklin Park.

The groundbreaking celebrates the start of the first project funded in Cook
County under the BUILT in Cook loan fund. BUILT (Broadening Urban Investment to
Leverage Transportation) is a HUD Section 108 Loan Guarantee program that allows
the County to borrow money from private investors at reduced interest rates to
promote economic development, stimulate job growth and improve public
facilities.

"The Cullerton Avenue Industrial Area is home to 10 companies and employs more
than 1,300 people," President Preckwinkle said. "This loan of up to $4 million
will be used to fund public improvements including street reconstruction, sewer
and drainage work, and we anticipate 133 new jobs will be created. The project
is an example of what can be done to promote economic development and job growth
in our industrial communities."

"The Cullerton Avenue Industrial Area project is made possible by government at
various levels and businesses working together to address infrastructure needs,
where all are partners in project financing to keep and expand jobs in the
Village, Cook County and the region," said  Franklin Park Mayor Barrett
Pedersen.

"HUD's Section 108 Loan Guarantee Program is a powerful public investment tool
to drive economic development in underserved areas," said Antonio R. Riley, HUD
Midwest Regional Administrator. "It will be a boost to the Franklin Park
community and will provide employment opportunities for area residents."
